HEADLINE: BOOK REVIEW;
Why Nassau County Is No New York City

BYLINE: By BARTH HEALEY 

 BODY:
SITTING in southbound traffic on Glen Cove Road, waiting for a vast tractor-trailer to make a tight right turn through the tangled traffic onto Old Country Road, one forgets there was life in Nassau County before the internal combustion engine.
Last week Hofstra University offered this aid to memory: an edited collection of papers delivered a year earlier at a conference presented by Hofstra and the Long Island Studies Institute to mark the centennial of the establishment of the county, on Jan. 1, 1899. 
 Some histories herein, mostly dry but well written, stretch back to the earliest settlements in the 1640's. But the focus is on the years leading to Nassau's "independence" and beyond, and the emphasis is frequently on the fact that -- thank heavens -- Nassau is not New York City.
In 1898 the western two-thirds of what was then Queens County -- Long Island City, Newtown, Jamaica and Flushing -- was joined to New York City; the eastern third -- Hempstead, North Hempstead and Oyster Bay -- was left in a sort of limbo. That limbo lasted a year, until Nassau County was created. (Among the many bits of trivia: the name Nassau originated in the 12th century.)
Two themes that drive so many conversations on the Island today run though this centennial history: politics and the environment.
Strong-willed male Republicans dominated the county's development, including Senator Thomas C. Platt, who muscled approval of the new county through the State Legislature in 1898, and J. Russel Sprague, who centralized executive power in 1936, making Nassau the first county in the nation to have an elected chief executive.
One of the more enlightening essays is by Marjorie Freeman Harrison, a library media specialist at Lawrence High School, who tells how G. Wilbur Doughty built on the cohesiveness of the Italian immigrant community in Inwood to solidify Republican power.
Two enviornmental issues seemed to dominate the South Shore: the decision to sell water from Hempstead to Brooklyn (and thus deplete Island supplies) beginning in 1871 and the dredging and sewage disposal that had to be addressed in the development of Long Beach in 1907. Both are laid out clearly here.
The compendium touches on other conversation points.
Is Nassau County "united"? The various roles of the Hempstead Plains -- farmland and military training ground and now the route of major east-west road and rail divides -- are described in several essays, but still the consensus is that the north-south social and economic gap has been bridged.
How much power should developers have?
This issue is examined at some length by Patricia T. Caro in her chronology of the drawing of the Queens-Nassau border, especially in the Five Towns area (an article that could have used more detailed maps).
There are a few misfires. Articles on the Jewish communities and on women in the clergy seem to lack the "Island-ness" of the others. The six short summaries on health care are perfunctory. And an article on Alan King and Billy Crystal titled "From Soup to Nuts: Laughter in the Suburbs" does not seem to have any point.
The index -- a key component of any reference work -- is uneven (William Burden, the originator of the plan to sell water to Queens, is omitted; a passing reference to Frank Sinatra is included).
Overall, though, this book is a rich, well-written source of information. Several towns are covered in some depth: Hempstead, Inwood, the Bellmores, Farmingdale (two articles), Long Beach. Almost all the 32 papers include extensive bibliographies.
A browse through this collection could prove a welcome distraction after a morning spent inching along Old Country Road.
 
NASSAU COUNTY
From Rural Hinterland to Suburban Metropolis
Joann P. Krieg and Natalie A. Naylor, editors
 
Illustrated. 336 pages. Interlaken, N.Y.: Empire State Books. $19.99, paper.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The Search For Money To Preserve The Land

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
NED ELLIS'S dairy farm in Hebron has been in the family since 1903. When real estate developers make lucrative offers for parcels of his land, he turns them down.
"We're supposed to be caretakers of the land," he said. "If we sell our land, we're shooting ourselves in the foot." 
 But the economics of farming in Connecticut are such that many farmers do sell. The state lost 21 percent of its farmland between 1984 and 1997, when the United States Department of Agriculture estimated the state's remaining farmland at some 380,000 acres.
"I don't think people understand the gravity of the situation," said Mr. Ellis, who can name seven farmers who have sold their farms since the beginning of this year alone.
A group called the Working Lands Alliance -- a coalition of agricultural organizations, food security groups, conservation organizations, local government associations and farmers -- is working to save the state's farmland. The alliance supports a bill before the General Assembly (H.B. 5173) that would revitalize the State Department of Agriculture's Farmland Preservation Program.
Funded through bonding, this program allows farmers to sell their land's development rights to the state for an amount equal to the difference between its fair market value for development and its value for agricultural use. In return, a permanent easement on the land restricts all nonagricultural uses.
The result: The farmer can keep farming, and the land is protected from development, even if the ownership changes. Some 20 states have similar programs.
In February, the State Bond Commission approved the purchase of development rights to 251 acres of Mr. Ellis's 450-acre farm and to an entire neighboring farm of 173 acres. In the current market, a developer would probably offer about $5,400 per acre. The state will pay about $4,000 per acre.
Mr. Ellis plans to use a portion of his proceeds to buy the neighboring farm, which he has rented for the past decade. It will be affordable at its agricultural value of $1,400 per acre. Mr. Ellis said he had no doubt that the owner would have sold the acreage to developers had he not been able to sell the development rights.
Mark Ruwet, the executive director of the Connecticut Farm Bureau, cited three situations that cause farms to be sold. First, there is an aging population of farmers for whom the farm is the only retirement investment. And because of the high price of land, selling is a very attractive way to retire, he said.
Second, some Connecticut farmers sell in order to buy farms in places where land is less expensive.
Third, when a farmer dies, heirs often are not interested in farming. In many cases, because of estate taxes, they have no alternative but to sell.
And when farms are sold, those willing and able to pay top dollar are usually developers, not other farmers or young people who want to start farming.
That's where the Farmland Preservation Program comes in, said Robin Chesmer, a farmer in Lebanon. Eleven years ago, fulfilling a lifelong dream to farm, he purchased the cows and leased the land from a retiring dairy farmer. Three years later, the retired owner sold the development rights to the state, enabling Mr. Chesmer to buy the farm for about one-third of its previous value.
"That was what allowed us to get into the business," he said. "We were able to purchase the farm for its agricultural value rather than its development value."
The Farmland Preservation Program can help keep a farm in the family, Mr. Chesmer said. "You want to retire and you've got 20 years ahead of you," he said. "If you sold the development rights, you could invest it, and the next generation could purchase the farm and keep it agricultural."
But for every farmer who has benefited from the Farmland Preservation Program, there are many who have been unable to participate.
Since the program began in 1978, it has preserved 26,610 acres, short of its 130,000 goal. Since 1995, the state has acquired the development rights to 12 farms, with applications pending from more than 200 farmers.
Many farmers do not apply because they know of the long waiting list, and many who would have preferred to sell their development rights ended up selling their land for development, Mr. Ruwet said.
The main problem, said Mark Winne, the chairman of the Working Lands Alliance, has been insufficient money. The bill supported by the alliance would authorize $50 million in bonding over the next five years compared with $7.5 million over the previous five.
A second problem, Mr. Winne said, is that more than $6 million of the money already authorized has not been spent.
Under current law, the Department of Agriculture must obtain approval from the Bond Commission for each development-rights purchase. "The governor sets the agenda of the Bond Commission," Mr. Winne said. "If the governor doesn't call farmland up on the agenda, nothing happens."
Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, said that many more projects are authorized by the General Assembly than can be paid for by the Bond Commission.
"There are a number of very worthy projects competing for Bond Commission money," he said, such as a multiyear project to preserve open space and a half-billion dollar school construction project.
The legislation supported by the Working Lands Alliance would direct the Bond Commission to authorize the issuance of bond funds for farmland preservation in two installments each year and would give the commissioner of agriculture the authority to spend the money without getting approval for each individual purchase. However, the Finance Committee recently removed these provisions from the bill.
According to Joseph Dippel, the director of the Farmland Preservation Program, it aims to purchase the development rights from the best farms that apply, in terms of productivity, soil quality and location. "We work with the number that we have funding available to work with," he said, which he put at about 15.
"You try to protect farms in areas where you have other farms because they make their own best neighbors," he said. "A farm surrounded by development is quite often difficult to farm because of the sights, sounds and noises typically associated with farming, whether it's running an irrigation pump or the smells of spreading manure. We try to cluster farms together so they could be maintained as economically viable farm communities."
Some of the best farmland in Connecticut and around the country is being lost, Mr. Winne said. "We need to be planning where our food is going to be coming from for the long term. We can't just say Connecticut land is best used for growing houses."

HEADLINE: In West Seattle, Constructing Rooms With a View

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING 

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
THE economic boom is visible in the new housing seen in many older neighborhoods here, among them West Seattle, the birthplace of the city, where high-density housing is rising along the Puget Sound in the area where the first settlers landed in 1851.
On Alki Beach across Elliott Bay from the downtown, a 10-minute drive away, developers have constructed 21 buildings in the last decade or so, with a total of about 440 condominiums. About half of them have been built in the latest development spurt in the last five years. 
 Now, two developers are framing two luxury buildings, with 15 more luxury condos. The apartments command sweeping views of the water or the downtown skyline and are replacing ramshackle turn-of-the-century cabins that were summer homes for city dwellers.
"We like this area because there is not a lot of beachfront around the downtown," said Mark Pryde, a vice president of the Pryde Corporation, which sold the last of its 20 apartments at Point Nautica last year. Pryde has built six buildings in the last six years at Alki Beach, with a total of 140 apartments. "The condominiums have water views that will never be blocked, and Alki Beach has a 'resort town' feel, with restaurants and pastry shops," he said. "We're seeing the rebirth of older cities all across the country, and this is happening in West Seattle now."
With 96,000 residents, a mix of blue collar and professional, West Seattle was annexed by the City of Seattle in 1907.
In the early 1900's, West Seattle was a thriving community when the Luna Park amusement park was built on the tide flats. Initially, it drew crowds that arrived by train or ferry from downtown Seattle to ride the roller-coaster, but its popularity later dwindled, and under pressure from prohibitionists, the park closed in 1913. Its remains burned down in 1931, and Alki Beach became neglected and blighted. Many people considered West Seattle the boondocks because the Duwamish River, which forms its eastern boundary, cuts it off from the rest of the city.
 West Seattle's fortunes began to change in 1983 when a high-rise bridge was built over the river, connecting with Interstate 5. At Alki (pronounced with a long i, like bike) Beach, the city invested in a four-mile-long promenade, boathouse and fishing pier. By the late 1990's, new condominiums and single-family homes were going up, and restaurants and a bakery were thriving. In December, Starbucks opened a branch.
NOW, housing prices are heating up. In 1999, the average price for 154 condominiums sold was $272,288, compared with $229,730 for the 227 sold in 1998 and $191,999 in 1997. In 1999, 1,403 homes sold at an average price of $237,779, compared with $209,115 for the 1,323 homes sold in 1998 and $184,248 in 1997. West Seattle is still more affordable than Seattle as a whole, where the average sales price in 1999 was about $300,000.
As land becomes scarcer in the Alki Beach area, prices for the new condos are rising. At Point Nautica, the latest Pryde development, prices ranged from $450,000 to $1.8 million for apartments with 1,500 square feet to 4,000 square feet. At Pryde's first building in 1994, prices ranged from $250,000 to $400,000 for the same amount space.
The company sold about half of its condos before construction even began at Point Nautica. But the high prices make the developers nervous. "Higher land costs create a thinner market," Mr. Pryde said, "as more people can afford $250,000 units than $500,000."
 A few blocks away, on the eastern side of Alki Beach, the Sabey Corporation is completing the shell of a five-story building, called Duwamish Head. Each condo will occupy a single floor, with 4,000 square feet plus 700 square feet of patio or terrace. Sabey has sold the top three floors at about $2 million each, and buyers will hire their own designers to install the kitchens and to complete the decorating. Joe Wang, the development manager, said the first- and second-floor story units are unsold, priced at $1.4 million for the shell and $1.8 million if Sabey completes the interiors.
 Down the street, construction crews for the Seagulf Group are framing the third floor of a six-story building containing 10 condominiums with 1,681 to 1,880 square feet priced at $599,900 to $786,000. Two 3,750-square-foot penthouses will be priced at $2 million each. Gerald Potter, the sales agent for the project, said the smallest unit is sold -- to the banker that financed the project. "The lower units have a 35-foot span of windows," he said, "and the penthouses 70 feet, to capture views."
Tom Roth, a Prudential Northwest Realty salesman, said: "Construction on Alki will continue for some time as a number of sites are still left. A lot of units will soon go into areas by the beach that do not have views. People want to be by the saltwater and where things are booming."
 The rising prices at Alki Beach are causing Matt Vaughn to delay construction until he sees how the market evolves. He has another reason to delay development of his site, which includes three quaint 1920's houses. "It's hard to tear down the homes, especially since I live in one," he said.
 ABOUT three miles inland from Alki Beach, the 30-year-old Westwood Village shopping mall is in the middle of a $10 million expansion, adding 50,000 square feet to its 350,000 square feet. Tom Sroufe, the senior vice president of Wesbild Inc., the mall's owner, said that plans include a new 12-screen movie theater with 2,200 seats.
 A few blocks from the mall, the nonprofit Delridge Neighborhood Development Association has just begun selling 17 two-bedroom town houses. The 1,000-square-foot units, priced at $150,000, are part of the Brandon Court mixed-use project that also houses the association's headquarters, a Gai's Bakery and city offices.
"We worked hard to keep the town houses affordable as part of our goal to create a thriving neighborhood," says Paul Fischburg, Delridge's director. The group's next project will be a 6,500-square-foot building with a Seattle Public Library branch on the first floor and 19 low-income apartments above.
 A few blocks away, Jefferson Properties will develop 15 acres, a former sand and gravel pit, into 141 homes priced from $180,000 to $230,000 for 1,200 square feet to 1,800 square feet.
"This is the largest vacant residential land parcel left for development in Seattle because it has environmental problems from contaminated soil that was dumped long ago," said Ray Stevenson, the developer. He plans to clean up the site this summer and start construction next year. "Unfortunately, these are the types of sites for homes that are left in the city."
 But Mr. Stevenson added, "West Seattle is a great area and appeals to people who are so tired of the traffic bottlenecks on the freeways and no longer want long commutes to the suburbs."

HEADLINE: Saving the Farm Through Cooperation

BYLINE: By ALAN BISBORT 

 BODY:
THE stories have a sad sameness to them. A family can't afford to keep a farm, a developer makes an offer, the land is re-zoned residential, and housing replaces fertile fields and open spaces. And it happens so often that the small farm almost seems doomed to become a quaint relic, like the colonial-era syllabub churn or the cracker barrel.
But a loose-knit group of farmers is going about the business of preserving farmland through a movement called community-supported agriculture, in which people buy "shares" in a farm's produce in advance, then receive regular deliveries throughout the growing season. 
 Financially, and in other ways, the membership buffers the farm's ups and downs.
"If the farm has a bad year, like last year with the drought, the members don't abandon it," said Ellen Greist, who with her husband, Walter, has been running a community-supported farm, Mill River Valley Gardens, in North Haven, since 1989. "It's supported in good times and bad, and the farm remains a part of the community."
Starting in 1986 with Indian Line Farm in Massachusetts and Temple-Wilton Community Farm in New Hampshire, the movement has now spread throughout the country. Figures vary as to how many community-supported farms are in the United States -- most are in the Northeast, with clusters in Minnesota, Wisconsin and California's Bay Area -- but estimates range from 600 to 1,000 farms, serving 100,000 households.
Connecticut is home to 20 such farms.
"Everybody's story is different," said Mr. Greist, whose four-acre farm is on land that was fallow for over a century. Despite the drought, the farm produced 83 shares last year. "We grew 75 items and managed to put out shares each week, but the totals were 35 percent below our goal. It was wonderful to have the support to tide us over. We had many hands to help with the weeds."
There are various levels of commitment in community-supported agriculture. Some members pay a flat fee and make weekly pickups of their share of produce; some work off all or part of the cost of their share by helping on the farm.
At tiny (one-acre) Mad Mares Farm in Bethany, one full share costs $300, buying each of its 50 or so members 21 to 24 weeks of large weekly portions of some of the following: lettuce, mesclun, kale, leeks, cucumbers, tatsoi, mizuna, onions, bok choy, beets, radishes, carrots, chard, turnips, beans, peas, peppers, arugula, tomatoes and potatoes. Crops are ready for weekly harvesting as early as June and continue into November.
Some of the system's selling points are obvious: easy access to fresh vegetables and preservation of open land. Most community-supported farms use organic farming methods -- i.e., biological rather than chemical fertilizers and pesticides -- and many people believe it creates healthier soil.
Some advantages are not so obvious: the distribution system -- often individual pickups from the farm -- creates less truck traffic, water pollution and waste.
And some are almost unquantifiable: the psychological lift town residents get when they make a difference that they can see, and when they can, literally, become reconnected to the earth by getting their hands dirty.
"They know where their food comes from," Mr. Greist said, "and they can participate 365 days a year."
One of Connecticut's largest community supported farms is in Granby, on land bequeathed by Tudor and Laura Holcomb to be used for agricultural education. A group called Friends of Holcomb Farm spent three years devising a plan for the 320 acres that includes an environmental center, a grazing program and a 16-acre community-supported farm, which began operating in 1994.
Run by the Hartford Food System, a nonprofit organization that tries to increase access to affordable and nutritious food, the farm also has a program that teaches urban and minority youths about agriculture and augments their diet with produce.
"We have a very strong belief in this as a community builder and an empowerment builder," said Elizabeth Wheeler, Hartford Food System's program director. "The object isn't to make this a work-for-food situation. It's education and outreach."
In 1999, Holcomb Farm's community-supported operation, with a permanent staff of six, raised 120,000 pounds of produce, which was shared by 215 member households and 14 social organizations connected to Hartford Food System. Among them was Granby Social Services.
"Granby has become more of a bedroom community for professionals rather than the old agricultural community it was," said Ms. Wheeler. "Ironically, some of the lower income people in Granby now are the ones who formerly worked on farms."
An early March meeting in Hartford organized by Mrs. Greist, the North Haven farmer, brought together proponents of community-supported agriculture and members of Northeast Organic Farming Association in Hartford at an End of Winter Conference.
The mood was positive at the all-day conference, which included seminars on mechanized farming, organic land care, biotechnology and "community organizing for positive change."
Among the attendees was Elizabeth Henderson, who runs a community-supported farm in New York and wrote, with Robyn Van En, the movement's bible, "Sharing the Harvest: A Guide to Community-Supported Agriculture" (Chelsea Green).
"Farmers alone have been shouldering the risks of an increasingly ruthless global market, which has forced millions of them from the land," she said. "Most people don't know where or how their food is grown. They cannot touch the soil or talk to the farmer who tends it."
Community-supported agriculture offers "one of the most hopeful alternatives," she said.
Also attending was Bill Duesing, one of the leading lights of the small organic farm movement. Connecticut has 54 certified organic farms, some of which have begun to incorporate aspects of community-supported agriculture. Mr. Duesing, with his wife, Suzanne, runs Old Solar Farm in Oxford, directs the Oxford Land Trust and syndicates a regular farming column, as well as offering commentaries on community radio.
"I think that C.S.A.'s have the possibility to be, and some are, an alternative food-distribution system," he said, referring to farms using community-supported agriculture. "Distribution is 80 percent of the cost of food in this country."
But he was less optimistic about the effect on sprawl.
"I'm afraid that nothing short of great disaster or major economic changes will stop sprawl," he said. "However, I imagine that C.S.A.'s are having some effect keeping suburban land productive. It is also hopeful and encouraging to see the relatively rapid growth of C.S.A.'s, and farmers markets, community gardens and school gardens, in this country over the just the last 10 to 15 years."

HEADLINE: The View From/Niantic;
Puppies and Prisoners: Lessons in Compassion

BYLINE: By CYNTHIA WOLFE BOYNTON 

 BODY:
THERE is no proof that prisoners who care for animals will one day carry that compassion onto the streets. But state corrections officials said that two female Labrador retrievers -- one yellow and one black -- living at the women's York Correctional Institution had made inmates happier, better behaved and, in some cases, willing to take on responsibilities for the first time.
The dogs arrived at the Niantic prison in January as 9-week-old puppies to take part in the Prison Pup Partnership. The program teaches inmates how to train dogs to turn lights on and off, open doors, retrieve objects and perform other tasks for people who are deaf or in wheelchairs. It is sponsored by the National Education for Assistance Dog Services, or Neads, a nonprofit group based in Massachusetts, and has been running for two years in a handful of other prisons in Massachusetts and Maine. 
 "Having dogs around is as great as having kids around," said Mike Burns, unit manager at York. "They make everyone friendlier and the atmosphere a lot nicer. And this is a wonderful program because everyone benefits: first, all those involved with taking care of the dogs, and then the disabled people who get them."
And at York, he said, everyone wants to take part. Inmates in the home economics department have made beds and blankets not just for their dogs, Pride and Doc, but also to send on to other dogs in the Neads program. Culinary arts workers bake fresh dog biscuits daily.
Prison staff members are also involved, Mr. Burns said. He and others often volunteer to take the dogs to the veterinarian or to dog-sit. "These two dogs have made York a different place," he said.
York is the first Connecticut prison to take part in the program. But another Prison Pup Partnership could be set up this year at the Brooklyn Correctional Institution, said Pamela Richards, the warden who oversees these and four other state prisons.
York officials used donations from residents and local kennel clubs to buy the dogs for $500 each from Guiding Eyes for the Blind, a New York breeder, and to pay for food, veterinary care and other supplies.
Prisoners and puppies may seem like an odd match, said Sheila O'Brien, the Neads executive director. At one time, even she was skeptical of the mix. But she said the program had been a success since the first Prison Pup Partnership was established in 1998 at the men's North Central Correctional Institution in Gardner, Mass. The program has relieved the need for foster families to take in puppies and train them, a constant problem since Neads was established in 1976.
Ms. O'Brien said the participation of prisons had cut the Neads waiting list for trained dogs from five years to one. "It's rare to have a partnership where everyone is happy, but everyone benefits from this."
The intense contact dogs receive from inmates has also reduced the normal 18-month training program to a year, said Capt. Rhom Saunders, a York unit manager. Each dog has one inmate as her trainer, but most of the 90 women who live in the minimum-security housing unit with Doc and Pride help walk and play with them.
Mr. Saunders said dogs did not get that level of attention on the outside. "If you're a Neads volunteer in the community," he said, "you probably work full time, have kids who need to be driven to soccer practice and can't be with the dogs more than a few hours a day at best. These women really don't have anything to do but care for the dogs. They give constant attention."
Carol, 47, and Donna, 45, are the York prisoners responsible for the puppies. Both are convicted murderers and have been at York for more than a decade. Donna has served 17 years of a life sentence, and Carol 16 years of a 35-year sentence. The prison would not allow the inmates' full names to be used, because of a state policy intended to protect victims who may feel a prisoner is being glorified.
Carol and Donna applied to be trainers, and Mr. Saunders said they were chosen because of their enthusiasm and good conduct records.
"The women training these dogs are doing something really right," said Ray Cogeshall, a counselor supervisor and unit manager at the prison. "But we can't forget that to get here, they broke the law. They did something really wrong."
The dogs sleep in cages in the women's prison cells, and then follow them throughout their daily routines, which include classes, chores and on-site work responsibilities. "Some people think it's easy to be in prison because we have no bills, no kids to care for," Donna said. "That may be true. But we also don't have anyone to love. These dogs give us unconditional love."
Karen Smith, 48, of East Haven, received a dog through the Neads program (though not through the prison partnership) three and a half years ago. Confined to a wheelchair because of severe multiple sclerosis, she relies on Dakota, a golden retriever, to pick up dropped objects, pull her wheelchair through grocery stores and brace her as she slides onto the couch or into bed at night.
"This dog allows me to be independent and, in many ways, has opened me up socially," Ms. Smith said. "When I'm with Dakota, people notice her first, not my wheelchair. And that makes them more comfortable around me.
Paul Ruane, deputy superintendent of the prison in Gardner, Mass., which has had the Prison Pups Partnership the longest, stressed the importance of such restorative justice programs.
"Prisons aren't the best places to be," Mr. Ruane said. "No one wants to be there. Everyone's antsy. And you don't get a lot of psychological rewards from planting flowers, or picking up trash, that will help you reintegrate into society. But the dogs teach caring and compassion. They give inmates someone to care about, and get them out of the 'poor me' syndrome. That's a big deal."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2812 words

HEADLINE: Bloustein Makes, Policymakers Take;
Those Who Make Decisions Affecting Public Life in the State Rely on the Institute at Rutgers and Its Well-Known Dean

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
THE census takers haven't even gone home yet, and already James W. Hughes is writing about what they will find. As the megabytes from the census bureau spill in next year, he will write again. And again. "I'll be in my demographic sandbox," he said.
From his desk at Rutgers, Mr. Hughes will draw the outlines, as he has for a quarter-century, of the state's state of being: where the people live and what they live in, where the jobs are and where the money goes. But while Mr. Hughes is much cited as the man mostly likely to know what 8.2 million New Jerseyans are doing, he is not working on this by himself. As dean of the university's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, he presides over a knowledge factory for the state, or at least for the policy wonks within. 
 The researchers here are studying, among other things, curriculums in poor school districts, job training for the long-term unemployed, municipal tax-collection methods and the effect of abandoned factories on neighborhoods. They are, in sum, constantly evaluating the public life of New Jersey, and doing so for the vast, vague constellation of people called policymakers.
Legislators, state and municipal officials and policy organizations depend on the Bloustein school's array of publications from the highly general, like the Legislative District Data Book, to the highly specific, like a report called "The Potential Impacts of Revaluation on Property Tax Burdens in Newark."
State agencies contract with the school for research. Municipal officials take its training programs. Legislators consult its faculty members, the dean foremost among them. And all of them hire its graduates.
"It's unusual to get the combination that we have with Hughes and the Bloustein school; New Jersey is very fortunate," said Peter Francese, who was the publisher of American Demographics magazine when Mr. Hughes was a contributing editor.
"Hughes takes very, very seriously the idea that Rutgers is a state institution," Mr. Francese added. "Not everyone takes it that seriously. But I bet he wakes up each morning and says, What can we do for New Jersey? What intellectual power can we bring to bear on the problems here?"
So while the Woodrow Wilson school at Princeton looks at The Hague, the Bloustein school looks at Paterson and Vineland.
"We like mucking around," said Cliff Zukin, chairman of the public policy department and director of the Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll. "It gives us a thrill to write a research paper that somebody uses. We like to send students out to make a contribution to the state."
Bari Anhalt Erlichson, who teaches education policy at Rutgers, said that when she was finishing her Ph.D. in political science at Stanford University three years ago, she yearned for "real-world circumstances" and was not even sure she wanted to stay in academia. Now at work on her second report of court-ordered reforms in school administration, Ms. Erlichson is visiting and interviewing at dozens of schools.
"It's very difficult to come across these positions," she said. "It requires a strong dean and a strong leader who can evangelize the importance of real-world work."
While the Bloustein school (named for the late university president) is fastidiously, academically nonpartisan, it has plenty of political connections. Jim Florio, probably the state's best-known Democrat, is a faculty member. Raymond H. Bateman, the former Senate president and a Republican, has had an office at the school. Others are in frequently for conferences and guest teaching.
Rutgers has always been of interest and use to politicians, of course, and the Eagleton Institute of Politics has been an academic center. But the Bloustein school, founded in 1992 as an umbrella for the university's graduate programs in public policy (read: government) and urban planning, is more public service than political science.
Academically, the school splays, which many say is the point. In the last four years, it has spread out some more, adding research centers in labor, transportation and urban redevelopment. In that time, the research staff has doubled, to 67.
"I'm not aware of any other school that has the comprehensive mix of activities and resources," said Henry A. Coleman, an economist who heads the school's oldest research organization, the Center for Government Services. "It's a wonderful conglomeration."
The lobbying, recruiting and organizing has fallen largely to Mr. Hughes, the dean since 1995. No one else could know the place so well.
The joke around the faculty, Mr. Coleman said, is that "Jim Hughes has been here since high school." That is not true; he was away for two years, in the Army. But he did enroll at Rutgers in 1961, as an engineering student, and returned immediately after his Army service. Not knowing exactly what he wanted to do, he entered in the new graduate program in city planning, earning his Ph.D. in 1971. He then joined the faculty.
Mr. Hughes, with his inventory of facts and his dry humor, is a kind of inescapable resource in New Jersey, the man journalists turn to for a trenchant comment on unemployment rates, consumption figures, school spending or just about anything else related to the state. When Ms. Erlichson went house-hunting on a recent weekend, the real-estate agent volunteered, "Oh, I just saw your dean quoted in the paper."
But he is also consulted and cited outside the jurisdiction. In the last year, for example, in the Cleveland Plain Dealer (on the subject of Newark's economy), the Christian Science Monitor (the coming bulge in the elderly population), the Chicago Daily Herald (downtown retailers), the Cincinnati Enquirer (the maturation of suburbs) and on CNN (the job market for new college graduates).
Early in his career, Mr. Hughes wrote about national housing trends. But that, he said, leads to messy inquiries about population shifts, incomes, jobs, transportation and the structure of the American economy, all of which he happily took on.
With his colleague George Sternlieb, he started the Rutgers Regional Report, a series of papers tracking the region's economy; when Mr. Sternlieb retired, Joseph J. Seneca, a Rutgers economist, replaced him.
As the audience grew, Mr. Hughes became known as a forecaster of everything from the emergence of high-tech corridors to homebuyers' demand for fireplaces. He also became an official explainer of the waves of people outward and westward from New York -- which, he explains, is just one ripple in the nation's most colossal trend: "All we've been trying to do is correct for a fundamental navigation error by the Pilgrims, who were aiming for Santa Monica."
While this wisdom lends itself to popular consumption, it takes such titles as "Commercial Office Space Overhangs" -- in which, in 1993, he and Mr. Seneca reported the dramatic shift from Manhattan to North Jersey. (Fact: 82 percent of all the rental office space ever built in New Jersey had gone up after 1980.)
It was a theme set out in "The Suburban Employment Perimeter," in which the authors noted that "the invasion of large-scale post-industrial corporate settlements and their service retinues" had established the sites for economic recovery in the 1990's.
The latest report, "The Emerging Wealth Belt," traced the shift of population and jobs from the state's north to its center. The next report, scheduled for publication next month, anticipates the 2000 census findings.
The topics, Mr. Hughes said, present themselves: "We get a lot of calls from legislators, and you'd sense there was a need for study in one area. We know what the next hot policy issue is."
He and Mr. Seneca tell them every year, too, as opening speakers for the legislative budget hearings. Before the Assembly Budget Committee last month, Mr. Hughes spoke of the "Great Trans-Millenial Economic Expansion," which he predicted would slow a bit next year.
Assemblyman Leonard Lance, the budget committee chairman, said of the presentations: "They are indeed performers. But behind the wit, which I certainly enjoy, is very valuable information.
MR. FRANCESE, who spent more than two decades in Ithaca, N.Y., said: "I cannot imagine anyone from the State University of New York doing that. They've not got the kind of vision about the future, and the powers of analysis and the credibility."
Whitman administration officials call, too. Shirley M. Bishop, the executive director of the state Council on Affordable Housing and a former student of Mr. Hughes's, said, "I can pick up the phone and call Dean Hughes and he is readily available to give me insights and information."
Ms. Bishop said other faculty members and alumni were also prime contacts.
"Other institutions are not sourced the way Bloustein is," she said. "The quality of the faculty is exceptional."
The school has always helped state and local officials in more systematic fashion, usually through the Center for Government Services, a kind of think tank for school finance, property taxation, reapportionment and similar issues. The center also trains hundreds of municipal officials.
And now government agencies contract with the school's Center for Government Services and its three newer research centers, focusing on work force issues, transportation and brownfields and neighborhood redevelopment.
"Those are the big three issues for the state of New Jersey," said Carl E. Van Horn, the director of the John J. Heldrich Center for Work Force Development. "Always have been and always will be."
Mr. Van Horn said the only other state university taking a comparable role was the University of Wisconsin, long known for its research on state issues. He said New Jersey's need for something like it was impressed upon him while he was on leave from the Rutgers faculty and serving as Governor Florio's policy director, before the Bloustein school was founded.
"I felt disadvantaged, if you will, not having information at hand to advise the governor," he said. "I had Wisconsin envy."
The work force center does do research on a national scale, including a survey of American workers on issues like job security and the information economy that is reported periodically in a publication called Work Trends.
But the center has many state-level projects; recently, for example, it evaluated the state's program for people who have exhausted unemployment benefits.
The study cost the state $300,000, while private consultants probably would have charged $1 million, Mr. Van Horn said. "We already have the computer facilities here at Rutgers," he said, "and very bright Ph.D. students who are not making $80,000 a year."
The Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center at the school also has a mix of national, regional and state research projects. For its director, Mr. Hughes recruited Louis Gambaccini, who as transportation commissioner in the 1970's engineered the creation of New Jersey Transit.
And the new National Center for Neighborhood and Brownfields Redevelopment is, despite its name, an outgrowth of a proposal to do more research in New Jersey.
Michael Greenberg, the center's director and an expert in urban environmental health, said he had been drawn away by his work on nuclear and chemical weapons sites -- two kinds, he noted, that New Jersey does not have -- and wanted to pull together research on neighborhoods suffering environmental and economic damage.
As Mr. Greenberg recalled, "I sat down with Jim Hughes and Jim Florio and some other people and said, 'All this time I've been working on contamination and public health problems everywhere but in my own state. I'd like to set up some kind of research organization and take things I've done in Colorado, Indiana, Alabama, and apply them to New Jersey.'
"The two Jims helped me figure out how to do it."
The word often used for the research centers is "entrepreneurial": they need grants and contracts and thus, whether as a matter of money or academic pride, they need to market their work.
The school is good at that, said John Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a liberal think tank in Trenton. "They're aggressive in finding audiences," Mr. Shure said. "I think it's a further sign of New Jersey becoming an entity that people identify with and think of as their home."
RESEARCH in state and local issues is not new to state universities, of course. But it is still the first new idea for land-grant institutions since the late 19th century, when they set up agricultural research stations. (And Rutgers extension service agents in all 21 counties can still tell you how to grow bigger tomatoes.)
Like all land-grant schools, Rutgers has to balance competing demands: to serve the state and to cultivate a larger reputation.
"If you adhere too much to what the traditional academics want, you're not serving the function of a public policy school in that youre not being of service to a community," Ms. Erlichson, the public policy professor, said. "If you're only interested in service to the community, then the academic world shuns you."
Tom Dalessio, a policy adviser in the Governor's Office of Policy and Planning, and a member of the university's board of trustees, said: "There's a natural inclination among faculty to want to be renowned and to study national and international issues. It's symptomatic of other problems in New Jersey. We always treat ourselves as second best."
Mr. Dalessio, conceding some bias as a trustee and an alumnus, said the Bloustein school's reputation was growing fast.
"The urban planning program has long been one of the top five," he said. "I imagine that in the next 5 or 10 years, when it comes to the study of public policy, people will mention Bloustein in the same breath as Wilson and the Kennedy School."
Whether that comes to pass or not, faculty members say New Jersey is nothing if not good material: court-ordered school finance and housing plans, urban decay and suburban sprawl, tax problems, a roaring new economy and 566 municipalities trying to govern.
"I was in California, which is a very exciting policy arena," Ms. Erlichson said. "Coming here and finding New Jersey is in many ways more interesting is a surprise."
 
The Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy
 
Location: Civic Square, Rutgers University, New Brunswick
Founded: 1992
Enrollment: approximately 300
Dean: James W. Hughes
Faculty: 44
Support and research staff: 67
Degree programs: undergraduate degrees in urban studies and public health; 15 graduate programs, including public policy, city and regional planning, and programs offering joint degrees in law and public health.
Research centers: The John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development, the Center for Government Services, the National Center for Neighborhood and Brownfields Redevelopment, the Voorhees Transportation Center.
Sample of publications: The New Jersey Legislative District Data Book, Rutgers Regional Report, School District Achievement Index, Rankings of Municipalities, Work Trends.
Budget: $3 million in state funds; $13 million in grants, contracts and continuing education tuition.
 
If You're Going to Be Quoted . . .
 
James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, has to be one of the most most quoted people in New Jersey. That's because he knows a lot. It is also because he is more quotable than, say, the average legislator or cabinet member. Here is a sample of recent pronouncements.
 
On baby boomers: "Baby boomers have moved from Hondas to SUV's, a move perhaps in parallel to their maturing derrieres."
 
On the baby boomers' vehicles: "We have $1.70 gasoline. Justice has been served."
 
On the enduring importance of location: "The dot-com people, who are spearheading the Internet revolution, cluster ever deeper into Silicon Valley and Route 128 around Boston, even while their technology supposedly lessens the relevance of place."
 
On the current economic expansion: "More New Jerseyans believe they were abducted by aliens than believe we have eclipsed the 1980's."
 
On the politics of development: "In 1992 the Clinton campaign was famous for saying, 'It's the economy, stupid.' But with the economy doing so well, the next campaign slogan might better be, 'It's the sprawl, stupid.' "
 
On the Bloustein school's building: "A countercyclical capital infrastructure investment project that was instigated in the depths of the last recession."
 
On his career: "I have had a Forrest Gump career trajectory. Things just came up."
 
On demography in general: "You really can predict the outlines of the future."
 
On his own forecasting: "We've predicted all kinds of things that proceeded not to happen."
 LAURA MANSNERUS

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2839 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
In Manhattan, a Scattering of New Hotels

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE last few years have been good for New York City hotels. Occupancy rates have been consistently near or over 80 percent, compared to 63 to 65 percent for the rest of the country. Room rates have been rising, with the cost of a night in the city last year averaging $213 before taxes according to Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm.
Because of the strong business, developers have found lenders willing to finance new hotels. As a result, from 3,200 to 4,000 new hotel rooms are set to open in Manhattan this year. 
 "This is the largest number of new hotel rooms to open in the city as long as I have been keeping a list, which is back to 1985," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, a hospitality specialist.
The projects -- some new construction, some the renovation of existing buildings -- are spread across Manhattan, from the southern tip of the island to the Upper West Side, rather than concentrated in the traditional Midtown and downtown business districts. Some real estate executives said this is a reflection of how Internet startups and related companies have rejected the high rents and perceived stuffiness of traditional business centers for places like the Flatiron District and Chelsea.
With a base of about 60,000 rooms already available, the influx of new rooms is expected to trim occupancy rates only slightly. And the new rooms may provide some good news for travelers by limiting the rise in room rates.
"The effect will be to probably reduce the occupancy rate by one half to a full percentage point and limit room-rate increases to $10 to $15 a night in calendar 2000," Mr. Fox said. Nevertheless, New York will remain a pricey location compared to the rest of the nation, where the average daily rate is estimated at $81 a night.
Other analysts argue that additional hotel rooms cannot be added fast enough. "The New York hotel market is not one of the largest in the nation," said Sean Hennessey, manager of the New York hospitality practice for PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. "Las Vegas and Orlando have about 120,000 rooms. It could be that we are underserved rather than on the brink of a glut."
The new offerings include both the luxurious and the budget-minded: the return of the Ritz-Carlton brand to Manhattan after an absence of two years, the advent of the Regent brand -- with a basic room rate of $545 a night -- and the arrival of a Red Roof Inn, with rates starting at $89 a night.
The single biggest hotel developer this year is Bruce C. Ratner, the president of Forest City Ratner Companies, which plans to open more than 900 rooms in hotels attached to entertainment and retail complexes in Battery Park City and Times Square.
The Embassy Suites Hotel in Battery Park City will have 463 rooms in a 383,000-square-foot complex facing North End Avenue that will also include a 16-screen, 4,000-seat Regal Cinema, a 20,000-square-foot sports club and several restaurants and stores, including a 6,500-square-foot Kinko's.
The 444-room Hilton hotel on 42nd Street has been built atop a 335,000-square-foot development that is to include a 25-screen AMC Entertainment motion picture theater, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum, an HMV music store and assorted restaurants and stores. Both Ratner hotels are expected to open this spring.
Mr. Ratner said the addition of the entertainment, food and other retail uses to the two projects improved the economics of the hotels to the point where he could obtain financing.
Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz Mountain Industries, which operates the SoHo Grand hotel and is due to open the 203-room TriBeCa Grand, at Avenue of the Americas and Walker Street, next month, said that finding financing for hotel projects is difficult.
"Hotels are the last asset class the lenders warm up to and the first one they go cold on," Mr. Stern said. "You can get hotel financing for about 18 to 24 months in any 10-year period."
Mr. Ratner said that when he took over the Battery Park City project three years ago, the hotel business was rebounding from a sluggish time in the early 90's and financiers were still skittish. "This is a good example of mixed-use development," he said. "Another developer had this site and could not make it work. When we took it over we doubled the amount of retail to absorb more of the cost of the land and taxes."
Since retailers typically pay a far higher rent per square foot than do other tenants, devoting the lower floors of the two projects to stores, restaurants and movies made the projects bankable, he said.
In addition, he said, putting entertainment and retail stores in the same building as the hotel improves the quality of a visit to New York.
"When people come to New York they don't want to just stay at a hotel," Mr. Ratner said. "Putting the retail and the entertainment in direct proximity to the hotel benefits both." Most of the rooms in the Embassy Suites open to a central atrium, eliminating the long, gloomy corridors common in large hotels. One wall of the atrium is decorated by what the company said is New York's largest painting, an 80-foot-high by 130-foot-wide work by Sol LeWitt titled "Loopy Doopy (Blue and Purple)."
At the 42nd and 41st Street entrances for the Hilton, which is between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, there will be sculptures by Tom Otterness of figures trying to topple clocks from the marquees. Original art, sculpture and historic photographs will be in the public spaces and guest rooms of both hotels. The value of the art commissioned and purchased for the two hotels is put at $4 million by the Public Art Fund, Forest City Ratner and Hilton Hotels, which were partners in the art program.
Some of the new hotels opening are much smaller than the Embassy Suites, the Hilton and the Sofitel -- the other big, newly constructed hotel, which is to open in June on West 44th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, with 398 rooms. Some emphasize a theme to differentiate them from hotels that simply offer a room for the night.
Few will be more highly themed than the Library, which is due to open with 60 rooms by the end of May. It is being developed by Henry Kallan, who recently opened a similar theme hotel, Giraffe, at Park Avenue and 26th Street. He also owns the Casablanca Hotel on 43rd Street just off Times Square.
The Giraffe incorporates balconies in many of its guest rooms to emphasize a European style. The Library, at Madison Avenue and 41st Street, is named for its proximity to the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.
THE Library will have a restaurant on the first floor and a library on the second. The library theme will be carried throughout the renovated office building, with room numbers using the Dewey decimal system and a "library card" instead of a room key.
Mr. Kallan said that each floor would have a different subject, such as social science, geography or Slavic languages. The rooms themselves will be stocked with books on the theme subject.
"If you are interested in a subject, you can book a room and read up on it," said Mr. Kallan, who added that he expects to attract guests from the publishing, fashion and cosmetics industries. He said he was exploring the possibility of staging special events with literary trappings, including one with a book-of-the-month theme.
Mr. Kallan said he would try to capitalize on the hotel's location a block from Grand Central Terminal by developing the 14th floor as a kind of clubhouse. Suburban spouses who wanted to come into the city early to shop before meeting a working spouse for dinner or a show would have a place to rest and store packages and would be entitled to the corporate rate if they decided to stay the night.
Rates at the Library are to range from $245 to $325 a night, with the corporate discount lowering that to $195 to $225, Mr. Kallan said.
Across 41st Street, Morris Moinian is preparing to open the Dylan Hotel in late June or early July. Housed in a building that was once home to the Chemists Club, the 108-room hotel is the product of a complete renovation that added four stories to the existing 10-story structure.
Mr. Moinian, who owns Jordan, a woman's fashion company, and the 300-room Wyndham Sugar Bay Hotel in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, said he was convinced that there is a place for boutique hotels that can attract people who prefer not to stay at mass-market properties, such as the big hotels operated by Hilton and Marriott.
"I think it will be attractive to creative people from the fashion and advertising industries who want a small hotel but one that is business-friendly as well," he said.
Mr. Moinian said he had spent $30 million to renovate the 1903 building, whose exterior is designed in the Beaux-Arts style. Of that, more than $1 million was devoted to restoring the facade, ornate plasterwork and other architectural details. The former ballroom, with its six-foot stone fireplace and 20-foot ceilings, is being converted to a restaurant that is being called, in deference to the building's origins, Rx.
"There was a lot of mahogany and stained glass, and we preserved as much as we could," he said.
Despite this sensitivity to the past, the guest rooms are fully wired for high-speed Internet access, with fax capability and two or three telephones in each room. There are two conference rooms on the third floor that can be combined to seat up to 75 people, and a two-bedroom grand suite with a 2,000-square-foot balcony. Room rates at Dylan will range from $295 to $395, with suites priced higher.
Mr. Moinian said he believed there were still opportunities to develop boutique hotels in Manhattan neighborhoods that were largely neglected manufacturing areas but that have been rejuvenated as the shortage of office space in traditional locations has brought an influx of new tenants from Internet and related businesses.
Right now, he said, he is looking in Chelsea for a suitable property. "Chelsea appears to be a continuation of SoHo," he said.
Mr. Stern of Hartz Mountain said the key to putting a hotel in a nontraditional area was that the area have a vibrant business community in addition to attractive living and trendy retail spaces. "Nontraditional businesses are spreading into areas like SoHo and TriBeCa," he said, "and they will generate demand for hotel rooms."
The downtown business district is also attracting hotel development. In addition to the Embassy Suites project, a high-tech Holiday Inn Wall Street opened last year at 15 Gold Street, and a Ritz-Carlton is being built on Battery Place near the southern tip of Manhattan.
The 311-room hotel at Battery Place is part of a mixed-use project being developed by Millennium Partners, which is also renovating the old St. Moritz Hotel, at Central Park South and Avenue of the Americas. When complete late next year, the former St. Moritz will also be branded a Ritz-Carlton and be managed by the company, which is a subsidiary of Marriott International. Twelve condominium units, each a full floor of the building, will also be sold.
The Battery Park project will also include 120 condominium units in addition to the hotel rooms. Matthew Hall, an executive with Millennium, said that the sale of the condominiums would improve the economics of the $175 million project. "Revenues from condominium sales will help cover infrastructure costs," he said. "It helps spread the risk and provides a different source of income."
The Regent Hotel, in the column-encrusted building at 55 Wall Street, has gradually been opening since last December, and executives expect it to be fully ready for business by May 1. (Hotel developers say that these so-called soft openings, in which only a few floors are ready to receive guests, are a way of getting some cash flowing early and are a means of training staff.)
The 156-year-old building, which has been home to a stock exchange and a customs house and had been the headquarters of National City Bank, has undergone an $80 million renovation and has 144 guest rooms plus a restaurant and lounge. Aimed at affluent business travelers -- presumably visiting their investment bankers -- the rooms have the typical array of technology features, such as Internet connections and multiple telephone lines for voice mail and fax.
A spokeswoman for the hotel said that no decision had been made about what to do with the dozen jail cells that are a legacy of the building's use as a Federal building during the draft riots of the Civil War. They are being used as storerooms, the spokeswoman said, but some thought is being given to converting them to wine cellars or a cigar bar.
Suites at the Regent can cost as much as $1,600 a night, but there are places to stay in Manhattan that do not require a bank loan.
Apple Core Hotels is converting an office building at 6 West 32nd Street to a 172-room Red Roof Inn, that brand's first entry into Manhattan. It is expected to open in early May, with room rates ranging from $89 to $199 a night.
Vijay Dandapani, Apple Core's chief operating officer, said the Red Roof Inn project, like the company's other four hotels in Manhattan -- the brands include Best Western and Quality Inn -- is focusing on hotel basics rather then themes.
"Most customers want a nice lodging experience," he said. "They want a comfortable bed and a quiet room."
He said that the 17-story former office building had a 50-by-80-foot footprint that made it "ideal for conversion." And Apple Core knew something about the location. It operates a Best Western across the street, at 17 West 32nd.
The hotel is aimed at travelers on a budget, but guests will find amenities not always available at lower-priced hotels. The Red Roof will have an exercise room, a meeting room and a business center with computing, copying and fax facilities.
Another facility aimed at budget travelers has been announced by Ian Schrager, a hotel developer associated with upscale, trendy projects, who has said he plans to convert the 960-room Henry Hudson Hotel on West 57th Street to a hotel with rates starting at $75 a night.
Meanwhile, another group is taking aim at the budget traveler by converting once-dowdy single-room-occupancy hotels in good locations to transient lodgings with room rates as low as $75 a night.
THE Citylife Hotel Group has converted the old Allerton House at 57th Street and Lexington Avenue into Habitat, which has been marketed mostly to European tourists. The hotel is on a popular shopping street, and the first floor is to house a Kenneth Cole fashion store, with the hotel's lobby on the second floor.
The old Broadway American hotel at 77th Street and Broadway in the heart of the Upper West Side has been transformed by Citylife into On The Ave (for avenue, although Broadway is not an avenue).
And by this summer, the former Martha Washington Hotel at 30 East 30th Street is to be be relaunched by Citylife as Thirty Thirty. There will be a total of about 1,100 rooms in the three hotels, but not all will be available for transient rental because some permanent residents remain. In each case all the rooms have been renovated and equipped with new furnishings and linens. Amenities include alarm clocks, color television sets, Internet access and free continental breakfast in the lobby.
"Our concept was to be the low-cost provider," said Kevin Maloney, a partner in Citylife. Mr. Maloney said that each property is distinctive and intended to appeal to different segments of the budget market.
At On The Ave, where the basic rate is $155 a night, the stress is proximity to the West Side's cultural institutions, such as the American Museum of Natural History, the Rose Center for Earth and Space and Lincoln Center, as well as the area's restaurants.
At Habitat the emphasis is on Midtown, including Rockefeller Center, St. Patrick's Cathedral and the Disney Store. There is one other detail at Habitat -- to get the $75 rate you have to accept a room with the toilet and shower down the hall and in separate rooms. For a room with an attached bath, the rate is $105 for a single and $125 for a double.
Mr. Maloney said the baths down the hall had been an obstacle to European tour groups, particularly those from Scandinavia. He said he hoped to encourage repeat business by showing that budget lodgings can be acceptable. "The idea is if they come and stay in the city and feel they have not been ripped off they will come back," he said.
Budget travelers may be tight with a dollar, but that does not mean they are technically unsophisticated.
Mr. Maloney said Citylife had been focusing most of its marketing efforts on the Internet over the last few months, and that it seems to be paying off.
"Twenty to 25 percent of our bookings are coming directly through the Internet," he said. "People in the budget range shop the Internet. We are getting over 200,000 hits on our site a month."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Growing a Business in Ethanol

BYLINE: By LISA SUHAY 

 BODY:
New Jersey's farmers are considering feeding their corn into gas tanks instead of chickens.
The reason is that the federal government is expected to mandate ethanol in gasoline to reduce automobile emissions. 
 Making ethanol requires corn, which is already growing on more than half the state's farmland, and a factory to distill it. It is the factory that is lacking, and a farmers' organization is pushing its members to build one.
A big impetus came last month when the Environmental Protection Agency announced its decision to phase out the use of methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., a gasoline additive that has been linked to drinking water contamination and cancer in animals.
The agency is expected to require "safe biofuel" additions, or oxygenates, which add oxygen to fuel and reduce pollution in exhaust.
"That makes ethanol the only commercially available alternative," said John Urbanchuk, executive vice president of A.U.A. Consultants of Moorestown, which was hired last summer by the New Jersey Farm Bureau, a trade organization, to do an economic feasibility study on building an ethanol distillery in New Jersey.
"If you are looking for options for increasing farmers' income, then this is one way to go," Mr. Urbanchuk said.
"There is a lot of attention to ethanol production around the country. Corn is the largest grain crop in New Jersey. In a normal year state farmers will produce approximately nine million bushels of corn, not the highest in the nation by far, but enough to make an ethanol plant here a viable option."
Corn from New Jersey is shipped mainly to Maryland and Delaware for chicken feed, according John Rigolizzo, a corn farmer and president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, in Trenton.
Farmers pay 25 to 50 cents a bushel in transportation costs to ship a crop that fetches only $1.25 a bushel; sales for ethanol would bring in about 15 to 25 cents more per bushel, according to the A.U.A. study.
The possibilty of building an ethanol factory has fueled the imagination of a growing number of farmers who are willing to gamble a percentage of their corn crop and cash on using their grain to make the fuel additive.
At the seven meetings held by the Farm Bureau this month, attendance has gone from a dozen farmers to better than 150 at one meeting.
Sites that have been mentioned include the Burlington County landfill in Mansfield and a spot in Salem County near the Delaware River port there.
"The Farm Bureau is always looking for a way for farmers to make more money," Mr. Rigolizzo said.
"If the E.P.A. rules in favor of using oxygenates, then this is going to take off. There'll be a demand. If they rule against, then this is all scrapped. We believe they are going in this direction, and this is an opportunity for New Jersey to not only take a leadership role, but to help farmers."
According to Mr. Rigolizzo, it would cost about $16 million to build an average-size plant to produce 10 million to 15 million gallons of ethanol a year. About 30 percent of that cost would come from farmers.
"We will be looking to raise about $3 million to $4 million from farmers and the rest from lending institutions and grants," Mr. Rigolizzo said.
The Farm Bureau is looking for investments from about 400 farmers, who would form a co-op. A share in the plant would cost $12,500; they would also be asked to sell corn to the plant at market prices.
According to Transportation Department statistics for 1997, the most recent available, New Jersey now uses about 12.5 million gallons of ethanol a year, and the country uses more than 15 billion gallons blended with gasoline. There are 55 ethanol distilleries in 20 states.
The American Coalition for Ethanol, in Sioux Falls, S.D., touts its value to farmers. Its Web site says, "The demand for grain created by ethanol production increases net farm income more than $12 billion annually."
Mr. Rigolizzo calls the response by New Jersey farmers "terrific so far."
"Even the most skeptical farmers are asking for 5 and 10 shares," he said. "They're excited by this idea, and it takes a lot to get us excited about the future."
Richard Melchert, a corn farmer and owner of Richview Farms in Elmer, in Salem County, said:
"I think I am in favor of the plant. When I first went to meetings last year, the numbers didn't really jump off the page at you. Then I started seeing articles about it in Farm Journal magazine and other places and started thinking this could be the answer.
"Now you go to the Farm Bureau meetings on ethanol and it's standing room only, so opinions have changed."
What got Mr. Rigolizzo to the same position was two years of investigation into the making of ethanol fuel from grains and visits to ethanol plants.
The plants "smell kind of like a nice wine," he said.
Mr. Rigolizzo also paid attention to the economic study by A.U.A., which was completed in December.
In addition to creating a market for corn farmers, Mr. Urbanchuk noted, a local ethanol market would keep corn farmers away from other markets like tomatoes and other garden crops.
"Keeping grain farmers out of other markets will keep prices for tomatoes from being driven down by the increase in crops," Mr. Rigolizzo said. "Guys scratching and scraping to find niche markets could keep their grain crops. That's good for everybody."
He added: "When the study came in, we got very excited about this idea. Next thing is a marketing study. We want all the ducks in a row on this. Then we start working on the state government for support. We have a lot of phones to ring."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
DeNiro Eyeing Yonkers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The actor Robert DeNiro and Harvey Weinstein of Miramax are negotiating with state officials to build a movie studio, which would include the world's tallest sound stage, in an old industrial complex on the Yonkers waterfront, Edward A. Sheeran, the city's director of economic development, said.
The studio would be built on a 16-acre site in the same building where "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" was filmed. That building has a 92-foot-high ceiling, the highest on the Eastern Seaboard, Mr. Sheeran said. 
 The city has agreed to reduce the assessed value of the property from about $9 million to about $2.5 million because of the cost of cleaning up industrial contaminants on the site, Mr. Sheeran said. It has also agreed to refund $700,000 to the current owner, British International Cable Corporation, a transportation and development company in London, with North American headquarters in West Nyack.
The estimated cost of a cleanup is about $7.5 million. The property, was used to produce copper cable since 1886, when the Habirshaw Cable and Wire Company owned it. It was occupied by Phelps Dodge from 1930 to 1984, when BICC bought it and operated its plant for 12 years.
Saying that the film industry was attracted to Yonkers because of its proximity to New York City, Mr. Sheeran added, "Not a week goes by without some movie scene being shot here." ELSA BRENNER

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1034 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Where the Shirts Are Scanned, Not Stuffed

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IN 1996, David Fraser Walker and Martin Brighty were enjoying success as sales executives in the venerable British neckwear business when their company, Holliday & Brown, went through a downsizing and they found themselves out on the street.
Happily for them, though, the street wasn't just any street. It was Savile Row. 
 So there on an exclusive thoroughfare known for its purveyors of gentlemen's clothes and accessories, they set themselves up as Hunters Partnership Ltd., selling handmade silk ties in traditional English patterns from their cluttered second-story premises to retailers in Britain, Scandinavia and the United States. They also serve walk-in customers adventurous enough to enter by way of the centuries-old military tailor on the floor below.
This winter, thanks to an innovative application of the World Wide Web, they opened their Savile Row address to the world, enabling people continents away to make a personal, though virtual, call. While visiting, customers can even try on some ties.
On the Hunters interactive Web site --
Luxuryties.com -- customers can choose from 16 Savile Row ties and see how they go with particular shirts. They can select from 10 shirts offered on the Web site or paste shirts in from other online suppliers. Or they can even pull their favorite mauve number from the bottom drawer, photograph it, scan it in and then match ties online.
I recently tried the Web site and looked in on the operation, which for me is only a short Underground ride away. I found that there are advantages to shopping for ties on a machine that go beyond geographical convenience.
For one thing, a computer will not tell you that the print you have selected is you, absolutely you, 100 percent you. The screen just sits there, quiet and unobjecting, while you make awful choices. It emits no patronizing sighs when you make good ones.
Mr. Brighty, 33, floor man turned Web site owner, acknowledged the point. "Even if the approach is a gentle 'Can I help you please, sir?' people tend to freeze," he said. "We like to think this is offering a bit of Savile Row in a nonintimidating way."'
For those who are intimidated not by the street's doormen in swallow-tail coats and striped trousers but by technology itself, the Web site includes step-by-step instructions on how to find the right regimental stripe for, say, that lilac-checked shirt that goes to war with every design on the local tie rack.
The ties average $70, including delivery, less a 15 percent discount for those who buy three at once or who join the Hunters Tie Club, whose application is on the site.
I FOUND the site easy enough to navigate, and there is something about a Savile Row cravat that outshines the ones I get from airport tie-and-sock shops whenever spaghetti sauce ends up on my shirt front.
Clicking on a tie and dropping it in place beneath the collar has some of the drama of a long ball to the corner that either brings everybody home or falls ignominiously foul. Just inches separate the smash hit from the howler. But why bother to go on this virtual journey in the age of globalization?
"Gentlemen want to look English, and this is Englishness at its best," Mr. Brighty said. "If you want to look English, why not buy the real thing and be authentic?"
The site, up just two months, has recorded 86,000 hits, and it hasn't been written about widely until now.
Eager to attract young Web surfers who may have gone bare-necked all their lives, Mr. Walker, 37, is installing diagrams showing the three most common methods for tying a tie -- the four in hand, the half Windsor and the full Windsor.
When Internet Assist Ltd. of Kingston-upon-Thames designed the site, it believed the interactive shirt-and-tie matching to be the first of its kind. "We did lots of research and we found nothing like it," said Hannah Oppenheim, the firm's managing director.
Checking out the Hunters line is a quick education in the Savile row dialect. The line includes three basic types: foulard ties, which are silk prints; madders, or prints on heavier silk; and jacquards, or woven silks, usually with stripes or elaborate designs.
I found myself admiring the traditional techniques that Mr. Walker and Mr. Brightly described so jauntily. All the ties are made from natural fibers, with pure wool linings, silk tippings inside the tie ends, loops that keep both flaps of the tie together and a spring thread that holds the shape.
The regimental rep stripes come in patterns from traditional English and Scottish fighting forces like the Royal Hussars, the Queen's Royal Lancers, the Light Dragoons and the Seaforth Highlanders. Mr. Brighty mentioned that his great-grandfather had been a tailor in the Royal Fusiliers.
Wearing regimental stripes in Britain can be socially perilous. "Germans love the old Royal Army Medical Corps ties, and you know, they'll be in a pub when it's half deserted and some old fellow who's from the ranks will come up and try to cadge a drink off of them," Mr. Brighty said.
IT is a tricky business, this matter of selling ties around the world. "The Japanese don't like ties with swords on them, but they adore cutesy little dogs and cats and teddy bears," Mr. Walker said. "With the Middle East, it's no crosses or stars."
Americans are fond of the kinds of patterned wildlife ties that shooters of game birds wear with their tweeds. But some people closer to home, where blood sports is a charged issue, aren't. "One of our neighbors had 'Hunting scum' written across his window," Mr. Walker said.
In the end, there is no telling what influences tie choice. "We used to hear stories that if times were going badly, people began buying ties in darker colors," Mr. Brighty said. "But then someone pointed out that when there was a recession, people actually bought more ties, because they couldn't afford a whole new suit."
Until recently, the most popular colors with Hunters' customers were red, blue and green. But then Monica Lewinsky famously gave a tie to President Clinton. "We suddenly had a rush of orders for the same kind," Mr. Brighty said. "So now the favorite colors are red, blue, green and gold."

Barbara Burby, Samuel Wang
