HEADLINE: A Color Only a Fan Could Love

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
HENRY FORD said customers could have any color car they wanted as long as it was black, but Mr. Ford never went to college, which explains why he never made anything of himself.
Had he graduated from, say, Michigan State -- which recently won the N.C.A.A. basketball championship -- he might have offered the Model T in the Spartans' team colors, green and white. 
 Such boosterism inspired managers at Nissan's truck plant in Smyrna, Tenn., to paint several dozen Frontier Crew Cabs in the Halloween orange of the University of Tennessee Volunteers, who won the national collegiate football championship in 1999.
"There is a lot of school spirit in the area," said Tom Groom, spokesman for the Smyrna operation. "All of the trucks got scooped up and sold in a hurry."
In all, 72 Crew Cabs and one preproduction Xterra were painted orange during the spring of 1999 as the plant prepared for full production of the vehicles. "It was kind of an experiment, as a way to draw attention to dealers," said Mr. Groom.
The paint-shop manager, Tom Collins, got a color sample from the University of Tennessee, then adjusted the color slightly to make it less "aggressive" and to avoid any infringement on the university's copyrighted color.
In a country where even caskets are available in sports regalia, why don't more cars come in school colors? First, because the economics of car-building resist low-volume paint runs. Modern vehicle plants run on squeaky-tight schedules, made even tighter by the current boom in sales. Custom paint orders require that the paint circulating systems be stopped and flushed -- a process that can take as long as a week, according to the DuPont color marketing manager, Bob Daily, who went to Waynesburg College in Pennsylvania (brown and yellow).
In Tuscaloosa, home to the Crimson Tide of the University of Alabama, the Mercedes plant is running "25 hours a day," said James M. Resnick, a company spokesman. While it would be fun to produce a Crimson Tide edition, he said, "it would take time and energy away from the core production."
Mr. Daily pointed out that "even a small car is a very big area," and that many sports teams' colors simply wouldn't wear well on vehicles. "We have to be guided by our own opinions of good taste," said Mr. Daily. "Of course, if you are a proud alumnus, your opinion might differ."

HEADLINE: CALLINGS;
A Forefather of Venture Capital

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN; Laura Pedersen-Pietersen is a Manhattan author and public speaker. Her column profiling people whose work is their passion appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: yourmind@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: ST. PAUL

 BODY:
AT 84, Alan K. Ruvelson has every reason to dismiss those bumper stickers that read "Lead, follow or get out of the way." Ever since he was a teenager in Minnesota, he has been a chronic joiner.
And that joining instinct, so famously scorned by Groucho Marx ("I don't care to belong to any club that will accept me as a member"), has served Mr. Ruvelson quite well. It has even had an impact on the nation's economy -- for among his many accomplishments, Mr. Ruvelson was a venture-capital pioneer. 
 "He was one of the founding fathers of venture capitalism," said Samuel L. Hayes III, an investment banking specialist at Harvard, who met Mr. Ruvelson when they led venture capital seminars in the 60's.
It all started in 1928, when Mr. Ruvelson entered the St. Thomas Military Academy here, decades before "network" became a verb. As one of a handful of Jews at the school, he saw early that getting involved was a way to build bridges. So he joined clubs and other school activities.
After graduating from the University of Minnesota with a business degree, he joined his father in the diamond business, married his college sweetheart and joined the local PTA and assorted community groups. He also began exhibiting, as he put it, "dangerous amateur Republican tendencies" for someone from a fundamentally Democratic family and area. By the early 1950's, he was campaigning for Dwight D. Eisenhower, and his loyalty was rewarded in 1953 when he was appointed a regional field adviser for the new Small Business Administration.
While the job did not even pay the proverbial "dollar a year," it did let him learn of Washington's plans for easing the path toward financing small businesses. So during Eisenhower's second term, Mr. Ruvelson was first in line for a license in the Small Business Investment Companies program.
In 1959, he pioneered the nation's first such company: First Midwest Capital, still based in St. Paul (though now called First Midwest Ventures and primarily a consulting business). "It was like traveling across the prairie, making your own wagon tracks," he said of the firm's early days.
First Midwest made the first investment under the program, in the Pride Seed Company, a producer of hybrid corn seed in Glen Haven, Wis., that later became part of Novartis.
In 1971, Mr. Ruvelson was also one of the first to invest in a software company, Comserv Inc., eventually acquired by Dun & Bradstreet.
He was a pioneer in other ways. In the early 1960's, he discovered a capital-gains tax loophole that attracted many other investors to the venture capital field, though Congress ended that incentive by changing the tax laws in the 1980's.
From 1959 to 1986, when Mr. Ruvelson turned more toward consulting, First Midwest invested about $15 million in 63 companies. Most were later bought by larger concerns.
His ideas turned the small-business lending universe upside down. Previously, loans were made in exchange for collateral; now investments were made in exchange for equity.
Mr. Ruvelson embraces the legacy. "Prior to that, there were really only wealthy families like the Whitneys and the Rockefellers who did venture investing," he said.
He was also one of the first investors to effect a leveraged buyout -- that of H. & Val Rothschild Inc., a mortgage banker that was later sold. "People didn't call it an L.B.O.," he said, "just a high-risk deal."
Still active in First Midwest and his many civic committees, he notes that his voluntary activities have helped him come across deals that would have otherwise escaped his attention. But then he often gave these civic pursuits priority over his business. "I could have made a lot more money had I not spent so much time trying to solve local business problems," he said. Even in his investments, he favored ones that fostered growth around the Twin Cities.
The leading venture capitalists of today are far wealthier, he acknowledged. "Just because you're first doesn't necessarily make you the richest," he said, laughing heartily. "Being a pioneer means you have to make the first mistakes as well."
What does he see as the future of venture capital? "Stepped-up activity with less government involvement." Young people today, he said, do not understand the personal and professional value of volunteerism because the robust economy has insulated them. "Whatever you do, get involved." he advised. "You become part and parcel of all that you see and do. It broadens you."

HEADLINE: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Justin Kerrigan;
Rolling Stoned

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
WHEN the Welsh hyphenate writer-director-actor Justin Kerrigan blew into New York on Sunday night, the people at Miramax, which is releasing "Human Traffic," his film on the rave scene, must have gone for the Advil.
It's not that Mr. Kerrigan, 26, is one of those bad boys who trash hotel rooms. It's that he's candid about his decadent drug-fueled lifestyle, which is celebrated in his film. 
 Which means it's pretty entertaining to meet him flying without a conversational governor in a bar in Greenwich Village, just off the plane from London, as he sets out to party through the night.
Mr. Kerrigan is emblematic of a batch of ravequake directors who have established a new genre of beach party movies set in the club world of the 90's. A night with him seemed like a live-action version of his film, jarringly unabashed and slightly blurry.
"Human Traffic" details 48 hours in the lives of five 20-somethings in Cardiff, Wales, who are stuck in dead-end jobs and live for Saturday night, when they can take drugs and dance. It is based on him and his friends, and the subplot about impotence is based on his own experience.
"I had sexual insecurity big time," he offered. "But I got over it."
The working life of the characters in the film is also familiar ground. Mr. Kerrigan worked in the British Home Stores when he wasn't on the dole. That was before Miramax flew him business class on British Airways to New York, after giving him a three-picture deal.
As for drugs, another subplot in the movie, Mr. Kerrigan not only likes them, he makes no secret of doing them. At 11 p.m. he broke away from sipping Jack Daniel's and Cokes to slip into the limousine to call a friend. He just wanted to make sure that when he was finished drinking Jack Daniel's and Cokes he could drop by and get stoned.
This attitude has taken Mr. Kerrigan from Cardiff to the highest circles. He refers to Harvey Weinstein at Miramax, which bought the film last fall, as "the Al Capone of the movie industry." Last year, he met the Queen at Windsor Castle after "Human Traffic" won some awards. "And I wanted to say, 'Have you seen this film?' "
There he was, he said, in the Great Hall, and in came the Queen "and her posse."
"Suddenly she's there and I didn't know what to do, so I stuck out my hand," he said. "You're not supposed to touch the Queen or make the first move. But she was nice and she took my hand. And then she stayed to talk. And finally I said, 'So do you rent this place out for parties?' "
He shared the information that he smoked a joint in the Great Hall, and that "I woke up in Bayswater with no money, no cab fare, and I had to stop and say, 'What happened?' "
By midnight, the car was headed uptown to party sites unknown, and it was time for this reporter to be dropped off. Sharing his gen-Ecstacy philosophy about success, Mr. Kerrigan made clear that people can get all they need from the visual environment. "I've only read four books in my entire life," he said. They are "Conversations With Woody Allen," "Conversations With Martin Scorsese," Douglas Coupland's "Generation X" and "Mr. Nice Guy," by Howard Marks, a pot dealer.
He fretted about his schedule. The next day he would leave for other cities. "Miramax is giving me two days off in Houston," he said. "They're turning me loose in John Wayne territory. What are they going to make of me in Houston?"
Hey, anyone who can handle Harvey Weinstein and the Queen can handle Houston.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
The Chicken, the Egg and the Reign of Gasoline

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONCE upon a time, just after the Persian Gulf war and the oil-price spike it caused, the government came up with yet another plan to reduce American dependence on imported oil.
The big idea was to promote alternative fuels for vehicles. The plan Congress passed in 1992 was intended, by the far-off year of 2000, to replace 10 percent of the gasoline and diesel fuel used by cars, pickups, vans and sport utility vehicles with something not made from oil. By 2010, it was supposed to replace 30 percent. 
 So far, it has been a fairy tale. There are indeed about one million cars and light trucks on the road equipped to run on natural gas, ethanol, methanol, propane or some other substitute, but hardly any of them ever do. The country has made only about an eyedropper-full of progress for each gallon of gasoline or diesel burned.
Many advocates of alternative fuel blame the car companies. Car companies blame the Energy Department. The Energy Department blames Congress. And everybody, by and large, still uses gasoline.
Officials at the Energy Department say they have tried hard to make the 1992 program work, but that they were hobbled from the start by weaknesses in the plan, contained in the Energy Policy Act. "It's like going after a grizzly bear with a fly swatter," said one Energy Department official, who asked not to be further identified.
Nobody ever thought it would be easy. The authors of the plan recognized the obvious, that no one would buy a nongasoline car until its fuel was available at filling stations all over the country, and that no one would build the filling stations until there were cars to use the fuel. They tried to solve the chicken-and-egg problem by tapping the buying power of large public and private vehicle fleets.
The law, passed by a Democratic Congress and signed by President George Bush, required two categories of fleet owners -- the federal and state governments, and companies that sell electricity and natural gas -- to include a certain share of alternative-fuel vehicles among their new purchases. The figure for the federal government this year is 75 percent.
But the law contained a crucial compromise. It called for vehicles that could use alternative fuels, not those that must use them, to spare fleet owners any danger of being held hostage by fuel suppliers.
Today, some 30 light-duty vehicle models -- sedans, station wagons, mini-vans, pickups and sport utility vehicles -- are built to run solely on some alternative fuel, usually natural gas or propane. But "sales are still stuck in the basement," said the Energy Department official, accounting for fewer than 1 of every 1,000 light vehicles sold.
A second, more successful provision called for stretching gasoline supplies by adding filler chemicals to ordinary gasoline, like Hamburger Helper to ground beef. But the most popular, known as M.T.B.E., proved to be a threat to groundwater supplies, and the Clinton administration now wants to ban it.
Other parts of the law worked better; for example, energy use per square foot in federal buildings has been cut by more than 20 percent. But that saves coal and natural gas, not gasoline. The effort to diversify transportation fuel has had some success in heavy vehicles like trucks and buses, but not in the light vehicles that use most of the fuel.
One giant hurdle is retail availability. Of the 145,000 gas stations in the United States, only about 50 sell fuel that is more than 10 percent ethanol. None are in Washington, so parked in the garage beneath the Energy Department headquarters are three ethanol-ready cars that have never seen any fuel but unleaded regular. (The federal government is helping to open an ethanol pump at a station near the Pentagon in Arlington, Va.)
About 1,300 places have compressed natural gas, but most are bus depots, United Parcel Service hubs or the like. Only a few dozen are ordinary service stations. That creates a special problem, because natural-gas vehicles typically go only about half as far on a tankful as gasoline vehicles do.
Some fuel companies tried to help; in the early 1990's, Amoco added natural gas at 37 of its service stations, at a cost of more than $250,000 apiece. But sales were so slow -- the equivalent of 20 gallons of gasoline a day -- that the company gave up.
THE authors of the Energy Policy Act hoped that fleets would get the ball rolling, and that high gasoline prices would lead to demand for alternative fuels. But they were wrong, partly because for years the price of gasoline did not cooperate. Natural gas and ethanol are roughly competitive with what gasoline was selling for last year, and are notably cheaper than gasoline today. But expectations are paramount, and most car shoppers today do not believe that gas will remain expensive for very long.
"The increased use of alternative fuels very much depends on the price of gasoline," said Dan W. Reicher, assistant secretary of energy for efficiency and renewable energy. "At least today, ethanol is a very competitive fuel." With a tax subsidy already in place, he added, suppliers "can make money at a price point somewhat below the current price of gasoline."
Except perhaps for electric cars, the technology needed for the vehicles is mostly in place. "We've proven they work," said Bill Webster, director of fleet management at the General Services Administration, which buys much of the government's car fleet, including 27,000 alternative-fuel vehicles. "The problem is, you have to have an infrastructure."
Another problem is that Congress gave the Energy Department authority to require local governments and big corporations to buy alternative-fuel vehicles too, but the department has not done so.
"It was optional," said Lisa Cutler, a spokeswoman for the department. "We only had to do it if it was critical to meet Epact goals," she added, using a shorthand name for the law.
And builders of alternative-fuel vehicles say one reason so few are on the road is that many government agencies that are required to buy them simply do not.
"It's really a challenge," said Art Garner, a spokesman for Honda, who said his company had spent millions of dollars to develop a natural-gas-powered Civic that California says is the cleanest internal combustion car made. "The letter of the law is not pursued very stringently," he said. "Nobody's complied with it." And Ford Motor, which makes the most natural-gas-powered cars, said sales were nowhere near what they would be if everyone were complying. Mr. Reicher said that the shortfall was only about 500 cars and that the Energy Department had written letters to noncompliers.
As for the public at large, voluntarily buying an alternative-fuel car hardly makes sense on economic grounds. Natural gas has been selling for the equivalent of 75 cents or so a gallon, according to Gilbert P. Sperling of the Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition -- attractive today but less so when gasoline goes for $1 or $1.10. For a typical household car or van, he said, "you're paying $5,000 more for a vehicle that uses only 500 gallons a year." For buses that use thousands of gallons a year, he said, switching is a "no brainer," but for light-duty vehicles, "we're not seeing much activity."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Thinking Defensively As the Bears Thrash

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
AFTER soaring 86 percent last year, the Nasdaq composite has plunged by one-third in just five weeks -- a bear market by any definition but one that some people say is nearing its end. After all, much of the technology on which investors are betting when they buy popular Nasdaq stocks seems to also have the effect of shortening market cycles, allowing excesses to be wrung out in days or weeks instead of months or years.
That is the optimistic view. Other people contend that this remains treacherous territory and that things could get considerably worse. One of them is Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist for J. P. Morgan. He took time Friday morning to discuss Nasdaq valuations and some alternative areas for stock investment. Following are excerpts from that conversation: 

Q. A lot people think we are close to a bottom in the Nasdaq, but you don't agree. Why?
 
A. Even at 3,500 or so we're still almost 1,000 points above where we were in mid-October. The stocks are at extraordinarily high levels. The Nasdaq's probably trading -- even if we're very generous and say tech earnings can grow 25 percent a year -- at a price-to-earnings-growth ratio between 6 and 7. Some companies warrant that, but does tech as a whole? The answer is an unambiguous no.
Our rough-and-ready approach is that at the 3,000 level we would think of going back to a neutral on technology, and in the 2.000-to-3,000 range, that's what we'd consider a really true new buying opportunity.
 
Q. So you can say you saw this downdraft coming?
 
A. We were early. But it was inevitable. Looking back to the 1970's, there have been only two years when the Nasdaq, if it got very far away from its 200-day moving average, didn't have a pullback. In the summer of '98, the moving average broke and brought the Nasdaq back to its trend.
 
Q. With the latest inflation report, more interest-rate increases seem likely. Do you agree with those who minimize the effect of higher rates on technology companies?
 
A. No. Tech is very vulnerable to higher interest rates for three reasons. Capital spending of most companies buying high-tech equipment is now significantly higher than their cash flow, meaning they have to borrow. Investors who buy tech stocks have been using debt; not just buying on margin but maybe instead of taking money out of the market to buy that new sport utility vehicle they get a home-equity loan. And a higher risk-free return, such as on Treasury bonds, leads to a lower fair value for stock prices.
 
Q. Are there any technology stocks you like now?
 
A. We're quite defensive. The only grouping we recommend investors be overweighted in is information technology services and computer services. Two companies that are very strong and have very reasonable valuations are I.B.M. and Computer Sciences.
 
Q. Would you say that the market generally has been, or will be, gravitating toward what you might call brand-name technology and away from junk technology?
 
A. I'd call this conservative, reliable tech rather than high-stakes tech.
 
Q. You have a 50 percent allocation to stocks -- and 25 percent each to bonds and cash -- so where does this money go?
 
A. What we've been doing is recommending that investors increase their exposure to consumer staples such as foods, pharmaceuticals, household products and beverages -- groups that have been generally out of favor since '97.
 
Q. Are people taking this advice -- to turn to these traditional favorites that have lagged so badly?
 
A. There's been a fair amount of skepticism because, except for the drugs, these companies have been delivering disappointing earnings. But we think that this stemmed from four factors, all of which have reversed or are in the process.
Revived consumer spending in other parts of the world should be kicking in just about now. Second, a shift from a very strong dollar to a flat-to-weaker dollar. Third, we're starting to see improved pricing for these companies, a modest 2 to 4 percent, but the trend is up, not down. Finally, consumer staples lag when corporate earnings are accelerating and we think they're right at the peak now. The next four to six quarters will give you weaker year-over-year growth. That's exactly when you want to own pharmaceuticals and consumer staples.
 
Q. Which specific companies do you favor?
 
A. We like Bristol-Myers and Schering-Plough. In household products we like Procter & Gamble; if you liked it at 100 you've got to love it at 65 -- and we do. In food and beverages we like General Mills and PepsiCo.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

TICKER: JPM (NYSE) (91%);

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM;
Yes, They Buy No Bananas, Is La Marqueta's Lament

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Louis, King of Bananas, stands behind a row of familiar and yet unfamiliar fruit. Those roughly oblong objects with barklike skin are malanga, he says, and those other oblong items that look like turnips are gautia, from Puerto Rico.
The king, whose real name is Louis Santana, explains that these foods should be boiled in soup, or cut up and fried. He also sells thick, spotted plantains from Puerto Rico, evergreen-colored pumpkins from Costa Rica and, of course, bananas. 
 But Mr. Santana hasn't made a significant sale in weeks. His stall in La Marqueta, the once-bustling hub of market life in East Harlem, has few visitors these days. He remembers when the market was so full of vendors, about 400 at its peak, that it could take the whole afternoon to push through the entire complex.
Back then, the market's five indoor buildings, which stretch from 111th to 116th Streets on Park Avenue underneath the Metro-North viaduct, were humming. But now only one building, at 115th Street, is still open. Yesterday, Mr. Santana lamented, he earned just $12. One day last week, he made $3.50.
"There's more business in a cemetery than there is here," he said.
The city's Economic Development Corporation hopes to change that. By June 1, Best Farms Produce, a company that has run a successful business at the Essex Street Market downtown, will take over about a third of the 115th Street portion of La Marqueta, said Bruce Brodoff, a spokesman for the Economic Development Corporation. As a result, for the first time in years, the 115th Street part of the market will be fully occupied.
Last week, the city also hired a new manager for La Marqueta to improve marketing. The first in a series of holiday promotional events will take place on Mother's Day, May 14. There will also be several musical events, arts and crafts shows and exhibits in the coming months.
"We anticipate that there will be a significant increase in the number of shoppers," Mr. Brodoff said.
The East Harlem Chamber of Commerce is also working on plans to reinvigorate the market. Henry Calderon, president of the chamber, said that instead of focusing on products that can be purchased elsewhere in East Harlem, the market should be revamped as something unusual, like a tourist shopping area.
"Its time has passed," he said. "The pushcart vendors were put there under Mayor La Guardia. You cannot go back to what it used to be."
Meanwhile Mr. Santana, who started working in the stalls when he was 8, remembers the early boom years. He also recalls the decline of the market in the 1970's as merchants on Lexington Avenue began to draw business away, and he watched as the city tried to renovate and revive the market in 1996.
As change looms for La Marqueta again, Mr. Santana is a little wary.
"They come to the market from time to time and promise everything," he said. "But they never do anything." NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: Your Ad Here

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
NEW YORK is disappearing.
Landmarks and lampposts, windows and rooftops, even the pavement. All disappearing. 
 The city is disappearing under a blanket of advertising that has usurped almost every surface, turning what were once public realms -- sidewalks, skylines and streetscapes -- into private marketing arenas where dot-coms, clothing chains, liquor companies, television networks and other businesses wage a larger-than-lifesize battle for New Yorkers' attention and money.
"The visual character of the city is being transformed, and there's a sense that no one is in control," said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, a civic organization that began its fight against billboards with a lawsuit that forced their removal from Bryant Park.
In 1904.
New York has never been a pristinely commercial-free environment. Much of its manic, marvelous jolt comes from the kinetic creativity of promotion, from the tension between aesthetes and hucksters.
Just think of the dazzling signs of Times Square, as the critic G. K. Chesterton did in 1922. "What a glorious garden of wonder this would be," he said, "to any one who was lucky enough to be unable to read."
Today, however, the garden has escaped its borders. Apart from churches and synagogues -- and the newly restored pedestrian ramps at Grand Central Terminal -- there are few places of public assembly still untouched by the iconography of spending and consuming.
And the impending completion of 4 Times Square, with 4,900-square-foot ad panels almost 800 feet in the sky, promises that a sign posted at 42nd Street will soon be visible in New Jersey.
"People are kind of open to this intense signage," said Raymond Gastil, executive director of the Van Alen Institute in New York, which concerns itself with public design. "The cat's out of the bag. You can't just keep it in Times Square as a special signage zoo."
"A lot of architects look to signage as a new opportunity for communication," he added. "It's 'Blade Runner Comes Alive.' And maybe that's not so bad. At least in visuals."
But there are stirrings of protest as neighborhood after neighborhood falls to the advertising juggernaut.
As recently as 1994, there was not a single printed "grand format" advertising mural in New York, according to Unidigital, a media company that has since covered many walls in the city. Today, as more and more buildings, windows and all, are draped in stupendous vinyl panels, marketing may be said quite literally to frame New Yorkers' lives.
"When I first saw someone looking out the window of an ad, it struck me as a tremendous metaphor for the goal of branding: to become the infrastructure, to create a lifestyle that we can live inside," Naomi Klein said. Ms. Klein is the author of "No Logo: Taking Aim at the Brand Bullies" (Picador USA, 1999), which examines global marketing campaigns and the backlash against them.
Old-fashioned signs had to be painstakingly painted in a kind of color-by-number method. Computer technology permits the quick reproduction of photographic images at gigantic scale and with astonishing clarity, making it as easy to alter a New York City vista as to place an ad in a magazine.
New York is by no means alone under the blanket. Apple Computer has even managed to hang "Think Different" banners, featuring Pablo Picasso and Gustave Eiffel, on the facade of the Louvre.
But the effect of hypercommercialization feels particularly jangling in a city that does not want for stimuli. Colossal body forms and vast logos seem to diminish and trivialize the architecture around them.
How can even the most ornate Corinthian colonnade hope to compete for attention with an equally large bare torso? Or with sidewalk scaffolds, construction barricades, telephone booths, awnings, subway entrances, bus-stop shelters, vending boxes and hot-dog stands ablaze with advertising?
Illuminated trailer-truck billboards and taxis with neon rooftop signs jostle for space with sightseeing and commuter buses that have been turned into ads from headlight to taillight, and across all the windows in between.
City lampposts recently sported banners for Philips light bulbs and HBO under the veneer of public service announcements for the Times Square New Year's Eve celebration and for a free boxing clinic for youths.
Under foot and all around town, the Gap and other stores have commandeered sidewalks at night, beaming advertising from lamps onto the concrete. Overhead, HBO projects promotional slides onto the blank walls of 2 Columbus Circle.
Sign makers have their eyes on even more territory. At a forum on Wednesday sponsored by the Municipal Art Society, Tama Starr, the president of the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation, said, "Rationality demands that 34th Street be opened up to signs to reflect its character as a retail and transactional environment."
Sail into Manhattan across the Hudson and you are greeted by "Parmalat." The milk and food company has taken over the side of a warehouse in the West 20's.
Though each single instance may be dismissed -- or excused -- as ephemeral, the collective impression of a hundred fleeting glimpses is that life in New York is now one ceaseless, unrelenting branding campaign. And it is worth wondering, when everyone is shouting, whether anyone can be heard.
"It has changed a city of neighborhoods into just a drive-through advertising extravaganza," said State Senator Thomas K. Duane, a Democrat who represents some of the areas most conspicuously transformed by the barrage: SoHo, TriBeCa, the Flatiron and Ladies' Mile districts (around Union Square, Madison Square and the West 20's).
"New York is already noisy and it can be smelly," Mr. Duane said, "and now there's no way even to rest your eyes."
 
A Municipal Superego To Police the Supersigns
To judge from appearances, city officials have been less vigilant policing supersigns than they have been in trying to curb other forms of expression like provocative museum exhibitions, political gatherings on the City Hall steps and ads that poke fun at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
But the administration has taken some measures. The Landmarks Preservation Commission and the Buildings Department have prevented, removed or contested numerous signs that were oversized, inappropriate or simply illegal.
And the City Planning Department will be offering its own signage rules "imminently," said Jennifer Chait, a spokeswoman, without elaborating on exactly when that might be. The rules would limit the size, height and illumination of signs in manufacturing districts, which are liberally regulated under 39-year-old zoning rules that were written before industrial areas like SoHo and TriBeCa became residential.
The new rules would not affect existing legal signs, Ms. Chait said. But, she added, "The city does intend to increase enforcement."
Mr. Barwick of the Municipal Art Society wonders just how effective any regulation can be that is drafted in the coming months. "We're in an election year," he said. "Who wants to offend giant media companies?"
And what politician would want to deprive landlords of what almost amounts to found money? Depending on the size of a wall, its orientation and location, a mural sign in Manhattan might yield $5,000 to more than $100,000 monthly.
Since the penalty for an illegal sign is not likely to exceed $1,000, it has little deterrent effect. Even when the laws are enforced, advertising companies and landlords can simply accept the fines as a cost of doing business.
 
One Viewer's Excess Is Another's Urban Delight
Regulatory efforts hit another stumbling block: what constitutes excess is a matter of taste.
At one moment, community groups are battling the illuminated Travelers umbrella logo at 388 Greenwich Street. Then they are rallying to preserve the Guardian Life sign atop the former insurance company headquarters on Union Square.
The truth is that the cityscape that New Yorkers revere as most authentic and therefore inviolable is most likely the one that they first encountered.
Anyone who arrived between between the mid-60's and early 90's may nostalgically recall the streamlined Pan Am logo atop 200 Park Avenue, though an earlier generation saw it as a glaring assault on the understated avenue.
Similarly, the newcomer whose plane landed yesterday knows a New York with a Travelers umbrella on its skyline and a 120-foot Nasdaq sign at 4 Times Square, developed by the Durst Organization and designed by Fox & Fowle, that has turned a patch of the building's skin into an animated, ever-changing ad.
In any case, excess is a more genuine New York trait than restraint ever was.
"It's never been a city of half measures," said Don Allman, the president of TDI, one of half a dozen media companies that have been transforming the look of cities around the world.
TDI and Infinity Outdoor (formerly Outdoor Systems), another leader in the field, are wholly owned divisions of the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, in which the CBS Corporation holds a controlling interest.
In a promotional brochure, TDI offers advertisers the chance to "consistently hammer home your message on as many fronts as possible" in the "least expected and most impactful places." Under its "station domination" plan, a single company can take over a municipal hub with banners, posters, floor decals and displays.
In February, The New York Times dominated the Port Authority Bus Terminal. American Airlines has taken over the World Trade Center concourse, and Cablevision has permeated Pennsylvania Station.
"New Yorkers believe that if they're going to do anything, they're going to do it bigger, louder and arguably better than anywhere else in the world," Mr. Allman said.
 
Mural, Mural on the Wall, Who's the Biggest of Them All?
The most transfiguring medium at the moment is the wall mural, which began appearing in the mid-90's. Generated by computer onto flexible vinyl panels, it is limited in size only by the building on which it is slathered; sometimes, with a bit of extra framework, not even by that.
"These large graphics have the powerful visual impact advertisers desire and have even had the effect of transforming the urban landscape of some larger cities," wrote William E. Dye, the chairman and chief executive of Unidigital, in the company's 1998 annual report.
The speed of the process makes it possible for clothing chains like the Gap to change messages with the season, if not more frequently, something that was practically impossible with handpainted signs.
As a result, pouty waifs with heads as large as newsstands and limbs the size of tree trunks peer impassively at New Yorkers all over town. The landmark former Knickerbocker Hotel at Broadway and 42nd Street has turned into a virtual copper-topped kiosk for an ever-changing array of Gap fashion.
"The Attack of the 50-Foot Woman" is the name given to this phenomenon by Ronald J. Kopnicki and Christabel Gough, writing in Village Views, an architectural preservation magazine. They calculated that some figures on wall murals rival the Colossus of Rhodes, which rose 70 cubits (at least 105 feet).
Even the colossus didn't have apartments inside. A five-story-high model for Dockers trousers recently loomed over the intersection of Lafayette and Prince Streets, with a window in his face, another in his chest and another in his groin.
Some windows are not even accorded that much dignity. Two dozen of them in a building at Lafayette and Houston Streets have been obscured lately by ads for ABC and Monster.com. "There's something deeply wrong when banners are put up over the windows of apartment houses and factories," Mr. Barwick said.
But the case of the Alwyn Court, a landmark apartment building at Seventh Avenue and 58th Street, is a reminder that matters are not always so clear cut. For three months, a six-story mesh banner for FamilyWonder.com hung from construction scaffolding around the building, obscuring views of its sumptuous architecture.
For the co-op, income from the sign is a vital subsidy in a $4 million renovation, which may make it financially feasible to clean the sculptural terra-cotta facade or restore a long-lost cornice.
"We're not doing this just to make money," said David Hering, a member of the board. "It's specifically targeted to restore the building."
As for life behind the sign, he said it was not too bad. "It gives the effect from the inside that it's foggy all the time," Mr. Hering said. "It's like San Francisco."
 
Looking at Blank Walls And Seeing Dollar Signs
The FamilyWonder.com sign exemplifies another trend. Internet-related spending for outdoor advertising increased to $101 million nationwide last year from $13 million in 1998, according to the Outdoor Advertising Association of America, a trade group in Washington. All told, $4.8 billion was spent on outdoor advertising in 1999, the group said, an increase of 9 percent over 1998. Of that total, $250 million was spent in New York City.
New Yorkers might be forgiven for thinking that $249 million of that was spent in and around Houston Street, ground zero in the billboard battles, where some signs are untamed, while others in landmark districts fall under the close scrutiny of the landmarks commission.
"As the economy picked up, the value of buildings as billboards exploded," said Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the commission. "When every blank wall is a potential dollar sign, the pressure on us is extraordinary."
Historical precedent suggested that some signs were not only permissible in the SoHo Historic District, but in keeping with its character, she said.
So rather than ban signs outright, the commission requires that they be painted on the walls, not printed on vinyl or mesh. Signs cannot cover more than one-third of a facade nor surround or obscure windows. And the commission prefers typographic and monochromatic design to enormous garish images.
The commission has drawn other lines, too.
It rejected a History Channel sign above "The Wall," a 1973 mural sculpture by Forrest Myers at 599 Broadway, overlooking Houston Street. It vetoed an Emporio Armani sign on a 181-year-old house at Spring and Wooster Streets because private dwellings did not historically carry signage.
It turned down a rooftop sign in the South Street Seaport Historic District and a plan to cover the Paramount Building in Times Square with a network of lights and signs. And it is unlikely to approve a 32-by-80-foot banner for Forbes.com at 921 Broadway, near the Flatiron Building.
"Every photo you'd take of the Flatiron Building would have this enormous blue statement for Forbes.com," Ms. Raab said.
For its part, the Buildings Department has moved against a rap album billboard at 210 West 125th Street that used a thinly disguised obscenity; a banner for The Wall Street Journal that greeted drivers on the Queensboro Bridge; and a recumbent 85-foot-long Dockers boy at Houston Street and the Bowery, among others. In each case, the action was taken because the signs were installed without permits. "We do not regulate content," said Paul Wein, a spokesman for the agency.
Another Dockers boy, at Lafayette and Bleecker Streets, was defaced last year by vandals, who splattered his heart with blood-red paint. "Our city is not the pages of a magazine," the attackers said through an anonymous spokesman. "Advertisers are decimating the city's landscape."
Small though they may be, there are indications that the consumerist landscape is facing growing resistance from groups like the Billboard Liberation Front in San Francisco and the Adbusters Media Foundation in Vancouver, British Columbia.
"The industry calls it freedom of speech," Mr. Kopnicki and Ms. Gough wrote in Village Views, "while people ask, why is there no right to freedom from advertising?"
Still, Ms. Klein, a Toronto journalist whose book "No Logo" has done much to bring the anticonsumerist movement to wider attention, wonders just how much can or should be done to tame the branding of New York.
"It's so complicated here," she said on a recent visit, standing under a polymorphous aqua-colored Yahoo! sign at Houston and Mulberry Streets that would have been at home outside a 1950's motel. "Part of what people love about New York is the spectacle of over-the-top commercialism."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
In China Pact, Executives Sense a Hornet's Nest

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
NEARLY 100 chief executives applauded mildly when Gene Sperling, the White House economic adviser, finished his pitch for the China trade agreement. Mr. Sperling had been preaching to the choir: no one wants Congress to ratify the agreement more than the nation's top business executives. But their first question to him afterward revealed a concern that, in backing the trade bill, they are stepping on a hornet's nest.
They wanted to know what John L. Sweeney, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., would have told them if he, rather than Mr. Sperling, had addressed this gathering of the National Association of Manufacturers in Miami last weekend. Labor unions oppose the bill, which would upgrade China's trade status and open it to more American exports. 
 "I think Mr. Sweeney's general view would be that China is a country that puts labor organizers in jail, and we don't want to do business with a country that does that," Mr. Sperling replied.
No problem so far -- the chief executives agree that labor rights are violated in China, as are civil rights and environmental protections. But while unions and environmentalists want rules written into the agreement, corporate America argues that open trade will force reform.
Maybe. If that were the only issue, Congress would probably approve the trade agreement when it comes up for a vote in the week of May 22. But it is not the only issue. What Mr. Sperling said next, trying to explain Mr. Sweeney, is the hornet's nest for a growing number of chief executives.
"In a dynamic economy like ours, there are dislocations, and even with 4.1 percent unemployment a lot of people are hurt by job loss," Mr. Sperling said. "Trade and globalization have become the whipping boys for these issues, whether they are related or not."
The demonstrations in Seattle last November, at a World Trade Organization meeting, and those scheduled for Washington this week, at a meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, focus attention on this pain. Globalization has made America more prosperous, a point corporate lobbyists for the China bill never tire of making. But public sentiment appears to be building against an open global marketplace that fails to protect labor, civil rights and the environment, and some chief executives are acknowledging that this sentiment cannot be ignored.
"They are fearful of an antibusiness attitude, and they are trying to avoid it," said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG, a polling organization that often surveys corporate thinking. "They are trying to be on the right side of this issue. And the irony is that, in a booming economy, you can still get people worked up about globalization."
An incipient reaching-out was evident in interviews with chief executives at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, in January, not long after Seattle. Leaders of the demonstrations took part in the Davos discussions. So did Lewis B. Campbell, chairman of Textron.
"In my dealings with unions over many years," he said, "I have found that when you discard out of hand their views, you are making a mistake."
Mr. Campbell proposed gathering representatives of business, academia, unions and environmentalists into a new forum to debate trade policy. "If this institution were inclusive of all global interests, and everyone had a fair voice, there would not be a need to demonstrate," he said, adding that the World Trade Organization would have to consider the institution's recommendations.
THE manufacturing executives in Miami reflected this thinking, or at least some did. "We have to get out the view -- perhaps through a forum that includes all sides -- that yes, there are issues with trade, but over all the economy has benefited," said James H. Keyes, chairman of Johnson Controls and of the manufacturers' association. "Free trade has created jobs, and has also cost jobs, but the jobs gained get buried under the publicity given to the jobs lost."
So compromise is afoot. Is that bad? Would the prosperity that has come with increasingly open borders be damaged if trade agreements included standards for civil rights, labor and the environment?
No. Standards -- the normal rules of a democracy -- have not been obstacles to trade. The real danger is in fighting too hard against standards, only to have free trade deteriorate, said Dani Rodrik, a Harvard economist. "Anti-dumping duties would reappear, Europe turns in on itself, China gives up on the World Trade Organization."
That is what America's executives are beginning to recognize. Or as Mr. Rodrik put it: "Companies may be learning that they are better off with moderate rules than with constant harassment."

HEADLINE: The World;
Living in the Past: Cuba Si, Korea No

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT 40 years of cold war and its aftermath, Fidel Castro has cast himself as the man who really understands the world, the intellectual scold of the rich and powerful, the nemesis of the world's last superpower. And there he was again last week, preaching to the world's rich nations about their obligations to the world's poorest nations.
Just north of here on the other side of the world, in North Korea, was a regime often seen as perhaps the most intransigent, introverted and unpredictable -- in other words, least worldly-wise -- on the planet. 
 But judging by events of last week, it is the North Koreans who seem to have come first to a reluctant understanding of how the world really works these days: That what a desperately impoverished Communist outpost sitting next to a capitalist hotshot needs most is not an enemy to rail against but a partner to join futures with.
Consider how different that view is from the one Mr. Castro offered at a summit meeting of the world's poor nations in Havana, in the kind of speech he has been giving almost throughout living memory. He said the world was in need of a "Nuremberg to put on trial the economic order that they have imposed on us."
What was wrong with that picture, of course, is what has been missing from Cuba's foreign relations now for five decades: normal diplomatic and economic ties with the United States. Without them, history since the Soviet collapse strongly suggests that no number of visits from heads of state will make a moldering Cuba thrive.
Coincidentally, North Korea was also contemplating a summit meeting -- this one in June. It is to be the first ever between leaders of the two Koreas. In these two summit meetings are critical lessons about how to unravel the final, knotty strands of the cold war -- lessons that North Korea seems to have absorbed first.
By announcing that its reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il, will begin dealing directly and at the presidential level with South Korea, Pyongyang may have finally figured out how to come in from the cold. Although caution is still very much in order, diplomats and political analysts here say North Korea may be signaling a historic shift in its strategy by deciding that South Korea's greatest value is as an awkward partner rather than an unredeemable foil.
For Cuba, an analogous development would be to see Mr. Castro finally come to terms with an American president -- Bill Clinton is his ninth -- perhaps after concluding that without the United States, no conceivable amount of Canadian mining or tourism investment will suffice to re-energize his country's economy and prospects.
Of course Mr. Castro cannot be blamed alone for the yawning political distance between Cuba and United States. Where Cuba is concerned, Washington has simply never had a Kim Dae Jung, the present South Korean leader, who at great political risk conceived and doggedly pursued a policy of engagement with the North.
"Instead of trying to first disarm the North, as Washington has so adamantly tried but failed to do, Kim sent representatives of nongovernmental organizations north with food, clothing and medicine," said Kenneth C. Quinones, a former State Department Korea expert who is director of Mercy Corps International's Northeast Asia Project. "Instead of economic isolation, he encouraged businessmen from the South to go North." Several recent administrations, including Mr. Clinton's, have toyed with the idea of "normalizing" relations with Cuba, only to conclude that the calendar of domestic politics made the costs too great.
Those costs were amply illustrated last week by the inability of even President Clinton's attorney general, Janet Reno, to get a quick resolution of the travails of Elian Gonzalez, trapped as he is in a custody battle between a father who wants to keep living in Mr. Castro's Cuba and relatives in Miami who revile Mr. Castro above all else.
Well into his 70's and perhaps with his eye fixed on history, Mr. Castro seems to find little appeal in making concessions to Washington, especially of the democratic kind. "The Koreans have a summit, there is a two-nation policy in China and Vietnam reforms its economy, but none of it matters because of a notion called Cuban exceptionalism," said Anthony P. Maingot, a professor of sociology at Florida International University in Miami. Using the Spanish word for vanity and unreality, he continued: "What we are left with is Fidel and his vanidad, and when you are talking about totalitarian states, personalities count. He simply sees no benefit from change." The next generation of Cuban leaders may well be more pragmatic, with the essential caveat that they deal with Washington, not the conservative, Miami-based exiles.
It is in this light that the announced Korean summit appears most impressive. EXPERTS differ over what brought it about. For some, dollars alone are the answer. Pyongyang itself has described the last couple of years of economic free fall as resembling a near-death experience. As a senior South Korean official said last week, "They have come to realize that we are likely to become their main donors in areas like food and fuel." Moreover, lowering tensions would likely pave the way for the North to attract aid and foreign investment.
Others, however, believe that politics are driving a North Korean regime that is essentially shielded from internal security threats. Now is simply the time, they say, when the diplomatic stars are all aligned, meaning that Seoul, Tokyo and, perhaps more tentatively, Washington, seem ready to do business with Pyongyang.
"We are at a serious moment here, where things could go very, very well," said Leon V. Sigal, a Columbia University expert in international relations. "To say they could still go badly is not news on the Korean peninsula. But we could be seeing fundamental shifts in the political relationships, and this is taking place because Seoul, Tokyo and Washington are moving in the same direction for once."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Had Enough? Do You Feel Poor Yet?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
WHAT are investors in the Invesco Technology fund thinking now? The fund has been up an average of 48 percenta year since 1994. But it is down 32 percent since its high for the year on March 9. Are they feeling poorer? Or is this just a blip and, on balance, they still feel pretty good?
The answers to these questions -- especially after the brutal decline in stocks last week -- say a lot about the stock market's impact on the economy. A lot rides on whether recent market volatility is enough to slow what is known as the wealth effect -- and, therefore, consumer spending -- or whether the market will have to decline a while longer to dampen consumers' profligacy. 
 There is no doubt that there was a lot of market volatility well before the roller-coaster ride of the last several weeks.
Consider the performance of the Nasdaq composite index. In 1997, it moved 1 percent or more, up or down, from the previous day's close on 33 percent of trading days. That was near a record at the time, just below the 34.9 percent of 1974 and well above the 23 percent of 1987.
In 1998, volatility increased, with moves of at least 1 percent on almost half -- 45 percent -- of trading days. In 1999 that figure climbed again, to 58 percent.
So far this year volatility is off the charts. Seventy-five percent of the trading days have ended with moves of 1 percent or more. There have been 23 days with moves of 3 percent or more, already surpassing the previous annual record of 20 in 1999..
But it is not clear that volatility has had much of an impact on consumers.
Rising volatility can be a signal of turning points in the market; indeed, there were steep plunges in the Nasdaq and other major market indexes in 1997 and 1998. Still, the Nasdaq ended up 21.6 percent and 39.6 percent, respectively, in those two years. Last year, it rose an unprecedented 85.6 percent.
And the pace of consumer spending, as measured by personal consumption expenditures, increased each year -- 3.4 percent in 1997, 4.9 percent in 1998 and 5.3 percent in 1999.
Joel Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis, said that "there is a lot of speculation that, other things being equal, volatility will reduce the wealth effect." But, he added, "I am unaware of evidence that confirms or refutes that."
Neil M. Soss, the chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, says that when he looks at a "three-dimensional" view of the stock market this year, he cannot yet reach a conclusion. The Nasdaq has seen record volatility and the Dow Jones industrial average has bounced around a lot. But the Wilshire 5000 Total Market index, which tracks most of the stocks traded in the United States, had been much more stable, at least until last week.
"Should I say 'Nothing much has happened'?" Mr. Soss asked, referring to the Wilshire index. "Or should I say, 'Yes, something has happened; the volatility will make for a more cautious consumer'?" referring to the Nasdaq and the Dow. "I don't think the answer is in yet."
The answer to the question is crucial to the outlook for consumer spending and, therefore, to the pace of economic growth. And that pace will decide how high the Federal Reserve has to raise short-term interest rates in order to slow growth. In five quarter-point moves since last June, the Fed has raised its short-term interest rate target, the federal funds rate, to 6 percent. But the economy is still rocketing ahead.
So if volatility won't help slow down consumers, a deeper swoon of the markets may be necessary. Mr. Prakken said the Wilshire index, which finished the week down 9.7 percent, would have to stay where it is, or fall further, for several quarters before it would have a noticeable impact.
But with the swoon in the market on Thursday and Friday, the volatility and sharp declines might finally get the attention of American consumers. For the year, the Nasdaq is now off 18.4 percent, the Dow 10.4 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index 7.6 percent.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Nicholas S. Battelle;
Standish Small Cap Tax-Sensitive Equity Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
NICHOLAS S. BATTELLE is fond of fly-fishing for lunker bass in Boston Harbor and loves to tour the Berkshires on his motorcycle, a 1998 Triumph Thunderbird with 900 cc under the tank. But ask him where his mind wanders as he frolics amid New England's natural bounty, and he acknowledges: "I think about work."
Henry David Thoreau, Mr. Battelle is not. But as portfolio manager of the $263.3 million Standish Small Cap Tax-Sensitive Equity fund, he has a work ethic that has produced some smart returns. The fund gained 55.6 percent a year, annualized, for the three years through March 31, compared with 35.2 percent for its category of small growth funds, according to Morningstar Inc. 
 As its name suggests, the fund aims to minimize taxes. Its annualized tax-adjusted return, assuming a 39.6 percent tax bracket, is 55.3 percent over the same period -- just three-tenths of a point below its outright return. That compares with a tax gap of 2.4 percentage points for its peer group.
The fund has a minimum investment of $100,000, so interested individuals may want to consult a financial adviser, who can pool clients' assets to help meet the requirement.
In picking stocks, Mr. Battelle said from his office in Boston, "we look for small capitalization, aggressive-growth companies that deliver high-octane growth, focusing on new companies with large future potential." These are mostly companies with market capitalizations of $300 million to $2.5 billion in the areas of technology, business services and technology-related health care.
With such a leaning towards new-economy stocks, it is no surprise that the fund has not escaped the recent Nasdaq sell-off; it fell 8.7 percent from March 10 through Thursday.
But Mr. Battelle, 57, says his methodology is tried and true. "Call it old-fashioned security analysis," he said. "Our stock-picking process is more organic than systematic."
Unlike many other money managers, he does not use computers to screen company financial data. Instead, he works closely with the fund's three analysts in look for companies with annual growth of at least 20 percent -- but not necessarily profit growth. Because two-thirds of the fund's companies are unprofitable, growth can be measured in a variety of other ways. For Internet companies, they consider customer volume and sales growth and evaluate business partnerships.
They talk to management to assess a company's competitive strength -- reviewing its products, product cycles, technology and marketing. Mr. Battelle particularly likes companies that are only beginning to gain market share but whose sales growth is strong.
Any major changes in the portfolio's 70 or so stocks, he said, must be approved by at least two of the four people who work on the fund.
He generally sells a stock when its price jumps 20 to 30 percent higher in a month than the overall market, or when it exceeds 5 percent of the fund's assets. He may also sell when he sees fundamental changes in the company or its industry.
Selling can be tricky, given the fund's emphasis on minimizing taxes. When a stock's price falls at least 20 percent below its initial cost, it is usually though not always sold; the loss can be used to offset gains in other stocks. The fund sold Great Plains Software at $44 a share on Monday, generating one such loss; it had bought the stock on March 1 at an average price of $67.
The fund did not distribute any gains to shareholders in 1996, 1997 or 1998, but Mr. Battelle anticipates some gains this year, as he has sold many stocks he bought at low prices.
DESPITE last week's sell-off, he remains bullish on small stocks. "We've done the correcting, and much of the damage is done," he said. "I feel good about the prospects of small-cap stocks."
Mr. Battelle sees bargains among some biotechnology companies, radio broadcasters and even business-to-business Internet stocks.
Despite the recent slump in its stock price, he likes Gene Logic, a Gaithersburg, Md., company that builds genomics reference databases, which map the human genome.
The company is rapidly signing up subscribers among big drug companies, researchers and health care organizations, he said, calling its market opportunity "open ended."
"Subscriptions are high-octane revenues," he said, "because once they build the database and absorb marketing costs, additional subscriptions are almost pure profit."
He expects the company to break even in 2002. He bought the stock at $56 in January, before the technology sell-off; it now trades at $25.4375, and Mr. Battelle has recently added to his position.
Another favorite is the CoStar Group of Bethesda, Md., which maintains an online database of commercial real estate that is used by brokers and corporate relocation managers. Subscriptions are growing 60 percent a year, Mr. Battelle said, and the company will soon offer online property auctions.
Mr. Battelle bought shares in January 1999 at $18.56; they now trade at $27.375. He expects the company to break even at the end of 2001.
He also likes iGate Capital of Oakdale, Pa., an information technology consultant that once specialized in solving Year 2000 computer problems. It now designs and builds Internet and intranet systems to link company operations, customers and suppliers, he said, and is an incubator for Internet businesses. Describing its market opportunity as "unlimited," Mr. Battelle expects initial public offerings for seven of its nine subsidiaries this year.
He bought the stock in January at $26.34. Despite the market sell-off, the shares trade at $32.50.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Inflation's Toll on Inflated Markets

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
MORE than $2 trillion in investor wealth got vaporized last week. It was the worst week in Nasdaq history, and one of the worst in Wall Street's.
While the stock market's ascent into the stratosphere in recent months had been breathtaking, the speed with which this fortune vanished was nothing short of stupefying. After the government's announcement on Friday that the Consumer Price Index for March showed broad and troubling increases, stocks across the board collapsed. The Dow lost 5.66 percent, while the Nasdaq plummeted 9.67 percent. 
 "The C.P.I. kicked the market when it was down," said Christine A. Callies, chief equity strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Investors had decided that valuations in tech were too inflated and needed to be adjusted. When the report came out, investors decided that the market P/E had to come down, too."
Inflation is growing at a 3.7 percent rate, year over year. Tony Crescenzi, a bond strategist at Miller Tabak, said investors were troubled by higher housing costs -- up 0.4 percent -- and medical costs, which rose 0.5 percent.
"The report could be an anomaly," said James L. Crawford, portfolio manager at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen in New York. "But when you look back over the past year, inflation has been creeping up. Most people wrote that off to oil, but those folks who have been saying inflation is nonexistent have to rethink here."
Looking for a silver lining in these ominous clouds, some investors may hope that the decline in stock prices means that the Federal Reserve will be less aggressive in raising rates in coming months. Not so, said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"There is a long way to go to rein in an economy that is growing 6 percent-plus in the past six months and going full steam ahead in the spring," he said. "Mr. Greenspan cannot afford to take his foot off the brake in this climate."
Though the Nasdaq composite has fallen 34 percent from its March 10 high, the broader Wilshire 5000 index -- which Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, watches as a proxy for the overall market -- is down only 15.4 percent from its peak of March 24. As a result, Mr. Roach said, he expects the Fed to raise rates one-quarter point in May, again in June, again in August -- and possibly more.
Ms. Callies says that while the Nasdaq has been mauled, the broader market will not necessarily follow it into bear-market territory. "The market was never as good as the Nasdaq made it look," she said on Friday, "and today it is not as bad as it looks, either."
Investors looking to hide amid the turmoil should consider old-fashioned value stocks, Ms. Callies said, including shares in metals and paper companies, and energy service and exploration concerns. Mr. Crawford likes consumer companies that have been beaten down, like Gillette and Colgate-Palmolive, and real estate investment trusts.
Inflation frightened investors on Friday, but Mr. Roach said the movement in prices was still modest. A more important shift was in the levels of risk that investors seem willing to take. "Valuation does matter in the stock market," he said. "We're getting down to more reasonable levels in some of the more overvalued pieces of the market. But with the fundamentals of the economy intact and inflation signs minimal, stocks can find a level and hold."
