HEADLINE: Global Storm: Loan Agencies Under Siege

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
As the police built barricades and wrapped razor wire over the gleaming glass front of the World Bank headquarters here, James D. Wolfensohn, the bank's Australian-born president, gathered his staff members this week and told them to "remember to stand tall, because we are way ahead of the protesters."
It was a telling moment of defiance in the battle over who is to blame for the widening economic inequities that thousands of people are arriving in Washington to rail against, and that led the police to shut down the demonstration's headquarters today and arrest about 600 people. 
 "What I find demoralizing is that there is no organization on earth that is doing more for the poor than we do," Mr. Wolfensohn said in a hurt tone this week. "Globalization is not something the World Bank can turn back. It's not something the International Monetary Fund can stop. We can only help people and countries adjust to it, to try to close the gaps."
Mr. Wolfensohn paused and then, referring to the head of the World Trade Organization, the initial target of the protesters' ire in Seattle late last year, he added, "You know, Mike Moore said today that blaming us for civil strife and poverty is like blaming the Red Cross for war."
Perhaps so, but second-guessing generals and doctors is hardly new, even in economic wars. The television videotape on Sunday is likely to focus on the noisiest and most vociferous of the street protesters, who call for closing the bank and the fund, regardless of the impact that may have on lending money to countries that the markets shun or intervening in the next global economic crisis. But they are hardly the only critics taking aim at the half-century-old institutions.
Barely a week goes by in Washington these days without an environmental group criticizing the World Bank's 650-mile-long oil pipeline project in Chad and Cameroon, or a development project on the fringes of Tibet that has been caught up in the politically sensitive question of whether the bank is helping China dilute the proportion of Tibetan people in the area.
Commissions galore are re-examining whether the bank still lends too much to middle-income nations and not enough to the world's poorest. The I.M.F. is still embroiled in battles over whether it did more harm than good when it placed strict budget-balancing and interest rate requirements on nations hit by the Asian contagion. And then there is the World Trade Organization, which is not meeting in Washington but is a target nonetheless.
In Europe and Asia, the W.T.O. is seen as a tool of Washington, forcing countries to ingest hormone-treated beef or allow in American manufacturers. In Washington, it is seen by many on Capitol Hill as a rogue bureaucracy intent on setting labor, environmental and trade rules that override national laws.
"I think one of the common complaints is that many of these organizations don't listen as well as they say they do," said Andrea Durbin, director of international programs for Friends of the Earth, who frequently deals with the institutions. "The Indonesians have a new saying for dealing with the World Bank: they invite us, they inform us, and then they ignore what we have to say."
But it is also clear that the criticism is having some effect. The I.M.F. now publishes far more data about the economic condition of its member countries than ever before. And Mr. Wolfensohn comes to today's meetings brandishing charts showing that big power projects, once 25 percent of the World Bank's lending, now account for just 2 percent and that spending on nutrition, education and "microloans" to small businesses, many run by women in the third world, has skyrocketed.
He talks about new partnerships with the World Wildlife Fund in Brazil. For the first time, the top issue for the Development Committee, the bank's main policy-setting body, is a review of programs to fight AIDS, taking the bank into areas previously handled by the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
But it is also clear that many of these changes do not strike at the core of the bank's operations and that the pressure for far bigger reform is growing. Twice in the last few months Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers has given speeches calling for "a new division of labor between the I.M.F. and the World Bank."
While Mr. Summers hedged his comments to avoid fueling more extreme critics, he is clearly worried that the bank lent far too little money for humanitarian purposes during the Asian crisis, and should get out of some lending that could be handled by the private sector.
A careful reading of Mr. Summers's speeches suggests that he harbors considerable skepticism that the bank's talk of reforms is matched by reality. But in an interview on Thursday, he insisted that "the people who work at the international institutions are as concerned with reducing hunger, disease and poverty around the world as anyone in the streets." And he added: "There may be differences about what kind of economic approaches work best. But it's wrong to suggest that anyone has a monopoly on moral virtue here. What we should be doing is finding the strategies that work in raising living standards for desperately poor people."
In fact, to wander the halls of the bank and the fund this week was to run into people who sounded a bit shellshocked. The bank in particular is heavily staffed with people who, in the words of one of Mr. Wolfensohn's top aides, "10 years ago would have been more likley to be on the outside of the barricades, and then decided they could get more done inside." And naturally there are bureaucratic rivalries between the institutions.
While many of the proposals to reform the bank and the fund appear to be at cross purposes, there is rough agreement that both have strayed from their main missions.
"Everyone wants the bank and the I.M.F. to return to their core competencies," said Nancy Birdsall, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, who participated in a study with the Overseas Development Council. "The question is how to do it."
The I.M.F. should lend to poor countries, she said, but "not for too long, because they get sucked into other issues, from reforming education to bank supervision to designing the medical care system."
"Let's put poverty reduction in the World Bank, and managing crises back in the I.M.F.," she concluded.
But another major study, commissioned by Congress and headed by Alan Meltzer, a Carnegie Mellon professor who until recently called for the elimination of the fund, concluded that the I.M.F. should lend money to countries in distress for no more than 120 days, with perhaps one renewal. Fund officials say that is ridiculous; they would have been pulling money out of Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea before their recoveries had gathered any steam.
"Some of these ideas don't make any sense," said Stanley Fischer, the fund's No. 2 official. "It's fine to say that countries shouldn't rely on the I.M.F., just the way it would be nice if people didn't need to rely on psychiatrists. But sometimes you need some outside help, and it's usually when all the private money is pulling out."
Because the fund's track record has been mixed at best -- not surprising, since countries come to the fund only when they are in dire financial straits -- it has been a ripe target. Moreover, there is little question that some of its policies in recent years made bad situations worse.
Moreover, the fund is at a vulnerable moment. Its longtime chief, Michel Camdessus, just retired, and a bruising battle over the selection of his successor divided its board.
As the new chief, Horst Kohler of Germany, arrived in Washington this week, he was greeted with a vituperative blast by Joseph E. Stiglitz, the former head of President Clinton's council of economic advisers and then chief economist at the World Bank. The protesters on the street, Mr. Stiglitz wrote in the magazine New Republic, will "say the I.M.F.'s economic 'remedies' often make things worse -- turning slowdowns into recessions and recessions into depressions."
"And they'll have a point," he said.
The fund, he added, "undermines the democratic process by imposing policies" in return for its emergency cash. But his main complaint appeared to be that it was not willing to adopt his approach to handling the Asian crisis when he was at the bank.
The I.M.F. and economists have shot back. "When countries arrive at the I.M.F., on a stretcher, this is not the time for cute ideas," Rudiger Dornbusch, an M.I.T. professor and a critic of the fund, wrote in response. "Drastic politics are necessary to avoid hemorrhage, currency collapse and irreparable meltdown."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 16, 2000, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 20 about the proliferation of sexual enhancement drugs in the wake of Viagra, and the resulting competition among firms and inventors, misstated a doctor's involvement in the patent process for prostaglandin E-1, a cream for women. The doctor, Michael Wysor, did not challenge a patent application from a drug company, Vivus. He applied for a patent after Vivus did, but before its patent was granted. Both applicants were granted patents. A letter from the doctor, dated March 10, alerted The Times to the error, and patent research delayed this correction.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Shaping the brave new world of sexual medicine: From left, Jennifer Berman, urologist; Laura Berman, sex therapist; and Irwin Goldstein, urologist.; The organ chamber at the urology lab of Boston University, where rabbit vaginas are tested by researchers. (Photographs by Clang for The New York Times); Sexual Healing: Soon, a variety of remedies for sexual dysfunction -- and ways to enhance sexual performance -- will become available to men and women.
 
Testosterone patch: This device, made by Procter & Gamble, delivers testosterone to the pelvic region. But it's not for men only. Several companies are working on a version for women whose testosterone production and sex drive have decreased after hysterectomies or other sex-organ surgery.
 
Viagra: The Granddaddy of pharmaceutical sex medicine, the little blue pill was introduced to the market in 1998. Its popularity has helped to make its producer, Pfizer, the second-largest drug company in the world.
 
Prostaglandin E-1 cream: To stimulate blood flow to the genital area, Vivus is developing a topical cream for women that contains this ingredient. It is intended to alleviate arousal and orgasm dysfunction and enhance vaginal lubrication.
 
Alprostadil cream: NexMed is working on its own topical cream for women, similar to prostaglandin E-1. It is also developing a topcial therapy for male impotence.
 
Clitoral device: Beyond pills or hormonal creams, one company is taking a nonpharmacological approach to treating women with sexual dysfunction. UroMetrics is developing the Eros Clitoral Therapy Device, a small pump with a cup, about the size of a thimble, that fits over the clitoris. It is designed to stimulate blood flow to the organ, thereby enhancing sensation and lubrication and enabling its user to achieve orgasm more easily.

HEADLINE: American Effort to Isolate Belgrade Falters

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 15

 BODY:
Despite the indictment of President Slobodan Milosevic on war crimes charges and the efforts of Washington to isolate his government, the Western diplomatic quarantine of Yugoslavia has broken down, with every major European country represented here by senior diplomats.
Only the United States has no diplomats here and has no plans to send any as long as Mr. Milosevic remains in power, even though it continues to retain a local staff of about 50 people. 
 Most NATO countries withdrew their diplomats during the war, but have slowly seen the need for some representation in Belgrade, generally regarding Yugoslavia as too important to ignore. But sending new ambassadors is awkward because convention requires a meeting with the head of state, who in this case has been indicted for war crimes.
On the French Embassy here, there is a sign that says, "Embassy of Switzerland, French interest section." The embassy functions with three envoys, who issue visas, provide consular services and also behave quite like diplomats. Similarly, the British, with a senior diplomat who had already served four years here, are formally represented by Brazil, the Germans by Japan.
And both France and Germany have issued limited visas, for European parliamentary meetings, to Yugoslav officials like the former Socialist Party spokesman, Ivica Dacic, who are on the European and American lists of people banned from traveling to the West.
In general, the Europeans want to distinguish between the isolation of the government and Serbian people, who still regard themselves as Western-oriented. The tension between the Clinton administration and the European Union over the efficiency of sanctions and how to bring down Mr. Milosevic surfaces regularly, with many Europeans believing that opening up trade, contacts and travel with Serbia will bring down Mr. Milosevic much faster than isolation, which his government manipulates in its propaganda of a brave Serbia surrounded by enemies.
This winter, for example, the Europeans went ahead with oil and energy aid for Serbian cities controlled by the opposition against strong initial American objections, and the Europeans also forced through the lifting of a ban on air travel to and from Belgrade -- one of the main requests of the democratic opposition here.
Just last week, Australia rebuffed sharp American complaints and sent a new ambassador to Belgrade who presented his credentials to Mr. Milosevic on Thursday, together with the new Russian ambassador, in a ceremony covered lavishly in the state news media here.
Washington and many European capitals are trying to avoid giving Mr. Milosevic that kind of propaganda opportunity, which would let him show that the world is coming to terms with his survival in power.
The Australian foreign minister, Alexander Downer, said Canberra had refused a direct American request, reportedly from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, to drop the appointment, or at least to skip the meeting with Mr. Milosevic and fax the new ambassador's credentials instead.
But the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry has insisted that countries abide by the Vienna conventions governing diplomacy and present credentials to the head of state. The Americans "asked us if we would fax the credentials," Mr. Downer said. "The Yugoslav authorities made it clear they wouldn't accept faxed credentials."
The Greeks and Italians, NATO members with traditionally close historical and business ties to the Serbs, kept embassies open here during the bombing war, as did Canada. The Italians also want to send a new ambassador here, but are trying to negotiate a way to avoid a meeting with the indicted Mr. Milosevic.
But they are expected to have no more success than the Australians did, which will force them to either meet Mr. Milosevic or downgrade their official representation here to a charge d'affaires or deputy chief of mission ad interim, appointments that do not require the presentation of credentials to the head of state.
Diplomats here said they had hoped that the strange tale of the Portuguese ambassador, Antonio Tanger de Correa, would create a model. Portugal is the current president of the European Union, a six-month term that ends with June, and Lisbon asked Belgrade to approve the appointment before the war and Mr. Milosevic's indictment.
Unusually, given his European role, Belgrade agreed to accept his credentials at the level of the first deputy foreign minister. But the government does not invite Mr. Tanger de Correa to receptions or official meetings because his credentials have not been presented to the head of state; it invites the Portuguese deputy chief of mission instead.
"At first we thought there would be a 'Portuguese model,' " one diplomat said. "But we were wrong. The Portuguese ambassador is really treated like a nonentity here, not really like a diplomat at all."
A Yugoslav diplomat said: "We are a real country and not some African colony," stressing that diplomatic conventions require ambassadorial appointments to be accepted by heads of state.
Other governments have avoided the problem by not rotating ambassadors or by bringing in lower-ranking diplomats, effectively downgrading relations. This is what Washington had done even before the NATO bombing war, with the embassy here headed by a senior diplomat, Richard Miles, who had been an ambassador in other countries but had a deputy rank here. Mr. Miles is an ambassador again, now in Bulgaria.
The Czech Republic, which is applying to the European Union, has kept its ambassador here, Ivan Busniak, for about four years. But Prague is unsure if it will rotate him. If he leaves, Prague -- mindful of its Western orientation -- has decided to replace him with a deputy chief of mission ad interim "and wait for better times," the ambassador said.
The Clinton administration denied a report in the Sunday Times of London last week that it would send a low-level diplomat here by June.

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 16 about the faltering United States effort to isolate the government of Yugoslavia referred incorrectly to the status of the Canadian Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air campaign against Yugoslavia last year. It did not remain open during the bombing. The embassy suspended operations on March 23, the day before the campaign began, and reopened in October.

HEADLINE: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

BYLINE: By Anita Gates

 BODY:
No film has ever done more for the self-esteem of middle-aged men without gym memberships than THE FULL MONTY (1997), directed by Peter Cattaneo. Robert Carlyle heads a group of unemployed steelworkers in Sheffield, England, who decide to earn some much-needed money by becoming male strippers. Tom Wilkinson, as the dignified former foreman, is also memorable in this irresistibly endearing comedy - Thursday at 8 p.m. on Channel 5.
 
Some middle-aged men have other hobbies. Even those of us who swear by Adrian Lyne's 1997 remake with Jeremy Irons and Dominique Swain have to admit that Stanley Kubrick's original LOLITA (1962) is a haunting, provocative film. It was no mean feat to film a novel about an aging pedophile and the adolescent girl he worships, not from afar, at a time when an actress wearing a slip on screen was considered risque. James Mason is Humbert Humbert, Shelley Winters is Lolita's emotionally needy mother, and Peter Sellers, as has been noted elsewhere, steals the film as Quilty, Lolita's other admirer. But let's face it, Sue Lyon, 16 at the time, does look much too mature to be Nabokov's nymphet - Sunday at 6 p.m. on TCM.
 A tough Philadelphia cop needs a place to hide from the bad guys, so he moves in with the Amish. Only an actor as sure of himself as Harrison Ford could look as convincing raising a barn in the Pennsylvania sun as he does carrying a gun, and he does both in Peter Weir's physically gorgeous WITNESS (1985). Kelly McGillis is charminga s the young Amish widow who takes a sinful shine to him. And although you can't call it the film's finest scene, there's something particuarly satisfying about the moment when Mr. Ford, disguised as an Amish farmer, has had enough of tourists taunting his pacifist hosts and punches one (tourist) in the nose - Sunday at 2:30 p.m. on TBS.
 As long as we're talking about Harrison Ford, this year's recipient of the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award, look for him in full hero mode in Phillip Noyce's CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER (1994). Mr. Ford plays Tom Clancy's C.I.A. agent hero, Jack Ryan, this time up against Colombian drug lords and with action sequences galore - Tuesday at 9 p.m. on USA.
 Were it not for Diane Keaton, BABY BOOM (1987) might have been sitcomishly silly. But she's outstanding as a single, career-driven Manhattanite who inherits a relative's baby girl and is not pleased - at first. Ms. Keaton's character is forced to restructure her life, which ultimately means packing up and moving to the country. Where the local veterinarian just happens to be tall, handsome, available and Sam Shepard. Ms. Keaton's character finds additional happiness as a devoted mother and big-time mail-order entrepreneur - Sunday at 1 p.m. on TNT.
 You probably thought single moms were an invention of the 20th century. Tell that to Marmee (Spring Byington), who has to do double duty with her houseful of daughters while Mr. March is away. Byington is only one of the joys in Little Women (1933), still the grandest of the three film versions of Louisa May Alcott's novel, set in 1860's New England. And how could it miss, with Katharine Hepburn as the beautifully headstrong Jo? Joan Bennett as Amy and Edna May Oliver as Aunt March as among her co-stars. And who else but George Cukor could have directed? - Saturday at 5 p.m. on TCM.
 - Anita Gates

HEADLINE: Towns Protest Proposed Water Rules

BYLINE: By NICOLE ITANO 

 BODY:
ASET of groundwater protection regulations being proposed by the State Department of Environmental Protection has come under fire from a few central Connecticut towns whose officials believe the rules will cripple their economic growth.
Local officials said the regulations weren't needed because businesses already obey a host of other environmental regulations, but the D.E.P. said current regulations aren't doing enough. With opponents predicting the regulations will make their towns inhospitable to business and environmentalists countering that the rules are needed to protect the state's drinking water, the issue is becoming a classic battle over the proper balance between business and environmental interests. 
 "If mobile pollutants are discharged in these areas, they are going into the wells, they are not going to Nova Scotia," said Supervising Sanitary Engineer Randy May. "What I keep saying to people is would you build a foundry on the banks of a public reservoir? They say of course not."
The regulations date to a 1989 bill that passed the State Legislature unanimously and applies to any aquifer that provides water for at least 1,000 people. The rules would prohibit businesses that use certain hazardous materials from moving onto land above aquifers that supply public wells. The list of businesses that could be affected by the new regulations includes gas stations, dry cleaners, chemical manufacturers and electronic circuit board producers.
Although the new regulations would apply to only 2 percent of the state's land, there are some towns above aquifers that feed public wells that said the rules would hinder development over large portions of their land. Most of the affected areas are concentrated along the Farmington and Quinnipiac River valleys and in a handful of central Connecticut towns.
The elected officials and business owners in these towns are the most vehement opponents to the proposal. Fifty-eight percent of Plainville and 36 percent of Southington will be affected by the rules, and officials there are worried that the effects will be drastic.
"If it was only 2 percent of Plainville, we could handle that," Town Manager Robert Jackson said. "But when you get to 60 percent, that's a major impact. What that means to us is tax dollars. It means that we won't be able to use that land for certain uses."
Mr. Jackson and other opponents of the regulations said they want clean water. They just believe pollution can be prevented through regulation rather than prohibition. A public hearing on the new regulations is scheduled for June 16 at the D.E.P. offices in Hartford.
It is in those areas where the regulations are most controversial that the need for them was most strongly seen a decade ago.
One of the bill's sponsors was Angelo Fusco, a former state representative from Southington who counts the aquifer protection program among his greatest achievements.
"I saw a town's drinking water being devastated by pollution, both past and present, and I wanted it stopped," said Mr. Fusco, a Republican. "My former district had two Superfund sites within five miles of each other, the old Southington land fill and Solvents Recovery Inc. I wanted to make sure that the damage that happened in my small community never would happen again."
The regulation's opponents, many of whom are Mr. Fusco's former colleagues and constituents, argue that times have changed and that businesses take their environmental responsibility seriously.
"The reality of the matter is that these regulations are 20 years behind the time," said Paul Marin, an environmental consultant who has been working with officials and business leaders in Plainville and Southington. "There are a whole host of best management practices that people use today to keep the pollutants out of the environment. And it works. It is working." Mr. Marin added that most of the state's contaminated wells were polluted decades ago, long before anyone recognized the hazards they posed to human health.
State officials and environmental groups counter that even industries that take strong environmental precautions pose a threat to groundwater. They point out that between 1998 and 1999 there were 1,800 to 2,000 in the state reported industrial and commercial spills and that the number of contaminated wells in the state is steadily increasing. The D.E.P. said that between 1989 and 1999, 12 new public wells were polluted severely enough to require treatment. There are 139 such wells in the state.
"This is the most common-sense response to the problem of aquifer pollution," said Daniel Lorimier, a spokesman for the Connecticut Fund for the Environment. "It is certainly much less expense to prevent the pollution than to treat it after it happens. These regulations are long overdue and sorely needed by the state of Connecticut."
The decade-long delay between the passage of authorizing legislation and the public release of the proposed regulations on March 27 is the result of a long debate, both within the D.E.P. and between it and other constituencies, over the best way to protect the state's aquifer water. Agency officials said the current draft represented a long evolution toward a set of regulations that balance environmental and business needs. Opponents said that balance is still skewed.
"There's going to be all kinds of chaos if this goes through as currently thought of," said Roger Klene, president and chief executive of the Mott Corporation, a metallurgical company in Farmington located on one of the biggest aquifers in the state. "The biggest problem here is not for the companies. We're mobile. But the community can't move. It's left holding the bag for the devastation caused by these terrible rules."
Much of the disagreement between the D.E.P. and those who oppose the regulations is rooted in the two side's conflicting predictions about how the department will interpret the rules.
Local officials like Mr. Jackson and business owners like Mr. Klene said they believed the regulations will drive away businesses and restrict the ability of existing businesses to expand and remain competitive. They worry that even though the regulations will allow existing business to expand and make provisions for new businesses that use nonpolluting procedures, the D.E.P.'s permitting process will be so onerous that it will stymie the ability of business to adapt and grow.
"Our experience with the D.E.P. is that the people you talk to when you're talking about a regulation like this all are very reasonable people," Mr. Klene said. "Then when you get into the permitting part, you're dealing with a bureaucrat who doesn't care about how much you have to spend to do what they're asking."
The Department of Economic and Community Development said it was still too early to determine the economic effect of the regulations, but emphasized that they had confidence that the D.E.P. will be able to balance economic and environmental concerns.
D.E.P. officials said Mr. Klene and others misunderstand the regulations and the agency's intentions.
"What dismays me is the lack of fact of some of the opposition," said Arthur J. Rocque Jr., the state commissioner of environmental protection. "They're basing their concerns on early drafts, sometimes drafts as many as two to three years old. Our position is that the way the regulations are drafted, with reasonable precautions against the inadvertent release of hazardous chemicals, virtually any activity can be located in these areas."

HEADLINE: Modern and Tate Team Up For Commercial Web Site

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
In an unusual marriage of the nonprofit museum world and the money-hungry e-commerce industry, the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and the Tate Gallery and its branches in Britain have formed a partnership to create an Internet business for art, culture and design.
Plans for the company include a Web site to sell commissioned design products and to offer such educational programs as live Webcasts of lectures and concerts. It will also carry archival material on art. 
 Profits from the site will help pay the museums' escalating operating expenses. This will be the first time any art museum has used its reputation, expertise and outreach to start a profit-making company.
But the Modern and the Tate are not the first nonprofit institutions to do so. In the last few months several academic centers -- Columbia University, the New York Public Library, the British Library, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History, the London School of Economics and Political Science and Cambridge University Press -- have teamed up to start Fathom.com, a Web site designed to provide specialized information and general knowledge.
To preserve the museums' tax-exempt status as nonprofit institutions, the venture by the Modern and the Tate (as yet unnamed) will be a separate entity with its own staff, board of directors and offices. A chief executive is being sought to run the business from New York.
"This venture is not just two guys dreaming in their garage, but a company built on two institutions' history, stability and knowledge," said Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Modern. "The Internet is a world of strange, overlapping and intersecting interests. We're all exploring how to operate in that world, and there's a scramble for the design and culture dot-com space. Between us we have the engine to found this new company, which will not only have a major presence in the United States but in England and Europe too."
The project comes at a crucial time for both institutions. The Tate is opening the $208 million Tate Gallery of Modern Art in Bankside, just opposite St. Paul's Cathedral in London, next month, while the Modern is embarking on a $650 million expansion.
"We both realized that to have a steady stream of income to ensure a strong future is crucial," Mr. Lowry said. "This company will have long-term value for both of us." Eventually, Mr. Lowry added, the company could go public.
While officials from both museums said it was too early to project how much money they could expect from the company, they expected revenues from advertising, licensing, merchandise sales, pay-per-view for certain types of events and information, as well as syndication of original content.
Mr. Lowry said he and Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, had been discussing ways they could collaborate beyond joint exhibitions when they realized that each was separately investigating the possibility of a profit-making Web site. "We were on parallel tracks," Mr. Lowry said.
Sir Nicholas said: "I don't think one should underestimate what a big move this is for us. For two fiercely independent institutions that hitherto have been competitors to join forces like this takes a huge degree of trust."
Though neither museum would discuss the costs needed to start the company or the profits it expected to earn, a source close to the venture said that the Modern had raised several million dollars. The next stage would involve raising about $50 million from investors.
The company is scheduled to set up its Web site later in the year or early next year.
Both museums have independent Web sites (www.moma.org and
www.tate.org.uk) that they plan to keep. Each museum had more than 5 million visitors last year, and each institution's Web site received an additional 4 million visitors. Together the museums manage retail operations with $50 million in annual sales.
Their joint site would be drastically different from either their Web sites or their stores, both directors said. For starters it would have ads, which the museum Web sites do not have. It would also sell products like furniture, design objects and books exclusive to the site and commissioned by designers and architects from many sources. The items would be more varied than those available on the Modern's current Web site, which offers merchandise mainly from its store on West 53rd Street. While the site would not offer original artworks, it would sell multiple-edition prints or photographs.
Among the educational programs it would offer are customized art tours, virtual-reality tours of collections and exhibitions, archival material, Webcasts of live lectures, concerts and performances from around the world and critical essays. There will also be ticketing for art events and courses.
Mr. Lowry does not see the venture as a conflict of interest to the museums' missions as educational institutions. "We have built in all the appropriate fire walls," Mr. Lowry said. "No trustee or their family and no staff member of either museum can invest in this company should it go public. It will have an independent board. There will also be licensing arrangements to safeguard our interests." Still, the museums intend to control the site's content. Two members from the boards of the museums will sit on the company's board.
In the curatorial world the formation of such a company may be looked down upon by some as being overly commercial, but Mary Lea Bandy, chief curator of film and video at the Modern and its deputy director for curatorial affairs, thinks otherwise: "Museums, like libraries and universities, are filled with curators, professors and scholars who are eager to share their expertise to as many people as possible, which is something a project like this can do. For those of us in film, video, architecture, design or photography -- any art form that exists in multiple forms -- the possibilities are fantastic."

HEADLINE: Fed Expected To Continue Same Course

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
As the markets reopen today, one of the biggest questions weighing on investors' minds is what the Federal Reserve might do. The answer: no change in policy.
Certainly that is the expectation on Wall Street. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has committed the central bank to a series of small interest rate increases until the economy slows and stock markets, in response, calm down. The sell-off Friday does not alter that policy. 
 "Unless there is evidence that the financial markets are under more strain than we have seen so far, there is no reason to believe that the Fed will alter course," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. What is required is evidence of a panic in which lending and borrowing dry up and markets cease to function.
That did not happen Friday. As Albert Wojnilower, an economist at Craig Drill Capital and the Clipper Group, put it, "As long as you were willing to sell at $5 or $10 or $15 down, there were buyers."
Through statements and actions, Mr. Greenspan has locked the Fed into a fairly predictable approach. He has argued that investors' enthusiasm for stocks is largely a rational response to rising productivity and to expectations of rising profits. But even rational markets can get ahead of themselves, and investors' gains from rising stock prices have created more demand for goods and services than the economy can continue to supply. The result is likely to be inflationary pressure.
Or so Mr. Greenspan has argued. As a result, the Fed has raised rates by a quarter of a percentage point on five occasions since last June. In this context, Friday's sell-off can be viewed as part of the change that the rate increases are intended to bring about.
Even after Friday's tumble, the major indexes are still far from reversing the gains of the 1990's. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Wilshire 5000, a very broad stock measure, are now only back to where they were a year ago, Mr. Lipsky noted, and the Nasdaq is still up nearly 34 percent since last spring.
For the Fed to change course now -- either cutting rates or even failing to go up another quarter point at the next Fed policy-making meeting on, on May 16 -- would be a signal to investors that the Fed stands ready to bail them out, Mr. Roach and others on Wall Street argued yesterday. That would cause stock prices to shoot up again, most analysts believe.
"The typical risk taker will say, 'Oh, that is nice, the Fed will bail us out,' " said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street bond firm.
The Fed has supplied relief to offset past panics, which it has defined as moments in which markets seize up. In panics, buyers all but disappear despite plunging stock prices. Lenders also pull back or seek the safe haven of Treasury securities. And markets, in effect, cease to function.
"Borrowers won't borrow, lenders won't lend and investors find themselves unable to buy and sell securities in the desired volumes, regardless of price," Mr. Lipsky said.
That happened on Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 21 percent -- far beyond the 5.66 percent decline on Friday. Reversing course -- then like now, Mr. Greenspan had been trying to slow the economy through interest rate increases -- the Fed cut rates and promised lenders plenty of liquidity to stay afloat if borrowers defaulted.
Mr. Greenspan, appointed Fed chairman only a few months earlier, fashioned that strategy, and he invoked the same rate-cutting policy again in the fall of 1998, after Russia defaulted on its debts and Long Term Capital Management, a hedge fund, almost failed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Stock Sell-Off Causes a Wave of Anxiety
The steep drop last week in the price of technology stocks, punctuating a three-week slide, seems to mark a turning point in perceptions. Unless the technology shares rebound quickly, some experts say, the Internet industry will no longer be seen as a sure thing for investors and entrepreneurs hoping to cash in quickly.
A few bad days are one thing, but with the shares of many leading technology companies down by 40 percent or 50 percent in less than a month, the sell-off is causing anxiety across the New Economy. Page A1.
 
China Economy Surged in Quarter
China's economy showed surprising signs of strength in the first quarter, with gross domestic product rising 8.1 percent, suggesting that a slide in growth rate may be ending. C12. 

Finding Balance for E-Commerce
Alex Stark, a practicioner of feng shui, the ancient Chinese art of harmonious balance, brought his talents to cyberspace last week. He performed a feng shui ceremony at the Web site of Corcoran.com, which sells luxury homes, concluding that the site was not aligned to promote harmony -- or e-commerce. Dissonant elements included misplaced "help" and "dream" buttons. Barbara Corcoran, whose Corcoran Group runs the site, said that she asked her Web designer to retune the site. C4.
 
Rally Supports a Coke Settlement
Former employees of Coca-Cola and activists who want the soft drink company to settle a racial discrimination suit began a five-day bus trip that will end Wednesday at the company's annual shareholder meeting. C2.
 
New Efforts in Journalism Diversity
The Freedom Forum and the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation are underwriting at least $5.5 million of new efforts to increase the number of blacks, Asian-Americans, Native Americans and Latino journalists entering the profession. C2.
 
Canada Press Baron Assails Bishop
Conrad Black, the Canadian press baron, attacked the local bishop in Calgary early this month, writing in The Calgary Herald that the bishop was a Leninist-style "useful idiot," among other things. Calgary's Christian leaders condemned the statement. C21.
 
Parents Dispute a Daughter's Tale
The article "Party's Over" in the April issue of Allure is full of family intrigue, sex and alcohol abuse. In the article, Taylor Stein, a blonde habitue of the Manhattan party circuit, speaks at length about how the childhood neglect she suffered contributed to her alcoholism. But there is one question of ethics raised by the article: the magazine never checked out Ms. Stein's stories with her parents, and in fact points out that it obtained the interview on the condition that it would not do so. Her parents now say the tale is a fabrication. Media. C21.
 
Technology Hurdles to Online Music
The record companies BMG and Sony Music Entertainment recently announced long-awaited plans to sell their music online through digital downloads. But the fine print suggests mainstream Internet users are not going to buy their music digitally any time soon. Despite the promise of digital downloads for the masses, the technical challenges could continue to confine the audience mainly to college students. New Economy. C4.
 
New Approach to 'Affinity Portals'
A fresh spin is emerging on "affinity portals" -- gateways aimed at every slice of the Internet population. Rather than spend millions persuading group members to come to a portal designed for them, companies are working with associations that already cater to such groups to build portals for their members. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C16.
 
Second Careers for 'Seinfeld' Actors
The second bananas of "Seinfeld" are turning up in campaigns for products ranging from cars and candy to soft drinks and prescription drugs. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C26.

HEADLINE: After Weekend Lull, Investors Wait forOther Shoe

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON and LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
Investors large and small looked ahead over the weekend, nervously wondering if the selling that tore through United States stocks last week will resume when the markets reopen this morning.
With markets closed, Wall Street only appeared quiet Saturday and yesterday. But behind the scenes, securities firms and many investors were making preparations for today, which at the least promises to be volatile. Investment bankers said that mergers and initial public offerings are likely to be put on hold until the market settles down. Already, dozens of initial offerings have been canceled or postponed, including one for the AltaVista Internet portal. 
 Big mutual fund companies like Fidelity Investments mobilized employees to handle an expected surge in telephone calls from nervous investors. Money managers found themselves in their offices yesterday, talking to clients and considering whether to take advantage of last week's plunge to buy shares -- or preserve their remaining gains by selling more of their portfolios. In Silicon Valley, home to many of the New Economy stocks that have suffered the biggest declines, investors and technology company employees largely shrugged off their losses as to be expected in their volatile sector.
Indeed, outright panic was hard to find over the weekend, except among the minority of investors who have bought stocks with borrowed money and are facing margin calls, or demands from their brokers that they put more cash into their accounts as collateral.
But if hysteria was scarce, so was optimism about a quick turnaround. Many conservative investors still think that technology stocks are too expensive, and more aggressive investors are reeling from their enormous losses in the last month.
Frederic E. Rowe, a general partner in Greenbrier Partners, a money management firm in Dallas, said from his office yesterday that he was there "licking his wounds." Mr. Rowe, a value-oriented investor, said his conservative posture had helped him on Friday, when his portfolio fell less than the 5.8 percent drop posted by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Still, like many investors, Mr. Rowe said the speed and ferocity of the plunge had left him stunned.
"It happened so fast," he said. Instead of acting abruptly on today, Mr. Rowe said, he planned to "just sit there there and hold my breath."
Mark Rowland, an Atlanta money manager who has avoided buying the new technology names that led the Nasdaq market up last year and are leading it down this month, said that the that market remains expensive, despite its huge decline. "We used to sell dollar bills for $2," Mr. Rowland said. "Now we've cut the price to $1.50. An elevator dropping from the 100th floor to the 50th floor is not the bargain basement."
Like many cautious investors, Mr. Rowland said the Nasdaq sell-off was an important lesson for inexperienced investors whose aggressive bets on technology have been rewarded over the last couple of years. They are finally learning that stocks can drop as well as rise, he said.
"The stock market is an expensive place to go to grad school," Mr. Rowland said. "For the ready-fire-aim crowd, they need to do a little homework."
About the only Wall Street types who were working less than usual this weekend were investment bankers, who suddenly find few buyers for the companies whose shares they underwrite, or sell to the public. Their merger work has also faded, with many corporate executives reluctant to do deals when their share prices are swinging wildly.
Deal makers who would usually be working spent the weekend playing golf, at church services celebrating Palm Sunday, or soothing clients by telephone. But most bankers were saying that the merger pace will not slow dramatically unless the sell-off continues.
"There are certain sectors that will be disrupted but, in general, we are looking to the overall, real economy," Steve Munger, co-head of global mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said. And while the downdraft in Internet stock values has to be dealt with, he added, "it's not like it was unanticipated."
A rapidly declining market can also cause deals that have already been struck to unravel. But few blockbuster deals are pending, and the most notable of this year, January's announced combination of America Online and Time Warner, seems immune to market turmoil. One deal that could hit snags if the stock prices fall further and stay down is MCI/WorldCom's announced acquisition of Sprint, traders said.
Meanwhile, some money-losing Internet companies are already concerned that they may have difficultly lining up new investments, bankers said. Several companies, have called venture capitalists in search of new capital -- including eToys, according to a person close to that company.
Larger companies that do have spare cash are meanwhile deciding whether to buy or invest in the Internet companies whose shares have fallen. But few are likely to rush in today, opting instead to see if prices of Internet companies fall further. Traditional retailers, for instance, have already embarked on plans to build their own Internet sites, and have less need to acquire fledgling Web retailers.

HEADLINE: Strategists in a Strange Land

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Thomas McManus, equity strategist at Bank of America Securities, spent a lot of time on the phone over the weekend talking to clients and some time thumbing through two books from his library: "The Great Crash, 1929" by John Kenneth Galbraith and "Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds," Charles Mackay's 19th-century classic about investment mania.
"I'm looking for an analogous time," Mr. MaManus said yesterday from his home. "The behavior of individual investors at this juncture is a very important thing to consider, and all we have is anecdotal reports and our own conversations with clients." 
 Mr. McManus and other strategists are trying to divine what owners of technology stocks are likely to do today, after a weekend of brooding about the market's decline. But because their behavior is so hard to forecast, those in the predicting business are sticking with the outlooks they held before the market plunged on Thursday and Friday.
The technology rout sent the Nasdaq down 25.3 percent last week, its worst weekly decline. But many technology stocks have plunged much farther. Qualcomm, which makes wireless communications products, has fallen 33 percent the last two and a half weeks. Palm, which makes hand-held personal digital assistants, was down to $31.625 on Friday, off almost 67 percent from its March high.
"Some investors have seen a major portion of their investments vaporize," Mr. McManus said. "What does this cause them to do?"
He expects the low prices of old economy stocks -- the established industrial and consumer products companies -- will draw investors' attention and help offset further declines in technology stocks. And he will advise clients to raise the weighting of stocks in their portfolios to 80 percent from 75 percent. But, he acknowledges, big losses in technology might force some to sell other stocks to cover or offset losses.
Now is not the time to panic, said Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers and a longtime stock market bull.
"We're not gearing up for Armageddon," he said, noting that Lehman would not depart from routine this morning, beginning with a 7:45 meeting on the market's outlook. At 8:45, the firm's risk-management committee plans to hold its regular meeting.
Yet, Mr. Applegate said he did alter his routine on Friday by sending a note to clients as the Nasdaq was heading to a 9.7 percent decline and the Dow Jones industrial average was losing 5.7 percent.
"I told them this is not the end of the bull market," he said.
Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, spent the weekend deciding what he would say at Morgan Stanley's Monday morning strategy session. "Some of us were looking for this for a long time," he said, alluding to his longstanding view that the stock market was just too overvalued.
"I am going to say that the market is much less overvalued than it was, but that I think that technology has further to go and that the overall market has farther to go," he said.
The key to the market's performance today, Mr. Wien said, would be whether last week's drastic plunge had finally "broken the psychology that every dip is a buying opportunity." The sharp declines of the last several years did not accomplish that, he acknowledged, since they were followed by significant recoveries. "But this looks more like the kind of move that could break that psychology." If it does, it will take away a cushion for stocks, he said.
At Merrill Lynch, David Bowers, chief investment strategist, and Richard McCabe, chief market strategist, will join the regular morning meeting of analysts, according to James Wiggins, a spokesman.
Mr. Wiggins added that Merrill would urge its brokers to "remind their clients that the best investment approach is to take a long-term view and to keep their long-term objectives in mind."
"We have been in periods of volatility before," he said, "and this is the approach we take."
Abby Joseph Cohen, chief market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, said on Friday that she was sticking to her modestly bullish outlook. "As we look at our expectations for earnings, economic growth and so on, nothing has changed during the past two weeks," she said in an interview on CNBC. Ms. Cohen's always careful comments will be scrutinized because some investors think that she helped sour the mood in the market.
On March 28, she said she had cut the share of stocks in Goldman's model portfolio to 65 percent from 70 percent. At the same time, she said that technology stocks were "no longer undervalued."
In the CNBC interview, Ms. Cohen said, "We are very comfortable with the mainline technology companies with fabulous product development, revenue and earnings."
Her comfort, apparently, does not include the dot-coms, which had led the market higher and are now threatening to pull it even lower.

HEADLINE: An Appraisal;
From the Guggenheim, a Bold Vision for a Lower Manhattan Museum

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
How many ways can you say "Wow"? In the weeks ahead New Yorkers will certainly find more articulate words to describe Frank O. Gehry's design for a museum that the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation hopes to build along the East River in Lower Manhattan. Silence would be eloquent, too. But only for the repressed. Otherwise, this is the moment to look for noisemakers left over from New Year's Eve and give them one more toot. Here comes architecture.
Models of the design by Mr. Gehry, the architect of the acclaimed Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, will be presented in "Project for a New Guggenheim Museum in New York City," which opens on Wednesday at the Guggenheim's main building on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, designed in 1959 by Frank Lloyd Wright. The featured attraction is a large model, 12 feet long and 5 feet high, which displays the design in close-up detail. Other models present the project as it would appear in the Lower Manhattan cityscape, though there is no guarantee it will ever be built. The proposed site, near the foot of Wall Street, is occupied by three piers scheduled for development by the New York City Economic Development Corporation. 
 Even as a purely speculative idea, however, this museum project performs an important civic service. A steel-plated vessel, floating atop a vast outdoor skating rink, this is an icebreaker of a design, a plan for crunching through rigid streetscapes and frozen minds.
And it is a test of the city's willingness to think big. Will it get built? The question is a waste of energy. Like other sideshows that have kept New York in denial about the mediocrity of the buildings it puts up, the feasibility question distracts from the challenge presented by the design. This is the top form architecture comes in these days. Want some?
Thomas Krens, the director of the Guggenheim Museum, said that the institution is committed to building another museum in Manhattan. The Fifth Avenue building is too small to display more than a fraction of the museum's permanent collection, which also includes examples of large-scale contemporary art. Mr. Krens envisions an arrangement in which the Wright building would display work from the late 19th century to 1945 while the downtown building would present art from 1945 to the present.
"Project for a New Guggenheim Museum in New York City" presents the record of a creative process leading to the birth of an idea. If this one doesn't fly, we can count on Mr. Krens to have others. In 1998 he set his eye on another waterfront site, on the Hudson River. Local opposition helped deflate that dream and it could shatter this one, too. Financial and government support are also hurdles.
Lower Manhattan is well stocked with cherished landmarks like the Brooklyn Bridge, the World Trade Center, the Woolworth Building, Trinity Church and 70 Pine Street. But it has been some time since the district's architecture has risen to their iconic level. One of the charms of Mr. Gehry's design is that it would recast mediocre towers in the supporting roles for which they are better suited.
If New York is a perpetual gift to the future, this design is its bow: a flourish of titanium ribbons (Mr. Gehry calls them wrappers) curled around half a million square feet of gallery space. The composition is roughly triangular, a pediment on square columns. The triangle is anchored at the northern and southern corners by two low-rise structures of boxy silhouette. The southern structure houses a terminal for a ferry that would take visitors to a sculpture garden on Governors Island. The northern structure contains a 1,200-seat theater.
Thirty-six galleries, ranging from 1,300 to 20,000 square feet, would be housed on three levels within the cloudlike tangle of ribbon and a 450-foot tower rising above it. The galleries would serve various uses. In addition to the permanent collection and temporary shows, they would present exhibitions for three departments: education, architecture and design, and art and technology.
As at the Guggenheim in Bilbao, the previous collaboration between Mr. Krens and Mr. Gehry, the museum's major space would be an atrium bathed in natural light; 26,000 square feet of gallery space would overlook the atrium's well. Escalators, forming a dramatic diagonal at the base of the space, would move visitors up from the open areas beneath the museum into the building's heart.
Six massive square columns, steel and concrete superpylons, would hold the mass aloft. Gardens, bridges, a waterside promenade and other public spaces would occupy petal-shaped platforms extending into the river. The free-form rink, beneath the museum's soaring underside, would be equipped with "Knife Ship I," a kinetic sculpture by Claes Oldenburg that was the focus of a performance piece created by Mr. Gehry, Mr. Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen for the 1985 Venice Biennale.
Looking at the models could give you whiplash. In New York architects have spent the last two decades viewing the present through a rearview mirror, as if the city came to a halt in the Art Deco era.
As with the Bilbao Guggenheim, Mr. Gehry shows that one of the purest ways to honor context is to play against it. Many have seen the Manhattan skyline as a geological formation of cliffs, peaks and canyons. Mr. Gehry treats the site as a natural wonder, a spot where mountains cascade into the sea. He has raised the horizon of the water, in waves that lap against the base of the cliffs, and pulled the sky down to the canyons, with changing light reflected in the museum's wavy metal surface. Expanses of glass, articulated with diagonal mullions, splash upward like jets of water formed by a Manhattan-bound meteor's narrow miss.
With the tower, the vertical dimension of the skyline reverberates into the foreground. The tower's leaning silhouette and flaring top talk back to the World Trade Center's scaleless, impersonal thrust.
Some architects, who still regard the Trade Center as an aesthetic abomination, have championed a revival of building crowns, by which they mean paperweights blown up to skyscraper scale. Here is another way to top a tower. Rip off roof. Cut jaggedly above penthouse. Let curtain walls droop. Instead of hiding structural spines behind marble and steel, as Mies van der Rohe did with the Seagram Building, just let them hang out there in the breeze.
Ordered complexity, not chaos, is the fundamental principle of this work. We should be used to this by now. It has been 35 years since Robert Venturi introduced the concepts of complexity and contradiction as an alternative to the unified simplicity of the International Style. Mr. Gehry's work, like Venturi's and Denise Scott Brown's, aims for the maximum complexity that can be transmitted through habitable space.
The wrappers are the most eye-catching element of the Guggenheim design, but it would be a mistake to think the project's importance rests entirely on Mr. Gehry's ability to sculpture arresting shapes. What matters here is the physiognomy of the shapes.
Intersubjectivity -- the idea that multiple perspectives can render a truth -- is the central concept governing this and other projects that Mr. Gehry has designed for the last 25 years. It is also the idea that many people find hardest to take. We still look to architecture to embody some ideal of external authority: history, science, nature and religion, to name a few. This Gehry declines to provide. Though he makes fleeting formal allusions to other times, other buildings, these images are mutable. They rise to the surface and sink back. Tell me what you see and I will tell you -- with wild inaccuracy, no doubt -- who you are.
Scale and relationship to context are two of the Rorschach tests this project must pass in the eye of the beholder. But the Guggenheim faces even bigger obstacles. Some will object that the design looks too much like Bilbao; New York, ever mindful of its uniqueness, deserves better than a remake of something designed for provincial Spain. Some will not want to invest hope in a project that has yet to obtain the required permits and financial and government support.
I wouldn't worry too much about the design's uniqueness. To philistines all modern glass towers are identical. When you've seen one titanium wrapper, you've seen 'em all. A model of the Bilbao museum, included in the exhibition, will enable viewers to compare the designs. But carping about formal similarity may just be part of the Nimby syndrome. Architecture is fine for Bilbao, but we don't want it here.
Since the demolition of Pennsylvania Station, the troops can be counted on to protest tinkering with a lamppost. We've only begun to awaken to the loss of heritage that occurs when a city is frozen in time.

HEADLINE: Entrepreneur Pushes Plan To Fix California Schools

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.

 BODY:
In Timothy Draper's world, change occurs at a breakneck pace. A billionaire venture capitalist, he finances Internet start-ups that grow from business plan to public company in mere months. He came up with the concept of "viral marketing," instantaneously circulating advertisements by e-mail the world over.
In Silicon Valley, the pace is known as Internet time. So it is no surprise that Mr. Draper wants to transform overnight an institution that has long been dragged down by myriad problems: California's school system. 
 Mr. Draper has spent $2 million to try to get the nation's most far-reaching school voucher plan onto the November ballot. Under it, parents would be eligible for $4,000 a year per child for tuition at private schools, including parochial ones.
"Education reform has to happen from the outside," said Mr. Draper, 41. "I have to be the one to make sure it happens."
Mr. Draper's mantra has a familiar ring in Silicon Valley, where free-market and libertarian strains and newfound wealth have inspired a rush of interest in California's initiative process. But, as they would say here, Mr. Draper's politics are a few standard deviations from the mean.
He calls public education "socialistic" and advocates free-market solutions at every turn, even advocating legalizing drugs. He said his plan would empower parents to act as consumers shopping for the best education possible for their children.
The plan reflects his extreme strain of laissez-faire economics. It calls for using existing educational money for the $4,000 vouchers. But according to the latest National Education Association figures, California spent $5,627 per student in 1997-98, 40th in the nation and roughly $1,000 less than the national average.
Critics call the plan a drastic and simplistic solution to difficult problems: overcrowded and outmoded buildings, a lack of qualified teachers, textbooks and equipment and a growing number of students for whom English is a second language.
"It's dealing with very complex subjects, and it runs the risk of totally undermining school funding in California," said Bob Cherry, associate executive director of the California Teachers Association, a powerful organization with 300,000 members.
The association will provide stiff opposition to Mr. Draper. In 1993 it spent $16 million to defeat a similar initiative that voters rejected, 70 percent to 30 percent. This year, it is gathering signatures to put on the ballot a measure requiring the state to spend as much or more per student than the national average.
Paradoxically, it is an earlier voter initiative that is blamed by many for creating the state's educational quandary. Proposition 13, passed in 1978, capped some property taxes, thus limiting a major source of school financing.
Mr. Draper's initiative does not even have the support of all proponents of vouchers.
Terry Moe, a professor of political science at Stanford University, supports vouchers, but said they should be narrower than Mr. Draper's proposal. "There is a reason why, around the country," Mr. Moe said, "the kinds of vouchers that are successful are targeted at low-income children, and are limited programs."
"It's unfortunate at this time when a well-designed voucher initiative could win," Mr. Moe added, "he comes up with this, and he does it on his own."
Officials from Mr. Draper's campaign said they were still gathering signatures on a petition to qualify for the November ballot though few contest that they will qualify.
Mr. Draper says his proposal will bring California spending up to the national average per pupil. But the language of the proposition does not guarantee that. Rather, it says it would "permit" the Legislature to amend the law to raise spending, leading some political scientists to say the measure implies that it will accomplish more than it can.
"It's a bait-and-switch," Mr. Cherry said. "It's not about raising it to the national average, it's about installing a voucher system."
Mr. Draper says he has an interest as a "frustrated parent" of four children in private schools and as a businessman who knows that high-tech firms cannot find sufficiently educated engineers and scientists.
He is not the first Silicon Valley entrepreneur to use the initiative process to seek change.
On the March ballot, California voters rejected propositions drafted or sponsored in Silicon Valley that would have banned corporate campaign contributions and allowed votes for "none of the above" in federal and state elections. Officials of high-tech companies also supported an unsuccessful measure that would have lowered the vote to pass a school bond measure to a simple majority from a two-thirds majority.
The campaign finance reform measure was sponsored by Ron Unz, a software millionaire, whose initiative against bilingual education was approved in 1998.
Dan Schnur, a Republican strategist in California and the former Republican political director of TechNet, a bipartisan Silicon Valley lobbying group, said the region's entrepreneurs did not have the patience for the political process.
"Going to subcommittee hearings gets boring really fast," he said. "They figure they can achieve the results through a ballot measure."
Mr. Draper said he planned to create a broader political coalition than the conservatives and religious groups that backed the 1993 proposition, though he has not disclosed any backers. He said he was prepared to raise $40 million, an atypically high amount, but would not say how much he was prepared to spend himself.
Mr. Draper is less the political novice than other referendum-backing valley residents. He has been a prominent fund-raiser for George W. Bush and has hired as his spokesman Barry Hutchison, the former press secretary for Newt Gingrich. Mr. Draper's father, William H. Draper III, ran for Congress in 1969, and in 1981 was appointed chairman of the Export-Import Bank by President Ronald Reagan.
The younger Mr. Draper spent a year on the state board of education, where, he said, he learned that "the system is failing the people."
Whether Californians will embrace such a far-reaching initiative, colleagues of Mr. Draper say he will put enough money and personal influence into the race to force people to think about it. Mr. Draper said he hoped the result would be a legacy that promoted his near religious belief in the free market.
"I will have lived a great life if I can be known for viral marketing and school vouchers," he said.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
An Unlikely Champion of a New Trade Pact With China

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SANDER M. LEVIN hardly fits the classic free-trade profile. He is a liberal Democratic congressman from the Detroit suburbs who proudly owns a 94 percent career voting record with organized labor.
Yet with thousands of protesters in town to demonstrate against the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and what they view as the evils of globalization, Representative Levin will be lucky if he isn't hanged in effigy. 
 The 68-year-old legislator is fine-tuning a plan that could give wavering House Democrats the political cover they want to vote yes on the biggest trade deal in years, an accord with China. If Mr. Levin succeeds, Congress will help hand Beijing a diplomatic coup while opening new markets for American goods but will still keep leverage over China's behavior on human rights, religious tolerance and the environment.
"Members are searching for a way to both keep the heat on China and get the benefits of what we negotiated," Mr. Levin said in his Capitol Hill office, where photographs of Thomas P. O'Neill and Robert F. Kennedy adorn the wall. "We have to strive to combine active engagement with constructive confrontation."
For 20 years Congress has gone through the motions of an annual debate and vote to grant China the same trading privileges that Washington gives almost every other country. Congress has never refused to provide this plum.
But now China is on the verge of joining the World Trade Organization, and as part of a deal negotiated last fall, President Clinton promised to try to lift the annual review and grant Beijing permanent trading status.
The House will vote just before Memorial Day, but the outcome is too close to call. The fate of the agreement rests with about two dozen uncommitted Democrats. Passage in the pro-business Senate is considered certain.
Enter Mr. Levin, a senior member of the House Ways and Means Committee, who is one of the fence-sitters and has long wrestled with trade issues. He voted against the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993 and opposed giving President Clinton fast-track authority to negotiate trade pacts. He has voted both for and against granting China normal trading status.
"I'm an activist internationalist who's worked on both sides: expanded trade and expanded issues of trade," said Mr. Levin, who banged on Japan's doors in the 1980's to pry open its market to American automobiles.
Mr. Levin came away from a 10-day trip to China in January convinced that this trade agreement would influence the future of U.S.-China relations for years to come.
"I came back feeling that changes in China are irreversible, but that the direction is not inevitable," said Mr. Levin, who talked to students, artists and intellectuals about how free trade could open up China's repressive society. "You have to shape globalization."
Mr. Levin sees himself as an organizer and a problem solver, and set out to steer all sides to a middle ground. He has drawn up a plan to monitor China once it joins the W.T.O., and to react swiftly to any violations. The proposal sets up a Congressional-executive branch commission to monitor China's behavior on human rights and trade -- the biggest concern of opponents to giving up the yearly review -- and arms it with a quiver of rewards and penalties.
THE plan would also write into law promises China made to the United States to avoid surges of Chinese exports into the American market.
At first, no one on Capitol Hill paid much attention to Mr. Levin's plan. But by the time lawmakers headed home last week for a recess and the administration anxiously sought to nail down undecided votes, the idea was catching on. Backers say Mr. Levin's plan could swing 10 to 15 votes.
Mr. Levin is not flashy, nor is the low-key, details approach he has used in shopping his plan to about 40 undecided Democrats and Republicans. A Democratic colleague once described him as "a pit bull with manners."
"What Sandy is doing is extremely helpful because he's trying to get some accountability over time," said Representative Tom Allen, a Maine Democrat whose vote is up for grabs.
The China trade wars have catapulted Mr. Levin into the limelight somewhat to the chagrin of his party's leaders. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader who is strategically neutral on the vote, has been dismissive of Mr. Levin's efforts, choosing to broker his own third way with the White House.
The No. 2 Democrat in the House, David E. Bonior of Michigan, is leading the charge against the deal, and has called Mr. Levin's plan toothless.
In a rare flash of pique, Mr. Levin bristles at that criticism: "It has a lot of teeth in it, and I hope they're sharp and will bite when they need to."
Sander Martin Levin, the grandson of Russian and Polish Jews, was born and raised in Detroit. After earning degrees from the University of Chicago, Columbia University and Harvard Law School, he threw himself into the political arena.
Mr. Levin served in the Michigan State Senate for five years, but after two failed attempts to become governor in the 1970's, he thought he was washed up in politics. He was assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development during the Carter administration.
But in 1982, Michigan's 12th Congressional District opened up, and Mr. Levin has occupied it ever since, forming the lesser-known half of the Levin brother act in Congress. (Mr. Levin's younger brother, Carl, is the senior senator from Michigan and ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee.) Mr. Levin and his wife, Vicki, have four grown children.
For Mr. Levin, who worked one summer at a Dodge auto assembly plant, the China pact brings his trade career full circle: "My feeling on trade is that it's more than the humdrum of tariffs. A key part of economic life is rolling up your sleeves on a daily basis to work it out and to avoid the extremes."

HEADLINE: In Havana, Official Stance And Many Conflicted Views

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 16

 BODY:
Elian Gonzalez was not only shipwrecked but kidnapped, in the official point of view here, which was on display in all its revolutionary fervor this weekend at a demonstration by thousands of people.
Despite a downpour, protesters of all ages brandished Cuban flags, danced, sang and spoke, with a sixth grader, Yisel Viamontes, taking on the question on many minds in the United States and to some degree here as well. Would Elian have a better life here or there? 
 "They say he could be a millionaire there," Yisel shouted from the stage at a rally on Saturday night in Las Tunas, 400 miles southeast of here. "Here he will be a millionaire, but with millions much different than over there, with more dignified millions. Here he has millions of brothers and sisters and friends and classmates."
Elian is certainly a cause celebre here -- the 39th anniversary of President Fidel Castro's proclamation of a socialist state perhaps has added to the ferment -- but in everyday conversation people do not speak about the case as much with revolutionary passion as with apparently conflicting emotions.
In the markets, squares and bustling streets of this capital -- its late 1950's cars and colonial buildings a backdrop both dreary and charming -- the latest twists and turns in the case have provoked a range of reaction.
Cubans acknowledge feeling frustration and confusion over the American justice system, puzzled that one judge may rule one way and another judge another way.
"All that has happened in the courts, it's very bureaucratic and hard to understand," said Fernando Suarez, an engineer who, like many professionals here weathering hard economic times, supplements his income by selling books at a market. "Can you explain to me why not even the attorney general could take the boy out of the house in Miami?" Mr. Suarez asked about Attorney General Janet Reno's failure last week to obtain the transfer of Elian from his great-uncle to his father.
Silvia Romay, 35, another vendor who is an engineer, said she could relate to the case because her father left Cuba in 1980 in the Mariel boatlift in which 125,000 Cubans left for Florida in a matter of months. Ms. Romay's father, with whom she has sporadic contact, now lives in New York City but she prefers to stay in Cuba.
"It's hard to be separated from your parent," Ms. Romay said. "The situation is so politicized now. Elian is just an instrument for all sides."
Miguel Hernandez, a construction worker, said the more time the boy spends out of Cuba the more likely he will become a national hero, "although I do not know that he should be."
"He is just a boy who by chance ended up in the United States and, sooner or later, will come back and go on," Mr. Hernandez said.
Cuban officials have said there are no plans to parade the boy when he returns, and few people doubt the case will end with Elian living anywhere but in Cuba. Celebratory rallies welcoming him back, however, seem inevitable, and a huge plaza was recently completed on the grand Malecon, the famous seaside drive in Havana, near the United States Interests Section.
Some may celebrate reluctantly, if at all.
For all the sympathy there may be for Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, there is also understanding of Elian's mother, Elizabet Brotons, who took the boy with her on her fatal boat trip to Florida. Those who say they understood why she took such a drastic move mention the lure of bountiful, higher-paying jobs in the United States and freedom merely 90 miles away.
"The thing is, he made it out and that is where he may belong," said a 24-year-old student who said he had thought about rafting to Florida but feared drowning. "Do you know how many people would like to switch places with him?"
Another man, a musician, referred to the increasingly prominent "Liberan a Elian" -- free Elian -- placards on display around town. " 'Free Elian' has two meanings, you know," the musician said. "There are people here who believe now he is free."
Not everyone here, despite the impression in much of the United States, is clamoring to cobble together a raft and flee. Many here appear to believe that the United States' economic embargo, now 40 years old, will ultimately end, opening the way to better economic times.
Mr. Castro, who has become closely involved in the Elian case, has not addressed the subject in recent days. Mr. Castro was the host of a summit meeting of third world leaders that ended here on Friday night. Today he was concluding talks with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, who extended his stay after the summit meeting.
But the case did not escape the notice of some foreign leaders here for the meeting.
"I will be happy, as will the Venezuelan people, the day that child again breathes Cuban air and sets foot on this heroic Cuban soil," said President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela, whose hard-line policies on the rich, affinity for military greens and criticism of the United States have drawn comparisons to Mr. Castro.
State-controlled media outlets like Granma, the official newspaper of the Communist Party, provide a daily dose of full-blown Elian news from the official standpoint. And for two hours every afternoon Cuban television broadcasts round-table discussions on the case.
Said the moderator on Friday evening: "Indignant and combative, we continue the fight for a boy who is all the children of the world."
