HEADLINE: Together Again, Clinton and Gore Raise Millions

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 16

 BODY:
The sweet scent of jasmine wafted up the leafy hillsides, the lights of Los Angeles twinkled below, and the cash register ca-CHINGed until it was stuffed with $2.8 million.
The Bill and Al Show reopened on Saturday night, a star-studded gala under the baton of the DreamWorks SKG trio, after being dark for five months. 
 Now that Vice President Al Gore has wrapped up the Democratic nomination for president, his campaign has deemed it safe to start reappearing with President Clinton. Wearing light brown sports jackets and open-necked polo shirts, they ventured out on Saturday night for the first in a series of joint appearances to raise money for the Democratic National Committee. (The show goes to New York on April 24.)
Mr. Gore is relying on the successes of the Clinton administration to sweep him into office. As he told his audience here, the nation's prosperity is "the wind at my back."
But he has also been campaigning at a slight remove from the impeached president.
And on Saturday night, Mr. Gore still seemed not have resolved his feelings toward Mr. Clinton.
On the slate patio of the fortresslike Greystone manor, with amber lanterns slung from overhanging branches and celebrities like Jimmy Smits, Whoopi Goldberg, Kevin Spacey, Antonio Banderas, Melanie Griffith and Jay Leno listening, an odd ambivalence toward the president emerged in Mr. Gore's remarks. In trying to praise Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore seemed to give him the back of his hand.
For example, he had wanted to say that the president was a man of big ideas. But he introduced that thought this way: "Of all the criticisms of President Clinton that I've heard, the one that rings the most hollow is that he has pushed small ideas, little proposals."
Later, he said that the job of president was so difficult, Mr. Clinton had nearly snapped.
"Of all the good things I could say about President Clinton -- I could tell you about the many, many times when I have seen him, especially in the early years, nearly buckle under the pressure of his office but never do so," Mr. Gore said. He paused here at length, as if surprised by what he had just said and wondering how to smooth it over.
"As I say this," he began anew, "I don't want to pretend that I know how heavy his burdens have been because there is no other position like the one that he has held on our behalf. But I've been close enough to it to see firsthand that those burdens are very heavy."
The audience was full of people infatuated with Mr. Clinton, and they seemed relieved when their man took the stage. He was casual and charming and had them laughing almost immediately.
The president played off a reference that Mr. Gore had made in which he disparaged one of Hollywood's biggest flops, the $35-million 1986 disaster "Howard the Duck." Saying that the news media wereralways "obsessively" seeking differences between Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton, Mr. Clinton added: "I liked 'Howard the Duck,' " bringing chuckles from the audience.
Jokes aside, the buzz was whether Mr. Gore could live up to the Hollywood-friendly standards set by Mr. Clinton, a natural performer and movie fan. (As one production executive said of Mr. Clinton: "He is into the creative process.")
So far, Mr. Gore is doing just fine in the cash department. There was an assumption that the vice president, because of his high-tech proclivities and because DreamWorks is leaving the money-raising field, might find Silicon Valley more lucrative. And on Friday night, he raised an eye-popping $2.6 million from 70 venture capitalists at the Silicon Valley home of Joel Hyatt, a Democratic fund-raiser and successful entrepreneur.
But Saturday night's Hollywood haul was $2.8 million from 100 people who paid at least $25,000 a couple -- more than at any recent event for Mr. Clinton.
And in California, Mr. Gore appears ahead of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who is presumed to be the Republican nominee. The latest Field survey put Mr. Gore 10 points ahead, prompting speculation that Mr. Bush may not be able to wage a serious contest here.
That is essential in raising money. A top Democratic fund-raiser put it this way: "You have a tough act to follow with Clinton. But poll numbers help a lot. When polls show you're going to win, it's easier."
One of the biggest problems for Mr. Gore, and other Democrats, is that the DreamWorks trio of Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, longtime Clinton promoters and experts at extracting millions from their friends in the entertainment industry, plan to retreat from the fund-raising when Mr. Clinton leaves office.
And Mr. Gore is just not as natural a guest here as Mr. Clinton. While Mr. Gore has visited California 66 times since he became vice president seven years ago, Mr. Clinton seems more at home here. And there is talk that he will spend much of his post-presidency in California.
"Clinton has a bond here, and Gore has just never worked California the way he has," one insider said. "There is no question that Gore can never get to the level Clinton has here among the two or three thousand people in the fund-raising world."
Even Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore's biggest promoter, seemed worried that donors here might be lulled into complacency and flag in their commitment to getting Mr. Gore elected.
"When you think it doesn't matter, when you get tired, when you wish somebody wouldn't call you again between now and November," the president told them, remember that the Republicans ended the economic expansion of the 1960's. "Take a deep breath and bear down," he implored them.

HEADLINE: Corzine Gives Broad Plans For Health And Schools

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 16

 BODY:
Jon S. Corzine may be running only for the United States Senate, but his proposals sound as sweeping as any president's since Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society.
He envisions a national health care system, with insurance for everyone. A national program of long-term care for the aged and infirm. And enough new federal education spending to cover college tuition for every high school graduate with a B average or better, and preschool for every toddler. 
 Even a cursory look at this breathtakingly expansive platform raises some obvious questions: How much would it cost? Where will the money come from? And are New Jersey voters, historically moderate, ready for a candidate who seems so much like a throwback to the 1960's?
Mr. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, says he is running "because it's time to get bold things done." In an era when fiscal conservatism is almost synonymous with patriotism, he has outlined programs that could cost hundreds of billions of dollars.
He has said much less about how he would pay for them.
His candidacy rests on two propositions: that a society awash in prosperity, its confidence in government buoyed by rising surpluses, should be ready to spend liberally to solve its most vexing social problems; and that the ideal guardian of the nation's purse strings is someone like him -- a Wall Street-hardened financier who has spent his career doing deals in dollar amounts of 9 and 10 digits.
Just four years after President Clinton, a Democrat, declared that "the era of big government is over," Mr. Corzine is perhaps the only prominent Democrat in America arguing forcefully for a reversal of the last two decades' steady shift in power from the federal government to the states.
"There's a generation of Democrats that is understandably afraid to get out on any tree limb at all," said Susan Estrich, who managed Michael S. Dukakis's 1988 presidential campaign and now is advising Mr. Corzine. "He isn't. He also brings the credibility, as a businessman, to say, 'We can do this, and your money will be well spent.' "
Mr. Corzine's stands on social issues, meanwhile, make his fiscal plans seem middle of the road. He supports allowing gays to marry legally and to serve openly in the military. He favors greater curbs on firearms than even the advocacy group Handgun Control. He opposes the death penalty and any restrictions on abortion rights, even for late-term procedures. And he supports affirmative action, including set-asides for minority contractors.
Not surprisingly, his opponent in the Democratic primary, former Gov. Jim Florio, is dying to meet Mr. Corzine head-on in a debate. "The people of this state do not want extremes," Mr. Florio said. "They do not want someone who's going to go out there promising them the moon."
But Mr. Corzine, 53, insists that more voters will be attracted by his authenticity than repelled by his positions. "Why should someone run for political office if they're only going to shape their views to poll-driven responses?" he said in one of two recent interviews. "I actually think that's why people are frustrated with politics in America. They know politicians tell them what they want to hear to get elected. I have to have a purpose in this exercise."
Mr. Corzine's purpose in running for Senate begins with the so-called social safety net. He endorses President Clinton's plan to allow investment of up to 15 percent of the Social Security trust fund in the stock market instead of only in safer, but possibly less lucrative, government securities. He supports setting aside $680 billion from future federal surpluses to cover rising Medicare costs.
"I want to take on getting these safety-net programs properly structured in a businesslike fashion," he said. "These things are vital. And if we don't pay attention to the details of how they are organized, our society's going to suffer."
It is on health care, however, that Mr. Corzine has focused the most attention in his speeches and television commercials. Unlike Vice President Al Gore, who wants to extend health care to the uninsured in increments, he speaks of "universal health care coverage" for all 44 million uninsured Americans as something that can and should be done immediately.
Like Hillary Rodham Clinton's ill-fated 1993 national health care plan, Mr. Corzine's proposal relies on employer mandates. All companies would be required to offer insurance to their workers, who would have to bear some of the cost themselves through premiums. Smaller businesses would join regional insurance pools to negotiate for discounts. The federal government would reimburse businesses with fewer than 200 workers for the costs through subsidies under a sliding scale.
But while Mr. Corzine continues to speak in universal terms, he leaves himself room to retreat to a half-measure. Pressed for weeks to detail his approach and its costs, he released late on Friday a one-page financial summary of two options. It stated that he favored making health insurance a matter of individual choice, and projected that half of America's uninsured would choose to remain uninsured, limiting the government's costs to $21 billion. To cover everyone, it said, would cost the government $42 billion and employers $36 billion more than they already spend.
Mr. Corzine said that more than half the uninsured might well choose to enroll up front, "depending on how aggressively the system markets itself."
"Once it is affordable," he added, "people will more willingly volunteer to take up the opportunity. We could ultimately move to some kind of requirement, but I don't think we should move there on the first step."
Still, Mr. Corzine's heart clearly is in truly universal health coverage. At a recent forum before nurses and other health care professionals, he was asked if he supported a single-payer system. He carefully avoided answering (though he later told a reporter that he opposed it). "Running around as a newcomer to politics and talking about what is generally labeled socialized medicine would probably be the kiss of death," he told the audience.
Mr. Corzine said he was proudest of his proposals for long-term care, an issue that has few champions in the national debate. "This is something that when I get there, I will be an advocate for the next 10 years, till we get something done," he said. "I think I can make a deal out of this, because I think it's something our society needs."
He supports Mr. Clinton's latest proposal for a $3,000 tax credit for patients or their caregivers, though he says it should be refundable and still dismisses it in the next breath as too little. "It's nuts," he said. "That's one month of assisted living."
As a more meaningful step, Mr. Corzine says he admires programs begun by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in New York, Connecticut, California and other states that were intended to entice people to buy their own long-term care insurance. Those pilot programs, which under existing federal law cannot be expanded to other states, assure participants that they will not need to exhaust all their assets before qualifying for Medicaid in old age.
But reviews have been mixed. "Policy analysts like it a lot, but people don't like these policies," said Joshua M. Wiener, an expert on long-term care at the Urban Institute in Washington. "Insurance agents don't like to sell them, either. It's opposite the way they normally sell. They usually say, 'Buy this product and you'll never go on that horrible Medicaid.' Now, they're saying, 'Buy this and, should you use up your benefits, we'll get you on Medicaid faster.' "
Ultimately, Mr. Corzine said he believed that a national long-term care system should be folded into Medicare or a Social Security-like program. Mr. Wiener said that this could cost $70 billion or more.
Mr. Corzine said the tab should be much less, because individuals and employers would both contribute, but he could not elaborate. "I'm very admitting that it's the formative stage, but I think we've got to encourage our society," he said.
He said that he deliberately set his sights higher than his expectations but that he was not unrealistic. But his grand plans, outlined on his Web site at www.votecorzine.org, do come at a price.
In education, for example, Mr. Corzine said he would raise spending by $30 billion to cover initiatives for preschool and kindergarten through the 12th grade. Beyond that, he wants to copy a scholarship program in Georgia, which pays for two years of tuition at a state college for any student who maintains an average of B or better. If students qualify for a national scholarship program at the same rate they do in Georgia, the cost could reach $16 billion a year.
Mr. Corzine also favors a fully refundable college tuition tax credit for low-income families. That would cost more than $9 billion after three years, according to the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington. All told, his education programs alone could add $55 billion to the nation's annual budget, roughly five times what Mr. Gore has proposed.
Mr. Corzine, who talks of "holistic" solutions and speaks admiringly of the welfare states in Scandinavia and elsewhere in Europe, says he believes in an "activist" government. But like any Democrat who survived the Reagan years, he refuses to accept the "liberal" label.
"I don't think working to try to take some of the pressure off the property tax system by having the federal government take on a greater element of responsibility in education, particularly in our more troubled schools -- it's not a liberal or conservative issue," he said. "It's a responsible effort to try to break some of the cycles of poverty and human degradation we've got going on.
"People are not going to find my support for closing corporate tax credits and tax loopholes that have been won by special interests as a liberal point of view," he continued. "I think they're just going to find it a responsible point of view."
Mr. Florio, the combative former governor, says Mr. Corzine's proposals are irresponsible or naive. He adds that Mr. Corzine rarely mentions what they will cost.
"At the very beginning, when he was out there, I chastised him gently, saying, 'You've got to be specific,' " Mr. Florio said of his opponent. "Then he came forward with this set of specifics that are unaccounted for in terms of the costs, and that's the opposite extreme. It's irresponsible to say, 'I'm for everyone having a good life, elect me.' Or on the other side, 'I'm for everybody having 17 Cadillacs in their driveway,' without saying how they're going to pay for them."
But while Mr. Corzine's Web site does omit any bottom-line dollar figures, Mr. Corzine asserted that his proposals could all be paid for with the $750 billion in non-Social Security surpluses projected by the federal government over the next 10 years. Where necessary, he said, senators could always cut pork-barrel spending. And in an economic downturn, he would favor deficit spending, he said.
"I don't think this is a budget-busting set of proposals," Mr. Corzine said. "And that's before the fact of whether I can get these implemented. I'm not expecting that everybody's just going to accede to everything that I've proposed. My whole point is, if you don't have an advocate for these kinds of positions, they'll never happen."

UNIVERSAL HEALTH CARE: $21 BILLION TO $42 BILLION
Mr. Corzine favors requiring employers to offer insurance but letting individuals decide whether to participate. He projects that half the nation's uninsured would voluntarily remain uninsured, limiting the government's cost to $21 billion out of $44 billion, the rest to be paid by employers and workers through premiums. To cover all the uninsured would cost the federal government $42 billion out of a $90 billion total.
 
For businesses with fewer than 200 workers, the federal government would subsidize employer premiums on a sliding scale. For the self-employed, premiums would be fully deductible.
 
UNIVERSAL LONG-TERM CARE: $10 BILLION TO $70 BILLION
Expand Medicare to cover America's long-term care needs. Price: $70 billion.
 
As a short-term step, approve President Clinton's $3,000 tax credit for patients or caretaking family members, but make it fully refundable. Price: $10 billion.
 
As an intermediate step, expand pilot programs in a few states where people can protect their assets from future Medicaid spend-downs by buying private long-term care insurance through state-sponsored plans.
 
UNIVERSAL QUALITY PUBLIC EDUCATION: $55 BILLION
Increase federal aid for preschool, primary and secondary schools. Price: $30 billion.
 
Two years of free tuition at public colleges for students with a B average or better. Price: $16 billion.
 
Refundable tuition tax credit of up to $2,500 for low-income families. Price: $9 billion.

HEADLINE: Miami Area's Mayors Ride a Volatile Political Wave

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 16

 BODY:
What excites Miami's Cuban-Americans about Elian Gonzalez is that his case presents the best opportunity in decades, since the failed Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, to humiliate Fidel Castro. But domestic conflicts are stirring this pot, too, and threatening Miami and its two top politicians with their own Bay of Pigs.
Alex Penelas, 38, a Democrat, was elected mayor of Miami-Dade County four years ago with the huge support of Cuban-Americans, who normally vote Republican, as well as the support of many blacks and non-Hispanic whites. Once perceived as a future governor or senator, Mr. Penelas faces a re-election race in the fall against a Republican Cuban-American, Miguel Diaz de la Portilla, a county commissioner who is more conservative than than he. 
 Joseph Carollo, 45, a Republican, was elected mayor of the city of Miami three years ago. In a city where Cuban-Americans make up the majority of voters, he survived an effort by the city commission to oust him in a special election last year that the courts overruled. Accused of taking his Cuban-American support for granted, Mr. Carollo faces a challenge next year from the former mayor, Xavier Suarez, who is also a Republican and a Cuban-American.
In local politics, "Fidel Castro is not even an issue," said Prof. Kenneth W. Goodman, director of the ethics program at the University of Miami. Alberto Duran, a board member of the Cuban Committee for Democracy, which favors Elian's return to his father, said, "This is a political struggle, a show of political muscle more than a stance against Castro."
"They want to prove they can keep this child here," Mr. Duran said. "Penelas is in a very tough political race, so he's taking extreme stands to get the Cuban-American vote, and Carollo is going to have a tough race in November next year."
The turning point in both mayors' role in the dispute came late last month when Mr. Penelas, with Mr. Carollo beside him, revived the 37-year-old image of George Wallace, Alabama's segregationist governor, as they stood on the steps of the federal courthouse here to lash out at federal law and its enforcers.
Mayor Penelas, until then a man known as a consensus-building moderate, declared that he would not let the Miami police help federal agents move Elian from his temporary home and would blame President Clinton and Attorney General Janet Reno for any violence and civil disorder that might occur. He and Mayor Carollo, who is known as a firebrand, have since promised to maintain order. But they will not let their police forces join federal marshals in moving Elian.
Analysts say the mayors have alienated all other ethnic groups, sullied their images as emerging leaders of their national political parties and further diminished the stature of a turbulent city that often ranks near the top of the cities with the highest murder rates and at the bottom of the cities that banks like to lend to. At moments in the latest twists of the Elian saga, analysts say, the mayors have let emotions trump federal law.
"What they both have at stake," said Dario Marino, a pollster and an associate professor of political science at Florida International University here, "is the good name of Miami and the ability to attract business. No one in the business elite wants civil disobedience." But as passions over Elian have begun to boil over, Mr. Marino said, "their first priority is not to alienate their Cuban-American base. If they alienate their Cuban base, they're both gone."
Hugh Gladwin, director of the Institute for Public Opinion Research at F.I.U., said: "The first level of political impact, until it's resolved and people start reflecting on it, is this huge polarization. People are going to remember." Because of the mayors' "pandering to popular sentiment," said Mayor Neisen O. Kasdin of Miami Beach, "Miami has taken it on the chin. It's not going to stop Miami's emergence as the capital of the Americas. But this is a setback for two or three years."
The two mayors have impeccable Cuban and American political credentials. Mayor Penelas's father, a labor organizer in Cuba, was in a Cuban prison facing a death sentence when he escaped with his family to Florida, where Alex was born. Joseph Carollo came at the age of 5 or 6, one of nearly 14,000 Pedro Pan children whose parents dispatched them to the United States and then followed months later.
The two soaked up American culture and education and began careers in politics. Mr. Penelas was elected to the Hialeah City Council at 25. Mr. Carollo, briefly a Democrat and a police officer, was elected a Miami city commissioner at 24. Both dress in the crisp suits and tightly knotted ties favored by members of the board of a chamber of commerce.
Early in the Elian case, after his rescue at sea in November, the mayors stood on the fringe of the custody debate while their Cuban-American constituents weighed the issues. In interviews then, the views expressed covered the spectrum of grays, including allowing Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, custody if he came Miami to collect him and bowing to federal court rulings.
But as the community's views coalesced, to the point now where many support Lazaro Gonzalez's defiance of a federal order to release Elian to his father, the mayors have declined to intervene.
In a poll this month that stunned analysts here, The Miami Herald found an acutely polarized city, with 83 percent of Miami-Dade County's Cuban-Americans supporting efforts to keep Elian in the United States and 55 percent of other Hispanics agreeing, but 92 percent of African-Americans and 72 percent of non-Hispanic whites supporting his return to Cuba.
With a Cuban majority in the city and a plurality in the county, said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Institute at F.I.U., "Carollo and Penelas want to make sure they're in the front of this movement."
The 4,000 or 5,000 people who demonstrate in front of Lazaro Gonzalez's home may represent only a fraction of the county's 743,000 Cuban-Americans in a total population of 2.1 million, Mr. Perez said, but when things get emotional, the mayors will have to take up the banner or get trampled by others carrying it. "The fact that this is foreign policy is academic," Mr. Perez said. "They're doing what their constituency wants them to do."
In responding to the passions of a single constituency, the mayors have alienated blacks and non-Hispanic whites. Marvin Dunn, a black who is the chairman of the psychology department at F.I.U. and the author of a book about the black experience in Miami in the 20th century, said the Miami Herald poll showing that 92 percent of blacks want Elian repatriated was stunning.
"We see far too many fathers abandoning their children," Mr. Dunn said. "When we see a dad stand up for his son, that's impressive." That such views are ignored, he said "is for me, for a lot of African-Americans, reprehensible. We feel we are a less important part of the community."
That may not hurt Mayor Carollo because of the city's Cuban-American majority. "But Penelas has more of a problem," Mr. Dunn said. James W. Corey, a political scientist at the University of Miami and a veteran of the Bay of Pigs, said, "I would say strategically, he's put himself in a precarious position."
The Cuban-Americans, said Susan MacManus, a professor of political science at the University of South Florida in Tampa, "forced him to go so far over to the right that it makes it difficult for him to win."
The only winners, she said, are the aging leaders of the Cuban exile community, who had been losing influence. The Elian affair, she said, "has galvanized them and emboldened them."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Points to Big Accomplishment: It Met as Scheduled

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Delegates looked bleary-eyed after their predawn wake-up calls, and a handful arrived several hours late. But the member nations of the International Monetary Fund achieved a major breakthrough today: They met.
That was perhaps the one definitive accomplishment the world finance ministers could announce after a full day of meetings to discuss global financial stability and to set the course for the fund. After globalization-wary protesters briefly shut down world trade talks in Seattle last year and threatened to do the same to finance ministers gathered in Washington today, the simple fact of the meeting was presented as a triumph. 
 "The meeting went on as normal," announced Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer and the chairman of the fund's steering committee. "It started on time, and it was completed in a normal way."
That included a relaxed lunch in the I.M.F.'s soaring marble and glass atrium, where formally attired waiters served jumbo shrimp and offered a selection of red and white wines.
The shouts of protesters could not be heard inside the earth-tone conference rooms of the fund's downtown Washington headquarters. But participants said the varied complaints of the fund's many critics in Congress, in academia and on the streets resonated in many of the policy proposals discussed during the sessions, including those for streamlined lending procedures and expedited debt relief for poor countries.
A carefully worded communique at the end of the day gave credit to outside critics for stoking a public debate about the future of the fund. And many of the finance ministers stressed that they had heard the protesters' messages.
"The world is going through a period of profound change, and that has made for debate here and some debate outside," said Paul Martin, Canada's finance minister. "Ultimately our aims are the same." He added that both parties want to figure out how best to deal with poverty.
There appeared to be modest progress on a range of issues confronting the fund, some of which are high on the agenda of outside critics. The finance ministers asked the fund's managers to continue a review of their lending programs with an eye to eliminating some. The fund was also told to review whether to use variable pricing on some loan programs so as to discourage repeated, long-term borrowing. The United States favors those proposals.
But some poor and middle-income nations expressed strong reservations about proposals that would make it more difficult for them to obtain loans or force them to pay the loans back faster. Their opposition highlighted how difficult it is to make quick changes at the fund, which has 182-member nations, though its board is in effect controlled by the United States and Europe.
"We find some of these proposals unacceptable and have serious concerns about them," said German Suarez, who heads a coalition of developing countries known as the Group of 24. He was referring primarily to a proposal put forward by a Congressional commission that studied ways of changing the I.M.F. and the World Bank, its sister lending agency.
The finance ministers' communique ruled out the possibility of completely eliminating the fund's long-term lending programs and expressed strong support for the fund's involvement in working to reduce poverty. The Congressional panel, known as the Meltzer Commission, had urged that the fund cease both types of lending.
On debt relief, finance ministers reiterated their longstanding pledge to free the world's poorest countries, including many in Africa, of crushing foreign-debt burdens. One problem is that some legislatures around the world, most notably Congress, so far have not allotted all the necessary funds to allow the fund and the World Bank to forgive past loans.
Jubilee 2000, a religious coalition, has called for stepping up the effort and for total forgiveness of debt owed by the world's 40 poorest nations.
Participants in the discussions today said the ministers had also considered proposals that would make it easier for the poorest countries to qualify for debt relief and to put the plans into effect faster once they do.
Of 27 nations considered under a debt-relief program approved in Cologne, Germany, last summer, only five have begun a qualification process and just one, Uganda, has actually had some debt forgiven. Many others have faced difficulties in proving to the fund and the bank that they have the good governance and adequate programs to meet the criteria for debt forgiveness.
Most finance ministers, traveling in police-escorted bus convoys, had little trouble winding their way through barricades to the fund's headquarters. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, the top-ranking American official at the meetings, was whisked by limousine from his office a few blocks away.
But the protests made life difficult for some officials. The Japanese delegation, fearing a tardy arrival, left its quarters at the Madison Hotel a few blocks from the I.M.F. at 4:30 a.m., arriving a short time later and waiting more than three hours for the start of the formal proceedings, a Japanese official said.
The French finance minsiter, Laurent Fabius, who had told I.M.F. and World Bank staff members that he wanted to conduct a dialogue with demonstrators during his stay, got full exposure. Protesters surrounded his limousine just before the 8 a.m. start of the morning session, forcing him to turn back. He waited for nearly six hours at a luxury hotel for bus transport through the barricades, arriving just at the conclusion of lunch.

HEADLINE: Against All Odds, a Complicated Casino Proposal Advances

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

 BODY:
Robert A. Berman stalked across the cavernous grandstand at Monticello Raceway on a recent afternoon just as the trotters breezed across the finish line to the desultory cheers of two dozen bettors and a couple of children scattered among the box seats.
He winced when the tote board showed that a mere $6,223 had been bet on the race, including the off-track action. It had hardly been worth the effort. 
 With the scruffy racetrack, and the empty parking lot, it was hard to picture the tens of thousands of vacationers who once flocked here from borscht belt hotels. But it is here that Mr. Berman wants to build a $500 million casino for the St. Regis Mohawk tribe, a project that he says will bring prosperity back to the Catskills and a windfall to him and his partners.
And on April 7, after six years of public hearings, environmental reviews, negotiations and nearly $30 million, he finally won the federal Interior Department's approval for his plan to donate 30 acres to the Mohawks for the casino. He and his partners would build and operate it under a management contract with the tribe.
"There's nothing here," said Mr. Berman, who grew up here and heads an investment group that owns the track. "This area has been devastated. The casino would create thousands of good-paying jobs. It'll drive demand for hotels and the people who work there will spend money in the community."
But even with the victory in Washington -- one that many thought would never happen -- Mr. Berman still feels embattled.
The casino venture still needs the approval of Gov. George E. Pataki, whose longstanding support for the project is now open to question, and possibly the State Legislature. Although Mr. Berman's partners include top Republican campaign contributors with close ties to the state's top economic development official, Charles A. Gargano, the battle in Albany will be joined by a combative group of gambling opponents, Atlantic City casino interests, unions and real estate developers.
To add to the intrigue, casino proponents and tribal officials say that a new force has sought to curry favor with the Mohawk tribe in an effort to gain control of the casino, or kill it: Arthur Goldberg, president of Park Place Entertainment, the largest gambling operator in the country, and his adviser, Alfonse M. D'Amato, the former senator.
"The casino could revive an historic area," Mr. Berman said. "We hope the governor will judge this project on the merits and ignore all the political noise in the background."
Mr. Berman's friends and critics in Sullivan County described him as a "wheeler dealer" who was always trying to get some project going in the county, even after business took him to New York and across the country.
"He was always very enterprising," said Ira Jay Cohen, the Sullivan County attorney. "Very inventive. I wasn't surprised years later when he surfaced as the head of this casino venture. He was always willing to take a chance."
The son of a local contractor, Mr. Berman, 40, was 19 when he opened the Bananas nightclub in nearby Woodridge at one of the county's many shuttered hotels. In 1981 and 1982, he ran Music Mountain, a successful concert series that included the Allman Brothers Band and the Grateful Dead at Avon Lodge, a former hotel owned by his girlfriend's family.
In 1987, he and four partners revived a twice-failed ski resort in Sullivan County called Davos. The county's resort industry had foundered badly in the competition with Atlantic City and relatively inexpensive air fares to Europe. But there was a boomlet in second-home construction. Mr. Berman's group expanded the ski trails and built a clubhouse, a lodge and hundreds of condominiums, town houses and single-family homes.
The recession in the early 1990's, however, brought construction to a halt, and the project's lender pushed Davos into bankruptcy court, leaving some residents and local contractors angry with Mr. Berman over unfulfilled promises. Mr. Berman eventually wrested back control of the property.
For much of the 1990's, Mr. Berman was involved with Watermark Investments, a holding company based in Manhattan that invested in real estate projects, an Internet lottery and hotel renovations. He said he stepped down from those ventures last month to concentrate on the casino.
The origins of that project date back to 1994, when the State Legislature once again did not approve casino gambling in New York. Mr. Berman told Cliff Ehrlich, whose family had owned the Pines hotel and was an advocate of gambling as a way to revive the county's beleaguered economy, that he had a way to get around the state's prohibition.
Mr. Berman, who had worked with the Coeur d'Alene tribe in Idaho on an Internet lottery venture, said that a seldom-used provision of federal law allowed for the creation of a casino on land donated in trust for a tribe. The trust would establish a tax-free sovereign Indian territory outside tribal lands expressly for a casino.
Mr. Berman and Mr. Ehrlich bought the failing racetrack in Monticello and approached the Oneidas, one of only two tribes in New York that had a gambling contract with the state and the wherewithal to both finance and operate a casino. When a deal with the Oneidas fell apart in 1995, Mr. Berman and Mr. Ehrlich struck an alliance with the St. Regis Mohawks, whose reservation is on the Canadian border, 350 miles north of Monticello. But the Mohawks could not finance or operate the casino.
For financial support, Mr. Berman enlisted an old friend, Joseph Bernstein, a developer based in New York City who had gained notoriety in the 1980's when he secretly bought skyscrapers in Manhattan on behalf of President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines.
Mr. Berman also picked up another partner, Alpha Hospitality, a gambling company that already had a deal with the Mohawks to run an off-reservation casino. Alpha was run by Stanley S. Tollman, a New York businessman who owned a number of hotels. Its directors and major stockholders included Mr. Gargano, who was appointed chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation in 1995. Mr. Gargano's connections to Alpha, whose casino project was being reviewed by the state, set off a storm of protest in the Legislature. He ultimately resigned from Alpha and sold his stock, although he and Mr. Tollman remain good friends.
"Mr. Gargano divested his holdings many years ago so there wouldn't be any reason to question anything," said Thomas Aro, executive vice president of Alpha. "But you don't resign your friendships."
Mr. Berman added: "Nobody is doing anybody any favors on this deal."
But Mr. Tollman may have other problems that could reflect poorly on Alpha and the contract with the Mohawks. The United States attorney in Manhattan is investigating his Tollman-Hundley Hotels company, which bought the Days Inn chain in 1989 in a highly leveraged $765 million deal. Less than two years later, Days Inn filed for bankruptcy protection.
Prosecutors recently obtained indictments of a former company executive, Howard Zukerman, on charges of tax evasion. In a declaration filed in that case, an assistant U.S. attorney, Stanley J. Okula Jr., stated that he was investigating Mr. Tollman's friend and former partner, Monty Drew Hundley, and three other unnamed executives at Tollman-Hundley in connection with "a massive scheme to defraud certain financial institutions."
Mr. Hundley was a founder of both the hotel company and Alpha. Mr. Tollman did not return numerous telephone calls requesting comment and Larry Horn, a lawyer for Mr. Hundley, declined to comment.
"It has nothing to do with Alpha," Mr. Aro said. "I have no knowledge of it."
In any event, the group drew up plans for the casino over the last five years and met with county legislators and federal regulators. Mr. Berman promised to expand the track when the casino was built. The two-story gambling and entertainment complex, which would include 200 gambling tables, a 12,000-square-foot poker room, a bingo room and 3,000 video lottery terminals, is expected to attract 9 million visitors a year and generate 5,300 people. In a series of negotiations, the tribe has agreed to give the county $5 million a year and to provide the state with up to 25 percent of the gross revenues from electronic gambling machines.
After 30 years of talk about gambling in the Catskills, few people thought the Monticello casino would ever materialize. But last year, David Flaum and Louis R. Cappelli, developers who are also heavy Republican campaign contributors, began buying property for resorts the likes of which had not been seen in Sullivan County. Gambling foes and Atlantic City casino owners like Donald J. Trump opposed the project in advertisements attacking Mr. Pataki as a pro-gambling politician.
Mr. Pataki has long said that Indian casinos could be an economic boon in traditional resort areas like the Catskills and western New York. He has also maintained that he has the power to approve Indian casino proposals. But last month, he filed a bill that would require the State Legislature to approve Indian gambling operations, a proposal that casino advocates believe would mean almost certain doom. Since then, the Pataki administration has refused to say whether the bill covers the Mohawks, a tribe that already has a gambling compact with the state.
"It's the last best hope for the area," said United States Senator Charles E. Schumer, who had lobbied the federal government on behalf of the casino.
A top state official said in a recent interview that the Monticello casino would be reviewed in the context of the state's overall relations with the tribe. In a meeting last Thursday, state officials made a settlement offer concerning the Mohawks' land claims. The offer got a favorable reception, according to one person who was briefed on the talks.
That gave casino proponents hope. But they must still get their management contract with the Mohawks approved by the National Indian Gaming Commission.
In an apparent break with the Atlantic City casino owners, Mr. Goldberg of Park Place Entertainment has been negotiating for six months to take over management of the Mohawks' small, money-losing casino in Hogansburg, N.Y., according to tribal officials, the current casino operator and others. And last week, he made overtures to Alpha concerning the proposed Monticello casino.
It is this kind of maneuvering that gives Mr. Berman headaches. He fears that Park Place does not truly want a casino in Monticello that could take business away from Atlantic City.
"I don't believe for a minute that they want a casino in Monticello," he said. "They've got too big a stake in Atlantic City.
"This thing rests on Pataki's shoulders," Mr. Berman added. "He has the power with a stroke of the pen to say yes to thousands of jobs and millions of dollars in revenue that now flows out of the state."

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Low-Cost Phone Service Is Proposed for Indians

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 16

 BODY:
President Clinton will announce a plan on Monday to provide basic telephone service for $1 a month on American Indian reservations, the White House said today.
William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said he expected the plan to benefit 300,000 households. 
 Nationwide, 56 percent of households on Indian reservations have telephones, compared with 94 percent for the population as a whole.
To pay for the plan, Mr. Kennard said he would propose adding $17 million to a program that underwrites phone service costs for low-income people. Long-distance phone companies, which pay subsidies to states to help low-income people, would pay the additional costs.
Also today, the Microsoft Corporation announced that it would give $2.5 million worth of software and $200,000 in cash to be divided among eight tribal colleges in an effort to help bridge the "digital divide" and economic disparity between Indian tribes and wealthier segments of society.

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Sharp Sell-Off In World Markets

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Monday, April 17

 BODY:
Friday's rout on Wall Street reverberated across Asia today, with so-called old economy stocks sliding together with technology issues as investors worried about the fallout from declining stocks on the United States economy and the nation's demand for Asian exports.
Stocks in South Korea were down 10 percent during the day after trading was halted briefly at the opening because of the steep decline. Japan's Nikkei index dropped 7 percent, and the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong was down more than 8 percent at its midday break. 
 "This is more than we anticipated," said Joe Lee, an analyst at Daiwa Securities in Seoul, South Korea. "It's not just the tech stocks. Everything is falling right now."
And in an indication of trading once the United States markets opened, the Nasdaq 100 index futures contract was down 2.3 percent and the S.& P. 500 contract was down 1.2 percent.
The shock waves came despite efforts by financial officials to calm investors, who were responding to a 9.67 percent drop in the Nasdaq composite index on Friday. Australia's All Ordinaries index dropped by more than 5 percent even after Prime Minister John Howard went on the radio to remind shareholders of the strength of Australia's economy.
Officials at the meeting of the Group of 7 industrial nations in Washington issued a statement on Saturday saying the global economic outlook was continuing to brighten. And Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan predicted that Wall Street's declines would not spread to Japan's stock markets.
Investors were concerned that lower asset values in the United States could dampen demand among consumers and companies for electronics, a key component of Asia's export-led recovery.
Much will depend on the direction of the United States markets this week, but many analysts said they shared Mr. Miyazawa's optimism that stronger economic fundamentals and a smaller number of Internet stocks would help reduce the effect in Tokyo and that markets would recover during the day.
"The magnitude of the sell-off won't be anywhere near where it is in the U.S.," said Kathy Matsui, a strategist at Goldman, Sachs in Tokyo. Japan is far behind the United States in terms of adopting information technology, she said, giving its technology companies much more room still to grow.
While the broad declines could bring a welcome dose of reality to speculative Internet stocks, analysts said they could turn up buying opportunities for companies that make the nuts and bolts of the network economy, like Fujitsu, NEC, Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Electronics.
Supporting such optimism were stock prices in Taiwan, which after falling on Saturday bucked the trend today by rising slightly.
Moreover, some analysts said a shift away from high-technology investments was likely to rekindle interest in emerging markets like Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines. Despite positive economic growth forecasts, a dearth of Internet-related stocks has left those markets far behind those in North Asia.
But other analysts said their concern was that so much wealth had evaporated with last week's declines -- more than $2 trillion -- that it could touch off waves of selling in Asia's smaller markets, with the potential for even more drastic price declines. Any such landslide in prices was likely to test government commitments to free-market dynamics and resist the temptation to intervene to protect asset values.
Rising stock prices over the last year made it easier for Asia's heavily indebted companies to service their loans and, in the process, reduced the pressure on governments to reform their banking sectors. A sharp decline in stock prices, analysts said, was likely to refocus attention on the need for such restructuring for Asia's long-term economic health.

HEADLINE: From Cell, Coalition Looked Like a Movement

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
As he sees it, Mike Saltz spent Saturday night in jail for exercising his natural-born rights of free speech and peaceable assembly.
A man who appears both sweet-tempered and thoughtful, Mr. Saltz, 22, a student at the University of Oregon in Eugene, was swept up in a mass arrest of roughly 600 people near the International Monetary Fund on Saturday. 
 He was trying to find some friends at a rally, he said, when he was arrested, cuffed wrist to ankle and charged with parading without a permit, an infraction legally less serious than a misdemeanor.
"I was really shocked," he said. "When it comes to disagreeing with the dominant view, your rights are really out the window. They can do whatever they want -- they're the police."
It was his first arrest. He spent Saturday night and Sunday morning in a holding cell in the bowels of the District of Columbia Superior Court before he paid a $50 fine and was freed. He had had no water to drink, he said, and only a doughnut to eat. But he had plenty of time to ponder his part in this weekend's street protests in Washington, in the diffuse movement for "economic justice" -- if it is a movement -- and the police reaction to it.
Mr. Saltz was raised in Yorba Linda, Calif., not far from Richard Nixon's family home. His family is a pure product of the American Dream, he said. But he began to get ideas about politics in grade school that were a little outside the mainstream in Southern California.
"I started getting interested in activism in the third grade," he said. Sprawling developments cutting into mountain lions' habitat first fired his imagination. He became interested in the Sierra Club and the radical ecology group Earth First. He started a political magazine as a high school freshman. His work drew anonymous death threats, he said.
"In 1994, before I went to college, there was the Zapatista uprising" in southern Mexico. The small but politically savvy rural guerrilla movement, linked to the outside world by e-mail, demanded land rights for Mexican peasants and protested the North American Free Trade Agreement. That set Mr. Saltz studying, as he put it, "how globalization creates a movement like the Zapatistas, a globalized activism."
When he went off to the University of Oregon, his thinking connected with what he calls "this strange coalition" that drew thousands of protesters like him to Seattle in November and to Washington this weekend. It is a collection of advocates for ecology and self-declared anarchists, traditional leftists and mainstream labor unions and dozens more groups deeply skeptical of the forces of globalization.
Sitting on a park bench today in downtown Washington, two blocks from the White House and four from the World Bank, he reflected on his experience in Seattle, where he was not arrested, and on the crowd in Washington, and said, "I'm beginning to call this a movement.
"It could break apart as easily as it came together," he said, "but it feels like it's coming together. In Seattle it was just forming. Now there seems to be a coherent, cohesive idea -- economic justice. The World Trade Organization was something to latch onto. It represents what we reject: an economy that is becoming less and less democratic.
"Governments are repressing movements for economic democracy like the Zapatistas. In this country, the government is cutting social spending. We're doing away with welfare, doing away with job security. There's more and more temporary work, jobs that don't provide a living wage. The economy's creating more billionaires, but there's a huge, growing gap between the rich and poor."
"I don't know if the movement is at the point of proposing a model," he said. "Maybe it's fair trade. Maybe it's getting people to think about what they buy, whether whatever they're buying is made in sweatshops or under exploitative conditions. Maybe it's getting people to see they have the power to change things."
For himself, in the future, it may be a career as a labor organizer, or working abroad in poor villages, maybe in Mexico, he said.
For today, it was enough to get out of jail and back into the streets and their continuing political carnival tinged with confrontation.
"I'm still trying to figure out for myself what the answer is," he said.

HEADLINE: Technology Sell-Off May Bring Shakeout of Dot-Com Concerns

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The steep drop last week in the price of technology stocks, punctuating a three-week slide, may mark a turning point in perceptions. Unless the technology shares rebound quickly, the Internet industry will no longer be seen as a sure thing for investors and entrepreneurs hoping to cash in quickly.
A few bad days were one thing. But with the shares of many leading technology companies now down by 40 or 50 percent in less than a month, the sell-off is causing anxiety across the New Economy -- even if many experts predict that Internet technology will continue its inexorable expansion into virtually all parts of the old economy. 
 Indeed, the long-predicted winnowing of dot-com companies now seems at hand, according to venture capitalists, industry executives and economists. The term "Internet" in a business plan, they say, will no longer assure funding for a start-up or a quick welcome in the stock market.
A more sober investment environment, they add, is not likely to slow the development or spread of Internet technology across the economy. The Internet, they point out, is a low-cost communications network that promises to curb inflation over the next decade, lift productivity and enhance the efficiency of business throughout the economy -- benefits, they say, that will be as valuable when the stock market opens this morning as they were a week, a month or a year ago.
Yet the underlying trend may provide scant comfort for investors. Fundamental technologies in the past -- railroads, electricity and automobiles -- have been marked by investment euphoria, waves of start-ups, fierce competition and harrowing shakeouts. An investment mania in Britain in the 1840's helped build that nation's railway system, but it eventually left a trail of corporate bankruptcies. From 1900 to 1925, there were more than 3,000 automobile start-ups in America turning out all manner of cars -- from three-wheel models to ones steered by shiplike tillers.
And today's technology investors have no assurance that the worst is over. Even after last week's decline, technology share prices are still far higher than other sectors. As of Friday's close, the ratio of the stock price to expected earnings for the 72 information technology companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was more than 41. That was nearly twice the level for the S.& P. 500 index as a whole.
"Maybe technology stocks are still overvalued by 25 percent or 50 percent or more; only the stock market can give us that answer," said Richard Shaffer, principal of Technologic Partners, a research firm. "But that fundamental shift of business onto the Internet in the last few years is a direction that is here to stay for years to come."
On Silicon Valley's Sand Hill Road, the Wall Street of the venture capital industry, there is no panic. But there is the view among venture capital veterans that another industry cycle may well be beginning -- as occurred in 1983, after the shares of personal computer companies swooned, and in 1987, after the stock market collapse in October, when the money pouring into venture funds slowed. Such a prospect means that fledgling Internet start-ups without profits may no longer be welcomed on Wall Street only a year or two after they were founded.
So venture capitalists -- who supply early funding to start-up companies in return for an ownership stake in them -- may be taking a more back-to-basics approach in the future. Venture capitalists may begin picking fewer companies to back and nurturing them longer to maturity, before they try to sell shares to the public in initial public offerings.
The changing environment for start-ups is making some would-be entrepreneurs anxious. At the Harvard Business School, last year's graduates plunged with abandon into the Internet revolution, especially those who helped found 35 start-up companies including Guru.com, UBUBU.com and eFrenzy.com. This spring, the class of 2000 seemed to be on a similar path -- until last week.
"The students are scared to death," William A. Sahlman, a professor at the business school and the co-chairman of Harvard's entrepreneurial studies program, said last Friday.
He noted that three groups of worried students considering start-ups had visited him in recent days, seeking his advice. "Right now, I'd say we'll have half the number of start-ups out of this year's class, compared with last year," he said. "And that's probably not a bad thing."
Longtime venture capitalists say a more measured approach would be a positive development, even if it would also mean waiting longer to cash in. Instead of investing $20 million in a start-up that goes public a year later, they might have to invest $100 million over three or four years in a new company before selling its shares to the public. And they may have to be ready to pull the plug on less-promising start-ups.
"A lot of the recent crop of dot-com companies will go under, and others will be sent to the fat farm," Michael Moritz, a partner in the venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, said. "But it's a tonic -- however painful its administration may be for some -- that is pretty healthy."
Investors in venture capital funds -- each of which typically backs many companies -- normally have their money tied up for five years or more. The funds are open only to wealthy individuals and institutional investors. The perspective of venture investors is a world apart from that of day traders. So it would take time before a lasting reversal on Wall Street affected the way business is done in the venture capital industry.
In 1999, venture capital funds in the United States raised $46.5 billion, up from $27.9 billion the year before. The surge in venture money actually invested in companies was even more striking -- to $48.3 billion last year from $19.2 billion in 1998.
Until now, the rate of venture investment has accelerated further. In the last 30 days, there were 670 new venture capital investments totaling $10.2 billion, or a rate of roughly $2 billion a week, reports VentureWire.com, which tracks the industry.
Yet as the technology-stock euphoria fades, venture capitalists say they expect the flood of money into venture funds to ease off. And if there is a lasting slowdown in Wall Street's enthusiasm for high-technology share offerings, there could be an end to the stratospheric returns some funds have racked up by taking companies public quickly and reinvesting in still more start-ups. Over the years, the average annual return of leading venture capital funds has been around 20 percent, compared with the 100 percent or more some have enjoyed in the last year or two.
Experienced venture capitalists have long recognized that a return to earth in technology companies was inevitable. But as investors who have benefited enormously from the run-up, they have mixed feelings about the steep falloff recently.
"I'm torn," said John Shoch, a partner in Alloy Ventures. "Sure, it's healthy to take the froth out of the market. But at the same time, we have four or five companies that are lined up to go public over the next few months."
Several Internet companies, including AltaVista, the Web directory and search site, have already postponed plans to sell shares.
Still, turmoil in the stock market does not mean venture capital funding will dry up. Even late last week, some companies went public. One start-up that Mr. Shoch's firm funded, Nuance Communications, went public last Thursday. Its offering price of $17 a share nearly doubled on the first day of trading, closing at just under $34. On Friday, when technology stocks plummeted, Nuance rose slightly, to $34.3125 a share.
Nuance, based in Menlo Park, Calif., has developed technology for making voice-recognition software work more efficiently. It is a promising technology, since new companies are trying to make voices and telephones -- not keyboards -- the main means of access to the Internet. At the same time, old-economy companies like banks and telephone companies hope to use the technology to further automate their operations.
"The environment is going to get more challenging," Mr. Shoch said. "But real companies with real technology and real businesses will get funded -- rest assured."
Such start-ups, venture capitalists say, will attract funds because investors are willing to bet that they are making technological building blocks for the Internet economy, and thus poised for strong growth.
The big shakeout among dot-com companies is expected to be among the consumer Web sites and services that raced to establish themselves as Internet brand names. In selected market niches, they have all tried to be the "next Amazon," and most, of course, will fail.
The economic impact of the winnowing will likely be healthy. As one venture capitalist noted: "It will mean we have two or three Web sites selling pet supplies instead of seven. That's hardly a loss."
That Darwinian process is familiar to many. In the early 1980's, there was a surge of investment in companies in the PC industry, which ended abruptly in the summer of 1983 when technology stocks collapsed. Companies with now-forgotten names like Eagle Computer, Northstar Computer, Kaypro, Word Star, Vector Graphics, Priam and Miniscribe fell by the wayside during the shakeout that followed.
"But out of each one of these cycles of investment frenzy and turmoil, a handful of tremendous companies have emerged -- Microsoft, Dell, Sun Microsystems, Cisco, Oracle and others," Mr. Moritz of Sequoia Capital observed. "And the same thing will happen this time."
The focus of venture capital investments in the Internet has already shifted from businesses that sell directly to consumers to businesses that help other businesses to work more efficiently. The so-called business-to-business market has long been regarded as the largest -- and most economically significant -- market for Internet technology.
As a low-cost communications network linking businesses worldwide, the Internet is expected to reduce the cost of materials, inventory management and product development.
The Internet's impact in overhauling this "back office" of the global economy is uncertain and just beginning. But most economists believe it will make a notable impact over time, just as electricity only really made a big difference to industry when factories were reorganized for mass production. A recent study by the Goldman Sachs investment firm concluded that business-to-business electronic commerce could reduce average prices across the economies of the five richest nations by nearly 4 percent over a decade or more.
It is no small irony, though, that the sure winners from the continued spread of Internet commerce are old-economy companies, whose operations are being retooled. (Another big class of winners is consumers, who benefit from lower prices.) As with past innovations, from railways to cars, the companies that supply the technology itself can be very risky investments indeed.
Back at Harvard, what did Mr. Sahlman say to the students considering start-ups but scared by the stock market's loss of faith?
"I told them that if you have a good idea and a top team of people and can attract the backing of a blue-chip venture capital firm, then there is no real personal risk," he said. "Even if the business fails, it can only be great learning experience in a part of the economy that is sure to become more and more important.
"But then," Mr. Sahlman noted, "it is harder to take that advice than to give it. After all, I'm a tenured professor."

HEADLINE: Family in Texas Challenges Mandatory School Drug Test

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: LOCKNEY, Tex.

 BODY:
For three years, people in this tiny farming town fretted that stopping the local drug problem was like trying to lasso the winds that blow day and night off the flat Texas plains. Teachers complained of students' getting stoned at lunch. Parents worried about peer pressure at school to get high.
Eventually, after an emotional public meeting and demands that something be done, the school board here enacted what is considered the toughest school drug testing policy in the nation. It requires that all junior and senior high school students take a mandatory drug test. There is no choice; refusal by a parent or student draws the same punishment as failure to pass the test, an in-school suspension for first offenders. 
 Now, as many other school districts across the country institute drug tests, Lockney, with only 2,200 residents, has become an unlikely constitutional battleground. A parent, aided by the American Civil Liberties Union, filed a lawsuit in March asserting that the policy violated his and his son's Fourth Amendment rights prohibiting unreasonable searches. Arguments in the case could be heard as soon as this summer by a federal judge.
"They cannot tell me how I'm supposed to believe," said the parent, Larry Tannahill, 35, whose 12-year-old son, Brady, attends the junior high. "I believe in the Constitution. And because I believe in our Constitution and our rights, you're going to punish my son? I don't think so."
Since 1995, when the United States Supreme Court opened the door to drug testing in schools by permitting the testing of athletes, the unanswered question has been where would schools, and ultimately the court, draw the line.
Until now, school districts had been tentative in pushing the boundaries, particularly because legal challenges to wider testing are pending in Oklahoma, New Jersey and other states. But Lockney's policy of testing every student has shattered any boundaries.
"If the policy has no teeth, there's no use having it," said Donald G. Henslee, the lawyer representing the Lockney Independent School District. Mr. Henslee said at least a dozen other Texas districts had inquired about instituting a similar policy.
For Mr. Tannahill, the controversy has made clear the tensions that can arise when an individual challenges the will of the majority, particularly in a small town. He and his wife, Traci, are the only parents who are fighting the policy. He was dismissed from his job as a farm worker, though his former employer says the firing was unrelated to the lawsuit, and he has found a threatening note outside his home. Some people have invited the Tannahills to leave town.
Up and down Main Street, people say they do not wish Mr. Tannahill any harm, but they cannot believe one person should stop them from doing what they believe is in the best interests of their children. To many parents, the drug test is a "tool" to provide students a reason to resist peer pressure to drink or do drugs. The debate over constitutional rights seems secondary to many people.
"I don't feel like it's violating my rights for my kid to be tested," said Kelly Prayor, 35, who has two children and is a teller at the local bank. "As far as my kids' rights, they're not responsible. What rights do they have? They don't have a right to drink or do drugs."
Lockney, which is between Lubbock and Amarillo, is a tiny spot in the agricultural sea of the Texas plains, which stretch to the horizon, interrupted only by telephone poles and windmills and, occasionally, a tree. The local schools are the biggest employer, and the red logo of the Lockney Longhorns, the high school, is painted on the two water towers and displayed in the rear windshields of many of the trucks rumbling through town.
People in Lockney do not believe that drugs are any worse here than in other small towns, but the issue has generated attention for several years. In 1997, nearly 300 people attended a public meeting to discuss drugs. A year later, 12 people were charged with selling cocaine, an event that stunned the town.
By then, school officials were studying drug testing policies, including those in several surrounding towns. Most of the policies involved testing students for extracurricular activities. One nearby town with such a policy, Tulia, is continuing the testing even as it is under challenge in federal court.
But Lockney officials were intrigued by another town, Sundown, which instituted a mandatory testing policy for all students in 1998 that has yet to be challenged. Last December, the Lockney school board approved its own mandatory policy and notified parents that testing would begin in February. Under the plan, all junior and senior high students would take a urine test and submit to random follow-up tests. Employees of the district also undergo the tests.
Today, all 388 students in junior and senior high schools in Lockney have taken the text except Brady. School officials would not say how many tested positive other than to describe the number as a "Texas handful." The in-school suspensions given to first-time offenders last three days and require students to complete their class work in a separate room. They also undergo drug counseling and are suspended from all school activities for three weeks. Repeat offenders face longer suspensions, though not expulsion.
Julie Underwood, general counsel for the National School Boards Association in Washington, called the Lockney policy "about as broad as it could ever be," saying it resulted from the "slippery slope" created by the Supreme Court's ruling allowing testing of athletes. Since then, Ms. Underwood said, the court has resisted clarifying the parameters for testing and has sent mixed signals.
In October 1998, the court let stand a lower court ruling enabling an Indiana school district to require a drug test for students participating in after-school activities. But last March, the court dealt a blow to another Indiana school by leaving intact a lower court ruling that prohibited the school from requiring suspended students to take a drug test before resuming classes.
"School districts don't know exactly how far they can take this," Ms. Underwood said. "There hasn't been a definitive ruling by the Supreme Court on mandatory testing or random drug testing by school districts."
Eric E. Sterling, president of the nonprofit Criminal Justice Policy Foundation in Washington, predicted that more districts would emulate Lockney as more parents felt helpless to prevent their children from using drugs. Mr. Sterling said the policy could be a deterrent for some students but he cautioned that it could further alienate students at risk of taking drugs. He said the "presumption of guilt" created by the policy flies in the face of the Pledge of Allegiance that students recite every morning.
"Their sense of liberty and what liberty means will be offended every time they're asked to provide a urine specimen without any cause that they're using drugs," he said.
A lanky, laconic man, Mr. Tannahill says he is hardly a rebel, but he fears his neighbors are too eager to give up their rights. He said that he had not used drugs and that he did not oppose some sort of drug testing policy, though not mandatory. His stance seems far more libertarian than liberal: he also says that growing gun control efforts violate the constitutional right to bear arms.
His family has lived in Lockney for four generations, and he calls the town "a good little community." Yet he was incensed that under the school testing policy his refusal to sign a parental consent form meant that Brady was considered guilty.
"I'm tired of letting our rights just be taken away," said Mr. Tannahill, whose younger son, Coby, 11, attends the town's elementary school. "They are taking my rights away as a parent, telling me I had to do this or my son would be punished. That's what really got to me."
Mr. Tannahill, who graduated from Lockney High, added, "The teacher taught me that if you give up your rights, and you're not going to fight for them, you'll lose them."
Mr. Henslee, the school district's lawyer, said the board was reconsidering its stance on parents who refuse to give consent. He said the board remained committed to mandatory testing but was considering alternatives to punishments attached to cases like the Tannahills'. Brady has been allowed to continue his normal classes and activities, pending the result of the lawsuit.
Mr. Tannahill, meanwhile, is struggling with life as a pariah. He said he had gotten friendly phone calls or quiet nods from some people, but few support him publicly. His wife works as a clerk at a nearby prison. Unemployed, he builds miniature barns and windmills at home that he hopes to sell on the Internet. He said his sons had been treated well at school, as if nothing had happened, but he remained wary.
Several weeks ago, the family's pet boxer was sprayed with orange paint from a paint gun. Mr. Tannahill said he found a note outside his house that read, "You're messing with our children, and next time maybe this won't be a paint gun."
At a school board meeting in March, Mr. Tannahill and his lawyer unsuccessfully asked the board to change its policy. Hundreds of people packed into the Lockney Independent School District's high school gymnasium for the meeting, many of them wearing T-shirts that read: "We asked for it. L.I.S.D. delivered it. We appreciate it." Speaker after speaker extolled the policy to loud applause until Mr. Tannahill's lawyer was greeted with stony silence.
"If looks could kill, me and my family would have been dead a long time ago," Mr. Tannahill said.
Graham Boyd, a civil liberties union lawyer who is representing Mr. Tannahill, asserted that the policy had many failings, including that a urine test does not detect all drugs. But beyond the legal questions, Mr. Boyd said he was surprised at the tensions that had arisen.
"This isn't about race or religion or one of the things you would expect to inflame a community," he said. "This is about drug testing a 12-year-old boy."
People in Lockney say Mr. Tannahill is not in any danger, though a few concede they would not mind if he left. Residents described the drug policy as a common-sense solution to help children resist drugs. A few people expressed doubts about the policy, but an overwhelming majority of parents and students agreed with Jordan Lambert, a senior and the quarterback of the football team.
"I think it's great," Jordan said. "I don't see how we're being forced to when we're more than willing. Ninety-eight percent of the student body is more than willing. Nobody is being forced to."
