HEADLINE: FINANCIAL LEADERS MEET AS PROTESTS CLOG WASHINGTON

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Thousands of protesters trying to shut down meetings of world financial leaders swarmed through the streets of the capital today, sealed off from their target by a virtual wall of police officers. A few brief clashes ensued, but for the most part, a day that some had feared would descend into chaos passed peacefully.
The finance ministers and other delegates from around the world were loaded onto buses early this morning and escorted by the police so their meetings could take place as scheduled. This evening, they tacitly acknowledged the shouting on the streets by conceding in a communique issued by the International Monetary Fund that their role had become a matter "of growing public debate." 
 They acknowledged a widespread fear that "the benefits of the world economy" are "not reaching everyone, especially in the developing countries." But they offered no new prescriptions, other than some reforms of the I.M.F.'s internal operations that are already under way.
Unlike on Saturday, when the police arrested some 600 people, today they arrested fewer than 20, but responded forcefully to any challenges, wielding clubs and pepper spray against protesters who defied them. Several were injured. But on several occasions, police officers did back off when challenged, effectively defusing conflicts.
All weekend long, the police acted sternly and pre-emptively, shutting down the protest headquarters early Saturday morning, making mass arrests of even peaceful marchers by that evening and shunting hordes of protesters around today. The combination allowed the police here mostly to avoid the kind of widespread chaos that disrupted world trade meetings in Seattle last year, a feat the protesters said they had hoped to repeat.
The 1,500 or so officers from city and federal agencies, many in riot gear, sealed off an area for many blocks around the buildings housing the World Bank and the I.M.F., standing shoulder to shoulder behind fence-like metal barricades.
On the other side of the barricades, demonstrators roamed almost at will, hoisting giant puppets and signs -- a pig labeled I.M.F. with the world in its mouth like an apple, red hands that said "spank the bank" -- and accusing the financial institutions of burdening poor third world countries with crushing debts, impoverishing peasants, destroying rain forests, supporting sweatshops and other policies that, as one sign put it, "sap the poor to fatten the rich."
For most of the day, the protests were peaceful. About 10,000 people gathered on the grassy Ellipse for a rally calling for changes in the world financial systems.
But there were at least two short, sharp clashes between police officers and demonstrators, where the officers used pepper spray and what appeared to be a form of anti-riot gas or smoke grenades and charged into protesters beating them with long sticks. And there were other moments of tension.
Mayor Anthony A. Williams said this evening that the police had acted with appropriate force when challenged today, and that the mass arrests of peaceful protesters the night before were justified as a matter of prudence.
"But it is like steering a raft down a raging river," he said. "You can control it, but then the unexpected can happen."
The Federal Office of Personnel Management said today that only essential personnel should report to work inside the protest zone on Monday. Many federal offices, like the Treasury Department, are in that area.
"It is a serious situation," Mr. Williams said. "It is simmering down, but again, people have been on the street for a long time, so nerves are frazzled. There is a sense of anxiety and anticipation."
Despite failing to achieve their avowed goal of blocking the finance ministers from attending the meeting, by late afternoon many of the protesters were jubilant at the attention drawn to their sometimes diffuse cause, which drew many of the same groups that descended on Seattle. Although many of the protesters were from no particular organization, demonstrators included people from a religious group Jubilee 2000, United Students Against Sweatshops, big labor unions and ad hoc coalitions like Global Exchange, 50 Years is Enough and the Ruckus Society.
"We're having a victory party in the street," said Patrick Rensborough, one of the spokesmen for the Mobilization for Global Justice, the umbrella organization coordinating the protest.
"We're celebrating that this movement has come about," he went on, standing at the edge of the rally in the Ellipse that went for most of the afternoon. "A few days ago most Americans didn't know the first thing about the World Bank or the I.M.F. These institutions can't survive public scrutiny. This is the first step toward shutting them down."
While the marchers paraded below with their signs bearing slogans like "Defund the Fund," the leaders of the I.M.F. were upstairs arguing over different issues, including who should get a bigger voice in running the institution.
Japan staged a minor rebellion aimed at winning a larger voice for itself and other Asian nations in the fund's operations. Tokyo had put up a candidate to run the I.M.F. earlier this year, although by tradition the managing director has always been a European. (The World Bank has always been directed by an American.) Though the effort did not get very far today, the world's second-largest economy was clearly laying down a marker that it no longer planned to acquiesce to the old order. "There's a sense that this has always been a white man's club," one senior Japanese official said recently, "and that needs some rethinking."
Meanwhile, several leaders of smaller nations said during the meeting that they were alarmed by reform proposals -- including those developed by a Congressional commission -- that would limit the size and duration of the fund's loans during economic crises. They fear that it would reduce the money made available to them.
The contrast with the message being delivered by demonstrators outside could not have been sharper. While developing nations fear that the fund's money could dry up, many of those on the street were arguing that the same money hurts the poor because it often comes with so many strings attached.
The communique issued at the end of the meeting bore no surprises. But it clearly anticipated the din outside. It acknowledged that the growing debate over the future of the fund and the World Bank "reflects a concern that the benefits the world economy is deriving from freer trade and more integrated and deeper international capital markets are not reaching everyone."
But in the end, it prescribed the kind of changes the fund says it is already pursuing: more disclosure about the financial state of member countries, more involvement of the private sector in international bailouts, a crackdown on the kind of misreporting of financial data that took the I.M.F. by surprise in its dealings with Russia.
It called for closer work with the World Bank "to lead in helping countries to develop policies to combat poverty and improve social conditions," carefully steering clear of the arguments over how much of that responsibility should fall to the bank, the traditional poverty-fighter, and how much to the fund, which manages international financial crises.
Even before the sun came up, clumps of 20 or 30 demonstrators were moving through the streets toward assembly points at Farragut Park and Washington Circle. By 7 a.m. they had blocked all of the intersections around the police perimeter, erecting barricades near the George Washington University campus. They used tipped-over garbage containers, old furniture and about dozen bags of mulch intended for the university's gardens, placed like sandbags.
But police officers were up even earlier. They began picking up the finance ministers and other delegates at the Watergate, the Four Seasons and other luxury hotels as early as 5 a.m., loading them into buses and vans and shuttling them in caravans escorted by motorcycles and cars, lights flashing and sirens wailing, by circuitous routes that took them through the sealed-off stretch of Pennsylvania Avenue past the White House and two blocks further to the I.M.F. meeting.
With the meeting safely under way, the police tactics for most of the day consisted mainly of maintaining their perimeter. On Saturday, they had moved aggressively to shut down the protesters' headquarters, declaring that it was a "fire hazard" and arresting some 600 people after boxing them in on the street.
Worried over the chaotic Seattle protests against the World Trade Organization last fall, the police have been training for weeks, have bought $1 million worth of new equipment, including shin guards, chest protectors and big gauntlets, and expect a $1.6 million overtime bill.
The demonstrators, including several hundred self-styled anarchists dressed solidly in black to their combat boots, most with sweatshirt hoods and bandana masks obscuring their faces, marched and wandered throughout the largely deserted downtown. At the midpoint of a sunny afternoon, protesters from the Ellipse rally merged with a crowd coming from the George Washington campus into a huge parade, chanting "This is what democracy looks like."
The crowd was overwhelmingly young, many organized on college campuses. And there were a few graying veterans of 1960's demonstrations, including the comedian Dick Gregory and Tom Hayden, one of the organizers of the 1968 Democratic convention protests and now a California state senator.
"It's inspiring," said Dan Swanson, 47, who marched with Students for a Democratic Society in his youth. "They're much more disciplined and aware than we were at that age."
The most serious clash between protesters and the police came a little after 10 o'clock in the morning as a group of about 250 black-clad anarchists merged with a larger group of protesters, and then suddenly began dragging trash containers and newspaper vending boxes into the street to form a barricade on 14th Street near New York Avenue.
As the police at first backed off, the anarchists seized several sections of barbed wire topped chain-link fence that the officers had been using as a partial barricade and, holding it before them, charged north toward a phalanx of officers in riot gear, some on motorcycles.
The officers, in turn, charged toward the demonstrators, with the motorcycles plowing over the chain link fence and into the crowd. Someone threw an orange traffic cone, knocking an officer off his motorcycle. Others threw rocks or bottles. Briefly on the defensive, the police officers waded in, nightsticks swinging, and overwhelmed the crowd in a melee that lasted about 15 minutes.
Suddenly a stinging, biting gas enveloped the crowd. The police denied using tear gas, although journalists at the scene said canisters appeared to come from the police side.
At a news conference tonight, protest leaders said the police had used tear gas in the incident. They showed a video of an officer clubbing a young woman, and said some of those arrested last night were held on buses for 14 hours. But they also praised senior police commanders for keeping their officers calm and avoiding confrontation.

HEADLINE: Financial Struggles At Medical Clinics For the City's Poor

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
A small health care revolution that has brought dozens of badly needed family doctors to new clinics in New York City's poorest neighborhoods is beginning to unravel, health and hospital experts say.
The clinics had been multiplying in the city since the early 1990's, embraced as an efficient and affordable alternative to hospital emergency rooms, an all-too-frequent source of basic care for poor patients. But they have been seriously undermined in the last few years by a sea change in health care financing, the experts said. 
 Many clinics are struggling to stay open, and hospitals are abandoning plans to build new ones. Last year, the number of applications for new primary-care sites was down 38 percent from 1995, according to State Health Department documents.
All the clinics have been hit hard by a rapid rise in uninsured patients in the last few years -- 27 percent of city residents under 65 lack insurance, according to the latest figures -- who can pay little, if anything, for care. Further, health centers that serve the poor have been hammered by heavy reductions in reimbursements from managed-care companies and from the Medicaid program, which pays the bills for the majority of the clinics' paying patients.
"The burst of development in primary care in poor neighborhoods that we saw five or six years ago has disappeared," said Dr. Spencer Foreman, president of Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, which has set up at least a dozen clinics. "At that time, people had money and they thought it was a good thing to do. But development has slowed way, way down, because we have run out of resources."
Indeed, 80 percent of the community health care clinics in New York City lost money at some point over the last four years, said John Billings, director of the Center for Health and Public Service Research at New York University.
The difficulty in maintaining a strong primary-care network is being felt in many other parts of the country, which all face the same financial hurdles, Professor Billings said. "It is much the same around the nation," he said, adding that some states, however, have committed more money to the problem.
What is more, a new report from the Community Service Society of New York found that the number of doctors in private practice in poor neighborhoods had barely budged in a decade, and had actually fallen in some areas. The report found a shortage of roughly 300 primary-care doctors in poor neighborhoods.
It was not supposed to turn out this way. During the 1990's, the number of primary-care doctors practicing in the city rose 20 percent, according to the Center for Health Workforce Studies at the State University at Albany. Dozens of primary-care clinics run by hospitals dotted the city, and the Primary Care Development Corporation, a private-public partnership, was founded to help the hospitals and others set up centers in underserved neighborhoods by providing tax-free bonds.
The clinics were envisioned as a more cost-effective way to provide routine care. With no doctors within miles, many New Yorkers had been turning to emergency rooms for basic care -- a costly and medically inefficient way to manage chronic diseases like asthma that poor people are often afflicted with.
"Primary care remains the most effective, cost-efficient way to deliver proper continuity of care," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society.
At the same time, hospitals in poor neighborhoods that were training residents watched as those doctors fled to other parts of the city, or even to other states.
"We were finding we could not attract our residents to stay in the Bronx," Dr. Foreman said. "It was perceived as being a troubled place to work, and what was frightening is that they would invest money opening up shop and then not be able to earn a living. So we took away the risk by opening up these centers for them."
With the same goals in mind, the Primary Care Development Corporation was formed in 1994 under Mayor David N. Dinkins to set up clinics in poor neighborhoods. When Rudolph W. Giuliani took office the next year, the clinic project was one of the few Dinkins initiatives he embraced. Through tax-free bonds and small loans, the corporation helps hospitals and other groups get centers off the ground. The corporation has helped finance 21 existing clinics around the city, and 6 more are under construction.
For patients like Sharaz Said, a Palestinian immigrant, the clinic that opened near her home in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, a modest building on a lot where an auto parts shop once sat, is about as close to medical nirvana that she has come. The Park Ridge Family Health Center was set up by the corporation in conjunction with Lutheran Medical Center.
After two years of taking her five children to the hospital for every minor illness, Mrs. Said now gets an appointment a few hours after calling Park Ridge. She sees the same doctor over and over. Her children are on an immunization schedule, and were enrolled by the center in an insurance program sponsored by the state. And once in a while, there is someone working at the front desk who speaks Arabic. There is even a tiny mosque set up at the clinic, because staff members noticed many of the patients -- a mix of Arabs, Chinese and Latinos -- praying in the hallways. "They make it very easy," said Mrs. Said.
But like most of the clinics that the Primary Care Development Corporation has helped finance, Park Ridge operates on very thin margins, and struggles to look for fat to trim in a system that is flooded with patients who have few other alternatives for good care.
Other clinics have even more uncertain futures -- Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, which serves an impoverished East Brooklyn community, is considering shuttering its clinics, a spokesman said.
So the corporation must now focus much of its effort on giving existing clinics technical help with a variety of tasks, including proper billing procedures and getting patients in and out speedily.
"Our hope is that as government policy and reimbursement rates get set, the rates for primary care get sufficient attention," said Richard Cotton, the corporation's chairman. "At this point we have been able to support proposals, but we are talking about a very thin margin of safety."
In a perfect world, of course, every patient could see a private doctor in a private office. But those doctors rarely set up shop in poor neighborhoods.
Many parts of the Bronx have few doctors in private practice. The Community Service Society study found that the number of doctors in Morris Heights, for example, has fallen 45 percent since 1990. In Soundview, the number has fallen 32 percent. Carlos Gutzman, who is 22 and lives in that neighborhood, said he had never seen the inside of a private doctor's office. He takes two buses to Lincoln Hospital when he gets very sick. "I guess a private doctor is great," he said, "but I don't know about them."
Because the pay is low, the best young primary-care doctors are usually not attracted to private practice in poor neighborhoods. So many patients end up getting care at places like the Family Health Center on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, where Dr. Hoi Yat Kam labors in his tiny office, with a small examination table wedged against the wall.
During a recent visit, the employees' lunch was splayed out on an exam table near a hardback chair where patients sit for their tests, in a dismal room where medical assistants give shots and take blood. No gowns are used; patients simply lift a shirt or a pant leg to show their problem. Boxes of drugs sit in tumbling piles on the floor.
Few doctors who have hung shingles in poor neighborhoods have connections to area hospitals, and so they are unable to admit patients, the Community Service Society found. The report also found that 70 percent of the doctors in private practice in underserved neighborhoods practice less than 16 hours a week, making care that much harder to come by. They usually do not have relationships with specialists to refer their patients to, and lack many of the resources that doctors working in large medical centers enjoy.
The lack of a specialist referral system further hinders any continuity of care in these practices. For example, Dr. Mario Perodin, a Bronx pediatrician, said he had sent patients with complex problems to the local emergency room with a note. "It is a crummy way to do it, and the worst part is that the hospitals do not send me reports," he said.
Dr. Ethan Wiener, who is a pediatrics fellow in the South Bronx and said he was devoted to caring for the poor, nonetheless believes that it will be almost impossible to open a private practice in a poor neighborhood once he strikes out on his own.
"If it were a financially viable model, I think a lot more people would be doing it," he said. "The clinic is a much better model for those communities, because it does provide the referral base. I think I like the idea of working within a team because we can provide a whole variety of support services."
Most health care experts point to the Primary Care Development Corporation as the most viable solution to the primary-care problem. Gov. George E. Pataki has earmarked some of the revenue from the state's increased cigarette tax to provide insurance to some state residents, which will help lessen their burden on the clinics.
However, as Medicaid patients are moved into managed-care plans, a money-saving goal of New York State, that gain could be offset because managed-care companies often pay lower reimbursement rates than the government, experts said.
"Here is a system where the numbers sound like a crisis, and we are in the middle of the good times," Professor Billings said. "There are a lot of people who day to day teeter on the edge, and one wonders what will happen when the economy goes south."

HEADLINE: First-Quarter Earnings Beat Expectations At 2 Banks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bank of America and Bank of New York reported first-quarter profits yesterday that beat expectations, powered by surging stocks. After last week's sell-off, however, they might be hard-pressed to post similarly strong future results. 
 Earnings at Bank of America rose 17 percent. Bank of New York, the world's largest securities processor, said its profit rose 6.8 percent.
For the big banks, whose earnings are sensitive to swings in the debt and stock markets, the first-quarter results may represent a high-water mark. Rising interest rates and last week's stock market rout could crimp results in coming quarters.
"It's somewhat of a live by the sword, die by the sword," said Harold Schroeder, a bank analyst at Schroeder & Company in New York.
Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., said higher fees from its securities unit and gains from its investments in companies pushed net income to $2.24 billion, or $1.33 a diluted share, compared with $1.91 billion, or $1.08 a share, in the period a year earlier.
Analysts had expected the bank to earn $1.24 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
The bank has become increasingly dependent on business outside its traditional lending operations. In the first quarter, noninterest income grew 26 percent, to $4.05 billion, and was 47 percent of total revenue, up from 41 percent a year earlier.
Fees from underwriting securities rose 149 percent as the company benefited from the bull market and a flood of initial public offerings in the first quarter.
Noninterest expense increased 4 percent, to $4.62 billion, as the company spent $201 million more to pay employees.
Net interest income fell 1 percent, to $4.6 billion, as the bank made less money on some of its assets, pushing its net interest yield down 0.31 percentage points, to 3.27 percent.
Shares of Bank of America rose 37.5 cents, to $50.3125.
At the Bank of New York, net income rose 6.8 percent, to a record $338 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $316 million, or 41 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. That beat analysts' estimates by a penny, according to First Call.
The bank, which handles more than $700 billion in securities for almost 30,000 clients worldwide, collects fees for holding stocks and bonds for clients and handling clerical duties like collecting dividend payments. Those fees from securities processing rose 28 percent, to $372 million, lifting total noninterest income 18 percent, to $737 million.
Growth in clients' portfolios helped increase assets under custody to $6.7 trillion.
Net interest income rose 5.5 percent, to $460 million, as the net yield on interest earning assets narrowed to 2.89 percentage points from 3.18 percentage points.
Shares of Bank of New York rose 12.5 cents, to $39.5625.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Reaction Far Exceeded The Action

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
NOW that we have an actual transcript of what Bobby Valentine told business students at the University of Pennsylvania last week, we discover that his most incendiary comments were appropriately reserved for baseball economics.
According to yesterday's edition of The Daily Pennsylvanian, Valentine advocates the building of one new baseball stadium in New York, to be used jointly by the Yankees and Mets. 
 "This would get me in a lot of trouble with my owner," Valentine reportedly told the students. "I don't think there's any way the city of New York and the public is going to co-venture two buildings in excess of a billion dollars for these rich kids that run around with baseballs and rich owners that make a lot of money."
Fire him? For such fair-minded candor, Valentine should get honorary membership to the city's planning board.
Oh, Valentine fired off a few zingers about Mets past and present. He astutely observed that Bobby Bonilla "found his stroke and lost 45 pounds." He said that "some would say" Benny Agbayani could do more with 600 at-bats than (not by name) Derek Bell. He shockingly said he supported the signing of the Japanese reliever Kazuhiro Sasaki last winter.
 As John McEnroe would say, big deal. Even Brad34, whoever he is, e-pologized for spreading the v-mail out of context. And unless there is a video out there of Valentine choking a student-economist, Steve Phillips owes one to his manager, lest he be judged by the same flimsy standard that moved him to fly off to Pittsburgh, on a wing and a Web site posting.
It isn't as if the Mets' general manager hasn't been caught in his own little web. Based on Phillips's past dalliances that embarrassed the organization far more than the manager ever has, and required a temporary leave of absence, should the Mets conduct an investigation the next time he is spotted in conversation with a female employee at the office water cooler?
"I needed to get clarification," Phillips insisted yesterday, in a continued assault on dot.com sense.
The minute Phillips landed in Pittsburgh last Friday, he authenticated a voice in a vacuum. He made the story hotter than it ever had to be, without even bothering with a transcript or tape.
Unless he doesn't own a telephone or all of his scouting is this complete, the only explanation is that Phillips flew off to pursue his own agenda, relative to his fragile coexistence with Valentine. So who was wearing the disguise this time? "If it became a big deal, then it's a big deal," Valentine said yesterday. "Just like the mustache thing."
What he meant was that these incidents, fairly or not, inevitably become part of the count that will probably lead to Phillips calling him out on strikes. Donning that disguise last season after being ejected from a game has now become part of Valentine's permanent record, as if having a little fun now and then is anathema to the integrity of the game.
Here, then, are the current regulatory terms of our national pastime: Androstenedione and other potentially dangerous performance enhancements -- allowed. Fake nose and mustache -- not allowed. "This is a tough place not to be perfect for me," Valentine said, sounding somewhat resigned.
He's far, far from perfect, but the simplistic casting of Joe Torre as Abel of the dugout and Valentine as Cain has been carried too far. While Valentine dispenses nuggets of opinion free of charge, Torre has saved a few less flattering items for one of his books. He has been a superb manager, an inspirational saga, but Torre generally becomes a lot more charming when he's engaging in a power chat with the likes of George Will.
 Valentine is clearly more insecure, less discriminating. He'd talk to a lamppost, if it had ears. On the subject of his unquestioned managerial skills, he can be tough to listen to, but when the Wharton School students invited him to speak, he committed what is practically a capital crime in contemporary sports. He said yes, and didn't ask for an appearance fee.
"I was foolish to be there in the first place, I guess," Valentine said.
He is who he is. Like him or not, you can't dispute the argument that the Mets were a sorry, insipid sell until he moved into the manager's office and began chatting them up. More than anyone, including Phillips, he has given them the effrontery to reclaim their share of the baseball audience in New York.
"I know this is the entertainment industry," Phillips said of Valentine's knack for attention, "but my preference would always be to be a little duller than what we are."
He's one to talk.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1463 words

HEADLINE: Janitors Struggle at the Edges of Silicon Valley's Success

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
From 6 p.m. to 2 a.m. each night, Guadalupe Herrera cleans offices at that pinnacle of high-tech success, Cisco Systems, and then she heads home to the garage where she, her husband and two sons live.
When Maria Godinez returns late each night from her $8-an-hour janitor's job at Sun Microsystems, she slips into the bedroom she shares with her husband and five children: part of a single-family house where four families and 22 people live. 
 Rosalba Ceballos, who also lives in a garage, vacuums carpets and cleans bathrooms at another Silicon Valley success story, KLA-Tencor, but because her rent comes to three-fourths of that job's monthly pay she juggles two other jobs to support herself and her three children.
High-flying companies like Cisco and Sun can rightfully boast that they have created a new class of employees -- stock option millionaires -- but they have given rise to another class of workers as well: the invisible toilers, for the most part janitors, who earn too little to afford decent housing in a booming region.
"It's not good that these companies are making so much money, while they're benefiting from the low wages they pay us," said Mrs. Herrera, whose husband works as a $7-an-hour janitor at a nearby nursing home. "It's not fair that they do this with us. In reality, we need more."
The janitors, almost all of them immigrants from Mexico or Central America, many of them here illegally, are whipsawed by two powerful forces: the influx of immigrants is putting downward pressures on wages while the region's red-hot economy is pushing housing costs skyward. As a result, the rent that many janitors pay for garages usually exceeds half their monthly take-home pay and often equals what people elsewhere in the country pay for a two-bedroom apartment.
Many high-technology companies said they do not have any responsibility for their janitors' wages or living conditions. The janitors, company officials say, are not their employees, but rather those of cleaning contractors hired by the electronics companies that have made this region symbolize the New Economy.
Kern Beare, a spokesman for KLA-Tencor, declined to discuss the janitors' situation, saying, "The janitors are not our employees, and we don't comment upon other companies' employees."
Mike Garcia, president of a union local that represents thousands of California janitors, called the companies' position indefensible, insisting that they were hiding behind subcontracting rules to dodge their responsibilities to the people who empty their wastebaskets and dust their shelves. Whether the janitors work directly or indirectly for them, Mr. Garcia said, Silicon Valley stars like Cisco and Sun have a moral obligation to make sure these workers do not live in poverty.
"These companies have a heavy responsibility," said Mr. Garcia, president of Local 1877 of the Service Employees International Union. "They can try to hide behind their cleaning contractors, but what they should really do is take responsibility for the plight of their janitors and their poorest workers. They should give them a fair wage that will lift them out of poverty."
Mr. Garcia, a leader in his union's Justice for Janitors campaign, said something was wildly askew when Silicon Valley's elite raked in millions in stock options, while the workers who hold the grimiest, least desirable jobs earned so little that they lived in garages.
Amy Dean, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Silicon Valley office, said, "Unfortunately, the New Economy is looking a lot like an hourglass with a lot of high-paid, high-tech jobs at the high end and an enormous proliferation of low-wage service jobs at the bottom."
With rents here rivaling those in New York City, many janitors are relegated to squalid situations: eight people from two separate families sharing a small trailer; nine adults living in a one-bedroom apartment; a janitor sleeping on the floor of a friend's metal-working shop; a janitor who says the single small window in the garage she lives in makes her think she is living in a prison cell.
Although Ms. Ceballos was reluctant to show her windowless garage to a visitor, she ultimately opened it up. Behind a clutter of unpacked boxes was a bunk bed, with a queen-sized bottom, where she sleeps with her 1-year-old daughter, Alejandra, and a twin bed on top, where her other daughters, ages 3 and 7, sleep. Her 22-year-old brother, a janitor who helps her make ends meet, sleeps on a mattress they place on the floor each night.
Ms. Ceballos moved into the garage in February because she could no longer afford the $1,300-a-month house she was living in after her husband left her. At $750 a month, the garage, which is rented out illegally, is a huge financial strain since the take-home pay from her night cleaning job is $954 a month.
"It's very difficult for the kids," she said. "They really can't play inside, but at least they can play in the backyard."
Shoulders slumped and puffy bags under her eyes, Ms. Ceballos seemed nearly defeated. After returning from work each night at 3 a.m., she goes to bed, and wakes up four-and-a-half hours later to prepare 7-year-old Carmen for school. Most days she also works as a cleaner at Macy's or the San Jose Convention Center.
Her finances took a big hit this winter when each of her daughters had the flu, forcing her to visit the doctor three times. Lacking health insurance, she had to pay $195, nearly a week's take-home pay.
Her immediate dream is a job that pays more than the $6.50 an hour she earns working for a nonunion cleaning contractor.
"What I'm really hoping for is a job that pays $8," she said, wanting in particular a unionized cleaning job with health coverage. "I can barely make it right now. It's not fair, we work so hard and they don't give us the wages or benefits we deserve."
For most of her eight-hour shift, she said, echoing many other janitors, there is nobody to talk to, and her company prohibits her from listening to the radio while cleaning.
Many janitors are looking with hope to contract negotiations in which Mr. Garcia's union local, which represents 5,700 Silicon Valley janitors, including ones at Cisco, Sun and Hewlett-Packard, is asking for raises that would lift the cleaners' pay to $12.50 an hour after three years, from the current $8.
Although that would be a 56 percent raise, union officials say it is reasonable because at $12.50 an hour, the janitors would still earn considerably less than their unionized counterparts in San Francisco and New York, where living costs are not much higher. Mr. Garcia's union local has organized the strike by nearly 8,500 janitors in Los Angeles, who are battling for a hefty raise, asserting that their current pay of below $8 an hour is too low to live on.
Ridiculing the proposal for a $12.50 wage, many cleaning companies assert that they need to keep wages low so they can win contracts through competitive bidding.
Richard Sanchez, president of Acme Building Maintenance Company, acknowledged that low wages hurt the janitors, but he said that if a unionized company like his granted large raises, then nonunion companies might underbid him.
Officials at many companies, including Sun and 3Com, declined to discuss the janitors' plight, but some executives said the cleaners' living conditions were an embarrassment that needed to be addressed.
"People should not live in garages regardless of where they work," said Steven Langdon, a Cisco spokesman. "The success of Silicon Valley has brought great things to many people, but for some it has made life more difficult. Wages are important, and Cisco hopes and expects that our vendors will pay the people in their employ fairly."
With the area's housing prices up 60 percent in five years, Cisco has joined government agencies and other companies in an effort to build affordable housing. But that effort, focusing on units in the $200,000 range, is geared more to $45,000-a-year teachers and middle managers than to $16,000-a-year janitors.
For Alicia Sosa, a janitor at Sun Microsystems, a $200,000 house would be as out of reach as Bill Gates's mansion. For now, she shares a bedroom with her husband, her 1-year-old son and her two daughters, 5 and 6, who somehow sleep together in a crib.
When one child is sick at night, it keeps the whole family awake. Mrs. Sosa and her husband never have any privacy, she said, and they see each other just a half hour a day, after he returns from work and before she leaves for her job.
"In Mexico, people tell you all these great stories about the United States, that there is money on the ground that you can grab with your own hands," she said. "People never tell you how hard it is to make it here."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Prices Rally Sharply, Easing Fears of a Collapse
Stock prices stabilized and then soared in the United States after plunging in Asia and sliding in early European trading. The recovery eased fears of a collapsing stock market that had intensified after the Nasdaq composite index lost a quarter of its value last week. 
 The Nasdaq composite index climbed 217.87 points, or 6.6 percent, to 3,539.16. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 44.88 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,401.44, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 276.74 points, or 2.7 percent, to 10,582.51. Page A1.
 
Profit Up at Financial Companies
The sell-off in technology stocks in late March hardly put a dent in the earnings of some big financial-services companies. Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Charles Schwab all reported their most profitable first quarters ever. C2.
 
Ford Posts 5.1% Rise in Earnings
Brisk sales of luxury cars and sport utility vehicles in the United States helped lift Ford Motor's first-quarter earnings 5.1 percent, above forecasts, even though its overseas operations continued to lose money, the company said. Shares of Ford rose $4.8125, to $57.0625, although experts said the increase mainly reflected a continued reaction to the company's announcement on Friday that it would spin off its auto parts subsidiary, Visteon, and pay a special dividend totaling $10 billion. C6.
 
L'Oreal Plans to Acquire Kiehl's
After 149 years as a small but intensely popular independent cosmetics company, Kiehl's has agreed to be acquired by L'Oreal, the French beauty products giant. C2.
 
Finance Officials Vow Poverty Fight
The finance ministers and central bank governors who oversee the World Bank, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protesters braved rain and an impenetrable police force outside, pledged to pay more attention to globalization's victims and commit "unlimited money" to fight AIDS in poor countries. A1.
 
Britain May Sell a Research Unit
Risking a breach with the United States military establishment and braving the swings of an uncertain stock market, the British government said that it would sell a 75 percent stake in a secret military research unit, the Defense Evaluation and Research Agency, in a public offering. But in announcing the plan on a day when the British stock market fell sharply, the defense minister, Geoff Hoon, indicated that the timing would depend on the likely valuation of an offering and could be delayed. C4.
 
Bank Earnings Beat Expectations
Bank of America and Bank of New York reported first-quarter profits that beat expectations, powered by surging stocks. After last week's sell-off, however, they might be hard-pressed to post similarly strong future results. Earnings rose 17 percent at Bank of America and 6.8 percent at Bank of New York. C6.
 
Profit Increases 18% at Eli Lilly
Eli Lilly, maker of the world's top-selling antidepressant, Prozac, said that its first-quarter profit rose 18 percent on higher sales of diabetes medicines and a schizophrenia drug. C2.
 
Mexican Farmers Protest Imports
Mexican dairy farmers are growing angry over powdered milk imports from the United States that they say are filling supermarkets and decimating local production. C4.
 
Ulster Petroleums Agrees to Sale
Ulster Petroleums of Calgary in Canada thwarted a hostile takeover attempt by Hunt Oil of Dallas, agreeing to a richer $45 million cash-and-stock offer from a crosstown rival, Anderson Exploration. C4.

SECTION: Section C; Page 17; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 925 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Chicago Exchanges Are Losing Stature as Havens

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 17

 BODY:
In times of market turmoil, investors have often turned to Chicago to manage their risk at some of the city's pioneering financial exchanges.
But these days, many of those exchanges are in turmoil and the city of Chicago is, if not at risk, perhaps somewhat diminished in stature as a center of the derivatives trade, according to financial experts. 
 The growth of electronic trading and the popularity of the over-the-counter derivatives market has slowly eroded the city's hold on the futures and options business. And just about every week there are reports of the exchanges' chaotic attempts to respond to those changes.
On Friday, for instance, the Chicago Board of Trade -- the giant futures and options exchange -- said that Thomas R. Donovan, its longtime president, had resigned after more than a year of feuding with the board's chairman over leadership issues.
The resignation of Mr. Donovan, who received a reported $10 million severance package, was just the latest blow to the futures and options industry here, which has engaged in internecine warfare within the city while also trying to battle competitive threats from electronic and international exchanges.
"There has been a long-term secular drift here," said Richard Sandor, who helped introduce financial derivatives at the Chicago Board of Trade. "Now, the viability of the Chicago exchanges depends upon how quickly they can adapt."
To be sure, retail brokerage firms have faced similar challenges from online brokers. And the nation's largest stock exchanges have been facing even stiffer competition from low-cost electronic trading networks that have grown into huge players in the Nasdaq stock markets.
Yet no segment of the financial industry seems to be undergoing the kind of brutal and often public battles that are now being waged in Chicago, where agricultural trading long ago gave way to pioneering efforts to create financial instruments that help manage risk, like bond and stock market index futures.
The Chicago Board of Trade -- for decades the largest futures exchange in the world -- seems to be taking the brunt of the criticism here. There was a heated election battle, a war within the leadership ranks between Mr. Donovan and David Brennan, a longtime soybean trader who was elected chairman in 1997. And confusion about how the Board is going to move into the electronic arena just years after spending nearly $180 million on a gigantic trading floor, one of the largest in the world.
Last year, volume at the Chicago Board of Trade fell more than 20 percent and the exchange lost its title as the world's largest futures exchange to a nine-year-old international exchange called Eurex, which was created out of a merger between the German and Swiss derivative exchanges.
And last month, partly because trading in the 30-year Treasury bond has dropped off, volume at the Board of Trade ranked third in its own city, Chicago. This put it behind the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in the number of contracts traded.
The board is now facing tough budgetary decisions because of the huge debt from its new trading floor, and $50 million it agreed to invest to create a joint venture with Eurex.
"The finances are strained but they are being managed," said Patrick Catania, executive vice president at the Board of Trade. "As long as the volumes are in this ballpark, we'll be okay."
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the C.B.O.E. are faring much better, but they are also facing competitive pressures from electronic trading, overseas derivatives business and new regulatory initiatives, like a push by the Securities and Exchange Commission to make the options markets more competitive with new electronic formats.
"That's why all the exchanges are re-examining everything," said Ellen Resnick, a spokeswoman at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. "There are new competitors out there and so we want to move with internet speed."
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange is trying to move ahead with a demutualization plan that would raise money and allow it to move quickly, and so is the C.B.O.E., which insists that its business has been soaring in all the chaos.
"Our side of the business is phenomenal; we're up 70 percent from a year ago," said William J. Brodsky, chairman of the C.B.O.E. "Clearly, the Eurex exchange has done phenomenally well, but the Merc, the C.B.O.E. and the Board have been doing three million contracts a day -- that's not insubstantial."
Still, Mr. Brodsky acknowledges that Chicago is facing real competition from new exchanges and new initiatives meant to create still newer exchanges.
"We're all being challenged but it's always the case that the one who invented it is being challenged," he said. "I think what's happening is we're being challenged by electronic markets and everyone is dealing with it differently. We voted two weeks ago to build our own electronic system."
Merton Miller, the Nobel prize-winning economist who teaches at the University of Chicago, says the big three financial exchanges here have been falling behind because of advances in electronic trading and the growth of the over-the-counter derivatives market, which is not subject to the same regulations.
"The exchanges have to carry so much water on their back, they can't keep up with the over-the-counter market," he said in an interview today.
"And now, little by little, electronics is taking over. So they may still innovate, but it won't be like it was 10 years ago."

SECTION: Section C; Page 18; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 855 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Sporting a Wall St. Hangover, Asian Markets Fall Sharply

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, April 17

 BODY:
The sell-off that engulfed Wall Street last week spread through Asia today, devastating stock markets and erasing investor wealth in some of the most severe declines since the global crash of 1987.
But the mood was less grim this time because much of Asia is climbing out of a recession that hammered share prices a couple of years ago. Few people expect the current market turbulence to snuff out the recovery. Many of the region's markets were sharply higher in early trading on Tuesday. 
 Still, the extent of the decline was hard enough to scare some politicians back into old habits. In Japan, where the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues fell nearly 7 percent, its worst loss in 12 1/2 years, government officials said they would recommend putting a trillion yen, or almost $10 billion, into the market to buy shares if prices fell much further. Such measures were used to keep Japan's markets steady in the past but have since been blamed for helping create a financial bubble that has taken more than a decade to deflate.
The Nikkei's 1,426.04-point slide, its fifth-biggest drop ever in both percentage and point terms, was aggravated by a change today in the index that increased its weighting in favor of volatile technology issues. Thirty stocks of mainly smokestack companies were removed from the index and replaced with stocks of high-technology businesses, an attempt to make the index reflect Japan's new economy.
But technology stocks were the hardest hit in the sell-off today and helped drag down the Nikkei. At the same time, selling by index funds of the 30 stocks removed further depressed the overall market.
The Nikkei index, though, closed at 19,008.64, back to where it was as recently as late January and well within the range it has traded since people started debating whether the country's economy is really recovering.
Economists across Asia focused on the positive side: while an extended market decline could dampen American demand for Asian exports, the region is far better prepared today to handle such a slump than it was even a year ago.
Most countries have emerged from bruising recessions that followed the financial crisis of 1997-98. And the regional shakeout left the economies healthier. The growth they registered last year was of a higher quality -- driven more by domestic demand and less by debt and corruption -- than the high Asian growth rates of the past. Increasing trade among Asian nations has made exports less dependent on the United States market than they once were.
"If this hits U.S. and European demand, it could slow down the pace of the region's recovery," said Joe Lo, senior economist for northern Asia at Citibank in Hong Kong, "but it won't send Asia back into recession."
Across the continent today, investors dumped technology stocks in favor of old economy companies. Technology-heavy markets were hit the hardest.
In South Korea, the Kospi index tumbled 11.71 percent, its biggest one-day loss ever, led by Samsung Electronics. The Korean market is now the worst-performing Asian market this year, down close to one-third in dollar terms since the end of December.
Hong Kong's benchmark index suffered its second-worst one-day point loss, falling 1,380.4, or 8.55 percent, to 14,762.37. Shares in China Telecom, which last week announced a 30 percent drop in profit in 1999, lost 15 percent of their value. Pacific Century CyberWorks, the darling of Internet stocks in Asia, fell 14 percent, endangering the company's plan to buy Cable and Wireless HKT.
In Singapore, the Straits Times index fell 8.69 percent. Electronics account for two-thirds of total exports.
China's markets registered a more muted reaction, partly because of strict capital controls that help keep its economy insulated from overseas markets.
The currency, the Chinese yuan, is convertible for only a narrow range of transactions, most related to trade. And the bulk of listings in the two stock markets -- one in Shanghai and the other in the southern city of Shenzhen -- are off-limits to foreigners.
China's "B shares," denominated in foreign currency and open to overseas investors, bore the brunt of today's selling: Shanghai's Class B share index fell nearly 4 percent while its counterpart in Shenzhen fell 3.19 percent. The rest of the markets registered more moderate losses. Shanghai's Class A share index lost 2.09 percent, and Shenzhen Class A shares fell 2.22 percent.
The capital controls helped China skate through Asia's financial crisis two years ago without serious economic dislocations. And they are likely to protect China from the current market gyrations, economists say. "The Chinese economy is relatively immune to this market downturn because external factors account for only a small part of China's economic growth," said Joe Zhang, head of China research at Warburg Dillon Read in Hong Kong.
Taiwan's market was a rare bright spot, with the benchmark index rising 1.43 percent. The market is the only one in Asia to trade on Saturday and so had already lost 5.4 percent in reaction to Wall Street's dive on Friday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1330 words

HEADLINE: Bracing For a Deluge, Getting a Trickle;
Reaction Proves Calm To Friday's Big Sell-Off

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
In Owings Mills, Md., yesterday morning, T. Rowe Price prepared for a major accident. Expecting a flood of nervous phone calls, the mutual fund giant put 200 employees on standby to support its usual staff of 100 telephone representatives.
But by noon it was clear that the company was more nervous than its investors. Wayne D. O'Melia, president of the service operation, said that only about 50 of these extra hands were needed because calling volume ran only about 10 percent above normal. "This is a nonevent compared with '87," Mr. O'Melia said. 
 Like Mr. O'Melia, financial professionals and individual investors everywhere yesterday seemed to be awaiting a disaster that did not come. From the floor of the New York Stock Exchange to the headquarters of the National Association of Securities Dealers in Washington, the mood in the morning was tense.
But as investors who fled the market last week stepped up to buy again yesterday afternoon, the weekend's awful warnings faded and Wall Street's naturally bullish bias returned -- at least for the moment. By day's end, many professionals were even saying that last week's plunge, although painful, might have done some good by ending a speculative bubble and clearing the way for a steady, but slower, advance.
"We are seeing a whole different side of the market that we didn't see Thursday or Friday," said Joseph N. Cangemi, a floor supervisor on the New York Stock Exchange with Francis P. Maglio & Company. "You are seeing a bounce off the bottom with the fresh money coming in."
"This is healthy," he added. "Today is a good reaction. There was a lot of excessive value in the market. It needed to self-correct, to even itself out. People can't keep buying so one-dimensionally and expect a return with no risk."
In Washington, Patrick Campbell, chief operating officer of the National Association of Securities Dealers, arrived yesterday prepared for another rough day. Instead, the data flashing on more than a dozen video screens in the windowless room signaled an orderly morning on the Nasdaq.
The biggest scrum Mr. Campbell saw yesterday was outside the N.A.S.D.'s Washington headquarters among people protesting against the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Inside the N.A.S.D. building on K Street, away from the sirens and helicopters and police bullhorns, the "war room," where top N.A.S.D. officials keep watch on the Nasdaq, was a relative oasis of calm, Mr. Campbell said.
Looking back later, Mr. Campbell said, "A lot of the first hour was the emotional part." But once the market absorbed selling by investors who had to raise cash to pay off loans used to buy stocks, buyers were lured back by the prospect of strong earnings reports and a fundamentally sound economy.
"I think things have stabilized here," he said.
Not that the morning went perfectly. At just past 10, James Raphalian, a stock trader for SG Cowen in Manhattan, suddenly found himself unable to do his job because of a computer problem -- on a day that many investors thought might set records for volatility.
Quickly, Cowen stopped making trades in many stocks, worried that it might lose money offering outdated prices in a fast-moving market. "Explain to me real carefully what in God's name is going on here," Mr. Raphalian said to a worried technician in the middle of Cowen's trading floor, a three-layered pit of voices and computer screens.
But the crisis did not last. Within minutes, Cowen had fixed its computers, and Mr. Raphalian could trade shares to his heart's content. And trade he did.
At T. Rowe Price, which manages $180 billion in eight million accounts, some callers did switch investments from the firm's science and technology mutual fund to less aggressive funds, and some asked that automatic investments taken from bank or from money market accounts be deferred this month.
But phone representatives also reported nearly as many bargain hunters as sellers, including one Texas man who bought T. Rowe Price's science and technology fund on Friday and eagerly did so again yesterday. "A lot of people are just going to hold out -- hang in there," said April Blahut, a telephone representative who fielded a steady succession of calls with aplomb.
Relatively few people commented on the state of the market, Ms. Blahut said, while on Friday many callers had asked, "Hey, what's going on?" After handling about a dozen calls between 10:30 and 11:30, Ms. Blahut reported that just one customer cashed in shares. In contrast, Ms. Blahut said she had more than 25 redemptions during her Friday shift.
At the T. Rowe Price walk-up counter in a neighboring building, Derek Dry, manager of the investor center, said he expected about 225 customers today, about three times normal. But most people were setting up or adding to retirement accounts and the rest were split evenly between buyers of either stock funds or money market funds.
"Nobody's selling," Mr. Dry said.
Telephones were also relatively quiet at Baron Capital, a New York money management firm. And Morty Schaja, Baron's president, found himself less nervous than he had been after the 1987 crash, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.6 percent in a single day. "Unlike in 1987, I clearly didn't feel the world was coming to the end," he said.
The difference is that the United States economy is far stronger now than it was 13 years ago, Mr. Schaja said. "Now it's a valuation issue, it's an adjustment," he added.
In fact, Mr. Schaja expressed some relief at the recent declines, although his firm has not escaped losses. "All the attitude by the retail investor has been this new age, new world kind of investing," he said. "That psychology has to be broken. In the last year or so, we've been in a trader's environment."
The buying by individuals extended past mutual funds to stocks, according to Birinyi Associates, a stock market research firm. Individuals put about $850 million into New York Stock Exchange stocks, while institutions added around $450 million, with most of that coming in the last half-hour of trading, Mr. Birinyi said.
That bullishness extended to the West Coast, where countless employees of new-economy companies have grown rich on the market's long boom. At a San Jose, Calif., office of Charles Schwab, few investors seemed worried.
Nancy Coldwell, 49, vice president of marketing for Cohera, a start-up, said she had no plans to sell. "I think dumping out just makes it worse," Ms. Coldwell said. "And dumping out now, you're at the bottom, and I think that's just stupid."
In Seattle, John Keister, the president and co-founder of Go2Net, a network of Web sites, said he thought last week's sell-off would be "very healthy for the Internet industry."
Go2Net was hardly unscathed in the Nasdaq's tumble. Its shares plunged from $97 on March 27 to $47.875 on Friday, erasing more than $1.6 billion from its market valuation. But Mr. Keister said he believed his company would be able to handle a shakeout among Web sites, because unlike many young Internet companies, Go2Net is actually profitable on an operating basis. And yesterday its stock rose to $55.25.
Mr. Keister was less optimistic about the future of his money-losing competitors. "Not everyone should be a winner here," he said. "A lot of companies were, and still are, overvalued."
Meanwhile, Internet chat rooms were filled with a blend of hype and insults, with bulls regaining their swagger as Internet favorites like JDS Uniphase turned sharply higher in afternoon trading. "Shorts hope for a sell-off -- it's over," a day trader called "Stimemarket" wrote. "My broker says buy."
As trading closed at 4 p.m. with the Nasdaq up more than 6.6 percent, Mr. Raphalian, the head of Nasdaq trading for SG Cowen, breathed a sigh of relief at the bad day that he -- and investors everywhere -- had dodged. "Money came back into the market," he said. "We're a lot better than how we started out."

Computer services

HEADLINE: Struggling to Fill Ranks, Army Moves to Find Ways to Keep Its Officers

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Complaining about confusing missions, low morale and the stress of seemingly constant separations from their families, junior officers are leaving the Army in such record numbers that the Army's leaders created two panels today to figure out how to keep them in the ranks.
After the latest Army figures showed a continuing drop in the number of lieutenants and captains willing to make a career of the Army, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, the Army chief of staff, commissioned a survey of 760 officers at the Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., asking them what issues were causing the exodus. 
 Their answers were collected by the college, but many officers privately passed them around in e-mail messages. Some said they often felt that the Army seemed to "rip" people out of their bases for missions that did not make sense.
Others questioned the loyalty of Army generals, saying "senior leaders will throw subordinates under the bus in a heartbeat to protect or advance their career," according to one e-mail message.
"Their focus is on short-impact fixes that make them look good and get them their next star," one soldier wrote.
None of these answers seemed to surprise General Shinseki, who had commissioned the survey before he spoke to the junior officers at Fort Leavenworth last month.
"There was nothing said that he hadn't heard before, but he wanted to get it right from the horse's mouth," a senior Army official said.
The shortage in junior officers means there will be fewer candidates for senior leadership positions, and, with the Army struggling to meet recruiting goals, it may also be difficult to find replacements for those junior officers.
Since the end of the cold war, the Army has shrunk by one-third while its deployments have increased by 300 percent, increasing the stress on the soldiers and the families. Those deployments included more peacekeeping missions and help with natural disasters which soldiers said were not what they had signed up for.
"We give soldiers expectations about doing exciting, war fighting type stuff and then we send them off to 'peacekeep' without fully explaining to them their mission," was one complaint in the e-mail messages. The substance of the survey was first reported in The Washington Post today.
Family members were especially irritated by what they considered an incomprehensible medical care system, by transfers every 18 months and by the shoddy housing in too many bases.
The booming economy makes it easier to leave in midcareer, but the young officers were adamant that the Army should not blame a strong job market for their dissatisfaction.
These comments were welcomed, said Brig. Gen. Bob Wood, the deputy commandant at Command and General Staff College, who will head one of the panels.
"The chief got exactly what he wanted: raw information and honest feedback," General Wood said.
That feedback will be included in position papers to help explain why the percentage of young officers willing to make the Army a career dropped to 35 percent last year from 52 percent in 1991. Non-commissioned officers are leaving at roughly the same rate.
But the Army is hardly alone in having a hard time holding onto its midcareer officers.
The Air Force continues to lose pilots to far better-paying commercial firms, even after offering them bonuses. The rate of pilot retention dropped to 41 percent in 1999 from 71 percent in 1997.
"We already had a retention summit this year," said Carol DeBattiste, under secretary of the Air Force. "We are cautiously optimistic but the job market is a major draw."
Ms. DeBattiste said that like the young Army officers, the midcareer Air Force officers said they wanted to spend more time with their families.
While the Navy said the rate of retention of young officers has improved in the first months of this year, a recent survey showed that only 1 in 10 junior officers wanted to stay and become a commander.
General Shinseki and Louis Caldera, the secretary of the Army, have asked for a full report from the two panels within three months after they begin work in May.
Lieut. Gen. Walter F. Ulmer of the Army, who is retired, wrote both the Army's study of similar problems from the Vietnam War and a recent private two-year survey of morale problems in the military.
While General Ulmer said the Army was a "dramatically better Army" than it was in those days, he did find some similarities in the problems the junior officers faced.
"There are great stresses to the institution today that are similar to those after the Vietnam War," he said in a telephone interview. "There are concerns about morale, lack of trust in Washington's policies, and a concern about whether all the missions are worth the sacrifice."

HEADLINE: In Britain, Putin Finds Reform Popular, but Not Chechen War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 17

 BODY:
In his first visit to the West since winning office, Russia's president-elect, Vladimir V. Putin, today courted foreign businessmen, met with the queen and offered some unsolicited advice on the stock market.
Eager to burnish his economic credentials and overcome Western suspicion about his K.G.B. past, he dismissed Friday's rout on Wall Street as little more than a blip. 
 "We don't think it is a catastrophe," Mr. Putin said soothingly as Prime Minister Tony Blair stood by his side. "It is a problem that is likely to corrected by the market in the near future."
The notion of a Russian leader reassuring nail-biting Westerners that their capitalist system is sound was a striking twist for those who recall the ideological debates of the cold war.
But Mr. Putin's goal is to restore Russia as a world power. And that means attracting foreign investment, integrating Russia into the world economy and maintaining correct, if not close, relations with the West.
London was the first Western port of call, Russians said, because it is a bridge between Europe and the United States -- and because Mr. Blair was the most ardent suitor.
"Despite what has happened in the North Caucasus, one would like Western opinion to have greater trust in Russian opinion," Mr. Putin said.
Despite a friendly meeting with Mr. Blair, respectful question-and-answer sessions with British executives and an audience with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle, Mr. Putin accomplished his task only partly.
Mr. Putin, who will be officially sworn in May 7, seemed to tell Western businessman everything they wanted to hear about his plans to reform his nation's tax system, fight corruption and shrink the government bureaucracy.
But when he shifted his attention to Chechnya and military issues, his easy manner vanished and his message changed. At his news conference with Mr. Blair, Mr. Putin delivered a stern lecture about the need to fight the rebels in Chechnya, who seek independence from Russia.
The only concession he offered was to point to the establishment of yet another commission to look into allegations of human rights abuses by Russian troops there.
The new group is all Russian, though ostensibly independent of the Kremlin, not the international body that human rights advocates have called for. And Mr. Putin himself played down the significance of the panel, saying he had learned about it on the radio.
Nor did Mr. Putin soften his opposition to the American plan to develop antimissile defenses, the most contentious issue dividing Moscow and Washington and one of the principal agenda items for the summit meeting between Mr. Putin and President Clinton to be held in early June.
Mr. Putin's 24-hour visit here was a bit of an echo of a much longer visit that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's made to London in 1984, when the British prime minister at the time, Margaret Thatcher, took the measure of the Soviet leader and pronounced that he was somebody with whom the West could do business.
Mr. Blair delivered the same verdict about Mr. Putin. And the British leader used the Russian leader's visit to cast himself as the premier European statesman and a kind of matchmaker between Russia and the United States on arms control and other tricky questions.
British officials emphasize the need to establish a good rapport with Mr. Putin during the "formative" period of his presidency. It is a task, they assert, that the United States is hard put to carry out during an election year, and which Germany and France do not appear eager to play, in part because of public sentiment against the war in Chechnya.
Today's meeting was the second between the British and Russian leaders. Mr. Blair was so eager to build ties with Mr. Putin that he met with him in St. Petersburg last month, even before Mr. Putin was elected.
"Some say that because of our concerns about Chechnya, we should keep some distance from Moscow," Mr. Blair said. "I believe the best way to get results is by engaging with Russia, not isolating Russia."
Despite the high marks he received from Mr. Blair, there was little public excitement over the visit here. And there was only a small group of protesters.

HEADLINE: On a Day of Protests, K Street Takes the Day Off

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The protesters marching downtown today failed to disrupt the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its partner organization, the World Bank. But the protesters managed to halt the business of another influential Washington institution: the law firms and lobbying shops of K Street.
K Street, both as an address and a symbol of the capital's influence industry, was the spine of a 20-block area that the city police cordoned off from traffic early today. Demonstrators marched up and down the avenue in their bid to stop the world financial leaders from pursuing their agenda. They failed, but, in a sense, they might have accomplished more than they realized. 
 "If they wanted to stop capitalism, they have certainly stopped it in the lobbying corridor," said Wayne Berman, chairman of Park Strategies, a lobbying firm at 1800 K Street.
Hundreds of lawyers, lobbyists and political consultants stayed home rather than try to navigate rain-soaked streets gridlocked with shouting demonstrators and police officers in riot gear. Clients who placed calls to many high-powered lobbying firms were greeted by automated phone systems with recorded requests to call back on Tuesday morning.
Mr. Berman said he had closed his office and flown half a dozen Park Strategies employees to the company's Manhattan offices for the day. But he acknowledged that he was not getting much work done; nearly everyone he had tried to call this morning in Washington had taken the day off.
"A combination of the protests, and Congress going on Easter recess this week has shut down the lobbying business," he said.
Mr. Berman said that, in New York, he watched on television as the police and protesters clashed on the street corner beneath his office in Washington. "Probably was a good idea to get out of town," he said.
Indeed, in the streets outside those offices and law firms, there were several tense standoffs. In one, a police officer said he mistakenly used tear gas on hundreds of protesters trying to stop a van near I.M.F. headquarters that they believed was carrying delegates. It was not. At noon, another face-off, ending in a handful of arrests, occurred at the corner of 20th and I Streets. But for much of the day, many blocks in the downtown area were nearly deserted.
Not all of the influence industry's commerce was halted today. Victor Kamber, a lobbyist and political consultant for 34 years, said that his Kamber Group was working at full staff. "It's quiet, only because a lot of our clients stayed home," he said.
Haley Barbour, the lobbyist and former Republican National Committee chairman, said he started his workday at 6:45 a.m., as usual. "Sure, I'm working," Mr. Barbour said. "It's Monday."
Mr. Barbour, one of the leaders of the firm Barbour Griffith & Rogers, said he had seen knots of protesters on the street outside his office during the lunch hour. "I didn't bother them," he said, "and they didn't bother me."
The federal government instituted its liberal leave policy, which it usually does during snowstorms. Most federal agencies in the protest zone, an 11-by-8-block zone east and west of the White House, were closed today, including the Departments of State, Treasury, Commerce and Interior.
And the K Street power haunts -- expensive dealmaker restaurants like Morton's and the Palm and upscale hair salons and cigar shops -- were either closed or as quiet as the Library of Congress.
While most law firms and lobbying concerns were closed, many of the watchdog groups that monitor the intersection of government and business remained open. It was business as usual at the Center for Public Integrity, on 17th Street, half a block from K Street.
"I think we have a lot of wimps in Washington who will use any excuse to stay home," said Charles Lewis, the center's director. "All I had to do was go to a different subway station. I had breakfast and lunch at the Art Gallery Grill, and you had cops and protesters there, eating together. The protesters were holding the door open for the cops. I guess the bottom line is they all have to eat."
