HEADLINE: Albany Leaders Reach a Deal To Cut Taxes

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 17

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders removed one of the last remaining obstacles to a state budget deal today, reaching tentative agreement on a broad array of tax cuts that would save New Yorkers $1.2 billion a year, according to aides involved in the negotiations.
The largest part of the package is $330 million to reduce a tax on utility companies that is passed on to consumers and businesses each month. That reduction was sought by Mr. Pataki and his Republican allies in the Senate. The deal also offers a virtual wish list of tax cuts sought chiefly by Senate Republicans: $200 million to provide a tax deduction for college tuition costs, $125 million to give tax credits for low-wage workers and a smattering of tax breaks for businesses. 
 The biggest concession to Democratic leaders of the Assembly was a plan to use $200 million to give a tax break to hundreds of thousands of married couples who are paying higher taxes than if they were single. The Democrats also pushed through a plan to create so-called tax-free zones for businesses in economically distressed areas, at a cost of about $40 million a year to the state.
The one major area of the budget that remains unresolved is education, though legislative leaders from both parties are said to be near an agreement that would increase aid to schools by roughly $1.1 billion. The biggest sticking point there is how to divide the additional money among school districts across the state.
Democrats in the Assembly are seeking to ensure that the New York City school system and other urban schools get what the Democrats consider to be their fair share of the state aid, while Republicans leaders of the Senate are pushing generous increases for suburban and upstate school districts.
The bulk of the new tax cuts are not expected to have any impact on this year's budget because they will be phased in gradually over the next four years. One major tax cut that was embraced earlier this year by the leaders of both the Senate and the Assembly will not make the final budget: reduction of the state's gasoline tax.
The tax-cut deal apparently settles one of the most difficult issues that has held up a final budget agreement. But aides to Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders cautioned that several minor details, including how to structure the tax cuts in future years, needed to be worked out before the plan was finally adopted.
The budget was due on April 1, but for the 16th straight year, the governor and the Legislature missed that deadline. Nevertheless, Mr. Pataki and the Legislature are further along than they have been at this date in most recent years, with the legislative leaders seeking to pass the entire budget by Wednesday.
The tax-cut deal comes nearly two weeks after Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders from both parties said that they had agreed to the parameters of a nearly $78 billion budget and that Mr. Pataki had agreed to refrain from making wholesale vetoes, so long as the Legislature remained within that figure.
The heart of the deal calls for the Legislature to add $1.4 billion to the $76.8 billion budget the governor proposed in January. But the increase will be partly offset because the Legislature intends to reduce the governor's estimates of what some programs will cost. In all, aides to the governor and the Legislature estimate that the final budget will be $77 billion to $78 billion, up 5 percent to 6 percent from last year.
The largest part of the tax-cut package is the $330 million set aside for the gradual repeal of a tax on utility companies that is passed on to consumers and adds several dollars a month to the average New Yorker's gas and electric bills. The gross receipts tax, as it is called, is a 3.25 percent tax on utility companies' gross sales of power.
The deal reached today achieves one of Mr. Pataki's main tax-cutting initiatives this year: the immediate elimination of the tax for manufacturers, who pay hundreds of thousands of dollars a month in power bills. Mr. Pataki and Republicans in the Senate have long sided with business leaders who contend that high utility costs are a major reason for the decline in manufacturing jobs in the state.
The agreement also calls for reducing the gross receipts tax to 2.5 percent for residential customers starting this year, and further reducing it to 2 percent over five years. The deal would also gradually eliminate the gross receipts tax for commercial customers like retailers over five years.
Regarding the proposal to make college tuition fully deductible, the deduction would apply to the payment of tuition at any accredited college or university in the United States or abroad. But it would not cover money spent on books, room and board and other educational fees.
For a family of four with a gross income of $55,000 a year, paying $12,000 a year in tuition at a private college, the new deduction would save $450, according to some estimates. The same family, paying the $3,400 tuition at one of the state's public colleges, would save $136.
As a concession to Democrats, the deal would eliminate the so-called marriage tax penalty. Under current law, two people who are married and have roughly equal incomes pay income taxes at higher rates than they would if single. Roughly a million couples statewide are affected by the tax code's marriage penalty.
Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders have apparently also agreed to set aside $250 million to expand a program that makes electricity available at below-market rates to businesses, in return for commitments to expand or stay in New York.
The deal also provides $25 million to offer tax credits for working parents to help them pay for child care. It also calls for spending $125 million to expand the earned-income tax credit, a break to the working poor. But unlike the other tax cuts, that one will be financed with money provided by the federal government to help states finance antipoverty programs like welfare.
While the tax cuts announced today would have only a slight impact on this year's budget, the budget will reflect $2.3 billion worth of tax cuts enacted in past years that will take effect this year, including a program that helps reduce local property taxes.

HEADLINE: Is Spending Rise Below Inflation? Depends on the Measure

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 17

 BODY:
The arrival of a new state fiscal year leads to another in a long series of lessons in how numbers -- normally so reassuringly immutable -- can become, in Albany hands, as easy to grasp as sand.
Last year, Gov. George E. Pataki boasted that the state budget raised spending at less than the rate of inflation, a claim that was widely scoffed at. So, did he make it? The answers, culled from a report issued today by the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, are "almost" and "it depends," because there are almost as many ways to measure the budget as there are people doing the measuring. 
 One thing is clear from the report: For the fiscal year that ended on March 31, state spending, adjusted for inflation, rose at one of the slowest paces since the 1970's, the years that put phrases like "fiscal crisis" and "default" in every New Yorker's vocabulary. Over all, the state spent $73.359 billion, up 3.9 percent from the year before.
Thanks to an unexpected assist from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, that was nearly under the rate of inflation. A year ago, inflation was running about 2 percent. But the United States Department of Labor reported on Friday that the consumer price index in March stood 3.7 percent higher than a year earlier, because of the petroleum cartel's cut in production, which caused fuel prices to soar.
Tracking state finances under Mr. Pataki, a Republican, can be a bit dizzying. He started out as a budget-slashing conservative, earning the wrath of many interest groups. Then he turned into a fairly generous spender as he ran for re-election, drawing fire from conservatives. Last year, he returned to fiscal restraint. But as lawmakers put the finishing touches on this year's budget, they are clearly going in the other direction, headed for a 5 to 6 percent increase in spending.
In the governor's five complete fiscal years, overall spending has increased an inflation-adjusted 4.9 percent. That is a relatively modest pace amid a boom that has had most states spending more freely. "We're doing a better job than the rest of the country in restraining spending growth," said Joseph Conway, spokesman for the governor's budget office.
Still, state spending did increase faster than consumer prices last year, right?
"No," Mr. Conway said. But a moment later, he conceded, "it depends exactly what set of numbers you're talking about."
The numbers are skewed by a 1997 program that was intended to lower property taxes. Ordinarily, a tax cut shows up on the books as a drop in revenue. But this one, paradoxically, shows up as an added expense -- and a rapidly growing one -- because the state makes payments to local school districts to help them hold down the property taxes they charge.
If that expense is subtracted, as the Pataki administration argues it should be, then overall state spending rose 3 percent last year, less than the inflation rate. But critics of the program say it has not succeeded in lowering taxes, turning instead into a new form of aid to school districts.
"It's pretty clear that what's going on in Albany is above-inflation spending," said Thomas W. Carroll, president of Change New York, a conservative, anti-tax group that has gone from Pataki cheerleader to Pataki critic.
Then there is the problem that there is not one common measure of state spending, but three. And all three are flawed.
The "all funds" budget, that $73 billion figure, includes federal grants for things like Medicaid and welfare. That money lies at least partly outside the state's control, and its relationship to the state's bottom line is indirect.
The "state funds" budget, which subtracts that federal money, is a better reflection of the state's own finances. But it is subject to some odd fluctuations and it includes things like tuition payments to the state's public colleges that have nothing to do with the state's real fiscal health. State funds spending was $49.8 billion last year, up 3.8 percent -- a shade more than the rate of inflation. But if the property tax cut program is taken out, the increase was just 2.6 percent.
The governor's office often contends that the real gauge of the budget is what is called the general fund, because it is the part generated directly by state taxes, and it is the area that Wall Street analysts scrutinize most closely. But in the last dozen years, lawmakers have shown great creativity in manipulating that number to keep it low, by simply declaring some things no longer part of the general fund.
The way the governor's office measures the general fund, its expenses totaled $37.2 billion last year, up just 1.6 percent. The way Mr. McCall's office calculates it, the fund reached $34.3 billion, up 1.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Killings of Livery Drivers Prompt Police to Step Up Measures

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

 BODY:
The outcry over the slayings of livery-cab drivers prompted new steps to combat the attacks yesterday, as the Police Department fleshed out its plans to protect drivers and the mayor proposed further steps to safeguard them.
At a City Council hearing, at two news conferences at City Hall and in discussions at police headquarters, the authorities emphasized that they had developed measures to protect the roughly 40,000 livery drivers in the city. Throughout the day, they were questioned about whether the steps announced so far would stop the slayings. 
 The officials were also asked repeatedly whether a man slain in Chinatown early yesterday was a livery cabby, making his death the eighth this year.
That victim, Jimmy Chan, 40, of 124 Mott Street, was found shot twice in the head and sitting in his Lincoln Town Car, which was not registered as a livery vehicle, a few blocks from the Manhattan Bridge. But the police were pursuing a tip that Mr. Chan might have had ties to illegal gambling in Chinatown. They said that he had $600 on him, and that his death appeared unrelated to the other livery slayings.
Seven livery-cab drivers have been killed so far this year; 11 were killed in all of 1999.
Reacting to the latest slayings, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, and Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Cab Drivers, held a City Hall news conference to denounce the violence and call for a comprehensive protection plan for drivers. Calling the killings assassinations, Mr. Vallone said, "We are very, very concerned, and we will continually monitor the activities of the Police Department to make sure that the resources that are necessary to stop this carnage are applied and are effective."
Mr. Mateo said the high rate of killings this year was distressing partly because the victims were in a business that served the killers' neighborhoods. "Most of these suspects are people from the inner city and they are committing crimes on inner-city people, and we need to stop that," Mr. Mateo said.
Hours later, Chief of Patrol John Scanlon testified before the City Council Committee on Transportation and provided an overview of the department's new Livery Task Force, which was created as a team of 40 officers in February and was expanded to more than 300 officers after two drivers were killed last week.
Chief Scanlon said the task force had been reinforced with officers from the Street Crime Unit, and would use more decoy livery cabs driven by plainclothes officers as well as establish areas where police officers would be posted to assist drivers who are suspicious of their passengers. The exact number of such areas, called safe zones, and their locations were still being worked out last night.
"Each borough is putting together their plans right now," said Deputy Chief Thomas P. Fahey, a police spokesman. "But it's safe to say that there will be several safe zones in each borough."
The department declined to say how many decoys would be added, or how many were already operating.
Chief Scanlon also said that patrol cars would make frequent stops of livery cabs carrying passengers to check on the drivers' safety, and that the department would refresh officers on signals used by cabdrivers when they are in trouble -- flashing the amber lights on the front and rear of the cabs, for example.
Chief Scanlon also noted that the number of livery-cab drivers slain had dropped sharply since 1993, when 37 were killed. Still, he acknowledged that the killings this year were grounds for concern. "In light of recent events, it has become even more clear that more work needs to be done in this area," the chief said.
As Chief Scanlon spoke, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir held a news conference at which Mr. Giuliani said he had signed an emergency declaration asking the Taxi and Limousine Commission to require that livery cabs have bulletproof partitions or video cameras.
None of the slain drivers were driving a car with a partition or camera, the police said. The commission was expected to meet on the measure today. On Friday, the mayor announced that $5 million from the Economic Development Corporation would be used to pay for the safety devices for the drivers.
The mayor and commissioner also hailed the arrest of two robbery suspects accused of holding up a livery-cab driver at knifepoint early yesterday. Police officials said the two were outwitted by a driver who sensed something was amiss and managed to call for help in the robbers' presence.
"The driver was suspicious and leery of them, so he told them he had a car problem," said Sgt. Brian Burke, a police spokesman. "Then he pulled over, lifted the hood and called the police on his cell phone." As the driver was talking to the police, Sergeant Burke said, the passengers demanded that he return to the vehicle and robbed him of $85. Police officers arrived within minutes and arrested Chris Murphy, 25, and Bernadette Farrell, 33, both of 619 Greenwood Avenue, Brooklyn, who were still near the cab. Both were charged with robbery and criminal possession of a weapon.
As public officials were announcing the new programs and the arrests, Mr. Mateo, president of the drivers' federation, said his members were grateful for the city's effort, but he expressed concern that some elements of the new police operation would not guarantee drivers' safety. For instance, he said, the safe zones might deter some robbers but would be of little use to drivers already in peril. "When you have a gun pointed at your head and you're told to turn right here, turn left there, you can forget about the safe zones," he said.
He also expressed frustration that the Police Department, which has pledged since February to combat the attacks on cab drivers, has only purchased two Lincoln Town Cars for use as decoys. At any given moment, more than 5,000 livery cabs are on the street, and two new decoys seem insufficient, he said.
Further, Mr. Mateo demanded that the police match the increased presence on the street with an increase in detectives.
Chief Fahey said that the department had already done so, and that as many as 20 detectives were working on each of the driver homicides. "These are hot cases right now," he said. "The guy who cracks these, it's going to be good for."
The police also said detectives were in Chinatown seeking clues in Mr. Chan's death.
The authorities said Mr. Chan owned a 1987 Lincoln Town Car and often acted as a cabby, driving his neighbors for money or traveling to the airport to pick up neighbors' friends and relatives. But the authorities said that he was not licensed as a cabdriver, and that his car had handicapped plates.
One police supervisor said Mr. Chan might have been "a driver for illegal gambling operations who picked up gamblers and took them to illegal gambling locations." Investigators were focusing on whether those connections led to his killing, the supervisor said, adding that Mr. Chan's vulnerability as a part-time cabdriver was not at the center of the case.

HEADLINE: Leaving the Crisis Room for the Classroom

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
EDWARD J. BLAKELY, dean of the School of Management and Urban Policy at the New School, used to be a force in California government, advising mayors in the Bay Area and Los Angeles, lawmakers in Sacramento and commissions convened to rebuild cities after earthquakes, fires, riots or military base closings.
"A lot of that business got done around my kitchen table," said Mr. Blakely, who arrived in New York in August and has yet to unpack the boxes in his office. "Here, I'm not one of the people in the loop, so to speak. And it's the first time in my life I haven't been one of them." 
 So what is he doing here, where his office windows look out on brick walls instead of the eucalyptus trees at the University of California at Berkeley and the bougainvillea at the University of Southern California, schools where he was dean of urban planning departments over the last 23 years?
"New York is New York," he said, sounding like Frank Sinatra on the sound system at Yankee Stadium. "For an urban planner, like for a financial person, you've got to do it here."
It also is a career move, at the age of 62, that fits into a three-stage life plan Mr. Blakely says he put in place even before his voice had changed. At the age of 11, he said, he had figured out that he wanted to be self-sufficient (a polite way of saying rich), then important (perhaps even famous) and finally nurturing (translation: teacher).
The drive for economic self-sufficiency came from his father, a custodian in San Bernadino, where Mr. Blakely grew up. But the elder Mr. Blakely was not an ordinary broom pusher. He had swept floors at the Los Angeles stock exchange while in high school, bought American Can at 10 cents and never looked back.
His son got the message and began investing in real estate while in his 20's. He was in the Bay Area then, buying up derelict properties ("No money down," the ads said) around Lake Merritt in Oakland, which soon became a prime residential neighborhood. By his mid 30's, Mr. Blakely said, he was secure for life. His latest venture is a 500-acre planned community in Corona, Calif.
Stage Two of the life-plan, the drive for prominence, came from his uncle, the head of the N.A.A.C.P. in Riverside. Like him, Mr. Blakely wanted to "be an important person some place." That place turned out to be Oakland, one of the nation's most interesting urban laboratories, with extremes of wealth and poverty, an unusually integrated population and access to a great university.
Mr. Blakely became the bridge between Berkeley and the city, raising millions of dollars from private corporate sources and providing faculty members and graduate students to assist in Oakland's rehabilitation. Through two mayoral administrations, he had an office in City Hall and was an adviser on everything from rebuilding freeways after the 1989 earthquake, to redeveloping shuttered naval bases and reforming demoralized schools.
Finally, in 1998, he decided to run for mayor himself, and likely would have won were it not for the entry of Jerry Brown into a crowded field. Mr. Blakely finished second to the former California governor and perennial presidential candidate. But he has served as Mr. Brown's educational adviser and wrote four ballot initiatives related to school reform that passed in last month's election.
With that responsibility behind him, Mr. Blakely says he is settling in here. He has yet to "learn the environment, the cultural scene, the social scene, the important actors," he said, many of whom will change in the next election..
Mr. Blakely said he did not anticipate becoming a political force here, as he was in California. And that is part of Stage Three of the life plan, inspired by an aunt who taught elementary school and shaped young minds. At Berkeley, Mr. Blakely said, teaching was a "sideline" to his political activities. At the University of Southern California, where he served as dean from 1994 to 1999 (with a year's leave to run for mayor) his task was administrative: merging the schools of public administration and urban planning.
NOW, he is back in the classroom, eager to "have an impact on the practitioners of the future." And his goal, for the 600 graduate students and 27 faculty members in the department, is to be at the forefront of moving the discipline forward. Along with its program in management and urban policy, the New School already trains health care administrators, managers of nonprofit organizations, and human resource managers. Next is a specialty in organizational change.
Mr. Blakely notes that "government is not the only player," as it was in the days of Robert Moses or Fiorello La Guardia. Wall Street is a mini-government, he said, as are the business improvement districts, like the one that transformed Times Square, and the development corporations, like the one that created Battery Park City.
Mr. Blakely grows animated talking about what he calls the "new geography" -- the connections between New York City and London, upstate New York and Canada, San Diego and Tijuana -- and the "new entities," like venture capitalists and minority entrepreneurs.
But will teaching this evolving discipline be enough for a man used to reaching the speaker of the California Assembly on the first ring? "See, I've done that," he said. "I don't need a repeat."

HEADLINE: The Protesters and the Bank

 BODY:
If the goal of protesters in Washington was to stop the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank from meeting, or shut them down entirely, they clearly failed. The numbers of people who descended on the capital were smaller than expected, and the Washington police engaged in pre-emptive arrests to stop disruptions. Still, the so-called Mobilization for Economic Justice did manage to create havoc throughout the capital over the last three days and call attention to tensions related to the growth of the global economy. There was little from the protesters about how the fund and the bank could be improved instead of scrapped.
Inside the opulent headquarters where they met, financial officials all said they understood the protesters' concerns and were in fact trying to change both the I.M.F. and the World Bank to accommodate them. The I.M.F. has declared its willingness to forgive a large portion of the debt owed by poor countries, but it only inched forward toward that goal. The overseers of the World Bank pledged to be more sensitive to those who have suffered as a result of global economic changes, and they committed "unlimited money" to fight the AIDS epidemic. 
 Even before the protests in Washington, both sides were gearing up for a battle reminiscent of the ones that shut down Seattle last year during a trade meeting. The agitators dreamed of halting the city's operations and achieving a widespread shift in public opinion. But the Washington police had clearly learned the tactical lesson of Seattle, making wholesale arrests simply to clear the streets. There were some reports of beatings of innocent people, but also reports of unwarranted attacks on the police by protesters. In the end, it appeared that most people on both sides exercised restraint.
For many Americans, there was less concern over the cries for economic justice from Washington than for the instability of their own stock portfolios in light of the gyrations on Wall Street last Friday. But the United States and other countries that superintend the I.M.F., the World Bank and the World Trade Organization need to keep up the pressure for reform from within. Without the support of people in donor and recipient countries, these institutions cannot continue to meet the challenges they face and bring about necessary improvements. With greater public understanding, they can help ensure that the global economy is not only strong but also fair and protective of human rights and the environment.

HEADLINE: U.N. Council to Review Sanctions Policy as Criticism Increases

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 17

 BODY:
The Security Council, faced with growing criticism of embargoes that fail to deter dictators but often hurt civilians, decided unanimously today to take a hard look at how sanctions are applied and how they can be improved.
In a long debate, no council member or representative of other nations expressed unqualified approval of the way sanctions are now used. The council president, Robert Fowler of Canada, announced that a working group, drawing on outside experts, would begin a six-month policy review. 
 The move reflects a wider sanctions re-examination taking place around the world, including studies by committees in the British and Canadian Parliaments and expert studies for Germany and Switzerland. There are many calls for "smart" sanctions that would be more precisely directed against leaders and their entourages.
This morning, speaking to a conference of United Nations officials, diplomats and scholars, Secretary General Kofi Annan said there was a "general lack of understanding and skepticism in the general public about the rationale and usefulness of sanctions." Even among nations not affected by sanctions, he said, "there appears a growing distrust of this instrument, and its ability to bring about change at a fair cost."
The United Nations is having a hard time responding to critics of sanctions against Iraq, where, according to a new estimate from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, 80 percent of the civilian population has been negatively affected.
The Clinton administration has been largely absent from this worldwide debate, diplomats say. It has instead continued to use sanctions or the threat of sanctions widely, sometimes pressing the Security Council to back up Washington's measures, to the discomfort of other nations.
Some diplomats say that barring a particularly terrible outrage by a leader somewhere, it will be very difficult in the foreseeable future to win a vote for sanctions, especially for a comprehensive economic embargo like that imposed on Iraq a decade ago.
"The Security Council has imposed sanctions 12 times since 1990 and only twice before then," Jean-David Levitte, the French ambassador here, said during today's debate, adding that the increase justified a reassessment of sanctions policy.
"The Sanctions Decade" is the title of a new book by two American scholars, David Cortright of the Fourth Freedom Forum and George Lopez of Notre Dame. The book (International Peace Academy/Lynne Reinner Publishers) studies 12 cases and summarizes suggestions for improving sanctions that have been made by experts around the world.
Today, the French and the Russians added a call for limited durations for sanctions, forcing complete reviews rather than rollovers at periodic intervals.
James B. Cunningham, the deputy American representative, said that once imposed, sanctions should be kept in place until the leader against whom they are directed changes behavior.
Security Council sanctions, carrying the possibility of military enforcement, are in effect in Afghanistan, Angola, Iraq, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan and Yugoslavia, the last for President Slobodan Milosevic's actions in Kosovo. Sanctions against Libya were suspended after two suspects were turned over to a Scottish court for trial in the 1988 bombing of Pan American Flight 101.

HEADLINE: Italy's Leader Shaken by Right's Gains in Regional Voting

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, April 17

 BODY:
Weakened by severe losses in regional elections on Sunday, Italy's center-left prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, submitted his resignation tonight. But President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi rejected it, and told him to consult Parliament.
Mr. D'Alema did not say he would seek a vote of confidence in Parliament, but that is the usual procedure when a government is imperiled. He did say he would seek a mandate at least until May 21, when Italians are to vote in a referendum that seeks, among other things, to create a bipolar electoral system. 
 But the prime minister's newly invigorated center-right opponents want him to leave office right away. If Mr. D'Alema fails to retain his slender majority in Parliament, Italy could be plunged into elections a year early.
Italy's center-right opposition leader, Silvio Berlusconi, received huge backing in the elections on Sunday as his coalition won 8 out of 15 regions. "The results are evident and indisputable; the government majority in Parliament is a minority in the rest of the country," he said. He called for early elections to "restore to the people their sovereignty."
After discussing the sobering results with his cabinet, Mr. D'Alema met with Mr. Ciampi. He argued that with the referendum in May, a new electoral law could emerge, dispensing with the current hybrid system that retains 25 percent proportional representation. Such a change, he said, would "guarantee the stability and authority of the government." But he promised not to use the referendum as a "shield" to preserve his shaky hold on power.
The regional election results, which were tallied today, underscored the strength of the Polo, the center-right bloc, as well as the popularity of its leader, Mr. Berlusconi, a media tycoon who was elected prime minister in 1994. He tumbled from power less than a year later when his coalition partner, Umberto Bossi, leader of the separatist Northern League, pulled out.
This time Mr. Bossi, who has scaled down his rebel platform from separatism to greater federalism, again joined forces with Mr. Berlusconi's center-right Forza Italia. As expected, their coalition held a firm grip on the affluent north. But Mr. Berlusconi's party, aligned with other small center-right parties, also won key regions to the south, including Lazio, the province of Rome.
Sunday was the first time Italians voted directly for regional presidents, who are akin, if slightly less powerful, to governors in the United States. Turnout was 72.6 percent, high by American standards, but almost 9 points lower than in the last regional elections in 1995.
The next parliamentary elections are supposed to take place in 2001. But on May 21 Italians are to vote again in a referendum that proposes the elimination of the remaining quota of proportional representation in Parliament, which many analysts say has kept the political system unstable. If passed, the referendum would introduce a system that would force small parties to coalesce into two blocs on the right and the left. But it is opposed by Mr. Berlusconi, as well as some center-left politicians, who fear that their small parties will become extinct.
The referendum is only one of many issues that have chiseled away at Mr. D'Alema's support.
"At its most obvious and banal level, the results reveal voters' rejection of the D'Alema government," said Lucio Caracciolo, a political analyst and editor of Limes, a bimonthly journal. "The center-left has failed to convince voters that they are doing anything about immigration or unemployment."
The heated, sometimes nasty campaign leading to today's results was waged not on local issues but a national agenda, marked most by the tactics of Mr. Berlusconi. A onetime cruise ship crooner, he returned to his deckside roots for the campaign, cruising up and down the coast on a luxury liner, keeping the spotlight firmly on his own perenially tanned persona. "There is no one like me," he told small crowds invited onto his boat from Naples to Venice during his 10-day campaign-at-sea.
Mr. Berlusconi, 63, who among other things owns the AC Milan soccer team and Italy's three largest private networks, has been investigated and convicted on charges of illegal campaign contributions and corrupt business practices like bribing tax officials (one conviction of false accounting was overturned on appeal in February) and still faces a battery of trials. But he has portrayed his legal battles as political persecution by leftist prosecutors, and many Italians, who admire him as a self-made tycoon, do not seem particularly shocked by his trail of convictions.
Mr. D'Alema, who will turn 51 on Thursday, entered the race confidently, predicting that his coalition would pick up at least one more region than it took in 1995, when the center-left won nine regions, three more than the center-right. He had hoped the election results would lend a stamp of legitimacy to his government, which was put together in a parliamentary maneuver in 1998.
Mr. D'Alema, a former Communist and founder of the non-Marxist party Democrats of the Left, nearly lost a no-confidence vote in December when his fragile coalition splintered. That left him with an even slimmer majority.

HEADLINE: World Trade Officials Pledging To Step Up Effort Against AIDS

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN and JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The world's top financial officials, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protesters braved a chilling rain and an impenetrable police force outside, pledged to pay more attention to globalization's victims and to commit "unlimited money" to fight AIDS in poor countries.
The finance ministers and central bank governors who oversee the World Bank said the bank should intensify its fight against AIDS because the disease is as much a problem of poverty as public health. More than 50 million people are infected with the virus that causes the disease, and it is spreading fastest in Africa, India, China and the Caribbean, all major World Bank clients. The bank has been active for more than a decade in fighting the disease. 
 The new commitment on AIDS came as finance officials sought to show that they were at least as focused on helping people and nations that have not benefited much from globalization as they are on speeding the international march of capitalism. They promised to accelerate debt relief for the developing world and to press rich nations to agree to import farm and clothing products from the poorest ones duty free.
But some of their promises are unlikely to be fulfilled soon. Wealthy nations have been slow to commit the money necessary for debt relief, and the World Bank has insisted on an intensive review of how third-world countries will use money made available when debt is forgiven.
The United States also watered down language on duty-free market access in a final communique today for fear that any broad commitment to open markets here would prompt a backlash from Congress and undermine support for the Clinton administration's push to grant China permanent normal trade status.
Protests against the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund wound down in a driving rain today as a small band of demonstrators scuffled with the police early in the morning, and others, their numbers greatly diminished from the more than 10,000 during the weekend, marched through the streets.
After several tense standoffs with lines of helmeted policemen, a strange street party developed as the police agreed to doff their gas masks and peacefully arrest protesters who stepped through a symbolic breach in their barricades in small groups.
Makeshift drums throbbed, puppeteers danced, and beach balls were tossed around as 500 people walked arm in arm in groups of a dozen or so to be taken to buses as the crowd chanted, "We're here! We're wet! Cancel the debt!" The protesters accuse the World Bank and the I.M.F. of spreading the gospel of free-market capitalism to benefit corporations while ignoring the environmental impact of their policies and worsening poverty in many countries.
Mayor Anthony A. Williams said at a morning news conference, "Our police officers and law enforcement officers played it right."
But while disrupting Washington on a Sunday is a small matter -- the downtown is virtually deserted then anyway -- the protesters did manage to close down normal business in the capital today. The city and federal government told many workers to stay home. And the police closed so many streets to traffic that they in effect shut down another major economic power: the lobbying firms along K Street.
Though protesters never managed to disrupt the meetings at the bank and the fund as they had hoped, the turnout of activists put officials on the defensive.
"It was impossible not to be affected," said James D. Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, who complained that the bank was being accused of causing poverty when all of its employees were devoted to alleviating it.
"I come to work every day with 10,000 colleagues who think that they are doing what we are being criticized for," Mr. Wolfensohn said. "I am a bit nonplussed, really."
Mr. Wolfensohn said the decision to step up the fight against AIDS was a example of the bank's commitment to fight poverty in all its manifestations -- and of what he called the protesters' ignorance of World Bank initiatives. The bank is well known for financing large-scale dams, roads and power plants in third-world nations, projects that critics say often do not do much to help the poor. Mr. Wolfensohn said the bank these days was much more focused on small-scale poverty-relief initiatives and efforts to combat diseases.
After reviewing the bank's policies today, the so-called Development Committee, controlled by the bank's member nations, made AIDS lending the bank's top priority. The bank has made loans to AIDS-related projects for a dozen years, but it has recently become more active in programs in Africa, India, Eastern Europe and several other areas.
The bank does not administer health programs itself. But Mr. Wolfensohn said it was prepared to help countries impacted by AIDS to develop prevention and treatment programs.
"We will make sure that no sensible program is stopped for lack of money," he said. "We will either provide it ourselves or we will help them raise it."
The finance minister of India, Yashwant Sinha, strongly supported the World Bank's efforts on AIDS. He suggested that they showed that the bank was more in touch with the interests of developing countries than protesters were. "Really nobody knows what they are protesting against," he said. "They were here to prevent us from doing our work."
After the large, peaceful protests on Sunday -- with some protesters garbed as sea turtles, others wearing shark fin hats, as in loan shark, and huge puppets like the "structural adjustment mechanism," a Rube Goldberg contraption with jaws that ate rain forests -- leaders of "affinity groups" gathered late Sunday night to reassess their tactics.
"We decided we needed to radically change our style today," said Terra Lawson, a 21-year old Yale senior.
They were to break into two groups, with the smaller band of about 400 going out early to try to cause trouble for the delegates being escorted by the police to the meeting. But in a series of scuffles, the police quickly stopped them with pepper spray, clubs and tear gas, arresting, they said, about 90 people.
A little before 8 a.m., a bus filled with delegates making their way to the World Bank crossed paths with about 100 demonstrators. Several protesters, black-clad anarchists among them, tried to sit in front of the bus. A squad of riot-equipped police officers jumped out of a van behind the delegate's bus, doused the protesters with pepper spray, dragged them away from the buses, and sped off with the delegates.
Chief Charles H. Ramsey was clutching a small red rose by the barricades this afternoon as a tense confrontation was defused. That face-off developed after the main body of 1,000 protesters managed to march at around 10:30 a.m., reaching a wide intersection near the George Washington University campus and the World Bank. Sirens wailed as the police in patrol cars, motorcycles and vans with black windows raced through the streets after the protesters.
"We're nonviolent -- how about you!" the demonstrators chanted.
Solid lines of police officers, cradling their nightsticks, blocked the streets leading toward the banker's meeting, bulging in their black riot gear. A loudspeaker among the demonstrators blared the Darth Vader theme from "Star Wars."
An anarchist climbed onto a traffic light and waved a black flag. At one point the police shot pepper spray at the protesters. The police blocked surrounding intersections several times, then pulled back. At one point, they pounced on a group of about 30 protesters, threw them to the ground, then let them go when they decided they were the wrong ones.
After several hours some of the protesters, including a young woman wearing what looked like a tree on her head, began negotiations by the barricades with Chief Ramsey and other ranking officers. Finally, an agreement was reached and relayed to the crowd. The protesters agreed to move back 10 feet, to sit down and be arrested in small groups. The police would take off their gas masks and make a gap in their barricades for the protesters to walk through before they were arrested.
"It was really tense when the police were pepper-spraying us," said Stephanie Finnernan, 15, holding a sunflower as she danced. "Then when we heard they were opening the gates, we were amazed. Then the arrests and cheers. Now people are dancing in the streets."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
U.S. STOCKS RALLY AFTER PRICES SLIDE IN GLOBAL MARKETS

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stock prices stabilized and then soared in the United States yesterday after plunging in Asia and sliding in early European trading. The recovery eased fears of a collapsing market that had intensified after the Nasdaq composite index lost a quarter of its value last week.
The action produced sighs of relief from Wall Street to Washington, where officials had spent the weekend reassuring investors that nothing was wrong with the economy. 
 But it also emphasized that the extreme volatility of the technology stocks that dominate the Nasdaq market was continuing unabated.
The Nasdaq composite was up less than 1 percent at 3:11 p.m., but then went on a tear and by 4 p.m. was up 6.6 percent for the day, making it the second-best day in Nasdaq history, exceeded only by Oct. 21, 1987, after that year's crash.
The late surge seemed to reflect orders from both individual investors and those from money management firms, in contrast to Friday, when the fall seemed to have been caused mostly by money managers trying to get out as fast as they could.
Other market measures also soared late in the day. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks ended the day up 3.3 percent, rising 44.88 to 1,401.44, and the Dow Jones industrial average ended up 2.7 percent as it gained 276.74, to 10,582.51.
None of the market indexes made up all of their Friday losses, however, and market strategists said it would be wrong to conclude that technology stocks would rally to their recent peaks Page C1 .
The size of the rally surprised even those who had remained bullish through last week's plunge. "I thought we would have an okay day," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, "but I thought it would be subdued." He warned that while economic fundamentals are fine, stock prices will probably be choppy "because the stock market does not do well typically coming off this type of volatility" and the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates again.
Many Wall Street firms, in issuing reassuring comments before trading began, noted that inflation remained subdued, despite a disturbing report on March consumer prices that rattled investors on Friday, and that corporate profits were strong.
The big gains in American stocks came at the end of a trading day that saw heavy volatility around the world, with Asian markets down as much as 11 percent, but that began to stabilize when a new offering of an Internet company in Germany found willing buyers and rose 40 percent from its offering price.
As stock prices were rising, interest rates were also on the rise, more than offsetting Friday's declines. The yield on 10-year Treasury notes rose from 5.85 percent to 6.04 percent. While last week's market chaos had encouraged some to think that the Fed might be less likely to raise short-term rates next month, yesterday's recovery seemed to end those hopes. A sharp decline in stocks, it was argued, could make people feel less rich and curb their spending, thereby slowing the economy's torpid growth and lessening the Fed's need to act to keep inflation at bay .
Even as the American stock market was recovering, investors appeared nervous about some of the technology companies that previously were intense objects of speculation. On average, the 50 hottest initial public offerings of 1999 rose less than half a percent yesterday.
In that respect, yesterday's recovery was different from the first big one of this month, when the Nasdaq market turned around in the early afternoon of April 4, after falling 7.6 percent the previous day and losing 13.6 percent more in early trading. Then the same issues leaped almost twice as much as the Nasdaq did.
"The companies that have been subject to less speculative froth" did better yesterday than other Internet stocks, said Henry Blodgett, the Internet analyst for Merrill Lynch, adding that he expected investors to continue to differentiate companies with earnings, or at least good prospects of profits within a year or two, from those with red ink looming indefinitely. "If the sentiment really turns negative, there is no floor on companies that don't have earnings you can point to," he said.
Within the S.& P. 500, an index that generally includes large companies with substantial operating histories, technology stocks rose 9 percent, according to Thomas McManus, an equity strategist for Bank of America Securities, far better than the overall index. Among leading large technology companies, Intel rose 11.3 percent, Cisco 17.7 percent and Oracle 17.8 percent. An index of Internet stocks compiled by TheStreet.com, by contrast, rose less than 2 percent.
The market got a boost from Abby Joseph Cohen, chief market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, who said "there are a lot of companies that are reasonably priced" within the S.& P. 500. She had said on March 28 that technology stocks were "no longer undervalued," but in an interview yesterday she said that "to the extent that technology stocks have gone down in price suggests that they are a better value."
Some still consider the big technology companies too expensive. Nicholas Sargen, global market strategist for J. P. Morgan's private clients, said that on Friday the technology stocks in the S.& P. index were trading at 43 times expected profits. "We still have a market pricing in a high premium for technology," he said.
The Nasdaq composite enjoyed explosive growth beginning last summer and continuing until early last month. While the index remains down 29.9 percent from its peak, it is up 42.5 percent over the last year.
Yesterday began on a scary note. Asian markets suffered steep losses, with technology issues doing the worst. The Japanese market fell 7.0 percent, Hong Kong lost 6.6 percent and South Korea fell 11.7 percent.
Major European markets opened with declines of about 3 percent, but ended the day with smaller losses.
The first indication that yesterday was not to be a day of complete bad news for shareholders came in Europe, where the initial public offering of T-Online, Germany's largest Internet service, rose 48 percent in the first day of trading.
Still, there was a clear sense of nervousness in the hours leading up to the New York opening. The overnight market in stock index futures -- a market that was being closely watched for signs of how New York would open -- gyrated rapidly as far more contracts were traded than on a normal Sunday night and Monday morning. But within minutes of the 9:30 a.m. opening of New York trading, it became clear that sell orders were not overwhelming the market.
There were some good earnings reports yesterday, from such companies as Ford, Bank of America, Citigroup, Charles Schwab and Merrill Lynch. But those reports came before trading began in the morning, and while they helped the individual stocks, they did not appear to have set off the late-afternoon surge.
Instead, it appeared to be a recovery of confidence both among institutional and individual investors. "I don't know anyone personally who is selling," said Wayda Pearle, 38, a welder interviewed yesterday at a brokerage office in San Jose, Calif. "I know a lot of people who are running to buy." He said he had bought $5,000 in technology stocks.
Fidelity Investments, the largest mutual fund company, said that it suffered "very small withdrawals" from equity funds yesterday, far less than Friday. But it added that its customers who traded in individual stocks had bought twice as many shares as they had sold.
T. Rowe Price, another major mutual fund company, said that it had a net inflow of cash into its stock funds, with much of the money going into two funds, one that specializes in technology stocks and another that focuses on blue chip stocks.

HEADLINE: The Sweetest Words of All: No Charge

BYLINE: By CLIFF ROTHMAN; Cliff Rothman is a writer in Los Angeles who specializes in culture.

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
WHEN the "Angels at the Vatican" exhibition toured the United States two years ago, it drew an average of 918 visitors a day to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 964 to the Baltimore Museum of Art and 1,804 to the Detroit Institute of Arts. But the St. Louis Art Museum dwarfed the others, with 2,420 people a day.
Two years earlier, "Splendors of the Pharaohs" drew 163,459 visitors to the St. Louis museum, 50 percent more than its closest competitor, the Indianapolis Museum of Art. And in 1993, "The Plains Indians" had 110,000 visitors in St. Louis, 10,000 more than even its organizer, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts. 
 "In the 10 years I've been here," said Kay Porter, the director of community relations for the St. Louis museum, "we've consistently come first for every touring exhibition."
Something in the water? Probably not. A more likely explanation lies in an unusual and alluring feature of the city's museum system.
Admission is free.
That's right: Nothing. Nada. Zilch. Although there is a charge for touring exhibitions like "Angels at the Vatican," visitors pay nothing to get into the museum itself. And the policy applies throughout St. Louis's museum system: the zoo, the history museum, the science center and (though at select times, and for local residents only) the botanical garden.
American museums derive an average of 20 percent of their earned income from admissions, according to the American Association of Museums, and fees vary widely -- from $5 at the Confederate Civil War Museum in New Orleans, for example, to $12 at the Guggenheim in New York and the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. But in St. Louis -- founded by working-class European immigrants who smarted from the memories of the elitism of their homelands' cultural institutions -- tradition dictates otherwise.
In 1904, after the close of the great Louisiana Purchase Exposition, the sole remaining permanent structure -- the Palace of Fine Arts -- was converted to what would become the St. Louis Art Museum, with free admission supported by local property taxes. There it is, etched into the building's limestone frieze: "Dedicated to Art and Free to All."
The next year, the zoo was added. "It was put to a public referendum so that the residents of the city of St. Louis had to vote in favor of it, which they did," said Charlie Hoessel, the zoo director.
Next came the Museum of Science. In 1983, the Missouri Botanical Garden was brought into the fold, followed five years later by the Jefferson Memorial Museum, renamed the Missouri Historical Society.
Through two world wars, the Depression and several recessions, admission has steadfastly remained free of charge -- a rare utopian dynamic with no local opposition and evidence that it attracts thousands of visitors, increases tourism, burnishes the city's egalitarian identity and is happily -- yes, happily -- supported by taxpayer dollars.
When an admission charge was proposed to pay for capital improvements, voters in both the city and county voted to double their museum tax -- a component of property taxes -- to keep the free admission policy, said Mr. Hoessel.
The system is overseen by an umbrella organization dubbed, somewhat lugubriously, the Metropolitan Zoological Park and Museum District. Four of its eight directors are appointed by the mayor and four by the county executive, whose jurisdiction includes the suburbs. The district's property tax -- now 22 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, or $220 on a house assessed at $100,000 -- raises more than $35 million a year, up from $4 million in the early 1980's.
In 1998, for example, the art museum received $11.6 million from property taxes, which provided 78 percent of its general operating support. The remainder came from various other sources, including paid admissions for special exhibitions and programs. Proceeds from the gift shop -- $1.2 million in 1998 -- are used to buy art.
HOW much does free admission affect attendance? The rec ords regularly set by touring art exhibitions offer one barometer. The St. Louis Zoo offers another. With nearly three million visitors a year, it has the second-highest attendance in the country -- just a few hundred thousand fewer than the much-better-known San Diego Zoo, even though the San Diego metropolitan area draws many more tourists than St. Louis.
"A rule of thumb in our industry is that your attendance should reflect your metropolitan population," Mr. Hoessel said. "We're way ahead of the curve."
Free admission doesn't morph museums into competitors of the local mall, of course, but even low-key weekend events have attracted turnouts that startle the management.
"We invited floral designers from the St. Louis community to create floral arrangements inspired by works of art," said Ms. Porter, the art museum spokeswoman, about an event held last month. "We expected to draw, oh, 3,000 or 4,000. More than 8,000 showed up."
The art museum regularly finishes in the top 10 in nationwide attendance, though the St. Louis metropolitan area ranks only 18th in population. In 1998, it had 803,000 visitors, half as many as the Museum of Modern Art in New York.
Do tourists pick St. Louis because some key attractions are free? "Well, 37 percent of our out-of-town visitors went to the zoo, 28 percent went to the science center, 16 percent visited the art museum, 16 percent visited the botanical garden," said Carole Moody, the city's director of marketing. "We see free admission as a factor. Families are looking for value. If they can do more things with the same amount of money within their budget, it makes St. Louis a more attractive destination."
Is there a downside? "Well, membership drives," Ms. Porter said with a laugh. "It becomes a little challenging to establish special benefits when admission is free."

HEADLINE: Nothing Against Old Art, but Gallery Rats Hunger for New

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SOLOMON; Deborah Solomon is the author of "Utopia Parkway: The Life and Work of Joseph Cornell" and a forthcoming biography of Norman Rockwell.

 BODY:
WHEN most people think about art, they think of museums, of climbing the grand stairs to the Met or spiraling down the ramps of the Guggenheim. But the adventure of art is hardly confined to Fifth Avenue. The throngs pouring into museums have little, if any, connection to the small, dedicated crowd of people who follow the contemporary art scene, and who tend to believe that museums have as much to do with supporting the life of art as the circus does with propagating wildlife.
Introducing the New York gallery rats. On Saturday afternoons, they converge en masse on SoHo, on 57th Street and particularly on West Chelsea, the latest art neighborhood in a city that has more than 750 galleries and remains America's art capital. 
 The goal of most gallerygoers is not to buy a painting to hang over their couch. Rather, it is to keep abreast of the scene, to survey new art as it springs into being. The notion excites: fresh work brought to light, most of it by undead artists, most of it consisting of cool and strange objects that might be either excellent, passable or eminently forgettable.
"I see very few museum shows," said Nancy Portnoy, a Manhattan art collector who is on an advisory committee at the Museum of Modern Art and is also a trustee of the New Museum of Contemporary Art. "When I want to see art, I go to galleries, which are about being in the moment, in the now, and discovering artists who haven't been given a gold star by museums. The only time I go to the Met is when I need some place to take my grandchildren."
Gallery rats, it should be noted, have no particular grievance against the art of the past. Many of them, in fact, have felt their hearts race in the presence of a Cezanne still life or a Corot landscape; they fully understand that museums house the physical and spiritual records of humankind.
On the other hand, when you see a work of art in a museum, you are seeing a work that is part of art history and has been touched over time by the gaze of perhaps millions of viewers. Museums offer the dream of the past; galleries, the slap of the new.
Asking people to compare galleries to museums provokes peculiar and disparate metaphors.
"Galleries are like the daily newspaper, while museums are like the Old Testament," said Robert Rosenblum, the curator of 20th-century art at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
As A. M. Homes, the novelist and art writer, suggested, "Gallery shows are like sushi, raw and fresh, while museum shows are like cooked French food, with an enormous number of steps going into the preparation."
Asked which he prefers, Wayne Koestenbaum, the author and cultural critic, listed 15 reasons to favor galleries over museums, from the economic ("galleries are free"), to the aesthetic ("the art in a gallery is more likely to surprise, shock, titillate, unnerve"), to the wryly personal: "When I see art in a gallery, I often have the illusion that it is possible to meet the artist. Art in a museum, even if the artist is alive, offers no such fantasy or hope of access."
Granted, gallerygoing can be intimidating. To enter a gallery specializing in contemporary art is to risk confrontation with a mysterious painting, sculpture, installation, photograph or video that can make the uninitiated feel clumsily insecure. It does not help matters that most galleries, with their all-white, blankly minimal spaces, are about as welcoming as a Soviet-era interrogation room.
And let us not forget that marvelous creature known as the gallery assistant, inevitably a willowy woman who looks as if she stepped out of Vogue, sitting at the front desk and eyeing visitors with a hauteur that confirms their suspicions that they do not completely understand art and should henceforth confine their Saturday outings to the Bronx Zoo.
That helps explain why gallerygoers tend to consist of people with a professional connection to art -- that is, those who either create art, collect art, write about art or curate art for museum exhibitions. Many of them are personally acquainted with one another, and will nod amiably when they pass on a sidewalk.
Such exchanges are a definitive feature of gallerygoing, and create the illusion that the art world is an intimate place, when in fact it is atomized, rivalrous and largely impersonal. In an odd throwback to Victorian etiquette, gallerygoers sign their names in guest books left open on the front counter of most galleries, then discreetly scan the other names on the page in anticipation of who they might see (or try to avoid) that day.
Naturally, there are a few interlopers. "Every so often," said Jay Gorney, an owner of the Gorney Bravin & Lee Gallery in Chelsea, "I might see a disinterested person, like a lawyer who goes to galleries the same way he might have a picnic in Central Park on a sunny day. It's a diversion."
But such stragglers are rare. "Artists are curious about everything," said Paula Cooper, who owns a gallery in Chelsea that bears her name. "They listen to music, they read books, they go to concerts. So why don't musicians and actors come to see art shows at the galleries? It's amazing how ignorant musicians are about art."
Truth be told, it is not only musicians who feel estranged from contemporary art. On Saturday afternoons, the sidewalks of SoHo resemble a subway platform at rush hour, but the passers-by are far more likely to be shopping for a postmodern lampshade than ducking into the galleries.
Then there is Morley Safer, the "60 Minutes" correspondent and modern-art basher, who recently said at a luncheon at the Guggenheim, "I have visited galleries on three occasions, and I never plan to go back."
If Mr. Safer and others like him are unwilling to make the effort, the art world functions just fine without them. A few years ago, the gallery scene moved from SoHo to the Wild West -- namely, Chelsea, around 10th Avenue in the 20's, where there is only one home-furnishing store, a Portico outlet, and enough remaining auto-repair shops to evoke the neighborhood's blue-collar past. The population strolling the wide, quiet streets consists mostly of gallerygoers and remains undiluted by shoppers.
THE power block is 24th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues. Here, in low-lying brick buildings that once were garages, newly renovated art palaces are lined up side by side: the Barbara Gladstone Gallery, Metro Pictures, the Matthew Marks Gallery, Andrea Rosen, Luhring Augustine and, at the end of block, within sight of the Hudson River, the Gagosian Gallery. Unlike SoHo or Greenwich Village before it, which were settled by quaintly impecunious bohemians, Chelsea was colonized by art dealers. For the first time, they bought spaces instead of renting them, which means they cannot be driven out should the neighborhood ever experience a Gap invasion.
If the galleries lack a mass audience, an economist might point out that their survival does not depend on a mass audience. It takes at least 250,000 visitors to turn an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art into a hit, but it takes only one high-rolling collector to turn a gallery show into a sellout. Unlike museums, galleries do not have to think about box-office draw, which gives them a flexibility, a capacity for aesthetic adventure and promiscuity, that museums might envy.
Curiously enough, two New York museums are making news this spring with shows that seek to simulate the experience of gallerygoing. "Greater New York," at the P. S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, the newly annexed Queens branch of the Museum of Modern Art, and the "2000 Biennial" exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, round up work by enough young, unknown artists to start a college. The shows are roughly tantamount to seeing 100 gallery shows under one roof.
But, alas, it is not the same, at least not in the eyes of gallery rats.
"The problem with the P. S. 1 show," said Bill Arning, the chief curator of the M.I.T. List Center for Visual Arts in Cambridge, Mass., "is that you have the authority of MOMA behind each and every work, the power of Picasso and the grandeur of modernism, whereas when you go to a gallery, there is no authority figure saying, 'This is something you should care about.' Galleries license the audience to make up its own mind."
On the other hand, an institution cannot be fairly vilified for the very qualities that define its excellence. Museums are valued because they order and classify the world's riotous jumble of objects. Not unlike great paintings or sculptures, museums make meaning out of chaos. Ideally, they separate the first-rate from the duds, elevate taste and present the achievements of civilization at their shining best.
Then again, at a time when most museums favor crowd-pleasing exhibitions that can make it hard to see a work of art without peering through someone's bouffant hairdo, gallerygoing represents what museumgoing once was -- a chance to gratify your art yearnings without having to stand in line.

HEADLINE: THE NEW POPULISM;
Once Confined to the Wings, Photography Becomes a Star

BYLINE: By TESSA DeCARLO; Tessa DeCarlo writes about the arts from the Napa Valley of California.

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
THE Museum of Photographic Arts in Balboa Park here used to be confined to a cramped 7,000-square-foot space tucked behind a stodgy sports museum carpeted in AstroTurf. The photography museum's new home, which opened April 4, has not only a highly visible entrance on the park's main avenue, but also state-of-the-art quarters with four times as much space.
Until recently, the only dedicated photography gallery at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston was on the side of a stairwell on the museum's lower floor. Last month the museum opened a second building, with a spacious first-floor gallery for photography, prints and drawings, as well as study and storage areas for the photography department. 
 "I used to joke that in most museums in America, photography was on the way to either the restroom or the restaurant," said Anne Tucker, the photography curator at the Houston museum. "Now, that's not necessarily so."
Accessible, stylish, diverse and relatively affordable -- embraced by contemporary artists, celebrity collectors and the public -- photography has become a hot ticket. So as the booming economy increases art museums' wherewithal for building their collections and expanding their galleries, more are giving attention and space to a medium that was struggling to get into museums only a few decades ago.
"For a long time, photography internalized the message that it was a secondhand, second-class medium, but over time that's been changing," said Arthur Ollman, the director of the Museum of Photographic Arts. "Now a critical mass has been achieved, and even institutions as sluggish as museums have had to recognize that photography has to be taken very, very seriously."
During the past 17 years, Mr. Ollman has overseen the growth of the museum from a nomadic institution with neither a collection nor a permanent home to a well-equipped institution in a prime location. The museum has been in Balboa Park since it opened in 1983, but until this year was confined to the space behind the Hall of Champions sports museum. Despite these unprepossessing quarters, the museum drew up to 75,000 visitors a year and originated critically acclaimed and widely traveled exhibitions.
Now the Hall of Champions has moved elsewhere in the park and the museum has spread out. Its new home has almost twice the exhibition space, as well as classrooms, a library, a 238-seat theater and preparation and storage areas with temperature-controlled vaults for black-and-white and color photographs.
The space, designed by David Raphael Singer, a local architect, is an appropriate setting for the museum's collection, which has grown to almost 6,000 items spanning the history of photography, and a library of more than 20,000 volumes. The reopened museum's inaugural exhibition, "Expanded Visions," shows off more than 170 highlights from the collection, including daguerreotypes, classic works by Dorothea Lange and Ansel Adams, and contemporary photographs by Sally Mann and Abelardo Morell.
Photography's increasing popularity is evident in other parts of the country, too. Most new museum buildings, like the Getty Center in Los Angeles and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, have plenty of space for photographic exhibitions and preservation, storage and study.
In addition, museums housed in older buildings have been renovated. A year and a half ago, the Art Institute of Chicago dug through one of its bearing walls to expand its photography-storage vaults. It was a good investment, said its curator, David Travis, because the institute's last three photography shows each drew about 70,000 visitors.
Even the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York had no photography department until 1992 and no permanent photography gallery until 1997. In February, the Metropolitan opened a research center devoted to the archives of Walker Evans and marked the occasion with a comprehensive retrospective, which runs through May 14. This week, the museum unveiled a show of large-scale modern photographs from its collection in a new exhibition space in the contemporary art wing.
Although photography has been striving for artistic legitimacy since it was first invented, its ascent from museum stepchild to grown-up has its roots in the 1960's, when Andy Warhol, Robert Rauschenberg and other art luminaries incorporated photographic techniques into their work. "After many years of getting very little attention from anyone but a handful of cheerleaders, photography got injected into the high-art tradition," said Peter Galassi, the curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art. "And after that it never went away."
SINCE that time, Mr. Ollman estimates, the number of American museums with photography departments jumped to about 200 from a dozen. Photography departments also opened in art schools and universities, and the publication of photography books and scholarly articles flourished. Artists as disparate as Cindy Sherman, Chuck Close and Gerhard Richter made photography a central part of their practice. And a growing community of collectors began pushing the prices of all kinds of photographs, including antique albums and contemporary styles.
"When I got into this field in the late 1960's, a million dollars could buy you every important photograph ever made, with enough left over to build a pretty good gallery," Mr. Ollman said. "Today you can spend $1 million on a really nice portfolio of two pieces."
The increased value of photographs has in turn encouraged museums to take them more seriously, especially because they can be cheaper than other artworks.
"For most institutions, this one included, the options to build your paintings collection in a really significant way are limited," said Malcolm Daniel, the Metropolitan's associate curator of photography. "With photography, there's still wonderful material bubbling to the surface, both historical and contemporary. And while the prices seem astonishing compared to where they were 10 years ago, they're modest compared to what you have to pay for a top-notch piece of antiquity or old master drawing. With photography it's still possible to create a great collection."
Even as photography breaks into the canon, its presence is helping to blur museums' traditional categories.
For example, the barriers that formerly kept paintings, drawings and photographs sequestered in separate galleries are crumbling as contemporary artists' mixtures of photography and other techniques free curators to mix media as well.
Thus the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington is adding photography, video and computer art to this year's edition of its 92-year-old painting biennial. The move "is an obvious extension of what we've been doing for several years now," said Philip Brookman, the curator of photography and media arts at the Corcoran. "The distinction between media is no longer relevant in the year 2000."
Photography also continues to challenge the very idea of what art is. So while the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art plans shows on the art-photography icons Diane Arbus and Ansel Adams, in recent years its photography department has also presented influential exhibitions featuring such distinctly nonart photography as police mug shots, geological survey photographs and anonymous snapshots. The Metropolitan is following suit this summer by showing "vernacular" snapshots.
Most photography departments in a growing number of other institutions now include cinema, video and computer art, as well as artists whose work mixes photographic processes with painting, drawing and other art techniques. "The dialogue with painting, with film, with other media," Mr. Ollman said, "just keeps getting more exciting."
