HEADLINE: Blue Chips of the Internet Increase Quarterly Profits

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The engine makers, parts suppliers and plumbers of the Internet have been responsible for the snap back this week in technology stocks. Companies like Cisco Systems, Oracle and Sun Microsystems can be seen as the ballast of the new economy, established concerns with steadily growing profits as opposed to the bubble of fledgling dot-com companies with their uncertain hopes of survival.
Three of the technology blue chips -- Intel, EMC and I.B.M. -- yesterday reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations. The laggard of the three was the International Business Machines Corporation, whose earnings rose but whose revenues declined 5 percent in the first quarter. Big Blue suffered from the lingering effects of the year-end decline in corporate spending on computers and computer services by companies focusing on the Year 2000 transition. 
 That problem is mostly behind it, according to company executives, who predicted I.B.M. would achieve growth rates of 10 percent or more in the second half of the year. Until then, however, Wall Street analysts regard I.B.M. a bit uncertainly, as a company that has not really delivered the proof that its transition to become a supplier of Internet technology to corporate America has yet paid off in higher growth.
But both EMC and Intel reported strong advances in revenue as well as quarterly profits. They join other leading technology companies -- like Sun Microsystems, which last week reported a surge in sales and earnings growth -- that are benefiting from the increased investment in information technology as corporations in industries from automobiles to banking retool their operations for the Internet.
The first of the three companies to announce its results yesterday, the EMC Corporation, is a leading supplier of the equipment increasingly in demand by companies as they adopt Internet technology.
EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., is the market leader in producing large data storage systems for corporations. As companies build Web sites, giving employees, customers and suppliers access to more and more business information, the demand for large, high-speed storage systems has mushroomed. EMC, more than any other company, has benefited from that trend.
EMC said its revenue increased 23 percent in the first quarter to $1.82 billion. Profits for the quarter jumped roughly 50 percent to $332 million, or 30 cents a share -- a penny above the consensus estimate of Wall Street analysts, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Michael Ruettgers, the chief executive officer of EMC, pointed to the rising sales to traditional companies. "We saw surges in demand from large companies such as Home Depot, Bertelsmann of Germany and Korea Telecom," he said, "as they built their Internet initiatives."
EMC shares rose sharply after it reported its quarterly figures, rising $5.625 a share to close at $130.
The Intel Corporation, the world's largest producer of microprocessors, also reported strong growth in the first quarter. Revenue increased 13 percent to $8 billion. Its profit, excluding certain expenses related to acquisitions, rose 52 percent to $3.1 billion, or 88 cents a share.
But those results were lifted $600 million, or 17 cents a share, by a one-time reduction in taxes because an examination by the Internal Revenue Service reversed previously accrued tax liabilities. Excluding the one-time tax bonus, Intel's profit was 71 cents a share, or 2 cents above Wall Street expectations. Intel's microchips not only power more than 80 percent of the world's personal computers -- still the primary devices for accessing the Internet -- but also many of the larger computers, known as servers, that deliver Web pages, e-mail and other data from networks to desktop users.
Intel's one real problem seems to be that it cannot keep up with the torrid pace of orders. "Demand was stronger in the quarter, across all product lines, than we had anticipated," said Andy Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer. "If we had had more parts we could have shipped them." I.B.M. reported that its first-quarter profit rose 3 percent to $1.52 billion, or 83 cents a share, easily above Wall Street's estimate of 78 cents a share. But the 5 percent revenue drop to $19.3 billion in the quarter caused some anxiety.
I.B.M. executives said that certain strategic steps, like pulling back from the difficult retail market for PC's, had trimmed total revenue but had also improved profitability. Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the I.B.M. chairman, was optimistic about the company's outlook. He said the investments I.B.M. has made in helping corporate customers make the transition to Internet technology was beginning to "pay off in exciting new growth prospects for us."
"Looking forward," Mr. Gerstner added, "we continue to believe that 2000 will be a good year for IBM."
Still, industry analysts were disappointed that I.B.M.'s revenue from software and computer services -- two businesses earmarked by management as engines of growth -- were flat. The company also stumbled in its data storage business, where it is trying to regain ground lost to EMC. "I.B.M. has to prove that it has the products and the strategy to gain market share again in the information technology industry," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
In after-hours trading, I.B.M. shares fell as low as $112 a share, after closing at $115.125 a share yesterday on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks RegisterImpressive Gains For Second Consecutive Session

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
With corporate earnings soaring, investors flooded back into United States stocks yesterday for the second consecutive day, retracing much of the ground lost last week.
Coming on the heels of Monday's gains, the rise put an end to immediate fears that small investors are ready to abandon stocks. Yet many Wall Street professionals remain wary that the market is still overly expensive. Some warned that the current rally may prove as ephemeral as the Nasdaq's bounce two weeks ago. 
 Even so, yesterday's gains were impressive. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 254.41 points, to 3,793.57. That 7.2 percent jump, coming on top of Monday's 6.6 percent rise, was the Nasdaq's second-biggest gain ever -- behind only the 7.3 percent increase on Oct. 21, 1987.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 184.91 points, or 1.8 percent, to end the day at 10,767.42, following a gain of 2.7 percent on Monday.
While both indexes remain well off their highs, the Nasdaq now stands above its close Thursday and has regained almost half of last week's scary 25 percent plunge, while the Dow has taken back more than half its 7 percent loss from last week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also performed well, rising 40.17 points, or 2.9 percent, to close at 1,441.61.
Adding to investors' cheer, several important companies posted first-quarter earnings well ahead of analysts' expectations. In the technology sector, Intel and America Online, which reported earnings after the market closed, both handily beat estimates by analysts. Old-economy stocks also showed their strength, with drug companies Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson both posting higher-than-expected profits.
Even so, several money managers and Wall Street strategists pointed to signs that the rally may not last. While earnings are growing fast, many technology stocks remain expensive, and the market's unusually high volatility is worrisome, they said.
"I think we're going to pull back from this," said Fred Kobrick, a veteran money manager who invests almost $2 billion. "People are doing this because they're afraid of missing the upside, not because they see undervalued companies."
Indeed, the weekend's warnings that individual investors might be fleeing stocks have proven ludicrously wrong so far. Since Monday afternoon, investors have bought stocks fiercely, especially in the technology sector, sending bellwethers like Cisco Systems and Intel up 15 percent or more. That is nearly a complete reversal of last week, when investors sent the Nasdaq composite index down 25 percent, including nearly 10 percent on Friday alone, on fears that technology stocks were overpriced and higher interest rates would slow earnings growth.
Christine Callies, chief United States market strategist for Credit Suisse First Boston, warned against reading too much into this week's gains. "This is pretty standard stuff for a market that went down 35 percent," she said. "The harder they fall, the faster they bounce."
The more relevant question, Ms. Callies said, is what happens next. She said that the Nasdaq could hit 4,160, a gain of about 10 percent above its current level, but that any rally would probably not hold.
"Most market bottoms require several attempts," she said. Ms. Callies also worries that investors could be underestimating the risk that inflation is accelerating, which would force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Higher rates would slow the economy and lower corporate profits, probably hurting the stock market.
"If core inflation proves to be higher than the market has thought," she said, "then the Fed is going to be in a very, very delicate position for many months."
Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore, said the Nasdaq rally was more a product of "defensive buying" than of "full conviction." Professional money managers, he said, are just saying, "I can't afford to miss this."
Mr. Cripps added that he would "be surprised if this is an up leg that carries us back to the old highs." In the weeks ahead, he said, the Nasdaq could even fall below the low it set Friday.
But Jeffrey M. Warantz, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said the details of yesterday's rally offered investors some reason for optimism. The rally was broadly based, unlike Monday's gains, which were confined mostly to the largest stocks. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks was up a sharp 5.8 percent yesterday, compared with a gain of just 1.2 percent on Monday.
Still, Mr. Warantz said he wished stocks would settle down. Investors may be pleased with their gains this week, but unless the market calms, he said, "we could turn around and have another 400-point down day."
A look at the biggest winners this week offers proof of just how quickly investors have turned back to their technology favorites. Four of the 10 best performers in the Nasdaq 100 index, made up the largest companies in the Nasdaq composite, were among the 10 worst performers last week.
The four winners: Applied Micro Circuits, which makes high-bandwidth products, up $2.625 yesterday, to $107.25, and 50 percent in the last two days; Echostar, which operates a satellite television service, up $6.4375 yesterday, to $57.8125, and up 35 percent this week; Network Solutions, which provides Internet domain registration services, up $27.625 yesterday, to $148.625, and 40 percent this week; and Broadvision, a manufacturer of e-commerce software, up $11.125 yesterday, to $38, and up 28 percent this week. Yet all are still below where they were before last week's sell-off.
In the Dow, the pattern is even more striking. Four of the 10 stocks that had the biggest declines last week were among the leaders in the rebound on Monday and yesterday, including General Electric, Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Microsoft. But all four are still below where they traded when the decline began.

HEADLINE: Tangling of Jewish Roots Bars Ethiopians From Israel

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 18

 BODY:
The Jewish center was packed today, the day before Passover: children sang in Hebrew. The ritual bath was filled. Three rows of workers flattened dough for matzos, baked in 30 ovens so smoky that the place seemed on fire.
If the people at the Beta Israel Community are not really Jews -- and the Israeli government says it has doubts -- they certainly work hard at their religious practices. 
 They are among the 26,000 people still in Ethiopia who claim to be Jewish and want to leave for Israel. To them and their many supporters, they are the ones left behind. In Israel, the Ethiopian population has increased to 70,000 people in waves of immigration since the mid-1980's.
"It's something special," Andrew Goldman, an American with a charity that assists the group, said today as he helped prepare the center for Passover, which celebrates the exodus from Egypt. "These people have been crossing the Red Sea in my lifetime."
But the Israeli government has been slow to act on their requests, saying their ties to Judaism are not as certain as those of Ethiopians who clearly maintained their faith and were allowed to emigrate in the past.
Some government officials say they worry that the motives are really economic: Ethiopia is one of the poorest nations, made worse by a severe food shortage in the last several months, and Jews here are among the worst off.
In Israel, pressure has mounted, as the Israeli Supreme Court last month ordered the government to develop a plan to process the Ethiopians' immigration applications. Earlier this month, Natan Sharansky, the Israeli interior minister, visited to see the situation firsthand.
At the end of his trip, he promised that applications would be handled more quickly; some people have been waiting 10 years. And he said he was horrified at the cramped and filthy houses where people are living.
"I can compare them only to the punishment cells in the Soviet Union, in which I spent years," Mr. Sharansky, a former Soviet dissident, told reporters in Addis Ababa.
But he was firm that only those with strong claims, under the law that governs who is considered Jewish, would be approved. "We can't open up for everyone who wants to come," he said.
They are known as Falash Mura, and what complicates their claim to be Jewish is that in many cases, their families converted to Christianity a few generations ago. Descendants say the families did so to avoid an emerging persecution from Ethiopia's large Christian population.
"We were hated," said Mitiku Yalew, chairman of the Addis Ababa Beta Israel Community. "They told us we had the evil eye."
His story is like many others. His grandfather, he said, was a practicing Jew near Gondar in the rugged north who taught Hebrew. Fifty years ago, as Christians in the area harassed the Jews, his father converted.
But Mr. Yalew said the conversion was only "pretend," a situation that often was plain to Christians, too. The family did not go to church. There was little intermarriage. Many Falash Mura still cannot be buried in Christian cemeteries.
At the same time, many people gave up Jewish religious practices because they were afraid of provoking their neighbors. "We didn't have any teachers to teach us about the Torah," said Mr. Yalew, who began observing Judaism five years ago.
Yeshinesh Koye, 19, said her grandfather converted to Christianity, but the family ended up practicing neither religion until recently. She has a cross tattooed on her forehead, common among the Falash Mura as a way of convincing Christians that they were not Jews. Asked why she began to observe Judaism, she answered: "It is my religion. It is inherited from my ancestors."
This ambiguity makes it hard to sort out the claims, Israeli officials say. Mr. Sharansky noted that there are few written records. And officials worry that if they let in these 26,000, many others will claim to be Jews to better their lives in Israel.
It is true that most of them lead terrible lives. With the hope of emigrating in the early 1990's, many left their villages for the cities. Their land was taken over, and now they live as urban refugees of sorts.
Gedamu Kassa, 75, sick and bone-thin, lives in a small room with walls made of cow manure with his wife and four other family members. His son lives in Israel. "Most of our relatives have gone to Israel and we want to join them," he said.
The Falash Mura and their supporters reject the idea that they are economic refugees alone. Many of them have relatives among the 4,000 Falash Mura who have made it to Israel, and who lead religious lives there, supporters say. "If they were just economic refugees there would be no reason for them to do that," said Joseph Feit, a New York tax lawyer on the board of the North American Conference on Ethiopian Jewry, the charity that Mr. Goldman works for. In the United States, the three branches of Judaism support emigration for the Falash Mura, and in Israel too there are many groups backing them.
Israel has accepted thousands of Russians, not all of them Jewish by Jewish law, a fact that the Ethiopians have noticed. "Since we are black there are serious investigations," Mr. Yalew said. "For Russians, they don't do the same thing. That is racism. That's a problem."
As they wait, the Falash Mura busy themselves at the center in Addis Ababa and another in Gondar. Most go there to pray three times a day. Nearly 5,000 children attend school at the centers, singing the Israeli national anthem before class. The center employs 850 people to embroider scenes of Ethiopian Jewish life, which are made into pillows and sold in the United States.
One of the embroiderers is Desalegn Gibte, 55, who stitches embroidery for about $20 a month. "We are doing this just to get paid," he said. "We barely get enough to pay rent."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Adam Nagourney and Judith H. Dobrzynski 

 BODY:

A Condolence Call Beats a Fax
HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, the target of more than a little criticism from ASSEMBLYMAN DOV HIKIND in the 10 weeks since she officially began her campaign for the United States Senate, paid a condolence call on Mr. Hikind on Monday. His father, Meyer, 79, died over the weekend. 
 Mrs. Clinton took a basket of fruit and spent 30 minutes at Mr. Hikind's mother's house. As he told it yesterday, Mrs. Clinton kneeled in front of his mother, FRIEDA, and expressed sympathy.
"She was extremely gracious, extremely kind," Mr. Hikind said. "She impressed my mother. I don't think my mother has stopped talking about it."
Mrs. Clinton has been making overtures to Mr. Hikind, a former backer of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, in recent weeks. But the question of Mr. Hikind's stand in the Clinton-Giuliani race did not come up on Monday, Mr. Hikind said.
Mr. Hikind did say that he had his mother roll up a sleeve to show the first lady the number tattooed on her arm from her 11 months in Auschwitz. "I told Hillary that will help explain why I feel so strongly about issues involving Israel," he said.
Mrs. Clinton was one of a line of politicians who paid a call on the Hikinds. Mr. Giuliani was not among them. He faxed a note to Mr. Hikind's office, though Mr. Hikind said that he had not read it.
"It left me empty," he said. "To be honest with you, faxing me a note to my office sort of speaks for itself."
 
From Park to Dots
KAREN H. PUTNAM, the president of the Central Park Conservancy for the last five years, is resigning. On her watch the conservancy's endowment climbed to more than $100 million from $14 million -- "and the park looks fabulous," she said yesterday. Before she leaves on June 30, the final installment of the conservancy's capital campaign, the new North Meadow ball fields, will be completed and dedicated.
She said she planned to work on advising "high net-worth individuals" about philanthropy. She also hopes to help set up a Web site for Internet-economy givers.
If timing is everything, is this the time to move into that world? Hasn't the Nasdaq composite index recently lost a lot of its value? "Yes, but aren't we looking at 40 percent higher than it was last year?" she said. "Long term, I'm very upbeat."
 
Surprise Roast
There were moments on Monday night when the Friars Club's salute to JERRY ORBACH -- a star of the NBC drama "Law and Order" and such theatrical hits as "The Fantasticks" and "42nd Street" -- came close to being a roast of PAUL SORVINO.
The master of ceremonies, FREDDIE ROMAN, said Mr. Orbach should be grateful to Mr. Sorvino, who left "Law and Order" in 1992. "Sorvino could have been on that show for another eight or nine years," Mr. Roman said, "but he wanted to do opera."
A bit later, the executive producer of "Law and Order," ED SHERIN, told the guests, "If Paul Sorvino were still on 'Law and Order,' there would not be a 'Law and Order.' " There was a gasp in the audience as he added, "I was saved from early retirement by Jerry Orbach."
Will O: The Oprah Magazine compete with Martha Stewart Living? "Don't know yet," Ms. Stewart said with a shrug at a party for O. "But there is always room for another good thing."
There was room at the party, at the Metropolitan Pavilion on West 18th Street, for a crowd that included EARTHA KITT, DIANA ROSS, DIANE SAWYER, TINA TURNER, BARBARA WALTERS -- and SEAN (PUFFY) COMBS. He noted that while O is written for women, "Sure I'm going to read it. It's Oprah. Anything that woman does I'm interested in."
ROSIE O'DONNELL, who was a guest at the party, had Ms. Winfrey as a guest on her talk show yesterday. By the time they stopped for a commercial, Ms. O'Donnell had volunteered to do a two-page feature about decoupage for O. "I swear to you -- when is it due?" Ms. O'Donnell asked.
 
Pleading Poverty
Most museum directors are reluctant to point out the gaps in their collections. But there was PHILIPPE DE MONTEBELLO of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, standing at a podium in its candle-lighted Temple of Dendur, announcing that the museum had no works by Donatello, Verrocchio or Caillebotte, and scarcely any archaic jades, a high point of Chinese art.
"I could go on, of course," he said, "but then this would begin to sound like a jeremiad."
There was nothing ulterior about his motive. More than 300 arts patrons had paid more than $1,000 apiece to attend the second annual dinner to benefit the Met's acquisition fund. Before they could enjoy the appetizer (cold baby lobster), they had to listen to his pitch.
MICHEL DAVID-WEILL, SID BASS, MICHAEL BLOOMBERG, DEDA BLAIR and BROOKE ASTOR later waited through pitches from curators before the main course. The dinner raised $750,000, but that will not buy much. A Caillebotte up for auction May 8 at Christie's is estimated at $6 million to $8 million.
 JAMES BARRON with Adam Nagourney and Judith H. Dobrzynski

HEADLINE: Board May Sell Schools Chief's Residence

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Just a few weeks after the New York City Board of Education began weighing the sale of its often maligned headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, another piece of board property -- with almost as intriguing a history -- has been suggested as a candidate for the selling block.
William C. Thompson Jr., the president of the Board of Education, said in an interview yesterday that he believed that the board should sell the stately Brooklyn Heights town house that it bought in 1990 to serve as the schools chancellor's official residence. 
 With the board in the middle of a search for a permanent chancellor and the assumed front-runner, Harold O. Levy, the interim chancellor, comfortably housed in his own apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the proposal raises interesting questions about whether any out-of-town candidates will receive serious consideration for the job.
Mr. Thompson, who said last week that the board had received about 80 applications for the job, many from outside of New York City, insisted that they would be seriously considered. The proposed sale "means nothing with regard to who the next chancellor might be," he said.
Rather, he said, selling the house is simply good business sense. "With real estate values at the level they are right now, it probably makes more sense to take advantage of that," Mr. Thompson said. "We could keep the money in some form that would generate income and use that to provide whoever the chancellor is with a housing allowance."
His idea is at such a preliminary stage that Mr. Thompson said he has not yet discussed it with the other six members of the board, who would be required to vote on the proposal.
But he could be right about the timing. Marilyn A. Donahue, a Brooklyn real estate agent who brokered the property's sale to the board for $995,000 in April 1990, said the five-bedroom, four-story town house, at 80 State Street, could fetch more than twice what the board paid.
The board agreed to buy a home in 1990 as an inducement to lure Joseph A. Fernandez to New York from Florida, where he ran the school system that includes Miami. Former board officials said the housing arrangement was intended to be similar to those that many universities used for their presidents or chancellors, including several schools in the City University of New York system. Typically, those homes are used for entertaining alumni and potential donors as well as for the school leader's residence.
But for years after the purchase of the federal-style town house, past the end of Mr. Fernandez's tenure in June 1993 and into that of Ramon C. Cortines, who served in the job from September 1993 through October 1995, the brownstone building, which includes a maid's room, a fireplace, terrace, patio and small front and back yards, was a source of considerable controversy.
Shortly after the purchase was completed, the economy slipped into recession, leading to drastic budget cuts throughout the Board of Education. But as the board was tightening the financial reins on school district superintendents and principals, it was also spending $250,000 on renovations for the town house.
Former school officials said the discussion over who was completing and paying for work on the house was so intense that it seemed that the neighbors must have been calling the news media whenever a plumbing truck pulled up in front.
Mr. Fernandez himself received no shortage of grief over the house. In 1993, the Internal Revenue Service began auditing his tax returns to determine if he acted properly in paying no taxes on the benefit of living rent-free in the house.
Rudy Crew, who was the latest occupant of the house and who resigned in December, turned the keys in to the Board of Education in March. Although Mr. Levy has no intention of living there, according to board officials, he has the use of the Brooklyn town house for education-related social functions.
With real estate prices in Brooklyn soaring and a shortage of properties for sale, particularly in Brooklyn Heights, a potential sale could be lucrative. Including the cost of the renovations, the board has invested more than $1.2 million on the house.
Ms. Donahue, the real estate agent, said she believed that the building could sell for well over $2 million. "Any fine brownstone will draw a good price right now," she said, because of low inventory in Brooklyn Heights and nearby neighborhoods. Some town houses in the area have recently sold for as much as $2.7 million, she said.
Nevertheless, Ms. Donahue said, "I would tell them to hold onto it."
"They may need it in a month or two," she said, depending on how the board's chancellor search turns out.
In all likelihood, the board would be able to keep the proceeds of the sale, which it could not in the potential sale of its building at 110 Livingston Street and two other nearby buildings that house the board's staff. At the direction of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city, which owns the three buildings, recently took the first step in attracting bids from developers. The town house, however, was bought by a state agency, which turned the title to the property over to the city, which in turn gave it to the Board of Education.
Although the board would be likely to make a handsome profit on the investment if the house sold for double its cost, its compounded annual return would be about 7.5 percent over the little more than 10 years since it was bought. That is somewhat mediocre when compared with other, albeit unlikely, alternatives.
To compare, if the board had invested $1.2 million in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index 10 years ago, instead of a Brooklyn town house, the investment would now be worth more than $6 million.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Stock-Trading Cheerleader Now Faces $45 Million Debt

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Among the many evangelists for online investing who have appeared in recent years, few have been as ubiquitous as Baruch Israel Hertz. His New York company, with its constant advertisements on CNBC, promises to make investing a cinch even for novices, providing stock quotes, market information and easy access to electronic trading. "You don't have to be a pro to trade like one," he says on the Web site of his stock-trading system, MyTrack.
But when stocks plunged on Friday, many investors who had borrowed heavily to play the market suddenly faced demands from their lenders that they put up more money to cover their losses. And one of the biggest losers was Mr. Hertz. 
 Mr. Hertz, 50, owes $45 million to four unidentified brokerage firms to cover his losses in trading stocks, according to a news release on Monday by his company, the Track Data Corporation. To meet the brokers' demand for him to put up more money, known as a margin call, he pledged 25 million shares of his own company's stock out of about 45 million shares he owns.
In a remarkable twist, Mr. Hertz has become the most public victim yet of the kind of investing he was promoting.
Even after this week's rebound in stocks, some investors who borrowed from their brokers to buy high-priced shares have not been able to come up with additional cash to cover investments that had fallen in value. This has alarmed Wall Street professionals and others who worry that when stock markets that have only gone up finally turn down, many people will be wiped out.
But even in Friday's carnage, nobody expected that the chief executive of an online trading company would be the one to generate one of the biggest margin calls ever.
In buying on margin, an investor borrows money from a broker to buy stock, paying a relatively modest interest rate and using the stock as collateral. But if the stock declines in value, the customer will be asked to put up more money to make up for the shortfall. This is known as a margin call.
Mr. Hertz declined through a colleague to be interviewed. "This was Mr. Hertz's personal account, his personal trading," said Rafi Reguer, Track Data's marketing director. "It was done with firms other than this one, in securities other than Track Data." Beyond that, Mr. Reguer declined to comment.
Mr. Hertz is one of a new breed on Wall Street, people whose backgrounds are in engineering and computer software rather than finance, who believe that every investor should be able to have Wall Street's trading action brought right into their living rooms through a computer. According to the company, Mr. Hertz earned a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Brooklyn College in 1971 and a master's degree in computer science from New York University two years later.
In addition to Mr. Hertz, everyday investors who are MyTrack customers star in its television ads, appearing on camera to give testimonials to the system. And much of the company's Web site is devoted to rave reviews from customers. The company began offering online trading to customers last June, charging $12.95 a trade and monthly fees of $20 to $95 for access to quotes, news and other market data. About 100,000 investors have registered for the service. For a more sophisticated system called MarkeTrack, customers pay $250 to $600 a month.
News of Mr. Hertz's misfortune has cast a spotlight on the network of companies he runs and is affiliated with. He founded the company that would become Track Data in 1981, merged it with a data provider called Global Market Information Inc. in March 1996 and changed its name to Track Data. The company has 375 employees worldwide.
Mr. Hertz and his company issued news releases unceasingly. In November, for example, the company issued 20 different news releases, announcing developments like its offer of a week of commission-free trading for its customers in celebration of the millennium.
On Nov. 17, Mr. Hertz made waves when Track Data put out a news release announcing that the company had no news to report that day. "Commenting on the lack of news today," the release said, "Barry Hertz, chairman and C.E.O. said, 'I want to apologize to our faithful stockholders who are looking each morning for our latest corporate developments. Rest assured that we do not take this lack of news lightly.' "
Following the lead of many companies who split their stocks to attract new investors, Track Data split its stock 2 for 1 twice last fall. At its peak in January, Track Data had a market value of almost $780 million; Mr. Hertz's 71.7 percent stake was worth about $560 million. The company's shares, which traded at $12.25 just more than two months ago, closed yesterday at $2.03125.
Investors who use MyTrack have most of their trades executed by the Track Securities Corporation, which in turn pays Track Data for the orders.
Track Securities, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., has had a number of run-ins with regulators in recent months. Last Thursday, the securities regulator in Connecticut found that the firm had been operating in the state without being registered and had employed unregistered agents. It fined Track Securities $25,000. And last August, New Mexico's securities regulator censured the firm and fined it $10,670 for filing a misleading document and for conducting activity in the state without a license. Florida regulators also fined the firm $2,500 in August for not registering a branch office and failing to establish and maintain adequate supervisory procedures.
In all three cases the firm neither admitted nor denied the allegations.
A Track Data's spokesman said Track Securities was owned and run by Jack Spiegelman, a director of Track Data. But according to a filing Track Securities made with regulators, Mr. Hertz appears to be a close affiliate of the brokerage firm. In that filing, Mr. Hertz is listed as president and chief executive of Track Data Securities, owning between half and three-quarters. Track Data Securities, according to this filing, is controlled by Track Securities.
Even after meeting his $45 million margin call, Mr. Hertz remains a man of means. He will be left with roughly 20 million shares of Track Data, worth about $40 million. And as chairman and co-founder of the Innodata Corporation, which allows customers to create and disseminate information online, he owns a 14.7 percent stake, worth $4.6 million at yesterday's closing price of $6.1875.
In addition to his salary of $375,000 at Track Data, Mr. Hertz was paid $75,000 last year for his work at Innodata, based in Hackensack, N.J. The company went public in 1993 in an offering underwritten by A. S. Goldmen, a small brokerage firm that was indicted last July by the Manhattan district attorney on charges that the firm orchestrated a securities fraud that cost investors $100 million in losses. The firm closed most of its operations in 1998.
Even before news of Mr. Hertz's margin call hit Wall Street, Track Data announced that it had retained an investment bank to advise it on strategic options, including a possible sale of the company.
"The company is going to make the decision which is really the best thing for the company," said Jay Gelman, senior vice president of sales at Track Data.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Public Spaces Uncluttered By People

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
SEVERAL dozen urban planners from across the country were busy yesterday morning studying public spaces in Manhattan, but they did not linger in the usual crowded spots. They went briskly across Rockefeller Center and up Fifth Avenue past St. Patrick's, stopping only when they reached the building just north of the cathedral, Olympic Tower.
There, a few steps east of Fifth Avenue, they inspected a cavernous public space unknown to most of the public: an indoor arcade extending from 51st to 52nd Street. Jerold S. Kayden, who was leading the tour for members of the American Planning Association, explained that the arcade had been designed to give pedestrians a less congested alternative to Fifth Avenue. 
 "Who would want to walk on Fifth Avenue when you can walk here instead?" he asked, and there was no need to answer. The only other people there were a security guard and a book vendor with no customers. Mr. Kayden, the director of the urban planning program at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, gazed at the sitting area and the three-story waterfall.
"At one time there was a restaurant here, but it failed," he said. "They tried a newsstand once, too, and then a serpentine arrangement of green benches." Now it is under construction again.
"This space has never worked, and I don't believe it ever will work," he said. "But I try to remain an optimist."
Remaining optimistic is an impressive feat when you consider the grimness endured by Mr. Kayden. He has visited every one of the more than 500 spots in New York known oxymoronically as privately owned public spaces. Together with the City Planning Department and the Municipal Arts Society, he is about to publish a book on the dreary plazas and arcades that have appeared since 1961.
That was the year developers were given the option of adding extra stories to their buildings in exchange for providing open space for the public at street level. Planners hoped for plazas and wide sidewalks that would remind people of Florence and Paris, but the results were more often reminiscent of prison yards.
The public-private deals often brought out the worst in both sides, especially until the rules were stiffened in the late 1970's. Neither took responsibility. Public agencies didn't bother demanding public amenities, and the private owners didn't try to make the properties attractive. Some locked the public out; others put spikes on ledges to keep anyone from sitting. "One of the spaces actually has a sign reading, 'No defecating,' " Mr. Kayden said. "When you have to put a sign telling people not to defecate, there's something very wrong with that space."
Mr. Kayden took the tour to what he considered a success story, the airy, glass-walled room next to the Newseum at Madison Avenue and 56th Street, in what was formerly the I.B.M. Building. He pointed to the people sitting and eating at metal tables scattered among bamboo shoots. "If any space could be called New York's living room, this is it," he said.
THAT was the favorite of all the 500 places in his book, but there was another spot on the tour that he liked even more. This one didn't make in the book because it wasn't a public space required by law. It hadn't been given by a developer in return for a bigger building. It was a little plaza on 53rd Street just east of Fifth Avenue, Paley Park, built in honor of the father of the founder of CBS, William S. Paley.
"Here in the densest part of Manhattan you have a wonderful oasis," Mr. Kayden said, pointing out the waterfall, the vine-covered wall, the trees growing out of the cobblestone, the moveable chairs and tables. All of it was provided and maintained voluntarily by the Paley family.
There were no rules like the ones governing all the other sites on the tour. At the Olympic Tower arcade, the owner was legally required to provide, among other things, 3 trees, 11 light fixtures, 13 benches, 50 planters and 52 moveable chairs -- and it didn't work. Here the Paleys could do whatever they wanted, and it worked.
Was there a lesson here for urban planners? Would fewer rules make for better spaces?
"Without rules," Mr. Kayden replied, "you would never have 500 public spaces. Private philanthropy would never have provided so many. The zoning rules have given us a remarkable number of spaces, even if a lot of them are bad. But laws are not sufficient. There's an element reserved for the spiritual contribution of the creator. There's a magic about Paley Park that is unique."

HEADLINE: A Clear Choice on China Trade

 BODY:
By permanently awarding China the normal trading status it has enjoyed for two decades, Congress can advance America's economic interests without diluting its support for human rights on the mainland or the defense of democracy on Taiwan. Yet while Senate passage seems assured, the House is wavering as both liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans withhold support. Both groups should reconsider their opposition.
Passing the trade bill, which is scheduled for a vote in May, would lock in the market-opening concessions by China. These include easier access for foreign telecommunications companies and a reduction of state controls over the economy, steps that would expand the sale of American goods in China. Over time, lower trade barriers could loosen constraints on information and political debate. Without the trade deal, American businesses would be at a disadvantage in the China market. 
 Some Democrats, including the House minority leader, Richard Gephardt, argue that granting permanent trade rights to China would sacrifice the leverage now available to Congress through its annual votes on China's trade status. But those votes have become empty rituals, with China's trading rights invariably renewed. Pressure on trade is an inappropriate way to seek human rights reforms in China, since trade restrictions insulate China from progressive outside influences.
Representative Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat, has proposed steps that would couple permanent trade status with new tools for monitoring and pressing China on human rights and fulfillment of its trade commitments. If warranted, Congress could also consider applying penalties allowed by World Trade Organization rules. This approach would create more effective American pressure on these issues than the annual trade status reviews.
Most House Republicans support the trade bill. But some have held back to protest Chinese belligerence toward Taiwan. China's threatening tone before last month's Taiwanese presidential election was troubling, but Beijing's rhetoric has lately been more restrained. Washington should continue trying to calm the tensions, not inflame them with the sale of sophisticated weapons to Taiwan.
The Clinton administration struck the right balance in its newly announced package of arms sales to Taiwan. This includes a variety of upgraded missiles and radars but rightly omits the four destroyers with advanced Aegis antimissile technology that had been requested by Taiwan.
Opening China's markets advances American, Chinese and Taiwanese interests. Other matters like the preservation of democracy in Taiwan and the expansion of liberty in China are equally important American objectives. They are best pursued by disentangling them from trade issues.

HEADLINE: Theme Song for Commuters Is 'Rush Around the Clock'

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Here is another leaf in the windy debate over whether people are working longer and harder these days: more people are using the bridges and tunnels to Manhattan every morning, and they are using them at ever earlier hours, the Port Authority announced yesterday.
What's happening, commuters and traffic experts say, is both a function of more people working, and changing work patterns that are blurring the boundaries between work and leisure. 
 So some people are at the Holland Tunnel at 5 a.m. because their jobs demand it. Some are there because child care requirements demand it. Some are going to the gym before starting work at the office.
Data on traffic flow simply provide information, not explanations. But much anecdotal evidence points to just how outdated the idea of a 9-to-5 workday has become.
"You have to stay ahead of the competition," said a chipper Dean Eberling, a securities analyst from Cranford, N.J., flashing a smile that would have outshone the sun had it been up as his sport utility vehicle lumbered out of the Holland Tunnel and into Manhattan at 5:10 a.m. "The early morning period is when a lot of institutional investors are making trades and I have to be available, so I'm in checking data and news reports."
Mary Kay of Clinton, N.J., 55 miles from the city, was in early as usual to put in some time in the gym before going to her Manhattan job. Why so early?
"I can't get to the gym at night, what with the kids and all," she said wearily as she emerged from the tunnel and headed uptown for the only personal time she would have in a long, busy day.
Lining up at the toll plazas with the other commuters were those who begin attending to the business needs of the city every morning while others sleep. There were two Federal Express drivers, Jimmy Lettieri of Piscataway and John Burk of South Belmar. Then came a Wall Street data processing manager, Peter LaFranca of East Brunswick, followed by a deli manager, Teddy Ramsumair of Elizabeth. They were followed by Con Ed's Bob Volpe from Monroe Township, and Roberto Guzman of Newark, whose passengers were his fellow steel workers on the way to a construction job on Long Island.
"It's the economy and they are working us to the bone," said Joe Falconite of Marlboro, who was heading to his pipe-fitting business in Brooklyn at 5:20 a.m. He said increasing numbers of early-rising construction workers were on the road. "There are absolutely more people on the road this early, more construction workers especially," Mr. Falconite said.
Like the half-hour lunch, the shorter vacation and beeper bondage, longer and earlier traffic backups at bridge and tunnel crossings are another indication that Americans are going in earlier and staying later at their jobs.
The traffic at the Holland Tunnel on a recent day was never really bumper to bumper at any point between 5 and 6 a.m., but came in waves of increasing frequency as the minutes ticked away.
According to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, vehicle traffic between 5 and 6 a.m. rose 10 percent at the Holland Tunnel, 11 percent at the George Washington Bridge and 19 percent at the Lincoln in 1999, compared with 1998.
Compared with 1996, by 1999 the traffic has increased by 32 percent at the Holland Tunnel, 42 percent at the George Washington Bridge and 39 percent at the Lincoln Tunnel. According the authority's figures, that is a 38 percent increase in 5 a.m. to 6 a.m. vehicle traffic in a four-year period.
"We started seeing these increases about five years ago," said Steve Napolitano, the general manager of the George Washington Bridge. "Most of it is economy-driven, and the truck traffic is up significantly."
He said that focus groups last winter found that many regular users of the bridge were taking advantage of new flexible programs offered by employers.
"It's not a 9-to-5 world anymore," he said.
Traffic is down slightly or unchanged at all other hours between 6 and 9 a.m. But overall in those hours, traffic increased by 1.6 percent, paced by the larger percentages of earlier commuters. In contrast to the earlier travel times on the roadways, riders on mass transit, like the PATH lines and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's New York subways, are increasing at all hours during the morning rush.
Still, Erin Brownfield, a spokeswoman for the Families and Work Institute in Manhattan, said the increase in earlier traffic was consistent with several other workplace trends. The institute's studies have found that people on average are working 44 hours per week, an average of 6 hours more than they are scheduled or paid to work.
"We are working longer hours and employers have higher expectations," said Ms. Brownfield, pointing to an International Labor Organization study last year that showed that Americans, with 1,966 annual hours of work, had shot past Japan, leading the world in hours worked.
Jerry A. Jacobs, a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania who studies workplace patterns, said that the increases, while modest, served to underscore that the "locus of work has not fundamentally changed, and coming into the office is the norm."
"We've been waiting for the effects of telecommuting to show up," he said. "But it seems that we are still waiting."
But researchers cautioned that the increase in earlier commuting could mean other things, both exotic and mundane.
Commuting times have been increasing anyway, rising to 23.5 minutes in 1997 from 20.2 minutes in 1977, and the earlier bridge and tunnel crossings might simply mean that higher housing costs in the areas closer to New York City are pushing people farther and farther out, increasing commuting times, Mr. Jacobs said.
Ms. Brownfield noted that a 1998 study found that 68 percent of companies nationally are allowing workers flexible hours. Many working parents concerned about leaving young children and teenagers home alone and unsupervised in the afternoons were taking advantage of the chance to start work earlier so that they could go home earlier, she said.
Jeffrey A. Warsh, executive director of New Jersey Transit, said that he had seen a spreading of rush hour, both earlier and later, in the ridership on the agency's trains and buses that mirrors the bridge and tunnel crossing trends. He speculated that more flexible work hours, a search for scarce parking places at suburban train and bus stops, and the "red hot economy" were all combining to alter the shape of rush hour.
In some cases, he said, demand for services that take people into New York City no later than 8:30 a.m. has dictated earlier trains and buses, simply because adding later ones wouldn't accomplish the goal.
"Some of this just has to do with the capacity of the systems," said James P. Redeker, the acting assistant executive director of planning for the agency. "There just isn't any more capacity later, no more space and no more parking."
Terry Vazquez of Roselle, N.J., whose workday in the billing department of a Manhattan hospital doesn't start until 8:30 a.m., has taken to grabbing a ride with her husband Louis, a postal worker, and crossing into Manhattan well before 6 a.m. just to avoid the crowds on the bus and two subway trains she would otherwise take to work.
"I do my overtime in the morning rather than the evening, although I don't really get paid for it," Mrs. Vazquez said as she and her husband were stopped at a traffic light.
"I know it sounds crazy and I might get an extra half hour's sleep if I didn't do this," she said. "But I just hate the crowds. Plus I get more work done between 6 a.m. and 8:30 than all the rest of the day."

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe Opposition Leader Warns Against Confrontation

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
As Zimbabwe rolls toward more violence, the worst thing that could happen, in the estimation of its main opposition leader, is to create a martyr out of its founder and once popular hero, President Robert Mugabe.
Instead, conciliation is the way to undercut Mr. Mugabe's push for confrontation, says the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, a magnetic trade union leader who has transformed himself into the chairman of the six-month-old Movement for Democratic Change. 
 "As much as I would like to take an aggressive stand, that's what he's looking for," said Mr. Tsvangirai, who is visiting here to dramatize the predicament of what was once southern Africa's best example of economic and social cohesion. "He's looking to be made a martyr. We don't need that."
With more sorrow than anger evident, Mr. Tsvangirai described Mr. Mugabe as a "man I was prepared to die for 20 years ago," but who now, at age 76, is obsessed by money, power and the nation's former colonial master, Britain.
Mr. Tsvangirai, 48, fresh from a visit to London, is making the rounds of official Washington, seeking support for free and fair national elections next month. He appeared to be pushing on an open door. President Clinton's deputy national security adviser, James Steinberg, sat next to him at a Georgetown dinner on Monday night and Mr. Tsvangirai met with the assistant secretary of state for African Affairs, Susan Rice.
Until now, the Clinton administration has supported Mr. Mugabe, seeking to use his position to bring a settlement to the war in Congo, where Mr. Mugabe has sent about 10,000 of his top troops. And it has shown scant interest in the showdown he was building between Zimbabwe's white farmers and state-sponsored black squatters.
But patience with Mr. Mugabe has worn out.
The administration is trying to encourage what one official called a "peaceful de-escalation" of the crisis so that yet another African country does not spin out of control. For neighboring South Africa, Zimbabwe's economic collapse would have serious consequences: Zimbabwe is South Africa's biggest buyer of manufactured goods.
Mr. Tsvangirai's visit was sponsored by the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs here. He impressed those who met him here, the official said, as someone "who did not focus on power but on unity and finding a collective way forward." It is vital that the coming elections include international observers, the official said.
But Mr. Tsvangirai said Mr. Mugabe appeared intent on fomenting chaos so that the country appeared to be ungovernable and he could declare a state of emergency and rule by decree. The Parliament was dissolved on April 12 in preparation for elections, but the absence of a sitting legislature could also be used by Mr. Mugabe as a step toward one-man rule, he said.
By dwelling on the question of race -- and specifically, the domination of the most arable land by 4,500 white farmers -- Mr. Tsvangirai said he believes that Mr. Mugabe has chosen a rallying cry, but a hollow one.
Most Zimbabweans were so mired in despair -- more than 50 percent of the population is unemployed and 2,000 people die of AIDS every week -- that offering a piece of land did not mean very much, he said.
"Poverty, unemployment, debt problems, corruption have a terrible effect on the standard of living of 75 percent of the people," Mr. Tsvangirai said. "When you talk of land in that sea of poverty it's meaningless. What does land do if you haven't got a meal?"
He said that land redistribution needed to proceed, but in a way that would not destabilize the agricultural industry, the backbone of the economy. Land reform, he said, "must be done with equity, empowerment and economic viability."
Mr. Tsvangirai said he is confident that in a free election, his Movement for Democratic Change will overwhelm Mr. Mugabe's Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front, which has dominated politics since it took power in 1980. A recent opinion poll showed that 65 percent of voters wanted a new government.

HEADLINE: Sewage Work Lags at Source Of Tap Water

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
A program to modernize 102 sewage plants discharging waste water into New York City's reservoirs is drastically behind schedule, jeopardizing the city's efforts to avoid having to build a $6 billion water filtration plant, according to federal and state officials monitoring the city's plan to cut pollution of its water supply.
The latest criticism of the city's sewage-control program came yesterday in a 40-page report released by James M. Tierney, an assistant state attorney general who in 1998 was designated by Gov. George E. Pataki as the state's "watershed inspector general" and charged with tracking the city's cleanup work. 
 The report concludes that the sewage-plant modernization program is "grossly behind schedule" and has not progressed beyond preliminary planning, making it nearly impossible for the city to fulfill its commitment to complete the work by May 2002.
"Giving them every benefit I could, if this continues at this pace, this program could be two years late," said Mr. Tierney, whose position was created as part of an agreement on a cleanup plan signed in 1997 by the city, state and several dozen communities around the city's reservoirs. "That's two more years that contaminants are flowing into the drinking water."
The delays mean that three years after the city committed to spending more than $75 million to fix the plants, no construction has begun, and more than 10 million gallons a day of inadequately treated waste water continues to mix with water bound for city taps, Mr. Tierney said.
Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the federal Environmental Protection Agency, said yesterday that the pace of the sewage cleanup was "an important part of our decision as to whether to allow the city to continue to avoid filtering."
Over all, water quality remains high. But as development intensifies in the rural and suburban hills around the city's 19 reservoirs, she and Mr. Tierney said, contamination could worsen without the sewage-plant improvements.
The work on the plants is an important component of a five-year $600 million city plan to stop pollution from tainting its biggest, cleanest reservoirs, which are in the Catskills. That plan was announced with much fanfare by city and state officials in 1997 and succeeded in averting a federal order for the city to filter its water.
The sewage plants, dotted around the reservoirs from Westchester to Delaware Counties, have long been seen by water experts as a source of pollution and parasites like cryptosporidium, which can cause diarrhea and severe complications in people with weakened immune systems.
The report from the attorney general's office echoes concerns raised in a letter sent by the E.P.A. to city water officials last fall.
"We're very concerned that the city is in jeopardy of missing most if not all of its deadlines for the sewage plant upgrades," Ms. Mears said yesterday. Next month, the agency is scheduled to issue a detailed interim report on the city's cleanup, and it will focus significantly on the sewage problem, Ms. Mears said. She said it was unlikely that continuing sewage problems alone would result in an eventual filtration order, but added that progress on this work "is certainly a very key requirement."
New York City is the only large city in the United States that has no filters for its water but also has sewage plants releasing waste water into its reservoirs.
So far, the enormous volume of the system -- more than a billion gallons a day -- has minimized the potential harm from the 10 million gallons a day flowing from the waste plants. But the E.P.A. has tightened rules for drinking water in recent years, leading to pressure on the city to clean up the plants.
Of particular concern are intestinal parasites like cryptosporidium, which are difficult to kill with chlorination alone and which can travel in poorly treated waste water.
Responding to the state report yesterday, Joel A. Miele, the city's commissioner of environmental protection, acknowledged that the program was behind schedule, but said state officials were not helping matters by focusing on criticizing the city instead of prodding upstate communities to cooperate.
A major roadblock for the project, he said, has been that the money and technical help are coming from the city, but the work must be initiated by the dozens of communities that own and use the plants.
"We're effectively dealing with 102 different entities," Mr. Miele said, referring to the plants' owners. "That in itself is mind-boggling."
He said some communities with old plants where repairs were particularly important were continuing to delay work for a variety of reasons, including trying to get more money from the city and exploiting the issue in local politics.
Mr. Miele declined to name specific towns because negotiations are still under way. "Some players are stalling for political reasons or economic advantage, and there are others who really want to get together with us and get this done," he said.
He said Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general, should have directed his office's criticism away from the city and toward state agencies that could help put pressure on watershed towns to accelerate the work.
Other city officials went further, implying that Mr. Spitzer, who is a Democrat, and the E.P.A., operating under a Democratic administration, were trying to use the issue to hurt Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who is running for a United States Senate seat against Hillary Rodham Clinton.
But in defense of his office's report, Mr. Spitzer noted that his subordinate, Mr. Tierney, had been appointed by two Republicans, Mr. Pataki and Dennis C. Vacco, a former attorney general.
Politics of one sort or another has shaped key features of the watershed cleanup. The effort -- including the sewage-plant work -- had its start three years ago, when the city signed agreements with the state, the federal government and communities around its upstate watersheds. Under the agreements, the city pledged to pay for upgrades at the sewage plants, to buy land to expand buffer zones around the reservoirs, and to enact rules limiting development and other activities that could contaminate the drinking water.
From the start, the city plan was seen by all parties involved as a compromise between keeping the water clean and accounting for the needs of the communities near the reservoirs. The result, by all accounts, is that the city is able to exert only limited control over activities in the 2,000 square miles of suburban and rural hills that funnel rainwater toward city taps.
Now, though, the weaknesses in the plan are becoming clearer, according to water quality experts. And the biggest weakness, many of them say, is in the effort to improve the sewage plants.
Yesterday, responding to Mr. Miele's comments, Mr. Tierney said it was still ultimately up to the city to move the project from planning to the pouring of concrete.
He acknowledged that the city's challenge, dealing with dozens of plant owners, was daunting. "I don't envy them this task," he said. "But these plants are the linchpin on a whole array of things. That's why it's really urgent that they get moving."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Budget Plan Scales Back Tax Cuts and Restores Spending

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a gesture of compromise to the City Council, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $36.7 billion city budget yesterday in which he sharply scaled back his earlier proposal for tax cuts and restored spending he had proposed to cut for libraries and other cultural institutions.
The mayor's budget proposal also called for several large new capital projects over the next three years, including $348 million for a new ambulatory care building, a children's center and a police laboratory for analyzing DNA evidence, all at Bellevue Hospital Center, and $96 million for an expansion of Lincoln Center. 
 The revised proposal signaled major concessions to the Council even before final budget negotiations, said Ronnie Lowenstein, chief economist of the city's Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan watchdog group. "This is a very big change from what he was seeking in January," she said. "He is not just saying here are a few small things. He's cutting his tax cuts in half."
Mr. Giuliani yesterday projected a record $2.9 billion budget surplus in the year that ends June 30. In January, he said that he intended to use any surplus to eliminate two widely disdained city taxes -- the commercial rent tax and the 14 percent personal income tax surcharge -- as the cornerstones of his 2001 budget. The total tax cuts would have amounted to $1.8 billion over three years.
But instead, apparently in a bow to budget watchdogs like the comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, who has warned that an economic downturn and pending labor contract negotiations could squeeze city resources next year, he pared his tax cuts nearly in half.
Under yesterday's proposal, the income tax surcharge would be reduced by half, to 7 percent. Mr. Giuliani still proposes ending the commercial rent tax and a flat $2-per-night fee imposed on hotel guests. He said these tax cuts would total $1 billion over three years, about $800,000 less than his original proposal.
Mr. Giuliani has also restored $50 million for libraries, museums and other cultural institutions that he had sought to cut, provoking an outcry from the Council. In other spending, his plan would set aside $64 million for summer school and $108 million for air-conditioning in classrooms. It also includes $60 million in federal funds to expand the police force by 1,230 officers next year, to 41,440.
The mayor used a City Hall budget address yesterday to repeat his call for the widespread use of merit pay to motivate teachers and municipal workers. His budget would set aside a merit pay reserve of $325 million in 2001, which would grow to $800 million in 2003 and remain constant in succeeding years.
Mr. Giuliani's proposed projects at Bellevue were part of a shopping list in a three-year, $26.4 billion capital plan for which financing is far from assured. Indeed, the capital plan would push the city's expenses far above the state-imposed limit on its ability to borrow by next year.
His capital plan would also dedicate $250 million to reconstruction of the Willis Avenue Bridge, which spans the Harlem River between the Manhattan and the Bronx; $189 million to buy compressed natural gas buses for the city's fleet, which serves neighborhoods not covered by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority; and $129 million for a new wing of the Kings County Hospital Center.
City officials hope to overcome the financing hurdle in two ways. First, Mr. Giuliani is lobbying for an amendment to the State Constitution that would lift or eliminate the debt ceiling. City Hall is also trying to persuade state legislators to give it more borrowing power under the Transitional Finance Authority, a three-year-old bonding agency backed by the proceeds from city taxes.
In contrast to prior years, when Mr. Giuliani's budget proposal has been an opening round for hard bargaining and bitter recriminations between the mayor's staff and the Council, several of its members seemed bemused yesterday by the mayor's early concessions.
"We think the mayor has moved in the right direction," said Peter F. Vallone, the Council speaker, at a news conference, "and we are pleased we don't have to get into negotiations over the libraries and cultural institutions."
Still, the Republican mayor's budget is certain to encounter resistance. For example, the Democratic majority, including Mr. Vallone, wants to restructure any across-the-board cut in the personal income tax surcharge to one that would be graduated to provide more tax relief to middle-income people than to the wealthy.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The arrival of open-source software arouses researchers' curiosity on what motivates programmers to work free.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise, and Progress." Four economic analysts -- Ms. Postrel, Jeff Madrick, Alan B. Krueger and J. Bradford DeLong -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
WHEN technology stocks took their sharp tumble last week, many companies appeared to lose one of their most important assets -- the ability to lure talented employees with options. To attract and hold the best, you have to offer the chance to strike it rich.
Or do you? What are we to think when the best of the best -- the elite programmers that industry wisdom deems 100 times more productive than the typical competent coder -- donate their precious time to develop software anyone can use without charge? That is the puzzle the open-source movement, most famous for the Linux operating system, presents to economists. 
 Unlike most commercial software, which comes as incomprehensible "ones" and "zeroes," open-source programs always include the source code, written in a programming language like C++. Any programmer can look at the code and change it to fix bugs or add features. Programmers contribute such patches to the user community by sending them to a central authority, recognized as the project leader. That person (or small group) decides which changes are good enough to become part of the recognized version of the software that is available to everyone. For instance, Linus Torvalds, the creator of Linux, screens patches for the core portions of that operating system. There are thousands of open-source projects, of varying popularity and complexity. Aside from Linux, some of the most prominent include the PERL language, Apache server software, the Emacs text editor and the Sendmail e-mail routing program. Companies like Red Hat make money not from the code itself, which customers could get free, but from the products or services bundled with it.
The great advantage of open-source development is that the process taps thousands of independent minds, making it much easier to find and repair software bugs. "Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow," writes Eric S. Raymond, a programmer and movement observer, in "The Cathedral and the Bazaar." (The essay is available at http://www.tuxedo.org/esr/ writings/cathedral-bazaar/cathedral-bazaar.html.)
Open-source programming thus emulates the marketplace -- Mr. Raymond's bazaar -- as well as the scientific peer-review process. Improvements emerge incrementally, from an open-ended, decentralized process rather than a central design. The software becomes more useful and reliable over time.
While its development looks like a marketplace, open-source software itself is a classic public good. You can use it without contributing to its maintenance and without paying a cent to all those programmers who created and improved it.
Hence the economic puzzle. As Josh Lerner of the Harvard Business School and Jean Tirole of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology ask in a recent paper: "Why should thousands of top-notch programmers contribute freely to the provision of a public good?" (Titled "The Simple Economics of Open Source," the paper is available at http://www.people.hbs.edu/jlerner/.)
Professor Lerner says he is skeptical of the argument that says "this new technology is so fundamentally different that all the old rules are off." Incentives, the economists believe, are bound to matter. But if that is the case, the question has ramifications beyond software, since many public goods depend on tapping the time and talents of volunteers.
Of course, open-source programmers often reap some direct advantages from their improvements. But solving their own problems has spillover benefits for other people, just as fixing up a rundown building for your own business makes the neighborhood nicer for everyone.
And a lot of people work on open-source projects they do not need for their jobs. One reason is that it is fun and interesting, as much recreation as work. That is true of many other public-good endeavors, from planting trees to running charity balls. They are not all selfless drudgery. Where virtue must be entirely its own reward, volunteers will be hard to find.
But fun cannot explain everything. After all, many open-source hackers are already paid to program, and they do not do that for free. Mr. Raymond argues that open-source developers work for status among other programmers. If you do good work, you become a big shot. Your name is forever associated with the code you have contributed, and because the code is open, everyone can see just what you have accomplished.
Hackerdom is a ruthless meritocracy, dedicated to winnowing out bad code and spreading good. A lesson for other voluntary endeavors is that praising people just for showing up will not attract the best talent. To be valuable, reputation and recognition have to signal something significant.
Along these lines, Professors Lerner and Tirole add a pecuniary motive -- one that traditional charities might call "networking." Contributing to open-source projects can enhance a programmer's career prospects. Especially for someone living and working in an out-of-the-way place, open-source work can attract the attention of potential employers or financial backers. The most striking example is Mr. Torvalds, who was a graduate student in Finland when he released Linux and is now a highly paid executive at a Silicon Valley start-up.
Professors Lerner and Tirole's signaling story assumes that the programmer already has a portfolio of skills and that open-source development simply offers a means to display them. But volunteering to work on difficult problems is also a way of honing new skills -- building your human capital, as an economist would put it -- and the open-source community offers feedback that encourages learning. This, too, is a form of career enhancement.
Open-source programmers are an interesting bunch of volunteers because they are among the most sought-after employees in the economy, and because their volunteer work has produced lucrative commercial spinoffs. But software is hardly the first public good provided through private efforts. While it may sound crass to consider them, every voluntary endeavor needs incentives for excellence. The public good often depends on respecting private gains.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: TALKS CONTINUE
Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland will be in London today for the second round of talks in 48 hours with his British counterpart, Tony Blair. Mr. Blair visited Dublin, too, as part of a continuing effort to resurrect the Protestant-Catholic coalition government suspended in February when the Irish Republican Army failed to make expected disarmament moves. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BOSNIA: SERB DEFENDANTS FREED
Two Bosnian Serbs facing war crimes charges were released until their trial begins because they have been in custody too long, the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague said. Miroslav Tadic, 62, and Simo Zaric, 51, surrendered in February 1998. Their trial has been delayed because of complaints by a co-defendant. (Reuters) 

GIBRALTAR: EASING CURBS
Britain and Spain ironed out longstanding irritations by agreeing to simplify border crossings, police and court cooperation, and banking between Spain and Gibraltar, but they did not otherwise change Gibraltar's British colony status. Madrid has long demanded that London cede sovereignty over the 2.5-square-mile peninsula. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
ARGENTINA: LABOR PROTESTS
The police, using rubber bullets and tear gas, clashed with hundreds of union activists who protested in front of the Congress in Buenos Aires to stop the Senate from passing a labor code that is at the heart of President Fernando de la Rua's economic policy. Thirty people were reported wounded. The measure, which has already cleared the lower house, would weaken national unions' ability to negotiate local contracts. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
MEXICO: INQUIRY SWITCH
A governing-party lawmaker could decide the fate of Oscar Espinosa, a member of President Ernesto Zedillo's cabinet whom the opposition wants impeached for what prosecutors say was embezzlement of $50 million during his tenure as Mexico City mayor. The opposition congressman who presided over preliminary deliberations was injured when a gunman assaulted him in traffic. In a random drawing, Representative Miguel Quiroz Perez of the governing party was chosen as the substitute chairman of the investigating committee. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SUDAN: AIR RAIDS LIFTED
Air raids have been suspended against southern rebel positions, apparently to allow international relief flights to the region, the official news agency said. President Omar el-Bashir, who ordered the halt, warned that warplanes would strike back if they were shot at by guerrillas of the Sudan People's Liberation Army, which has been fighting government troops in southern Sudan since 1983. (AP)
 
NIGERIA: U.S. OFFERS HELP
Concerned that ethnic and religious unrest will undermine democratic rule in Nigeria, a special United States envoy has met with President Olusegun Obasanjo to offer American help ending the crisis. Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering, who made the offer, did not specify what form the assistance might take. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: SUHARTO SON QUIZZED
Bambang Trihatmodjo, left, one of the sons of former President Suharto, was questioned for six hours by prosecutors, a day after a five-hour interrogation of one of Mr. Suharto's daughters. Like his children, Mr. Suharto has been undergoing questioning in a case involving corruption at charitable trusts he administered before being forced from office nearly two years ago. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: MASSACRE TRIAL BEGINS
The government opened a much-anticipated trial of 24 soldiers and a civilian accused of involvement in a massacre last July in the restive province of Aceh. They are charged with killing 57 villagers in Indonesia's campaign to quell a continuing separatist rebellion. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
EAST TIMOR: TIMOR RIGHTS TEAM
Attorney General Marzuki Darusman of Indonesia named a 79-member team to investigate human rights violations in East Timor last year. The investigators will look into a rampage of arson, rape, kidnapping and killing attributed to Indonesian soldiers and their local militias. The attacks followed the territory's vote for independence. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
PHILIPPINES: 2 HOSTAGES BEHEADED
Muslim rebels beheaded 2 of 29 hostages seized at a school last month, the rebels and a government spokesman said, because demands for the release of Islamic militants held in the United States -- apparently including Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing in New York in 1993 -- have not been met. The rebels have also threatened to kill Americans elsewhere in the Philippines. Press Secretary Ricardo Puno said independent confirmation of the beheadings had been obtained. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
CYPRUS: TURK'S NEW TERM
The Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash, 76, succeeded to another five-year term as president of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus after the only other contender withdrew from a scheduled runoff. The breakaway state is recognized only by Turkey, which invaded the island in 1974. United Nations-sponsored peace talks between Turkish and Greek Cypriots are to begin in New York on May 23. (AP)
 
MOROCCO: RIGHTING WRONGS
The government has begun compensating people unjustly imprisoned in detention camps under King Hassan II, who died in July. The first victims received $4,800 to $14,500 to cover medical expenses from the aftereffects of imprisonment. The government has made available $3.8 million, and further allocations are expected. (AP)
