HEADLINE: Mexican Election Spotlights Ailing School System

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: OTUMBA, Mexico

 BODY:
The Alfredo del Mazo elementary school has no running water or phone, and a short circuit knocked out the electric power for most of this year. Rain blows in on the pupils through broken classroom windows when thunderstorms sweep across the cactus outside.
So when Francisco Labastida, the governing party's presidential candidate, promised in a television commercial to install computers and offer English classes in every Mexican elementary school, teachers like Gabriela Garcia were skeptical. 
 "I think they should start by fixing our windows," said Ms. Garcia, who teaches fifth and sixth grade in the dilapidated rural school in Otumba, 50 miles northeast of Mexico City.
For weeks, educators and parents all across Mexico criticized Mr. Labastida's proposals as an election-year gimmick out of touch with the basic needs of most schools. Mr. Labastida finally retreated, acknowledging in a speech that the government could help many more students by patching schoolhouse roofs and improving Spanish instruction rather than introducing computers.
In previous presidential elections, governing party candidates referred to the schools mainly in self-congratulatory speeches extolling the heroic educational achievements of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, which has ruled Mexico for 71 years. But this year's race has aroused a genuine debate over education, with opposition candidates criticizing the top-heavy bureaucracy and inequities of the public schools.
On average, Mexicans attend classes for eight years, the government says, but Inter-American Development Bank figures show that the poorest 30 percent of students attend for just three. Recognizing that a better educated population is required for economic progress, all three major candidates have pledged to increase school spending. But that may not be an easy solution because President Ernesto Zedillo says that 27 percent of every government peso already goes to education.
Educators in several towns and villages surrounding Mexico City, asked about school financing, contended that little of that money reached their schools. Experts on Mexico's education system said extraordinary sums were frittered away by education bureaucrats.
Mexican schools are controlled not by local boards, as in the United States, but by a federal Education Department, which mandates a national curriculum, and 31 state departments, which keep academic records and send inspectors to oversee teachers. The same system, transferred to New York, would require a principal in Queens, for example, to negotiate even small curriculum changes with federal officials in Washington and to travel to Albany to register students' grades.
The Mexican bureaucracy is dominated by a teachers' union whose bosses are leaders of Mr. Zedillo's governing party, and they frequently press teachers to campaign for official candidates.
In the farm village of Atlatongo, a 90-minute drive north of Mexico City, the Ramon Beteta elementary school is named for a prominent governing party politician. The tidy school, shaded by jacaranda trees, is one of the best in its county, but different from most American schools. It has no cafeteria, gymnasium, science lab or lockers. It is just a line of concrete classrooms.
Its principal, Jesus Rangel Hernandez, said in an interview that he wondered where Mexico's relatively high education expenditures went. The government says it spends $661 on every elementary student. With 900 students, the school should get nearly $600,000 this year, Mr. Rangel reasoned, jotting figures on a paper. The government provides textbooks and pays his 24 teachers a total of about $240,000 annually. That should leave at least $300,000 for maintenance and other supplies, he said.
"But they give us nothing," Mr. Rangel said. Parent contributions pay for the salaries of a secretary and two janitors. From his desk he pulled a stack of letters sent over the years to authorities, requesting money to mend the school's fence, hire a janitor, and buy supplies like chalk and mimeograph ink. "It's always the same response: 'No money in the budget,' " he said.
"You know what I think they do with the money?" he said. "They spend it in the PRI's election campaigns."
Education Department bureaucrats and union leaders tried to strong-arm his teachers last year to campaign for the governing party candidate for state governor, Mr. Rangel said.
"The waste is extraordinary," said Carlos Ornelas, an education professor who is the author of a standard textbook, "The Mexican Education System." Many full-time workers for the union are classified on the payroll as teachers and given government cars. "I'd say 30 to 40 percent of the education budget is just squandered by the bureaucracy," Mr. Ornelas said.
 Miguel Limon Rojas, Mexico's secretary of education, acknowledged in an interview in his office in Mexico City that his efforts to trim bureaucratic waste had fallen short.
 "It's a considerable problem," he said. But it was worse, he said, before a decentralization in 1993 turned control of 115,000 federal schools over to the states. About 85 percent of Mexico's $23.7 billion education budget for the year 2000 goes to pay teachers and bureaucrats, leaving little for anything else, he said. Hundreds of rural schools with only a handful of students absorb disproportionate sums in salaries.
 "Our spending on physical plant and operational costs is insufficient, creating the sensation that the money isn't getting to the schools," Mr. Limon said.
The authorities have been reluctant to permit international scrutiny. After Mexican eighth graders took part with students from 37 other countries in a 1996 math and science test, the government embargoed the results. In another international test a year later, Mexican students scored lower than those from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Cuba.
"Mexico can't compete when our scholastic level is below the countries we do business with," Vicente Fox, the center-right candidate who is Mr. Labastida's leading opposition rival, said in a recent speech. He has pledged to wring more efficiency from the bureaucracy.
Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leftist who is the other major opposition candidate, has lambasted authorities for allowing classrooms to deteriorate.
Experts praised Mr. Labastida's first educational proposal last year, to lengthen the class schedule to a full day. Currently, students receive four hours of daily instruction, a total of 800 hours annually, compared with 1,500 in the United States.
But Mr. Labastida's promise in January of computers and English classes set off more fireworks. Party officials applauded. Teachers grumbled. Journalists ridiculed it as a costly fantasy. This month, when a Labastida aide visited the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based research institute, Jeffrey M. Puryear, an education expert, questioned the proposal.
"I said most specialists on Latin American education wouldn't start with computers," Mr. Puryear said. "They'd start with establishing education standards, measuring progress toward meeting them and building ways to make the school system accountable."
In a recent speech before hundreds of party officials and educators, Mr. Labastida reiterated his promise of computers and English instruction, but acknowledged that it would take years to carry out and that many schools had more pressing needs.
"My goal is to raise quality," he said. "There will be places where the first thing is to put a new roof on classrooms, or provide bathrooms. Other places may need more teachers or a library." He also said that strengthening instruction in Spanish, math and Mexican history was more urgent than computers and English.
At the Alfredo del Mazo school, named for another governing party politician, the principal, Pablo Gonzalez, said he welcomed the revision. "Many of our students don't even have pencils," he said.

HEADLINE: New Victories in Parliament Show Strong Hand of Putin

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 19

 BODY:
Last week, President-elect Vladimir V. Putin pushed the long-awaited ratification of a major arms control treaty through a compliant lower house of Parliament. Today, he scored a victory with regional bosses in Parliament's upper chamber, easily winning a vote to get rid of a prosecutor who was the scourge of former President Boris N. Yeltsin's Kremlin.
For good measure, the upper house also approved the nuclear arms reduction agreement known as Start II, which passed the lower house last Friday.
The most vivid display of loyalty from the governors and local leaders in the Federation Council, as the upper house is called, was their 133-to-10 vote to dismiss Yuri I. Skuratov, the general prosecutor whom Mr. Yeltsin tried twice to fire last year after he began to investigate corruption in the Kremlin itself. 
 "Russia now has a real, solid president, and it needs a full-blooded working prosecutor," said Anatoly Lisitsyn, governor of the Yaroslavl region northeast of Moscow.
In its earlier votes on Mr. Skuratov, the upper house voted against the Kremlin, displaying a rare rebellious streak that was a reflection of Mr. Yeltsin's growing political weakness.
Now, three weeks after his election on March 26, Mr. Putin has scored back-to-back parliamentary victories, proof that he has the political strength to command a majority in both houses.
But it is not clear what Mr. Putin plans to do with his mandate. Both the ratification of Start II and the dismissal of Mr. Skuratov are leftovers from the Yeltsin agenda.
The first attempt to dismiss Mr. Skuratov was made in February 1999, shortly after he started working with prosecutors in Switzerland on a corruption and kickback investigation that linked the Kremlin's property management office and Mabetex, a Swiss firm with extensive business in Russia. That investigation was used by Mr. Yeltsin's opponents to challenge his authority in the upper house, which under the Russian Constitution must approve any changes in the office of the general prosecutor, a position similar to that of the United States attorney general.
Backed into a corner, the Kremlin shifted the focus onto Mr. Skuratov himself. A state-run television channel broadcast a videotape showing the prosecutor in bed with two prostitutes. Despite the humiliation and a subsequent investigation into his conduct, Mr. Skuratov continued to battle for his old job, even after he was formally suspended.
Today, Mr. Skuratov lost his fight and acknowledged that the new political situation in Russia "objectively requires my departure." He said the future of his investigations would depend on "the position of the Federation Council and the president of the country, and if the president does nothing, then all these cases will disappear into the sand."
So far, Mr. Putin has done little to reveal his plans for Russia, including how he will carry out the "dictatorship of law" that he called for in his campaign. In the three weeks since his election he has continued to project the image of the resolute, energetic leader, which was enhanced this week with a three-day foreign tour that took him from Belarus to Britain and then on Tuesday to Ukraine.
His first major policy statement is expected soon after his May 7 inauguration, when he will address both houses of Parliament with a state of the nation speech. A more detailed program, now being prepared by a private research organization headed by German O. Gref, is expected to be issued later next month.
In the meantime, Mr. Putin seems to prefer to keep people guessing about his plans and policies, from the redefinition of the relationship between the central government and the regions to the rearrangement of broadcasting licenses among competing media companies.
Mr. Putin, in meetings with foreign business executives, has repeatedly stressed his commitment to the principles of a market economy. His naming last week of Andrei Illarionov, a liberal economist, as his chief economic adviser was seen as support for continued economic reform.
The Russian economy, helped by high oil prices, has performed better than expected a year ago, but Mr. Putin has reportedly called for a tight budget for next year, to be ready in the event of lower energy prices.

HEADLINE: Increases in Price of Oil Widen U.S. Trade Deficit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened to a record in February, elevated by surging oil prices and growing demand for imports, government figures showed today.
The deficit in goods and services trade grew to $29.2 billion in February from $27.4 billion during January as imports climbed to a record and exports fell for a second consecutive month, the Commerce Department said. 
 "The U.S. economy is surging at a pace so much faster than the rest of the world that exports just cannot hope to keep up with imports," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
A record amount of higher-priced petroleum products was imported in February. Since then, crude prices have fallen by about 13 percent. While that may keep the trade deficit from widening further, spending by consumers will also keep it from narrowing, analysts said.
"Domestic demand will have to slow sharply and international demand will have to accelerate even more for the trade gap to narrow significantly," said Steve Wood, an economist at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco.
Imports rose 1.5 percent, to a record $113.4 billion during February. The $8.8 billion deficit in petroleum products alone was the largest since the government started tracking those numbers in 1989, the Commerce Department said.
Excluding oil, imports fell 0.6 percent, reflecting reduced shipments of automobiles, televisions, videocassette recorders, clothing and toys. Still, nonoil imports were up 12.4 percent in February from the same month a year ago.
Exports fell for a second straight month, as outbound shipments of civilian aircraft and other capital goods declined.
Aircraft exports fell 37 percent in February after a decline of 4.7 percent a month earlier. February shipments may have been partly restrained by labor disruptions at Boeing, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer. As many as 19,000 engineers and technicians took part in a 40-day strike that ended on March 19.
Even so, exports of business services and goods were 9.5 percent higher than in February 1999.
Although the trade gap will subtract from first-quarter gross domestic product, consumer spending "will keep growth in excess of 6 percent," Mr. Wood said. That would compare with a fourth-quarter growth rate of 7.3 percent. The pace of consumer demand has elevated the concerns of Federal Reserve policy makers, who have raised interest rates five times since June to keep inflation from accelerating.
Oil will most likely play a lesser rose in the trade imbalance in coming months. An agreement in March by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other producers to increase output has since resulted in a decline in oil prices. In New York, crude oil for May delivery rose $1.24, or 4.8 percent, to $27.35 a barrel today, down about 15.6 percent from a March 7 peak of $32.39.
The merchandise trade deficit with Japan widened to $6.7 billion in February from $5.6 billion during January. The shortfall with China narrowed to $5.6 billion in February from $6 billion during January.
The deficit with Canada, the nation's largest trading partner, narrowed to $3.3 billion from $4.1 billion a month earlier. The deficit with the 15-nation European Union narrowed to $3.5 billion from $3.9 billion.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Mass of NuclearFriction;
Tension and Mistrust at New High for British Complex

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: SELLAFIELD, England

 BODY:
When John Storer took over a new high-profile job at Britain's most dispute-ridden nuclear complex in September, he expected "a fairly steep learning curve." Instead, he said, "World War III started shortly afterward."
Just as the 40-year-old engineer settled into his position overseeing a troubled nuclear fuel reprocessing unit, he was told that workers had falsified documents involving fuel rods even then in transit to Japan. 
 The implications were not lost on Mr. Storer. It was the first shipment of such fuel rods to Japan -- a crucial customer of British Nuclear Fuels, the government-owned company that operates the sprawling Sellafield complex. The discovery, moreover, coincided with efforts by the company to secure government approval for plutonium processing at a gleaming new unit here designed to turn out "mixed oxide" fuel -- a blend of uranium and plutonium. "The timing was a disaster," he said in an interview. "And worse still, it was self-inflicted. We had shot ourselves in the foot."
In fact, things turned out far worse than he had imagined, causing the equivalent of a commercial meltdown at this complex on England's wild northwestern coast, which has been a cauldron of environmental, commercial and social tension ever since the opening of the first unit, a nuclear power station, here in 1956 and a fire a year later that tarnished the company's reputation from the start.
 In an attempt to rebuild its reputation, British Nuclear announced a leadership shake-up on April 18, promised an overhaul of safety procedures and said it had embarked on measures to prevent a recurrence of the falsification of documents. It also said it would streamline Sellafield's management to introduce greater accountability and to unify myriad safety and management practices. Government inspectors said they would watch the company closely to make sure it followed through.
The falsification of documents, by some accounts to cut corners, was only the opening chapter in a chronicle of woes that has hammered the company's standing in much of Europe, Japan and the United States, and it is fighting to hold on to an estimated $9 billion worth of contracts to dismantle and clean up nuclear sites.
Indeed, the crisis has started a debate about just what business the company should be in -- reprocessing spent fuel for use in power plants, or disposing of nuclear waste and cleaning up nuclear sites, a business that some analysts say has huge potential, without the controversies associated with reprocessing. There is no easy answer. If the reprocessing unit is closed, there will be no raw materials to produce mixed oxide fuel, leaving the Sellafield complex with little but its nuclear waste storage operations and an aging nuclear power station. That would cost thousands of jobs.
Although the company and the British government remain formally committed to reprocessing, Hugh Collum, chairman of the company, hinted that change might be inevitable. "We must be in a position to consider the unthinkable," he told a parliamentary panel in London.
Not only that, the debate has spread across Europe to the whole business of selling mixed-oxide fuels, which are more expensive than uranium but which enable plant operators to re-use spent fuel without buying new uranium. Germany, which also says it received shipments from Sellafield with falsified documents, has raised concerns about "irregularities" in reprocessed fuel, known as MOX, from France.
Riding the wave of mistrust, the environmental group Greenpeace said recently that MOX from Belgium, France and Britain "cannot be guaranteed safe to use." And in southern England, a group of dignitaries from the Channel Island of Jersey plan to travel to France to press for the end of reprocessing at a government-owned plant at La Hague on the French coast that is Sellafield's main rival in MOX production. In the United States, reprocessing has been banned since the administration of Jimmy Carter, and British Nuclear's only other competitor is in Belgium. Germany, Switzerland and Sweden have suspended shipments of spent fuel that was to be reprocessed at Sellafield. Japan wants the company to take back the fuel it shipped there.
None of that is surprising considering the catalog of problems at Sellafield. After the falsification debacle, a routine inquiry by government inspectors discovered "systematic management failures." Those conclusions were published in February. In mid-March, the company acknowledged that a saboteur had severed six cables on a robotic arm in a nuclear waste disposal unit. At the end of March, Ireland and Denmark revived a long-running campaign against the company's environmental record on radioactive pollution of the atmosphere and of the Irish Sea, demanding the closing of the six-year-old, $2.88 billion Thorp plant -- the spent-fuel reprocessing part of the Sellafield complex.
Not surprisingly, the British government has postponed a plan to sell off 49 percent of the company, raising further questions about the opaque financial underpinnings of the reprocessing business.
And in this region, caught by history and geography between a long-gone industrial past and an uncertain nuclear future, between the slate-gray wash of the Irish Sea and the soaring majesty of England's Lake District, the fate of Sellafield's 10,000 jobs has become the single greatest topic of debate in pubs and stores and cafes and homes.
"Everybody's business around here is a spin-off from Sellafield," said Elvina Quayle, 53, who sells cut flowers and groceries from a modest store in Egremont, an old market town just north of Sellafield, and whose husband, Alan, has worked at the Sellafield complex for 38 years. "Sellafield has bought luxury for everybody in this area," she said. "If it's forced to close, it'll kill off the region." Indeed, said Irene Banks, 43, who serves tea and sandwiches at the Apple Tree cafe in Egremont, "we are just in denial here, trying to pretend none of this is happening."
After a partial tour of the complex, though, it seemed clear that the troubles stemmed from a blend of high-level, long-range management decisions and low morale among some of the same workers whose livelihood depends not just on the way the complex functions but also on the way customers and critics see its record.
For one thing, critics point out, Sellafield's ultramodern $480 million MOX unit was commissioned and built before the government gave approvals for it to handle uranium or plutonium. John Barbour, a British Nuclear spokesman, said that was because "there's no mechanism" to win the approvals before a plant is built. Yet the company took orders to deliver MOX that it was producing at a far less sophisticated demonstration unit that can turn out eight tons of MOX a year and began operating in 1994. The new plant, reflecting an assessment of likely demand, has a 100-ton annual capacity, but even with an array of computerized controls it has yet to start operating.
A Sellafield spokesman, Nigel Monckton, projected profits of $480 million over the plant's life span. He did not say what the life span was expected to be, but other reports have put it at 20 years. It was in the older, smaller plant, where data are punched manually into computer terminals along the production route, that the falsification took place. Workers called up a spread sheet accompanying an old order, Mr. Storer said, and simply punched in a new batch number.
The incident raised questions about the ties between workers and overseers. "Clearly there was commercial pressure" to meet customers' demands, said John Cane, a union representative. But "that plant was never designed to be a commercial facility," he said, despite the company's insistence that the older plant had been designed with some commercial use in mind.
In this case, the customer, Kansai Electric Power, had demanded an additional check on fuel pellets being produced. Normally, Mr. Storer said, clients were satisfied with three checking procedures. The fourth involved a random manual sampling of the diameters of 5 percent of the pellets -- a crucial measure because the pellets must fit precisely into a fuel cell's long, slender tubes.
The workers who were supposed to undertake those checks, Mr. Cane said, "had difficulty understanding the relevance of that." Senior managers, too, acknowledge design and data security problems at the demonstration unit, where work has been suspended since September. "It was a prototype, but it was designed to produce a certain amount," said Jeremy Rycroft, a British Nuclear executive. "Things weren't designed as ergonomically as at the new plant. It was a small-scale facility. But things should have been right."
Similarly, Mr. Cane said, several suspects in the severing of robotic cables seem to have borne grievances against the company over a new pension and work contract negotiated with the union and the suspension of a worker buyout program. A report by Britain's nuclear installations inspections agency found fault with Sellafield's entire "safety culture."
Nuclear reprocessing, which takes spent fuel from reactors and turns it into reusable uranium and much smaller amounts of plutonium, is a long-range business. When the Thorp plant opened in 1994, it boasted some $19 billion in contracts for the first 10 years of its life. In the deep, iridescent indoor ponds -- lined with stainless steel -- huge, silvery casks of highly radioactive spent fuel glimmer from far below the surface for as much as five years until their radiation levels begin to fall.
Now, Mr. Monckton said, the ponds contain some 2,800 tons of spent fuel -- a backlog that, at the current reprocessing rate, would take three years to clear. But of course, if reprocessing was halted, the raw materials for MOX production -- uranium and plutonium -- would also come to an end. And MOX production was projected to earn $80 million in its first 10 years.
No one at the company pretends that the crisis will be resolved easily, permitting new contracts to be struck, particularly in Japan, a key market that gave the complex a third of its initial reprocessing orders in 1994. "New business is an issue," said Mr. Rycroft, the commercial director of the Thorp reprocessing division. "We won't win new business until we solve the issue of confidence."
Critics insist, however, that the issue is not simply confidence but safety and overall strategy. Many have seized on Sellafield's vulnerability to pursue long-running campaigns against emissions levels from the plant's many nuclear processes, even though the company says the emissions have fallen radically since the mid-1970's. "There is mass hysteria," said Robin Simpson, a local Labor politician who also works at Sellafield. "Everyone is jumping on the anti-Sellafield bandwagon." The reprocessing plant draws particular ire from environmental campaigners because it produces its own highly radioactive waste.
"We don't want Sellafield closed," said Jill Perry, the local representative of Friends of the Earth. "But where we see its future is in cleaning up nuclear waste, and that's where its expertise should be focused." Indeed, she argued that halting the reprocessing business that accounts for roughly half of Sellafield's jobs could help the regional economy. "No responsible employer would open a factory or any other kind of business because of the radioactivity in this area. So stopping reprocessing might actually bring jobs."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Unless stocks take another severe dive, overall damage to the economy is likely to be minimal.

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle 

 BODY:
STOCK prices have regained some of their lost ground, but the enormous hit to wealth last week is likely to knock the nation's economy only partly off its stride -- unless the rout on Wall Street resumes in earnest.
From early January through last Friday, sell-offs have destroyed an estimated $2 trillion to $3 trillion in total wealth, including $1.5 trillion in household savings. Most of that was wiped out in last week's steep decline. 
 Spread the household decline over the roughly half the population that owns stocks and the loss averaged more than $12,000 a person. What if that turned out to be long-lasting, and each foray upward in stock prices soon gave way to another slide, as this week's rally began to do yesterday?
"If the market stays just where it was, there will be weeks of news media discussion about what went wrong and a lot of person-to-person conversation," said Robert J. Shiller, a Yale economist whose new book, "Irrational Exuberance," argues that stock markets are driven in large part by emotion and mimicry. "People learn what to do from one another."
But for all the talk, the damage to the overall economy is likely to be minimal -- unless markets take another severe dive, pushing stock gauges well below their lows so far this year. If the market merely fails to rebound, the growth rate of the economy should slow by this summer to about 3.6 percent, compared with last year's growth of 4.6 percent, according to estimates by Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis firm whose computer simulations of the economy's expected behavior are widely followed by government officials and economists.
Under the firm's projections, the unemployment rate could drift gradually upward to 4.5 percent next year from 4.1 percent today.
"Consumers tend to respond fairly quickly to sharp declines in household wealth," said Kenneth J. Matheny, senior economist at Macroeconomic Advisers.
Still, that downshift represents only a comparatively modest deceleration from the 4.2 percent growth Macroeconomic Advisers expected in the absence of a stock market correction. The red-hot American economy was already projected to cool off slightly in response to a series of interest rate increases engineered by the Federal Reserve. There have been five quarter-point rate increases in the federal funds rate since last June, and Macroeconomic Advisers allows for more, pushing the current level beyond 6 percent.
"This assumes that stock prices move sideways for six months," Mr. Matheny said. "If there is another big correction in the next few weeks, then we could seriously entertain the possibility that the Fed won't tighten again, and might even ease."
Whatever the Fed does, the market downturn is likely to arouse much more debate about interest rate policy. With the gross domestic product expanding at more than 4 percent on average in recent years, and much more in recent months, the Fed's rate increases have met with relatively little opposition. To most economists, the demand for goods and services seems to be outstripping supply, threatening inflationary shortages.
But if growth slows to around 3.5 percent, partly in response to weakness on Wall Street, that could bring the nation's increase in economic output within the range that many experts believe is sustainable without risking a serious escalation in prices. In that case, the Fed may not have to lift interest rates very much.
"Let's play with one percentage point of economic growth," said Alan S. Blinder, a Princeton University economist and a former vice chairman of the Fed. "To the extent the stock market takes this purchasing power away, the Fed has less to do."
The big question mark is the extent to which the so-called wealth effect will come into play. While some experts think such estimates are exaggerated, the rule of thumb held that on the way up, consumers spent perhaps 3 to 5 cents more for each dollar of increase in their households' stock portfolios. But some new research suggests that on the way down, the pullback in spending might be greater than 3 to 5 cents -- concentrated in high-end merchandise like luxury cars, jewelry, watches, boats and the like.
While the spending of high-end households is hit the hardest, changes in stock prices appear to "affect spending by households that do not own stock because they affect consumer confidence," James Poterba, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, reports in an article soon to be published in the Journal of Economic Perspectives. "Unfortunately, the only way to learn more about these effects may be by experiencing a downturn in stock market values."
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, estimates that the stock market wealth effect added about three-quarters of a percentage point to economic growth over the last year. "What stimulated spending will soon evaporate," he said.
Apart from consumption, the downward pressure on economic growth from an enduring stock market correction comes from changes to capital spending, stock options, pension fund contributions and debt. As consumption eases, so does the pressure to expand production through capital investment in new equipment. Less demand means less output, and capital spending may fall about 15 percent short of projections this year in response to the market downturn Mr. Matheny said.
The economy could take another hit if stock options become less popular. The companies that issue these options do not have to carry them as a labor cost until they are cashed in. But in a market that is moving sideways or down, stock options lose their appeal and employees may press for cash raises or bonuses. These do count as a labor cost, cutting into profits that drive expansion plans.
"Companies will take a wait-and-see attitude," said Rhoda Edelman, managing director of Pearl Meyer & Partners Inc., a firm that advises companies on compensation practices. "But there is a potential for higher labor costs."
Similarly, rising stock prices have increased the value of corporate pension funds in recent years, thus reducing or eliminating the need for cash contributions. The market correction, if it holds, means that companies will have to inject additional cash, cutting further into profits.
The biggest unknown is what will happen to heavily indebted families, many of which borrowed against the value of their homes or stock portfolios to pay for consumption or the purchase of more stocks.
"Most of these people must feel vulnerable if the stock market correction holds and therefore the flow of borrowing is likely to be lower," said Wynne Godley, an economist and debt expert at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute. "If the flow is lower, spending will be lower. We don't know the magnitudes yet, but that is the central point."

HEADLINE: Plan for Hudson River Institute Gains Ground

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
When Gov. George E. Pataki outlined plans in Albany in his State of the State speech in January for a world-class science center along the Hudson River -- a kind of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution for rivers -- there was applause, but no one ran for the exits to spread the news. Such speeches are generally full of trial balloons.
Now, though, the project appears to be gaining some traction. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Pataki outlined the first hiring of staff, the naming of an advisory board and the formation of a task force to find a site and define a mission for the Rivers Institute -- its working name for now. 
 And anticipating Mr. Pataki's formal announcement of these moves today, elected officials up and down the Hudson Valley rehearsed appeals for why each town or city was the absolutely perfect site.
Given that Mr. Pataki foresees an institution with perhaps 500 employees and an annual budget of $50 million or so, the officials, particularly in downtrodden communities like Newburgh, described it as a crucial shot in the arm.
But several officials echoed Glen D. Jennings, the mayor of Albany, who said that no matter where it ended up, it would benefit the whole region. "Anything that will bring jobs and more development and a focus on the river will be positive not only for the community that's chosen but for everyone on the Hudson," Mr. Jennings said.
But he quickly followed with a list of why Albany was just right.
Mr. Pataki said the economic benefits of creating a large science center in New York State were still secondary to the scientific benefits.
The governor said he was appointing John Cronin, the Hudson's recently retired "riverkeeper," a private pollution watchdog, as the first employee working on the project. Mr. Cronin's part-time job is to convene meetings of scientists, historians and residents to shape goals for research at the center.
The advisory board for the project includes Robert Gagosian, the director of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution; Robert H. Boyle, an environmental advocate and author of books on the Hudson; and a host of river experts. Mr. Pataki said the board and a state task force would have a year to define the institute's agenda and come up with a plan for financing the project.
Despite Mr. Pataki's focus on science, the main reason for excitement about the project among various elected officials from riverside communities remained the prospect of jobs and activity on shores that for decades have been forsaken by everything but weeds and rust.
T. R. Gallo, the mayor of Kingston, one of many Hudson Valley cities still suffering from the contraction of I.B.M., gushed about the merits of Kingston's Rondout Creek, which is already lined with museums, marinas and restaurants, as a perfect backdrop for the project.
Harold J. Porr 3rd, the city manager of Newburgh , said no place had the attributes of his city, with a long shoreline ready to accept research vessels and a broad bay where the river's two ecosystems -- its salty tidal front and its fresh water -- merge. He noted that the city has an 11 percent unemployment rate.
"The injection of a facility like this would be incredible," he said. "In Manhattan, it woul'd be just another nice thing. Do it in Newburgh, and it would transform us."

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 474 words

HEADLINE: Albany's Back Rooms

 BODY:
With much fanfare two years ago, New York's state legislators celebrated a new budget process that was supposed to be more open and democratic. But when a $77 billion budget package failed to win agreement this week because of Gov. George Pataki's last-minute insistence on debt reform, any pretense of legislative democracy in Albany evaporated. While budget conference committees debated in public, the real deals were being engineered by three men in a room -- Governor Pataki, the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver. This deprived the public, and most legislators, of any chance to understand the implications of all the horse-trading.
Drafts of this year's budget are laden with election-year goodies, some worthy, some not, that could win final approval on May 1 when the full Legislature is expected to return from spring break. The big question is whether the state can afford this array of political confection if the economy sours in future years. 
 The tax proposals, for example, include helpful tax credits for child care and low-wage workers, and a sensible, gradual repeal of a tax on utilities that is passed on to industry and other consumers. However, the burden of paying for this tax cut, as well as more questionable cuts for college tuition and married taxpayers, will fall mostly to future taxpayers.
The state's education package wisely boosts funding to schools around the state and especially in New York City. The increases would expand the availability of college tuition for poor students, reduce class size in public schools and provide pre-kindergarten classes to 4-year-olds statewide. But there is also a new formula for revenue sharing, or unencumbered funds, that tilts heavily in favor of upstate communities. The formula is acceptable this year, when upstate urban areas desperately need money and the New York City budget is laden with Wall Street tax revenues. But if the new formula becomes the standard, it could harm the city in leaner times.
Governor Pataki's plan to make certain that all buses purchased by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority burn clean fuel is a happy advance over New Jersey Transit's agreement to buy a horde of dirty diesel buses. But the M.T.A.'s latest long-term plan relies on a risky bond package. The plan would require a huge increase in debt service for the authority and deserves more public and legislative debate.
This entire budget package suffers from the secret way it was developed. Albany's legislators this week have been roaming the halls asking each other what is really going on. Although Governor Pataki's insistence on debt reform makes some fiscal sense, the discussions about it should be open, not part of a three-person negotiation that excludes the rest of the legislators and the public.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Reports by I.B.M. and Intel Lead to a Slide in Stocks
Disappointment with first-quarter reports from I.B.M. and Intel helped send stocks lower, ending the two-day surge after last week's sell-off. The dot-com stocks that have fallen so sharply recently were down again.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 87.16 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,706.41, while the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 92.46 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,674.96. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 14.1 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,427.47. Page C12. 

A Misstep, Not a Fall, for Growth
Stock prices have regained some of their lost ground, but the enormous hit to wealth last week is likely to knock the nation's economy only partly off its stride -- unless the rout resumes in earnest. Market Place. C13.
 
Apple Profit Beats Expectations
Apple Computer posted earnings that handily beat analysts' estimates for its second quarter. In contrast to the slowing sales for many PC makers, Apple reported strong demand across its product lines. Apple reported its results after the close of the market. Amid a broad decline on Nasdaq, its shares closed at $121.125, down $5.75. In after-hours trading, they traded as high as $125.5625. C7.
 
Trade Deficit Widens to a Record
The United States trade deficit widened to a record $29.2 billion in February from $27.4 billion during January, elevated by surging oil prices and growing demand for imports, government figures showed. C14.
 
Sales and Profit Rise for Daimler
DaimlerChrysler reported that sales climbed 17 percent in the last three months, but it paid for that increase in the form of lower profit margins on both Chrysler and Mercedes-Benz automobiles. Net income rose 3 percent, to $1.62 billion, helped by German tax reform. The results indicate that Daimler has yet to overcome the unrelenting price competition in the American car market. C4.
 
Cigarette Promoted as Lower-Risk
R. J. Reynolds Tobacco said that it would start promoting one of its brands, Eclipse, as posing a potentially lower risk of cancer and chronic bronchitis than traditional cigarettes, marking the first time that a producer has made such advertising claims. A23.
 
Chief Outlines the Future for Grey
Edward H. Meyer, 73, left, the supreme commander of Grey Advertising in New York, is making the first steps toward outlining the future of the agency. In a reorganization described to Grey employees, Mr. Meyer will become the head of a new holding company, Grey Global Group. Based on the appointments at Grey Worldwide, the new name for the core advertising agency, two executives seemed poised for promotion. One is Steven Blamer, who will become president for New York at Grey Worldwide. The other is Carolyn Carter, who will become president for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at Grey Worldwide. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.
 
Chase Manhattan Profit Rises 16%
Chase Manhattan said that its first-quarter profit rose 16 percent, exceeding forecasts, as a surge in trading revenue and fees from advising on mergers, plus gains on investments, lifted results. C11.
 
Airlines Post Quarterly Results
UAL and AMR, the parent companies of the world's two biggest airlines, United and American, posted first-quarter results that beat Wall Street expectations, while a strike threat hurt earnings at US Airways, which posted a bigger-than-expected loss. C13.
 
Earnings Increase 41% at Lucent
Lucent Technologies, the world's leading phone-equipment maker, said that its second-quarter profit rose 41 percent, to 23 cents a share, on higher sales of wireless and fiber-optic gear. The company had warned in January that net income would be 21 to 23 cents a share when analysts were expecting 26 cents. C7.

Court Extends Elian's Stay, And Faults the Government

TRIZETTO AND IMS HEALTH TO RECONSIDER MERGER

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Shares of the TriZetto Group and IMS Health Inc. rose sharply yesterday after the companies said they would consider restructuring their highly unpopular merger proposal. The stock-swap merger, originally valued at $8.4 billion but now down to $2.45 billion, failed to win investor support from the start. HEADLINE: Contract Accord Averts Strike by Doormen

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The union that represents workers at 2,900 New York City apartment buildings reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the real estate industry, averting a strike threatened for tomorrow that would have disrupted the daily routines of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers.
The settlement, coming just before Passover and Good Friday, was greeted with relief by many New Yorkers who live in the buildings where the 26,000 unionized doormen, janitors, concierges and handymen work. 
 Negotiators from the real estate industry and the union announced the settlement after two days of round-the-clock talks in which they had set an unofficial goal of reaching a settlement before the first Passover seder last night so as to minimize disruption for New Yorkers.
"I'm happy we've been able to reach this settlement in time for the city and its residents to enjoy a good holiday season in peace and harmony," said the industry's chief negotiator, James F. Berg, president of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations.
The current three-year contract is scheduled to expire at 12:01 a.m. tomorrow, and many New Yorkers had feared a replay of the 12-day strike of 1991, which left buildings bereft of doormen and janitors, forcing many residents to sort their own mail and haul their garbage downstairs.
At a news conference at the Sheraton New York, the negotiators declined to disclose details of the wage package for the workers, who earn $597 a week on average, or nearly $15 an hour. But one bargaining committee member said the accord called for a wage increase of about 10 percent over the three-year life of the contract.
The agreement, which the union's members are to vote on next week, also raises retirees' maximum monthly pension to $1,500 a month, from the current maximum of $1,000, the committee member said.
"I think it's a very good agreement," said Ramon Pabon, a concierge at 535 East 86th Street and a member of the union's 50-person bargaining committee. "It's something that's going to work for all our members. The best part is we didn't have to go out on strike."
Michael Fishman, the trustee running the apartment workers' union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, reserved special praise for contract provisions that will provide computer training for doormen and janitors.
Computer training, he said, will not only help the apartment workers do their jobs better, but it may also make it easier for these workers, most of them immigrants, to go to college or move to better jobs. In an unusual provision, money from the employer-sponsored training and education fund will subsidize the workers' purchase of computers.
Negotiators on the union's bargaining committee applauded the agreement and claimed victory, noting that the raises were higher than the rate of inflation and that they kept the union's members well in front of other building workers as the highest paid in the nation.
In addition, the union achieved its goal of obtaining a more generous wage increase than the 9 percent over three years accepted in late 1998 by 29,000 workers in New York City office towers. Those workers belong to the same local but work under a different contract.
For months, union officials had called on management to be more generous in this round of negotiations because the real estate industry was booming. "We think this is a step toward sharing the prosperity," Mr. Fishman said.
Officials in the real estate industry also praised the accord, saying the wage increases were modest and the industry could afford them at a time when rents and condominium prices are soaring. In addition, management negotiators noted, the wage increases are far less than the union had originally demanded, and an accord was reached without the disruptive strikes by janitors in other cities, including Los Angeles, San Diego and Chicago.
"This settlement is a fair agreement for all parties," Mr. Berg said. "I think it will move the city forward."
Mr. Berg asked that details of the agreement not be made public before he presented them to his board of directors at a meeting scheduled for this morning.
Negotiators said they talked until 1 a.m. Wednesday before breaking off into small groups, with the two sides remaining far apart. Mr. Fishman and Mr. Berg said they made considerable progress yesterday afternoon, as the two sides took the rare step of presenting their bottom lines 36 hours before the strike deadline, with an eye toward reaching an early settlement to avoid disrupting the holidays.
Around the city, apartment residents breathed easier, delighted that their elaborate strike contingency plans, including rotations for doorman duty, would not be needed.
Anne Cote Taylor, who had been helping organize residents of her Upper East Side building for the possible strike, said: "I'm pleased for everyone. Our staff doesn't lose pay, and life in the building goes back to normal."
In its original demands, the union had called for raises of 10 percent a year for three years, a figure that even union officials said they never expected to come close to.
Even though the union members have the highest wages of any building workers in the country, the union had argued that they deserved a large wage increase, partly to serve as a model for other janitors around the country.
Over the last week, management's negotiators had urged the union to accept a raise of 3 percent a year for 3 years, the same one accepted by the office building workers.
The peaceful settlement of the dispute is in sharp contrast to negotiations in other cities. In Los Angeles, 8,500 building service workers have been on strike for 17 days, asserting that their base wages are far too low to live on. About 5,500 janitors at Chicago office buildings walked out for 10 hours on Monday before reaching a settlement.
Among the other major issues of contention in New York were management's demand for more flexibility to lay off workers and the union's demand for contractual language that would make it easier to unionize janitors in the suburbs.
Mr. Fishman said the union had not achieved that goal, and management officials declined to discuss whether they had gained more flexibility in layoffs.
Todd Jenning, a handyman at the Schomburg, an apartment building at 110th Street and Fifth Avenue, said the best thing about the agreement was the increased pension, which was one of the union's major goals.
Mr. Jenning, a member of the union's bargaining committee, said, "We were prepared for a strike, but it's good to have an agreement."
Mr. Fishman, who took the union's helm in September, had repeatedly threatened to strike, saying his goal was to reinvigorate Local 32B-32J, which had lost members and esprit de corps in the two decades that it was led by Gus Bevona.
The Service Employees International Union forced Mr. Bevona into retirement last year because it was angry over what it called his dictatorial ways, huge salary and sumptuous penthouse at union headquarters.

HEADLINE: Chinese Adviser Warns Closer U.S.-Taiwan Military Ties Will Anger Beijing

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 19

 BODY:
Adoption by Washington of a proposal to enhance military ties with Taiwan would have a "disastrous" effect on American relations with China, a leading government adviser warned here today.
"This would be an openly hostile act by the United States toward China," the adviser, Xu Shiquan, said of the proposed law in an interview. "Sino-American relations would plunge again to the bottom and American interests would be seriously damaged." Mr. Xu is president of the Institute of Taiwan Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, the leading government-run research group on Taiwan affairs. 
 The proposed law, the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, would mandate closer cooperation between the American and Taiwanese militaries. The United States has not had a formal alliance with Taiwan since it switched diplomatic recognition to the mainland in 1979, but under the Taiwan Relations Act of the same year it has pledged to provide Taiwan with the means to defend itself against attack.
The bill, which President Clinton says is unneeded and overly provocative, passed the House of Representatives by a huge margin on Feb. 1. Its prospects in the Senate are unclear, but this week, after the Clinton administration said it would not sell Taiwan some of the advanced weapons it had requested, some Republican senators vowed to press harder for the legislation.
In a wide-ranging interview, Mr. Xu described Beijing's response to last month's presidential elections in Taiwan as "cool and restrained," but held out little hope of an easing of tensions unless Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, made a basic change in policy and embraced the principle of "One China" under Beijing's ultimate authority.
Mr. Chen was long an advocate of formal independence for Taiwan, which Beijing, considering the island a province separated by the civil war of the 1940's, has said would be grounds for military intervention. More recently, however, Mr. Chen has moderated this position, saying that a declaration of independence is unnecessary because Taiwan already enjoys de facto sovereignty.
Since his election on March 18, Mr. Chen has worked to avoid angering Beijing, saying he seeks peace and offering to negotiate an end to restrictions on commerce across the Taiwan Strait. He selected as his prime minister the departing defense minister, from the Nationalist Party, who opposes independence.
But Mr. Xu dismissed Mr. Chen's verbal olive branches and expressed pessimism about the chances of negotiations between Beijing and Taipei in the next year or two.
"I don't think he is any closer to the one-China principle," he said of Mr. Chen. "He still insists that Taiwan is an independent and sovereign state and that one China is not a principle, but an issue to talk about."
Beijing has given some breathing space to Mr. Chen, who takes office on May 20, by promising to "listen to what he says and watch what he does." But it has repeatedly stated that it will talk with his government only if he agrees that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China.
But Mr. Xu also predicted that Mr. Chen would find it difficult to make that leap, especially given his weak political position. And he offered no hope that Beijing, from its side, wouldseek compromise language.
Beijing is anxious to see Taipei lift its restrictions on direct commerce and communications with the mainland, for example, but will not take up Mr. Chen's offer to discuss even this practical matter, Mr. Xu said, without agreement on first principles.
"If it's a question of opening internal links within one country, then we welcome it," he said. "If it's 'state-to-state' links, then that's a provocation and we cannot accept it."
Under Beijing's proposal, if Taiwan will accept that it is part of China, then it can have enormous autonomy, retaining its own political and economic system, and even military. But any moves to formalize independence would be regarded as a provocation to war.
Mr. Xu said that Beijing's current campaign to vilify the woman elected as Mr. Chen's vice president, Annette Lu, was intended as a "warning to the extremist elements" of Mr. Chen's Democratic Progressive Party. "The aim is to deter the extremists from doing reckless things."
Ms. Lu, a Harvard Law graduate and a longtime, forceful advocate of Taiwan independence, offended Beijing with remarks in a recent television interview. For more than a week now she has been subjected to daily denunciations in the official press as a "traitor" and "scum."
"By criticizing Annette Lu, the mainland is actually helping Chen Shui-bian," Mr. Xu said, by discouraging words or deeds that could cause a crisis in relations.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Says China Trade Bill Will Erode U.S. Influence

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
The House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, said today that he would oppose permanent normal trade relations with China because doing so would sacrifice American leverage over Beijing's behavior on human rights and religious liberties.
In a passionate rebuttal to many of the Clinton administration's pro-trade arguments, Mr. Gephardt said that giving up the annual Congressional review of China's trade status would be "a recipe for serious trouble." 
 "America should not trust the Chinese government to make progress on its own and unilaterally surrender our nation's ability to influence Chinese policy through trade," Mr. Gephardt said in a speech in St. Louis.
Mr. Gephardt's announcement puts him at odds with virtually every senior Democrat in his party, from Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, the presumptive presidential nominee, to the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota.
But given Mr. Gephardt's strong ties to organized labor, which opposes the measure, his decision came as no surprise. He has spoken to Mr. Clinton about his views, most recently last week, and called Mr. Gore on Tuesday to explain his decision, aides said.
Laura Nichols, Mr. Gephardt's spokeswoman, said the call to Mr. Gore was "a simple notification." A spokesman for Mr. Gore said the vice president, who has been calling wavering Democrats in recent days, had no comment on Mr. Gephardt's decision or their conversation. Mr. Gore's presidential rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, supports the measure.
More important for Mr. Gore and for congressional Democrats eager to retake the House this fall, Mr. Gephardt has vowed not to let the vote divide the party in the fall elections. He says he will not make the China trade vote a litmus test of party loyalty or lobby his colleagues, leaving that chore to the No. 2 House Democrat, David E. Bonior of Michigan, who also opposes the measure.
The vote on China's trade status will determine to what degree the United States benefits from China's expected entry into the World Trade Organization.
"The manner in which Dick has conducted himself has really allowed us to secure a significant number of Democratic votes," said Representative Cal Dooley of California, a top Democratic vote counter for the measure who today predicted victory.
The crucial vote is set for the week of May 22. As many as 150 Republicans will likely support the measure, leaving Democrats in favor scrambling to scrape up the rest needed to reach the 218 votes for passage. About 40 undecided House Democrats control the measure's fate, and in interviews today, many expressed conflicting views on the significance of Mr. Gephardt's announcement.
Mr. Gephardt's timing is significant because the House is in a two-week recess, and during this last extended time at home before the vote, uncommitted lawmakers will be the target of lobbying from both sides.
In his speech at Webster University to an audience of students and civic leaders, Mr. Gephardt at one point sought to calm a debate over China trade that he said "has become overly polarized." But then in animated remarks, he assailed arguments for the deal, which he said put the nation's economic interests ahead of its equally important commitment to human freedom around the world.
"Sustainable development and worker rights must be at the core of our trade policy," Mr. Gephardt said. "Otherwise, we have no assurance that trade will contribute to enhanced living standards at home and abroad."
Acknowledging that the global economy is transforming market forces, Mr. Gephardt said he was neither "a protectionist, nor am I a free-trader," but rather an advocate for trade accords that incorporate tougher labor, environmental and human rights standards.
"There's no debate about whether America should engage China," he said. "The question is how to engage so trade access can be matched with steady progress toward greater human rights and rule of law in China."
House Republican leaders, who had been suspicious of Mr. Gephardt's silence until now on the trade bill, criticized him for being out of step with new economic realities.
"Mr. Gephardt's decision is based not on sound economic principles," Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said. "Rather it is based on fear, fear of the political power of big labor, fear of the implications of the new economy, fear of the future."

HEADLINE: Poverty Found To Be Rising In Families Considered Safe

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
For years, antipoverty efforts have stressed work, education and marriage as the way up the economic ladder for the single, jobless mothers who seemed to account for the bulk of urban poverty.
Now a new analysis of census data shows that in New York City, in the midst of an economic boom, poverty rates rose sharply among just the kind of families with children that were supposed to be safe: those that include two parents, a worker and a household head with more than a high school degree. 
 Comparing three years ending in 1998 with the last comparable stretch of prosperity, in the late 1980's, the study found that the overall rate of poverty in New York City among families with children climbed to 32.3 percent from 29.3 percent, despite a rise in education and employment that would have been expected to reduce poverty.
The official federal poverty threshold is $13,133 for a family of three.
The study, released yesterday by the nonprofit Community Service Society, suggests a collision of several trends: the growing gap between rich and poor, a surge in immigration and, as welfare changes push recipients off the rolls, increasing competition for low-end jobs with eroding wages.
The most optimistic interpretation is that new immigrants are a major factor and that as they assimilate, they will move up and into the middle class. But more ominous trends are seen by Mark Levitan, the author of the study and a senior policy analyst at the Community Service Society, which has been tracking poverty for years.
The gains in education and increases in jobs were outweighed by the emergence of a "new poor" within groups long considered largely immune to poverty, he said, as middle rungs of the economic ladder disappear.
For example, poverty rates rose by 10.6 percentage points for families headed by people with some college, and increased by 4 percentage points for families headed by someone with a bachelor's degree or more. Poverty also rose for families that included one worker, by 8.2 percentage points, even as poverty rates fell by 6.9 percentage points for families with no worker present. And for families headed by a married couple, the poverty rate rose by 6.7 percentage points, even as it dropped by 5.1 percentage points for families led by women.
Along with the rise in these poverty rates, the demographics of families below the poverty line shifted, with more of them having higher education, jobs and two parents in the household.
Though the study is the first of its kind, it echoes recent reports by the state comptroller's office that have highlighted an increase in payroll jobs paying less than $25,000 a year, coupled with a decline in the number of payroll jobs paying higher wages, and a study by the nonprofit Fiscal Policy Institute tracking a sharp increase in the working poor in New York City that has outpaced a similar trend in the nation.
The working poor include people like Doris Argueta, a cashier at the Metropolitan Opera House cafe, who looks at the furs and jewelry of operagoers and wonders why her wages were stuck in the $6 an hour range for two years and still have not risen above $7.66 an hour, despite a push by employees to unionize.
"Sometimes, I think because I don't speak very well English they're going to pay like that," said Ms. Argueta, 32, who left El Salvador seven years ago and shares a two-room apartment with her child and an unrelated family.
They also include John Hunter, 37, a father of six, who feels he gained no real ground moving from $6 an hour as a security guard in the late 1980's to $7 an hour buffing floors and scrubbing toilets in a building near Wall Street for a cleaning company.
His wife works fluctuating hours at a shoe store on Staten Island, where she is making $7.45 hourly after three years. "We're finding it very hard to pay bills," Mr. Hunter said. "I'm not getting ahead at all, not with the wages I'm being paid and no benefits."
Marcia Van Wagner, chief economist for State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, called the results of the structural shifts distressing.
"At the low end, you have lots of jobs and declining real income," she said. "At the high end, you have not that many jobs, but increases in inflation-adjusted earnings" like exercised stock options. The rewards of increasing productivity are concentrated at the high end of the spectrum, she said.
"This wasn't supposed to happen," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society. He said that the signs documented in the new study were "ominous" coming at the height of an economic boom.
But Lawrence Mead, a professor of political science at New York University who has written extensively in support of the welfare overhaul, disagreed, calling the increase in poverty small compared with the sharp reductions in city welfare rolls. Families are better off over all if they earn money rather than getting it from welfare, he asserted, even if their incomes drop.
"I'm not saying it won't be trouble in the future," Professor Mead added. "I think there is enough increase in the labor supply due to welfare reform that there might be some tendency for real wages to fall slightly. I'm not saying that welfare reform is finished: there is a question of making work pay."
The city's figures stand in sharp contrast to the nation's as a whole, which had a flat poverty rate of 15.8 percent for families with children in both periods, and tiny, probably statistically insignificant increases in poverty among the more educated, Mr. Levitan said. According to the Fiscal Policy Institute study released last year, the number of working poor families increased by 60 percent in New York during the 1990's, much faster than the nationwide increase of 24 percent.
One reason for the difference is that the city is one of a handful of places in the nation that draw poor immigrants from around the globe, Mr. Levitan said. But the proportion of poor families that are foreign-born is roughly the same as in the population as a whole, he said, contending that the trends captured in the study cannot be explained away by immigration alone.
Other factors he cited were changes in the city's economy that were ahead of the rest of the country, like the rise in corporations using temporary or contract workers.
"The problem is," Mr. Levitan said, "we are telling people to climb out of poverty on a downward-moving escalator."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
The Euro Falls Below 94 cents On Talk Rates May Not Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The euro fell to a record low against the dollar yesterday and could fall further on prospects that the European Central Bank will not raise interest rates next week or try to prop up the currency by intervening in the market to buy euros.
The single currency fell for a fourth consecutive day against the dollar, settling in New York at 93.82 cents, compared with 94.04 late on Wednesday, its lowest ending price since it was introduced at the start of last year. Intraday in New York, the euro traded as low as 93.54 cents. 
 "The market is going to dump euros at any opportunity," said Per Norr, a trader at Den Norske Bank, adding that dealers would probably sell it "and just wait for something out of the E.C.B." The likelihood of central bank intervention rises if the euro falls to 90 cents, as some analysts predict, he said.
United States economic strength and a degree of stock market recovery have pushed the dollar higher this week, while the euro was hurt by a weaker-than-expected report on German business sentiment, political upheaval in Italy and concern that the impasse between Austria and the European Union would remain unbroken.
In a little more than 15 months, the euro has weakened about 20 percent against the dollar and 25 percent against the Japanese yen, as the 11-nation euro zone economy has not picked up as quickly as some investors had anticipated.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
DDB Worldwide takes on the daunting task of changing consumers' ideas about J. C. Penney.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
ONE of the most successful campaigns that changed consumer perceptions about a retailer was created by the old Doyle Dane Bernbach agency, for the Ohrbach's department store chain. Yesterday, the successor shop to Doyle Dane, DDB Worldwide, was named to handle that daunting task for perhaps the most troubled of large contemporary retailers, J. C. Penney.
After a three-month review that began with the dismissal of Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., the Penney agency for almost nine years, the retailer named DDB as its agency of record. DDB, part of the Omnicom Group, will develop marketing initiatives for the flagging Penney department stores and catalog as well as its shopping Web site. 
 The famed retailer Stanley Marcus, who turned 95 yesterday, helped DDB land the assignment, with billings estimated at $100 million to $200 million; Mr. Marcus, retired from Neiman-Marcus since 1976, served as a consultant to the agency.
The Penney change is indicative of the increasing importance being placed on advertising and marketing by retailers, particularly in the realm of brand-building campaigns. Chains like Target, Banana Republic, Pottery Barn and Old Navy have attributed their popularity in part to decisions to spend considerable sums on burnishing their images as well as on sales and promotions.
DDB offices in Chicago, Dallas and New York -- along with siblings like Spike DDB, a joint venture with the director Spike Lee, and Rapp Collins Worldwide, a direct marketing agency -- will work on shining up the tarnished Penney name as much as they will strive to help peddle more merchandise.
That kind of turnaround is one of the most difficult assignments for an agency, because shoppers are notoriously fickle. Their impressions of the images of retailers are based to a large degree on intangible elements: Do friends coo or cringe when they see you carrying a bag bearing the name of a store? Do you feel clever or cheated when you compare the prices you paid with those charged by another retailer?
"We attracted 13 million new customers last year, but the bad news was we lost 15 million customers," said Stephen Farley, senior vice president and chief marketing officer at the J. C. Penney Company in Plano, Tex. "We need to get the brand to be more sticky, if you will."
"What J. C. Penney has to do is look in the mirror and understand what the customer has to say about us," said Mr. Farley, who has worked for agencies like N. W. Ayer and Saatchi & Saatchi as well as retailers like Payless Shoe Source. "She's not angry with us, she's indifferent. We've fallen off her radar screen. We need a better understanding of how to meet her needs."
"DDB exhibited a tremendous passion for the business as well as an understanding and appreciation of retail," he added. "And if you look at the agency's history in terms of building brands, that's important."
Needham Harper Worldwide, another DDB predecessor, worked for Montgomery Ward and Sears, Roebuck. And when Doyle Dane opened in 1949, Ohrbach's was a founding client. The agency created campaigns unusual in that era for their humor and low-key tone, which produced perceptions of Ohrbach's as a source of fashionable apparel at reasonable prices for canny consumers.
For instance, a print ad showed a sulking boy under the headline "We regret to inform you your school stuff is ready at Ohrbach's."
Though Ohrbach's has gone the way of Gimbels, S. Klein and Woolworth, present-day retailers like Old Navy and Target are presenting themselves in similar ways.
"It really always starts with the customer, who ultimately defines a brand," said Keith Reinhard, chairman at DDB, who spoke to reporters in conference calls with Mr. Farley from the agency's Chicago office. "We have a passion for representing the customer's point of view."
"The Penney brand has a lot of friends," he added. "Our job is to turn all those friends into lovers."
Attitudes about retailers can turn on a dime -- or a Penney. In the 1980's, a makeover for Penney, focused on clothing and home furnishings, proved a hit; the New York agency now known as N. W. Ayer & Partners, part of the B Com3 Group, played a crucial role in that turnaround. But Ayer lost the account in the early 1990's when Penney sales slumped during the recession.
Ayer was replaced by Temerlin McClain, now part of True North Communications. That agency's hold on the Penney account was initially strong because of sales-building image ads carrying themes like "Doing it right."
But recently, Penney sales began to slump as shoppers shifted their loyalties to discounters like Target and specialty chains like Gap and Old Navy. In February, Penney announced a 34 percent decline in profit for the fourth quarter of 1999, the closing of 45 unprofitable stores and the dismissals of employees.
"The most important thing is recognizing you're doing something that's not working," Mr. Marcus said in a telephone interview from Dallas, "and having the will power to overcome internal resistance to change."
Mr. Marcus said he was brought in as a consultant by Mr. Reinhard, who "became aware of me about six or seven years ago by reading one of my books, 'Minding the Store.' He asked, 'Would you help us out on this Penney account because I must tell you, we're not doing so well.' I visited a number of Penney stores, and a group of people I gathered visited the stores, and we compared notes."
"The report I wrote looked at Penney from the customer's point of view," Mr. Marcus said, "not the manufacturer's or Penney's. We thought some things were wrong, but nothing is always 100 percent."
Mr. Farley declined to discuss the strategy for a new campaign, planned for the fall, that he is already discussing with DDB. But he indicated that the company and the agency "have a unique opportunity" to persuade "the time-starved customer that Penney can provide her with all the things she needs under one roof, rather than piecing it together at a series of stores."
The Penney dismissal of Temerlin McClain in early January involved all creative tasks except the St. John's Bay line of apparel. DDB had earlier been named to handle two Penney lines, Arizona apparel and home products. Media buying, which had been handled by Mediavest in New York, another B Com3 unit, will be shifted to OMD USA, part of Omnicom. Media planning will be handled by DDB's Optimum Media.
The review began with five agencies invited to take part. In March, one participant withdrew: the Chicago office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North. That left as contenders DDB and three other agencies, all based in New York. They were: the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom; McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; and Saatchi & Saatchi. On April 7, Penney narrowed the review to two finalists, DDB and BBDO.

HEADLINE: The Next Balkan Crisis

 BODY:
Throughout the war in Kosovo last year, there was a sharp contrast between the behavior of Montenegro and Serbia. Although is it part of a Yugoslavia led by Slobodan Milosevic, Montenegro has a Western-oriented, democratic leader, Milo Djukanovic. Montenegro took in Albanian refugees, sheltered Serbia's dissenters and parried attempts by Mr. Milosevic to take control of the republic. 
 Now, however, Mr. Milosevic is trying again. To hold him off, Montenegro needs more financial and political help from the West. Although the republic has only 650,000 people, it is strategically important. A democratic and prosperous Montenegro would show Serbia's residents that life in Yugoslavia does not have to be miserable. If Mr. Milosevic takes over a region that was the focus of so much Western attention and rhetorical support during the war, he will gain a significant symbolic victory and further destabilize the Balkans.
In a recent interview with The Times, the normally restrained Mr. Djukanovic accused Belgrade of trying to overthrow him by creating a 1,000-member paramilitary unit and stationing it in Montenegro. Mr. Milosevic already has the Serb-led Yugoslav Second Army, with more than 10,000 members, stationed there -- enough men to give Mr. Djukanovic's loyal police a fight. During the war, these soldiers tried to impose a form of martial law. They are at it again. They have taken over airports temporarily, installed television transmitters on military bases -- useful for broadcasting Mr. Milosevic's propaganda -- and muscled their way into border patrols.
Mr. Milosevic would have trouble garnering public support for a war with Montenegro, a republic ethnically similar to Serbia. He seems to be trying to provoke Mr. Djukanovic into overreacting, which could offer a pretext for a coup.
Mr. Milosevic is also undermining the economy in hopes that Mr. Djukanovic will lose public support to Mr. Milosevic's allies. Belgrade is blockading Montenegro, which is heavily dependent on Serbia for trade. And Belgrade's threats have killed Montenegro's possibilities for foreign investment and resumption of tourism.
The West essentially needs to subsidize Montenegro until Mr. Milosevic leaves power. Given the republic's size, this is not that difficult. The United States gave $55 million last year, and will supply the same amount this year. European nations have also been generous. But because Montenegro is not a country, it has not gotten desperately needed money to rebuild infrastructure or restructure industry from the World Bank and other lending institutions. They should make an exception for Montenegro, as they have done for Kosovo.
The international community opposes formal independence for Montenegro, because it could provoke Serbia and encourage further turmoil in the Balkans. But Western leaders should visit, speak about Montenegro's importance and open trade and cultural offices there. The world should begin using Montenegro's port of Bar to help supply aid to Kosovo. Unless America and its allies make clear that they still care about Montenegro, Mr. Milosevic will move to gain control of the republic.
