HEADLINE: Metro Business;
City's Jobless Rate Increased in March

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Unemployment was up in New York City and down slightly in New York State in March compared with February, according to figures released yesterday by the State Labor Department.
The city's unemployment rate was 6.4 percent in March, compared with 6.2 percent in February and 6.9 percent in March of last year. 
 The state's unemployment rate of 4.6 percent was 0.1 percentage point lower than in February. The March 1999 jobless rate was 5.2 percent.
Nationally, unemployment was 4.1 percent in March, the same rate as in February, and 0.1 percentage point lower than in March 1999.
State analysts said 157,200 private-sector jobs were created between March 1999 and March 2000, an increase of 2.3 percent. Statisticians said the 7,124,700 private-sector jobs in New York last month was a record.
The Labor Department said the strongest March-to-March jobs gains were in Dutchess County, on Long Island, in the Utica-Rome area and around Syracuse.

Steel Plant to Be Built

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The nation's second-largest steel manufacturer announced yesterday that it would build a $50 million plant in New York that would employ 300 people.
The manufacturer, Nucor Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said it would build the facility in Chemung, 37 miles west of Binghamton on the Pennsylvania border. 
 The division makes steel joists and decks used to build floors and ceilings in malls, schools, factories and other one- and two-story buildings.
Construction is expected to start this summer. The opening is planned for next year. Nucor received financial aid from the town of Chemung as well as Chemung County and New York State. The corporation has 20 plants and is the nation's largest producer of steel joists and decks.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1695 words

HEADLINE: Defending Home Turf From Attack;
Fannie Mae Is Facing Assault By House Panel and Business Rivals

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Fannie Mae, the giant company created by the government decades ago to help make mortgages available to home buyers, is no stranger to hardball politics or high-stakes finance, having established itself as a power to be reckoned with both in Washington and on Wall Street.
Shareholder owned but federally chartered, it is an odd hybrid that dominates the business of channeling money between lenders and Wall Street by buying mortgages and packaging them into securities. Its chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, is a former White House budget director whose name has been floated by Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign as a possibility for the No. 2 spot on the Democratic ticket, and its executives have close ties to both parties. 
 But the company's very size and influence have now put it in the middle of a firestorm. Together with several smaller government-chartered corporations, Fannie Mae could soon supplant the federal government as the benchmark for creditworthiness in the bond market, a possibility that has already set off emotional sparring between the company and the Treasury Department.
Treasury officials are not the only ones raising questions about Fannie Mae's special status. In recent weeks, the company has also been fighting a bitter war of words with a powerful Republican lawmaker while simultaneously fending off a lobbying assault by its biggest and best-heeled business rivals.
On one level, the fight is over whether Fannie Mae and its smaller cousin in the mortgage finance business, Freddie Mac, should continue to enjoy special benefits conferred on them by the government in the name of making home buying more affordable for low- and middle-income people. Those benefits directly or indirectly give Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac an edge in raising money at a lower cost.
Their purely private-sector competitors in the housing finance industry say the situation is unfair. Sensing that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac may be politically vulnerable, a coalition of banks, mortgage companies and trade groups has mounted a well-financed and unusually aggressive offensive in Congress seeking to limit the ability of the so-called government-sponsored enterprises, or G.S.E.'s, to use their advantages to expand into related businesses.
The coalition, called FM Watch, includes General Electric's GE Capital, Chase Manhattan, the American International Group, Wells Fargo and many financial services industry trade groups. The members fear that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are intent on using their government-provided advantages to move into businesses like financing mortgages for people with questionable credit histories, selling mortgage insurance and making loans directly to consumers.
"Our goal is to ensure that the G.S.E.'s perform their original mission, which is to provide liquidity in the secondary market, and that they do not compete unfairly in markets that private enterprise is already adequately serving," said W. Mike House, FM Watch's executive director.
Executives at Fannie Mae say they are not getting into any new lines of business but are simply making mortgages available to more people -- exactly what the government intended them to do. They derisively refer to the new group opposing them as "the coalition for higher mortgage costs," and promise to fight back against what they see as a plea from their competitors for protection.
"This is part of what I believe to be the most concerted effort I've seen in 20 years around Washington by a group of really big companies to use the political process to try and make a buck," Mr. Raines said.
But beyond the competitive tussle, there is a far-reaching public policy issue: whether Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have grown so big and deeply entrenched in the nation's financial system that their ill-defined relationship with the federal government poses the risk of a taxpayer bailout if they were to run into financial trouble.
There has been a strong political consensus that the success Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have had in making mortgages available at the lowest possible cost to millions of home buyers has far outweighed any potential risks. Now, though, both the administration and Congress seem intent on at least taking another look at the question.
"The potential benefits that G.S.E.'s bring to a particular market must be balanced, therefore, against potential risks to the financial system and potential effects on market competition," Gary Gensler, the under secretary of the Treasury for financial markets, told a Congressional subcommittee last month. "Reconsideration of this balance is appropriate from time to time and as financial conditions change."
In the financial markets, Mr. Gensler's carefully hedged words were considered a coded suggestion that the government wanted to sever its ties to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The Treasury Department backtracked a few days later, saying that its basic policy toward the companies had not changed.
But in the meantime the entire bond market was roiled, and Timothy Howard, the chief financial officer of Fannie Mae, publicly called Mr. Gensler's testimony "irresponsible," a statement that he later said he regretted.
The sharp reaction in the bond market was in large part a function of forecasts that Fannie Mae and the other such enterprises would within three years have more debt outstanding among investors and financial institutions than the United States Treasury. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are raising money to finance their rapid expansion, while the Treasury is paying down the national debt as the government runs big budget surpluses. If the surpluses continue to materialize as projected, the national debt will be paid off by 2013, meaning there would be virtually no more Treasury bonds.
Making the issue of particular interest to investors is the very real possibility that the debt securities of Fannie Mae and those other enterprises will replace the Treasury bond as the national or even worldwide benchmark for low-risk debt.
Unlike Treasury debt, the debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to help finance mortgages is not backed by the full faith and credit of the United States government. But investors have long perceived that the government has made an unwritten commitment to treat Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as too big to fail.
Although the implicit guarantee has not been tested -- and indeed is explicitly contradicted in the offering documents for the debt the companies sell -- it has nonetheless generally allowed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to borrow money at lower interest rates than any entity short of the government.
In paying less to raise money than their purely private-sector competitors in the banking, securities and housing industries, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have long had a built-in cost advantage. Based on that advantage, the companies have been able to hold down mortgage rates for home buyers -- and to enrich their own shareholders and executives.
If Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac take on the benchmark role, it would reinforce the perception among investors that the housing companies are so vital to the financial system that the government could never let them default.
In an interview, Mr. Raines of Fannie Mae suggested that the Treasury Department's expression of interest in reconsidering the benefits and potential risks of government-sponsored enterprises was motivated by a combination of ideological opposition to government support for a company operating in the capital markets and a reluctance to give up the influence it exerts in the markets as the issuer of the benchmark security. (A day later, he called back to say that he had no objection to "the legitimate role of the Treasury in asking questions about large financial institutions and what role they may play in systemic risk.")
Mr. Gensler and other Treasury officials declined to be interviewed.
It is unclear what steps, if any, Congress will pursue. But one concern receiving particular attention is the heavy dependence banks have on debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Banks are permitted to make unlimited investments in the debt securities of the enterprises, while banks can hold only limited amounts of debt issues by other companies.
Government-sponsored enterprise debt also is counted as safer than traditional corporate debt by regulators when they assess the financial strength of banks. As a result, many banks have made such debt a big part of their capital base, a situation that has left some regulators and members of Congress speculating about the implications for the financial system if Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac were to get into serious financial trouble.
Many of the issues are being raised in hearings by Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the House Banking subcommittee that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
At a Banking Committee hearing earlier this month, Mr. Baker said he was concerned about the risks that government-sponsored enterprises would pose to the financial system in an economic downturn, and he compared the companies to Long-Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund that rocked world markets when it nearly failed in 1998.
Even as he stressed that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were healthy and profitable, Mr. Baker said that to ignore "the potential impact of a misstep" by one or both of the companies "is to flirt with a potential disaster."
Should the government-sponsored housing companies continue to grow unchecked in size and influence, Mr. Baker told the hearing, the government might ultimately find itself on the hook for a bailout that would be financed out of "your constituent's wallet."
Fannie Mae quickly responded that the comparison to a high-risk hedge fund was "unfounded," and that the company exceeds all regulatory standards for financial strength.
Invoking the defense that his company has used successfully for years, David Jeffers, a spokesman for Fannie Mae, said that a proposal by Mr. Baker to tighten regulation of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac "is going nowhere because it is antihousing."

HEADLINE: Seeking to Safeguard California Mountains by Way of Congress

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.

 BODY:
Postcards from this desert resort town often feature a golfer in full swing on a lush course, driving toward a majestic mountain range in the distance.
But if the two make picturesque partners, federal officials are weighing how best to secure the future of the pristine mountainous backdrop as the demands of development and tourism increasingly encroach on the Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains. 
 President Clinton has put the mountains on the short list of areas that he would consider designating as national monuments, a move that would make them off limits for any purposes that would change their character.
The possibility alarms some landowners worried about property rights, and developers concerned that it would have an impact on projects around the base of the mountains, many of which command top dollar.
But in an effort to protect local interests as well as the mountains, Representative Mary Bono, Republican of California, has introduced a bill that would confer monument status through Congress instead.
The bill, now in the subcommittee on national parks and public lands, tries to address local concerns by assuring, for example, that no protective perimeters with restrictions on use would be created around the monument, and that management of the monument would not change as the federal government developed a comprehensive plan for the area.
"We've been very encouraged," Molly McUsic, a counselor to Bruce Babbitt, secretary of the Interior, said of the Congressional effort.
Officials hope the legislation will be more palatable than a presidential declaration. Private landowners hold about 55,000 acres within the 272,000 acres in the proposed monument area, and developers, the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians and state and local officials all have stakes to protect. The monument designation directly applies only to federal lands, about 150,000 acres.
"We're beginning at the grass roots rather than the administration coming in and saying we know what's right for you," said Rusty Payne, a spokesman for Ms. Bono. "Monument is a dirty word sometimes with Western Republicans."
On April 15, President Clinton officially designated 328,000 acres in California as a national monument to protect sequoias. It was the fifth time that Mr. Clinton had created a monument using the Antiquities Act of 1906, which allows a president to change the status of federal lands that have scientific, historical or architectural significance. He has also expanded an existing monument.
President Clinton has now protected more land in the lower 48 states using the act than any other president. All the designations have been in the West. But some lawmakers and local people have accused the president of misusing the act, which they say was intended to set aside much smaller areas, and they see his actions as heavy-handed and detrimental to local interests.
Although the steepness of the Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains makes them nearly impossible to develop in many areas, development now reaches right up to the toe in several areas and extends into the mountains in some places. Pressure to build in the area is expected to increase as the Coachella Valley, which includes the desert towns of the region, grows to an estimated 475,000 residents from about 317,000 in the next 20 years.
The mountains are used in a variety of ways, including cattle grazing, sightseeing and recreation. They are also home to endangered bighorn sheep.
Private property owners are said to be evenly divided over the designation.
"The people who are against the monument or are worried about it are concerned about intrusion on property rights," said Ruth Watling, who is chairwoman of the Pinyon Community Council, an advisory group for the property owners.
Those supporting it are worried about intrusion from the increasing number of day-trippers and tourists who visit for hiking, hunting, horseback riding or off-road vehicle use.
The habitat in the area is quite fragile. Ms. Watling noted that it dated back as far as 12,000 years, when it was tall pines. Now it is home to pinyons and junipers, which will not regenerate themselves.
"It's really rare to see a seedling pine," she said. "Kind of horrifying and intriguing to watch."
Although much of the land is already held by state and federal governments, traditionally there has been little financing for management and conservation. Bill Havert, executive director of the Coachella Valley Mountains Conservancy, which has pushed for monument status, said such a designation would not only raise the mountains' profile, but would help to secure increased federal financing to buy private land in the area.
"We're not ultimately looking for the national monument designation to protect all lands from development," Mr. Havert said. "We're looking for the designation to at least maintain, if not enhance, Congress's willingness to fund acquisitions from willing sellers."
But private landowners and others who have interests at stake say they do not believe there is any need for the designation. Instead, they see it as a federal land grab, which will result in access restrictions and loss of property tax revenue.
"We already have protective measures," said Larry Paul, president of the Mountain Coalition, which represents private interests opposed to the designation.
"I'm all for protecting the environment," Mr. Paul said, "but we have everything to lose, and I don't see anything to gain. All that's going to happen is the limiting of uses we already enjoy."
Addressing such concerns was the purpose of Ms. Bono's bill, said Mr. Payne, her spokesman.
"Economic development is very important," he said, "but so is reasonable land management and environmental policy that preserves and protects. We are running out of land in America and Southern California, and we are leaving nothing behind for future generations."

HEADLINE: George Moore, 95, Ex-Banker Who Led Metropolitan Opera

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
George S. Moore, a banker who led the overseas expansion of what became Citibank and steered the Metropolitan Opera through turbulent financial times, died yesterday at his home in Sotograde, Spain. He was 95.
Mr. Moore, who eventually rose to become chairman of First National City Bank of New York (now known as Citibank) was born on April 1, 1905, in Hannibal, Mo., to a family of moderate circumstances. His father was a claims inspector for the Burlington & Quincy Railroad. 
 From early on he established himself as an energetic young man. During summers in St. Louis, were he grew up, Mr. Moore earned extra money selling honey and delivering orders for a delicatessen.
Later, he helped put himself through Yale by booking tours to Europe and tickets to Broadway shows for classmates.
After joining the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company in 1927, which eventually merged with First National City, Mr. Moore rose swiftly to positions of power.
Colleagues described him as a determined salesman who thought that more than five hours of sleep a night was a waste.
Mr. Moore is credited with moving aggressively to expand the bank's reach in whatever department he ran. As head of the bank's domestic division in 1957, Mr. Moore pushed for the bank's entry into real estate lending and expanded consumer loans.
Later as the head of First National City's overseas division, he set up new branches in countries across Europe and Latin America. The Latin American branches, while successful during his tenure, later caused the bank headaches as economies in the region collapsed.
But the legacy that Mr. Moore was most proud of, according to his son, George Moore of New Canaan, Conn., was transforming the caliber of the institution's workers.
When Mr. Moore joined banking, it was still a closed, conservative society staffed largely by the scions of old-line moneyed families like the Stillmans and the Rockefellers. Mr. Moore aimed to replace what he perceived to be indolent family heirs with motivated graduates of business schools.
The claims inspector's son took some pride in being a tough guy who could fire incompetent underlings.
"He was fanatical about finding top talent and inventorying people with high I.Q.'s," said Phillip L. Zweig, who interviewed Mr. Moore at length for a book on Walter B. Wriston, Mr. Moore's hand-picked Citibank successor. "But he was lightening in a bottle and did not suffer fools lightly."
Mr. Moore became president of the Metropolitan Opera Association in 1967. It was a troubled financial time in the opera's history, as the recent move to its Lincoln Center home had emptied the coffers.
Mr. Moore was determined to run the opera like a business and insisted that creative operations meet budgets. Under his tenure, the opera raised the price of tickets several times and postponed opening the season to trim costs. In 1973, the Met even canceled a scheduled production of "Don Giovanni" as well as free summer concerts that were to be held in Central Park.
Mr. Moore retired from First National City in 1970, but he continued to work long energetic days until he was almost 90.
Among his responsibilities was being the sole trustee for the Onassis family interests in the United States and being a financial consultant to numerous United States and foreign corporations.
He also kept a full social and philanthropic calendar. In his autobiography "The Banker's Life," (W. W. Norton & Company, 1986), he included among his friends Senator Jacob K. Javits, opera singer Maria Callas and the auto-fortune heir Henry Ford II.
In addition to his son by his first marriage, Mr. Moore is survived by his second wife, Charon C. Moore; their three children, daughters Christina Sendagorta and Maria Pia and a son, Steven C. Moore, all of Madrid; five grandchildren; and a great-grandson.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Insurer Fighting Microsoft Over Claims

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Microsoft's primary insurer wants to bar the company from claiming coverage for the cost of defending a barrage of private antitrust lawsuits.
In a suit filed last month in Federal District Court in Washington, Zurich American Insurance, a unit of Zurich Allied of Switzerland, asked a judge to declare that its general liability policy does not cover the legal expenses caused by Microsoft's antitrust woes. 
 Microsoft already has started submitting insurance claims for the cost of defending about 140 private suits. The suits seek to take advantage of a federal judge's ruling in the government's antitrust case that Microsoft illegally protected its Windows computer operating system monopoly from competition.
"Microsoft is trying to shift the economic consequences of its allegedly anticompetitive conduct onto its liability insurers," said Zurich American's lawyer, Thomas W. Brunner. He added that the antitrust claims were far removed from the intended coverage under the policy.
With high-priced law firms like Sullivan & Cromwell and Sidley & Austin representing Microsoft, the company's legal bills could easily reach tens of millions of dollars. And if the policy applies, Zurich American might also have to pay up to $4 million to cover any judgments against Microsoft, Mr. Brunner said.
Microsoft said its legal expenses fell under its policy.

HEADLINE: Lawyer Auction in an Auction Suit

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
For two months the federal judge presiding over mountains of litigation against the auction giants Sotheby's and Christie's knew that he faced a thorny problem: how to select the lawyers from at least 25 firms across the country to lead the growing class-action suit charging the two houses with price-fixing.
Yesterday he came up with an answer. Hold an auction. 
 Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan issued a court order yesterday in which he invited all the lawyers representing the approximately 40 plaintiffs so far to submit secret bids by May 12 to determine who will manage the plaintiff's case, a prize that could be worth millions. The judge appointed an interim team of six lead lawyers on Feb. 2.
The bids are to list a maximum amount of recovered money that the lawyers would be willing to see go entirely to the plaintiffs. For any recovery beyond that, the lawyers are to list a fee that they would take in full. If the recovery exceeds the sum of both of these, the lawyers would get one-quarter of the additional amount with the rest going to their clients.
Thus, experts said, the lawyers have an incentive to offer a maximum financial recovery to their clients at a minimal legal fee. If the recovery is exceptionally large, the lawyers would make much more.
The judge's innovation, experts said, was the formula that increases legal fees as the recovery increases.
They said that the plan relied on the kind of free-market competition that Sotheby's and Christie's are accused of subverting by colluding on fees and commissions charged to buyers and sellers since 1993. The houses are also being investigated by Federal antitrust prosecutors.
The judge did not promise to select the low bidder but "which bidder is likely best to serve the interests of any class that may be certified, taking into account the economic terms of bids as well as qualifications."
Such bargaining to limit lawyers fees in class-action suits has occurred in several previous cases, but Judge Kaplan wrote that his bidding process "never has been used as far as the court is aware."
He invited comments from the interim lead lawyers, who are likely to argue against changing lawyers now, and even from outsiders, and he said that if the plan drew significant opposition he might scrap it.
But Andrew K. Niebler, a Washington lawyer whom the judge cited as an expert on lead counsel auctions, applauded the new formula. "This is really an important advance for better aligning the interests of the class members and plaintiffs' class counsel," he said in an interview.
The formula also won high marks from at least one plaintiff's lawyer who had been prepared to drop out of the case, feeling, as he said, that "other guys carved it up."
Asked late yesterday if he had heard of the order, that lawyer, Stephen Susman of Houston, said, "No, but I love it."
"This is the way judges ought to do it," he said. "Pick the lawyers who offer the most reasonable deal to the class." Now, he said, "we'll definitely be back in."
The six interim lead lawyers have not responded to calls. They are Frederick P. Furth, Stanley M. Grossman, Michael D. Hausfeld, Robert N. Kaplan, Christopher Lovell and Robert A. Skirnick.
In another decision yesterday, the judge rejected Christie's contention that there was no basis for the lawsuit and commented, "Certainly the interim lead counsel and their clients are capable of pursuing the litigation in an appropriate manner."
One effect of the formula, the experts said, is to reduce the attractiveness to the plaintiffs' lawyers of a quick settlement, for which they might ordinarily do little work but get a big fee.
There are no set fees in class-action cases. Judges commonly award lawyers 10 to 30 percent, but the lawyers do not know the amount going in, creating uncertainties for lawyers and clients alike.
In class-action suits, where many plaintiffs sue collectively, lawyers often designate the lead members themselves and the judge approves them. Lead counsels shoulder the bulk of the work and also commonly reap the largest fees.
Judge Kaplan assured the lawyers that if he decided not to go ahead with his bidding formula, he would not reveal the bids. He also ordered them not to discuss their positions among themselves or try to rig their bids.

HEADLINE: White House Aides Criticize Republican Drug Proposal

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The White House has sharply criticized the House Republican proposal for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, saying it "seems like a Swiss cheese plan with more holes than substance."
President Clinton's economic policy adviser, Gene Sperling, and his health policy coordinator, Chris Jennings, said on Thursday that they were frustrated by the lack of specifics in the Republican plan and disliked the details that they did know. 
 But White House officials insisted that they wanted to work with Republicans in Congress to pass legislation adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare, the health insurance program for 39 million people who are elderly or disabled.
The House Republican plan, outlined last week, would use private insurance subsidized by the government to help pay prescription drug costs for people treated outside hospitals.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, in contrast, drug coverage would become a standard part of the Medicare benefits package, available to anyone willing to pay an extra premium, and the government would bear most of the financial risk.
At a White House briefing on Thursday and in interviews today, White House officials appeared to be sending two messages.
First, they said, the House Republican plan is flawed. Second, they still want to work out a compromise on the issue, which will figure prominently in the presidential campaign and in many Congressional races this year.
When asked to describe their strategy in passing the legislation, Mr. Sperling and Mr. Jennings said they had pinned their hopes on the Senate Finance Committee, where members of the two parties have a history of working together. The committee has held several hearings on Mr. Clinton's plan and on drug benefits in general.
Under the Republican plan, Mr. Jennings said, there is no guarantee that private insurers will offer affordable drug coverage in all parts of the country.
"We don't know what provision of the proposal assures that all, most or even any Medicare beneficiaries will have access to the new drug benefit," Mr. Jennings said.
The House Republicans are fleshing out their proposal, drafting legislation based on cost estimates they had received from the Congressional Budget Office.
John P. Feehery, a spokesman for J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, said: "White House officials are shooting in the dark. They want to turn this into a political issue. If they would try to work with us instead of just shooting at us, we might be able to get something done."
Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services, said, "The silver lining of the Republicans' prescription drug plan is that they finally came up with one, though it's two pages."
In a similar vein, Mr. Sperling said, "What we have now from the Republicans is a two-page document which has more questions than answers, and to us, it still seems like a Swiss cheese plan with more holes than substance."
The administration also said the financial outlook for Medicare was brighter than previously thought.
Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund will be solvent until 2025, two years later than previously projected, Dr. Shalala said. A report issued on March 30 by trustees of the Medicare program said the trust fund would be exhausted in 2023.
The two-year difference can be explained by a computer programming error, officials said. Because of the error, the government underestimated the interest that would be earned for the trust fund. The assets of the trust fund, beyond the amounts needed to pay benefits and other expenses, are invested in special government securities.
Richard S. Foster, chief actuary of the Medicare program, said the amount of the underestimate, $2.1 billion this year, would increase gradually to $20 billion a year by 2015.
Many liberal Democrats have questioned the sincerity of House Republicans, suggesting that they are drafting a prescription drug plan to provide political cover in this fall's elections.
But Mr. Sperling said he would not challenge the Republicans' motives.
"The best thing for us right now is not to try to read their minds, or read their motivations," Mr. Sperling said, "but, for the good of the country, to take seriously any suggestion someone makes that they are sincere and trying to work together with us."
The best way to respond to the Republicans, he said, is "by giving them the benefit of the doubt and taking them at their word that they want to work together."

HEADLINE: The Earth Day Challenge

 BODY:
Today, on the 30th anniversary of the first Earth Day, there is much to celebrate and much to remind us of the unfinished business of protecting the planet. While the job of cleaning the water, air and land continues, the world must begin tackling the less visible threat of global warming, an issue largely unknown 30 years ago. This new threat is less immediate and less easily solved, and therefore will require an even stronger commitment in the years ahead. This is essentially the message of the organizers of Earth Day 2000.
In 1970, some American rivers were so polluted with chemicals that they were fire hazards. Big cities were choked in smog, toxic wastes leached freely into the land, and bird and fish species were disappearing. In a generation's time, with the creation of the National Environmental Policy Act, the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, the Endangered Species Act and the Environmental Protection Agency, a great deal has been achieved to reverse decades of environmental degradation. 
 This shift was propelled by citizen activists and a handful of political leaders who first gave voice to a broadening ethic that made protecting the environment a political as well as moral obligation.
The same public passion and political will must now be summoned to confront the global greenhouse effect. Congress has given little attention to this issue. For that reason, the Earth Day organizers have done a public service by making global warming a focus of this year's program.
Unlike polluted air and contaminated water, global warming is not a local problem that can be seen or felt. But its impact on every region on earth could be devastating. Most scientists agree that the earth's climate is warming, due at least partly to the accumulation of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide that trap the sun's energy. Although the effect may be gradual, the consequences could be catastrophic, with increased floods and droughts, rising sea levels and destruction of ecosystems caused by climate change.
In 1997 more than 150 nations, including the United States, signed the Kyoto Protocol to limit the amount of greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere through the burning of fossil fuels. The agreement calls for industrialized nations to cut their emissions by 2010. But few nations have moved to carry out the agreement. The United States is the largest greenhouse gas emitter, but the Senate is opposed to ratification of the Kyoto agreement and the policies needed to carry it out.
Curbing these gases requires intensive energy conservation and the promotion of cleaner energy sources such as solar and wind power. The political and economic hurdles are substantial, both in this country and abroad. They can be overcome if the public is educated about the importance of this issue. The 30-year history of the Earth Day movement shows that when people are awakened to an environmental crisis, they will ultimately demand change in the way we live.

HEADLINE: Adding Arias to the Three R's;
Brooklyn School Uses Opera to Stimulate Young Minds

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Four fifth-grade girls from Public School 314 escaped class one recent afternoon in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, not to buy sweets at the corner bodega, or to swap secrets over blush in the bathroom, but to slip into a music room to work on their opera, a three-act (six-page) work involving a popular girl, a class clown and a meteorite blazing toward Earth.
By now, the four girls, who have been learning about "Tosca" and "Aida" since kindergarten and attending performances at the Metropolitan Opera since third grade, can bat around opera terms like aficionados. So as a group of second graders sang slightly discordant scales in the back of the music room -- which housed computers nicknamed Verdi, Rossini and Puccini -- 10-year-old Kristina Maisonet buoyantly described her original work, using an obscure term unfamiliar to even many opera lovers. 
 "This is really an opera seria, not an opera," Kristina said, explaining that an opera seria is chock-full of arias and short on recitative, or sung dialogue.
Neither Kristina nor many of her classmates come from homes where parents and grandparents listen to opera as daily background music. More than three-quarters of the 1,918 students at P.S. 314, also known as the Luis Munoz Marin Elementary School, are Latin American and Caribbean, and the second largest ethnic group in the school is Chinese.
But in 1992, Vincent Grippo, the superintendent of Community School District 20, started weaving opera into the fabric of the school, inspired by a teacher who wanted to shape her classes around an opera motif. And he says it has set off a remarkable transformation.
In 1989, the state education commissioner included P.S. 314 on a list of the 43 most academically troubled public schools in the state. While it is still not a high-ranking school, P.S. 314 finished 408th out of the city's 677 public elementary schools in reading achievement for 1999 and has escaped the list of failing schools.
"One of my expressions is, 'If it's good enough for the rich, why don't we try it on the poor?' " Mr. Grippo said. "It's art for art's sake, but beyond that, it creates self-esteem and a full human being. One of the reasons it works is because we're taking poor immigrant children and exposing them to a whole world of creativity and beauty."
On any given day, a group of kindergartners might be practicing screechy Suzuki violin; second graders might be rehearsing "Mikey's Dream," a 25-minute opera that they wrote and produced; a group of fourth graders might be working on an interactive CD-ROM about "The Queen of Spades," responding to a performance they had just seen at the Met.
The Metropolitan Opera Guild says the school employs the only full-time opera teacher in the New York City school system. The teacher, Mary Jo Lassen, tells students about the history of the form, helps them read and study Italian and French librettos with the help of translations, and has them memorize and sing transliterated arias. In the fifth grade, students can join an opera club to attend early rehearsals at the Met with Ms. Lassen.
They meet stars like Placido Domingo, write their own works in English and sometimes translate them and perform them in other languages. (Boys seem just as interested as girls, said Ms. Lassen, noting that last year most students in the opera club were boys.) Earlier this year, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade visited the school.
The children seem enchanted by the broad characters, the music and the mythic conflicts in opera, and seem unaware of how unusual their knowledge is.
"My sister's friends never went to an opera," Kristina said, slightly aghast. "When I was in third grade, the first time I went to the Met I thought I would get lost because it's so huge. Now we've met everybody. We pretty much know all the ushers."
In a hushed voice, her friend, Lauren Rius, 10, confessed to an apparent sin: "Before Ms. Lassen taught us, I had never even heard of Placido Domingo."
P.S. 314 still has its troubles. Measured against other public elementary schools in New York with students who have similar economic and social backgrounds, P.S. 314 performs about average on English tests, according to the most recent assessment by the New York City Board of Education. Last year, 41.2 percent of the students were reading at or above grade level. Still, Mr. Grippo said children studying the performing arts benefit in ways that cannot be measured on standardized tests.
Although students from 207 city schools sometimes attend opera through the Metropolitan Opera Guild, no other public school in New York offers as comprehensive an opera program as P.S. 314, said David A. Dik, director of education for the guild, the nonprofit educational arm of the Metropolitan Opera Association.
The program is financed through the Annenberg Foundation and a city arts fund called Project Arts. Elements of P.S. 314's program have been copied in about 20 of the district's 30 schools, although few have the same kind of financial support, Teachers at P.S. 314 say that its program improves their students' academic drive and helps them learn a wide range of basic skills.
"Each child in the class got a script, each child got to read with the other children, and along with their lines, they learned plot and structure," said Regina M. Gangi, a teacher whose second graders recently wrote and performed a 25-minute opera. "The other kids came along with math by building the sets, doing the electrical work, and that all has to do a lot with figuring out equations. It's a different way of having the children open up their minds."
By writing their own works in the music room (after school, during lunch break, and occasionally during class), the students seem to have gained insights into opera's appeal.
"You have to make it very juicy," Kristina said.
Her friend, Lauren, added, "You have to have a big climax, not something that happens every day."
The girls giddily narrated the plot of their work, "Friends to the End," to a visitor, their eyes beaming, voices overlapping.
"There's a popular girl and a boy who's like the class clown, and he becomes more popular than she is and so she gets jealous," Kristina said.
Amanda Colon, 11, continued. "So she shoves pills in his mouth and -- she doesn't want to kill him; she just wants to hurt him."
Lauren broke in, "There's a meteorite coming and the world is going to end, but then it's just a little rock."
But Tiffany Cortes, 10, with a coy smile, insisted that the ending was still under discussion.
Lauren conceded, "It's supposed to be a comedy, but we might make the world end anyway." Her eyes darted toward Ms. Lassen for confirmation.
Ms. Lassen is the force behind P.S. 314's devotion to opera. Twenty-two years ago, when she was a fifth-grade teacher and the school's music program was faltering because of budget cuts, she took a teacher training class from the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Later, she tried to introduce her class to "Rigoletto."
"I had one libretto and an audio tape of an opera performance," she recalled. "I read it out loud to the students. How boring!"
Ms. Lassen decided to give her students a more active role in their opera lessons, and eight years ago she requested permission to devote her attention to teaching opera to students in all grades.
Christina C. Cortes, the interim vice principal of P.S. 314, said that when she first saw Ms. Lassen's students sewing period costumes for a show, she was instantly intrigued.
"She was very focused on the elements of story, on narrative, setting, time, problem solving, solutions," Ms. Cortes said. "So it was a direct carry-over to their developmental learning in reading."
This year, second-grade students were asked to write and produce their own opera, which eventually became "Mikey's Dream." Last fall, two second-grade teachers, Mrs. Gangi and Laura Garzaniti, attended half a dozen daylong workshops arranged by the opera guild. Their students auditioned for various roles and responsibilities for "Mikey's Dream," from acting and writing to set design and public relations work.
At the end of March, members of the newly formed Star Opera Company, a group of about three dozen seven- and eight-year olds, performed "Mikey's Dream" four times, once for their parents and three times for a rapt audience of peers, many of whom sang along from their seats.
The work is about a little boy who cannot go out to play because his room is a mess and he has not finished his homework.
"I wish I had a servant," laments the protagonist, Mikey, played by Juan Carlos Martinez, 7. "I have one dollar. Maybe I can buy a servant."
He falls asleep and has a nightmare in which all his friends are fighting; but when he awakes, they are in his room, offering to help him clean up.
In his final aria, Mikey sings, "I am so lucky I have good friends."
During the third performance, one of five large set pieces started to crack, and the students, alone backstage between scenes, had to figure out what to do. One boy from Mrs. Gangi's class decided to stand behind the piece and hold it up throughout the scene, saving the show.
"It's really weird to think of a second grader figuring out that if he stood there behind it no one would see him," Mrs. Gangi said. The boy had been very unmotivated, she said. "He never used to have his homework done. But since this, he's been coming in and doing his work."
During a post-production discussion, some students even showed precocious signs of the kind of self-possession that sets the opera greats apart. Reflecting on her achievement, Melinda Lopez, 8, who played the leading female role, Ashley, dabbed her brashly colored eyelids like a true diva.
"The best thing is when you grow up, you can remember about this," she said. "And you can be a singer and you won't be shy."
 
Mikey's Aria
 
 CHORUS
 My life is not fair.
 I can't go out and play.
 I have to do my homework.
 I am stuck in my room all day.
 VERSES
 I have to clean my room.
 It's such a disgusting mess.
 My clothes are thrown all
 over the place.
 Where do I begin?
 My science project is due tomorrow.
 I haven't even read the book.
 If I don't finish my homework,
 My teacher will hang me like a hook.
 In my life I have so many problems
 I don't know what to do.
 I need lots of help,
 Maybe a friend or two.
 
 This aria, from Mikey's Dream," was written by Araceli Gomez, Stephanie Romo, Paola Contreras and Emmanuel Castillo. The music was composed by Angel Berrios, Mohammed Sakhl and Malik Jones.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Hey, Hey, Hey, Save My Caffe Latte!

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
After finding a community among anarchist squatters on the Lower East Side, Sascha Scatter decided to forgo college and became obsessed with riding freight trains. . . . His zines combine adventure-travel tales with thoughtful observations about the global economy. In Seattle he was tear-gassed seven times. His mission in D.C.: Guerrilla gardening -- activists planted trees, vegetables, and flowers on abandoned lots and lawns. His point: self-sufficiency. As Scatter sees it, there's plenty of food -- it just doesn't get to the people who need it.
-- From a Village Voice profile of heroic young New Yorkers at this week's economic protests in Washington. 
 More excerpts from a book that will not be written by Tom Brokaw, "The Most Excellent Generation":
As Justin prepared to ship out to Washington, resting in his family's apartment on the Upper West Side, he couldn't shake the ghosts of Seattle. It was always the same flashback: the shattering window at Starbucks, the cops in Darth Vader helmets, the last glimpse of Alex being led away in handcuffs. Why Alex and not him? Why hadn't he saved his buddy?
He sought comfort from his grandfather. "Survivor guilt?" the old man said. "Over a $50 summons? If you'd been with me on the beach in Normandy I could understand, but . . ."
His father was no help either. Dad just yapped about his protests at Columbia against some war. "My friends were getting shot up in rice paddies," Dad said. "What exactly are you protesting?"
"The Indonesian sweatshop that made your shirt," Justin said, but it was useless to explain globalization. They'd never faced such a devious enemy. It could sneak up on you anywhere -- in your sneakers, on your khakis, in your nose ring.
Was it safe to enter a chat room on economic self-sufficiency using a Japanese laptop made in Mexico? Had Alex's Nokia cell phone, like, betrayed him for marching against free trade? Should Justin have lent him the Motorola? The ghosts raged on.
Samantha hated the house in East Hampton, but there was no better pre-protest training camp for a guerrilla gardener. Her parents' housekeeper, Consuela, helped her plant the organic maize and jicama. Samantha tried explaining to Consuela, who had grown up on a farm outside Caracas, the concept of "sustainable agriculture."
"No chemicales," Samantha said. "No factoria farms. Todo naturale. No supermarket plastico."
"No supermarket?" Consuela asked.
"We fight for the farm de familia," Samantha said.
Consuela looked at her warily. "The farm of my family? You want to go there? I prefer the supermarket."
When the protests began in Washington, Ted's elite Whatever Unit was still struggling with the marchers' greatest challenge: inventing a chant that rhymed with "International Monetary Fund." It was even tougher than the World Trade Organization in Seattle. Ted had needed only 28 hours to come up with "Hell no, W.T.O.! We don't want your globe B.O." But I.M.F? But after 60 sleepless hours their nerves were as frayed as the pages of their rhyming dictionaries. The best they'd come up with was "I.M.F.! You are deaf!"
Then, as a group of marchers passed in front of a Gap and a giant chain drugstore, it suddenly came to Ted. "Flanking maneuver!" he screamed, and phoned his inspiration to squadron leaders. Within seconds the streets erupted: "One, two, three, four! We don't want your discount store! Full price! Full price! We all pay more!" Ted held his breath for what seemed an eternity. Then the chant started again. The line had held! Ted wept.
Justin looked up in disbelief. Today was his hope for redemption, but what was falling from the sky? Water! Squadron leaders tried a new chant -- "Rain, rain, go away" -- but their troops were fleeing. Samantha was almost trampled by a guerrilla gardener rushing to make his freight train.
"This is a suicide mission without Gore-Tex," Justin shouted. Alex wanted to press on, but Justin and Samantha dragged him into cover inside a Starbucks. Alex refused to accept defeat quietly. "The world is counting on our generation," he said, reaching into his day pack for a brick.
"Hello! Don't break the window until the rain stops," Samantha implored.
"At least let me finish my latte," Justin said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC PLAN;
Gore's Campaign, Confident on the Issues, Still Struggles With His Image

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ROMULUS, Mich., April 21

 BODY:
George W. Bush may be portraying himself as an unconventional Republican, but Al Gore plans to portray him as really unconventional.
Even as Governor Bush tries to move to the political center, the vice president is trying to define him as extreme. It is all part of a newly emerging strategy for Mr. Gore as he moves into what his advisers call the "compare and contrast" phase of the presidential campaign: compare his proposals with Mr. Bush's and then "contrast" them. 
 Translation: Mr. Gore rips his rival's proposals to shreds and presents his own as reasonable alternatives.
At the same time, Mr. Gore has his own careful balancing act to perform. While hammering Mr. Bush on policy matters, he is still struggling to overcome a problem that has dogged him since early in the campaign: how to demonstrate that he has a warm and human side, a passion for the presidency and ideals that are not tossed by political winds.
The effort to warm up his image is guiding much of the Gore campaign's planning in this stretched-out period until the party conventions this summer. Indeed, that effort is why he will be spending full days in schools, staying overnight with families and visiting them in their workplaces (yes, in earth-tone casual attire). The idea is to show him to be just an ordinary person who is both engaged and engaging.
Not that the issues, and the vice president's effort to depict Mr. Bush's positions as extreme, will be by any means ignored. The other day, addressing gun control, Mr. Gore said the governor's signing legislation allowing Texans to carry firearms into churches demonstrated how beholden he was to the National Rifle Association.
Today, at a news conference here in Michigan, the issue was the environment. Mr. Gore said that "Governor Bush seems to have the smug assumption that he can get away with calling himself an environmentalist," when Texas is "the worst-polluted state in the country."
Mr. Gore plans additional speeches in the next couple of weeks focusing on other differences with Mr. Bush, starting with the governor's proposal for a big tax cut, what the vice president calls a "risky tax scheme." That theme will be hammered relentlessly by the Gore campaign till November.
"People haven't noticed it yet," said Bob Shrum, a top Gore adviser, "but I assure you, they will: that George W. Bush doesn't have any money to pay for his tax cut or the programs he's proposing. By giving in to the right wing on the tax cut and proposing a tax giveaway for rich people, he has disabled himself."
Further, while it may seem that Mr. Bush is the one dominating the news lately with one fresh proposal after another, Gore aides express confidence that with major policy positions already laid out by the vice president, he is now well positioned to counter any public infatuation with his rival, much as he did in the primary campaign against former Senator Bill Bradley.
One central issue that should benefit the vice president is the economy. While he has distanced himself from President Clinton in several areas, he has of course fully embraced the robust Clinton-era economy. The Clinton economic record has been so successful that the voters, who once favored Republicans as stewards of the economy, now say they more trust the Democrats in that role.
Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant not affiliated with the Gore campaign, said this amounted to a sea change that should work to the vice president's advantage. "You could never convince voters that a Republican is more fiscally irresponsible than a Democrat," she said. "That's changed."
But while crediting Mr. Gore with positioning himself to benefit on issues, Ms. Gorlin, like others, said he had still not made voters comfortable with him as a person.
"He acts like he's someone who's too scared of losing," she said. "He thinks the answer lies in a rational process."
After nearly a quarter-century in public office and nearly a year formally on the presidential campaign trail, Mr. Gore remains a remote and distant figure, according to independent polls as well as his own advisers. Changing that perception, his aides say, is his most important mission.
"His biggest asset is that he came out of the nominating process strengthened rather than weakened, and we still have a good economy and we can say we're better positioned to keep things going," one top adviser said. "His weakness is his ability to connect. George Bush is a likable guy."
Mr. Gore's problem is virtually the opposite of Mr. Bush's. The governor is bulking up on policy statements with a Democratic tilt to compensate for the perception that, though likable, he is a policy lightweight who veered too far to the right during the primaries. Mr. Gore has to convince voters of his human side, of his understanding how ordinary people feel, and also that he has lasting principles that make him more than a mere political tactician.
"His biggest problem is that he needs to find himself," said another Democratic strategist not affiliated with the campaign. "The biggest thing that voters perceive is that he doesn't have a North Star."
That perception has been evident to Gore advisers, and to the candidate himself, since the fall, when they began a concerted effort to strip him of the trappings of the vice presidency and place him in settings where he could appear unscripted and have a chance to interact with people. The goal, then as now, was to cultivate an aura of humanity that still eludes him.
"For whatever reason, he doesn't project that warmth, that strength of his personality," said one supporter, Elizabeth Bagley, former ambassador to Portugal. "When people see him on a one-on-one level in a personal, intimate setting, then they realize he's a warm, caring person. He's become very good at town meetings. He likes them and gets positive feedback from them. What he started doing on the campaign, once Bradley became a threat, has really helped him."
In a continuation of the town meetings that Mr. Gore held as a congressman from Tennessee and renewed in the primaries, his campaign is putting him in settings that scream ordinary American life: schools, homes and workplaces. The idea is that once people see him on a human scale, they will perceive him as, well, more human.
"The stalwart vice president in a blue suit standing behind the podium -- that is still the view that prevails in most states," a Gore insider said. "We have to put him in settings where that's not the case."
His advisers think those settings allow him to demonstrate his assets: not just the breadth and depth of his command of policy, but personal assets too, like a willingness to open himself up to spontaneous situations and his hunger for the job of president.
This is essentially a national retail strategy, in which Mr. Gore is trying to win voters over one by one. "The lessons of Iowa and New Hampshire are clear -- the more people see him, the more they like him," said Chris Lehane, his press secretary.
This means not only campaigning exhaustively but also pushing the Gore story -- and the anti-Bush message -- through advertising.
"Both campaigns will be able to run Iowa- and New Hampshire-like campaigns, with real advertising budgets," a senior adviser said. "We will be able to really introduce the candidate and tell a story that has a beginning, a middle and an end."
Mr. Gore plans to visit a school at least once every two weeks. He spent two full days in schools last week, one in Ohio, one in North Carolina, staying with families overnight. The visits generated positive local news coverage while showing the vice president involved with real people on education, a topic of major concern to voters.
The Gore campaign is also preparing for a more concerted challenge from Mr. Bush than it received from Mr. Bradley. One theme that Mr. Bradley arrived at belatedly and expressed only sporadically is one that Mr. Bush has already begun to exploit: that Mr. Gore changes his positions with the political winds and so cannot be trusted.
As if it were a company logo, Bush press releases are stamped with perhaps the single most damaging sentence that Mr. Bradley spoke to Mr. Gore during the primaries: "Why should we believe that you will tell the truth as president if you don't tell the truth as a candidate?" The real issue, Mr. Bradley said, was one of credibility.
Mr. Bradley posed that question during a New Hampshire debate, after Mr. Gore, who early in his career opposed federal financing of abortion, maintained that he had always been consistent in supporting abortion rights.
The Gore campaign clearly perceives credibility to be a matter on which it is vulnerable and, taking a page from the Clinton playbook, is trying to turn the issue against Mr. Bush. In a virtual echo of Mr. Bradley's question, the vice president recently told a gathering of newspaper editors: "How can we believe what he says he would do nationally when we see what he actually has done as governor? This is about something more than public policy. It is about credibility."
That tack is only a slight detour from the larger message that the campaign has been delivering: that Mr. Gore has the experience to be president, while Mr. Bush would be too much of a risk. It will be countered by an equally simple message from Austin: that Mr. Gore cannot be trusted, while Mr. Bush would restore honor and integrity to the White House.

HEADLINE: Firms Going Casual Help Job Seekers Suit Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT WORTH 

 BODY:
As New York's major law firms, banks and consulting firms shift to a casual dress code, the question arises: what are they doing with all those suits?
The answer is they are giving them to job seekers, some of whom may soon be better dressed than the city's power elite. Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, which recently became the first major Wall Street law firm to go casual full time, asked all its lawyers and staff members to donate a suit or other business attire and collected more than 500 clothing items, including scores of costly suits. Other major companies have organized suit drives recently, including American Express, Goldman Sachs, PaineWebber, McKinsey and McGraw-Hill. 
 Last week, the managing partner of Cadwalader, Robert O. Link Jr., helped carry the firm's donated suits out to a delivery truck. Mr. Link, who donated two dark pinstripes, a Hugo Boss and a Burberry, said he was happy to see them go. "It's more comfortable," he said of the muted green shirt, chinos and blazer he was wearing.
Less than 24 hours later, Claudio Young, a 24-year-old unemployed man from Washington Heights, was trying on a dark Paul Stuart pinstripe suit that had been donated by a Cadwalader employee, along with a Brooks Brothers shirt, a yellow silk tie and black wingtips. "I'm not a suit guy; I'm a hip-hop guy," he said. In fact, he said he had never worn a suit or a tie before. His usual outfit consists of baggy jeans -- Mecca and Sean John are his favorite brands -- Timberland boots, a basketball jersey and a baseball cap.
Mr. Young received his suit in a Midtown warehouse belonging to Career Gear, a nonprofit organization that works with low-income men to give them the clothes they need for interviews and jobs.
Like many other Career Gear clients, Mr. Young has had his share of troubles. After dropping out of school, he developed a drug habit, and was arrested in August 1997 for selling cocaine to an undercover agent. But he completed a treatment program, earned his general equivalency diploma, and after three months of job training, wound up at Career Gear.
And like most of the men who show up at Career Gear's basement warehouse near Madison Square Garden, Mr. Young was uneasy about his new clothes at first. Few of the men who come here know how to tie a necktie, and some find the suits uncomfortable. "I had one guy with a scar from ear to ear, a former gang guy," said Connie von Tobel, a volunteer at Career Gear. "He didn't want anything tight around the neck."
Mr. Young will soon have his first job interview. "I want to pay taxes, you know, real taxes," he said. He hopes to find a position as a photocopy machine technician.
Is it possible that he will feel a little overdressed for his interview? Gary Field, Career Gear's founder, said: "I don't think so. What's more important is the way it makes them feel."
Alexander Pryor, a former hotel worker, put on a Brooks Brothers suit after going through addiction and job-training programs, and now has a job with the New York Center for Addiction Treatment Services. "It boosts your confidence," he said.
Mr. Field, a social worker who has had his own struggles with unemployment and addiction, founded Career Gear last year. He had worked briefly at a law firm where female lawyers donated business clothing to Dress for Success, which works only with women and has been in business for three and a half years. "The male attorneys kept asking why they couldn't donate suits," he said.
Both Mr. Field and Arlene Wallace of Dress for Success said the shift to casual dress among New York companies had been a tremendous windfall for them. Career Gear has received about 2,000 suits over the last year. Dress for Success's New York affiliate has received 8,000 to 10,000 pieces of business clothing in the last three weeks, most of them suits, said Ms. Wallace, the organization's associate director. Both groups have also received hefty donations from designers, including Brooks Brothers, Polo and Ferragamo.
Mr. Field added, however, that the shift to casual wear posed complications. For one thing, his clients will have to keep up. "We're working with retailers, so they can get dress-casual stuff when they come back for the alumni programs," he said.
As businessmen dress down and job-seekers dress up, will the suit's status suffer? Probably not. Even at Cadwalader, lawyers dress up when they meet with clients. And the suit has survived similar challenges in the past.
"It's a flexible scheme of clothing," said Anne Hollander, an art historian and the author of "Sex and Suits: The Evolution of Modern Dress."
"It's been around for 200 years, if not more," she said. "So it has a likelihood of lasting much longer."

HEADLINE: Mohawks Sign New Casino Deal, Leaving Catskill Plan in Limbo

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The leaders of the St. Regis Mohawk tribe, who were awaiting final approval to build a $500 million casino in the Catskills, have turned their backs on their original plan and instead have signed a highly unusual agreement with the largest gambling company in the world.
The deal would turn over exclusive rights to build, develop and manage any Mohawk casinos in New York State to the company, Park Place Entertainment, according to copies of the agreement given to The New York Times by people who deal with the tribe. Park Place is the owner of three casinos in Atlantic City. The rights to the Mohawk casinos could be worth billions of dollars, investment analysts who follow the gambling industry said. 
 In return, the impoverished Mohawks would receive a $3 million loan and a large percentage of the profits from any casino. Some industry analysts doubt that Park Place will ever build a Mohawk gambling hall because it would undercut the company's heavy investment in Atlantic City. Park Place's intentions are among the unanswered questions surrounding the deal, though the company says in the agreement that it will begin building a "gaming facility" within 36 months. It is unclear whether the agreement will stand up to federal scrutiny or a challenge by the tribe's original casino partners.
What is clear is that the agreement -- negotiated by Arthur M. Goldberg, the chief executive of Park Place Entertainment, with the help of former United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- will almost certainly delay the coming of any casino to the Catskills for years.
Originally, the Catskill Development Group had planned to donate 30 acres to the tribe for a casino in Monticello, N.Y., in return for a share of the revenue. The Catskill group learned only Thursday night about the agreement, which was signed by six tribal chiefs and Mr. Goldberg on April 14. Robert Berman, a partner in the Catskill group, said the tribe was misled.
"This is the greatest rip-off of an Indian tribe since the Dutch grabbed Manhattan for $24," Mr. Berman said. "We hope that the tribe will understand that Park Place is a wolf in sheep's clothing whose true intention is to kill the casino in Monticello to protect their interests in Atlantic City. The tribe is selling out its future for a $3 million loan. But I still believe there's an opportunity for the tribe to salvage this."
Mr. Berman said he believed the tribe could renounce the Park Place deal on technical grounds.
Donald J. Trump and other Atlantic City casino operators -- but not Mr. Goldberg -- have spent millions lobbying in Albany against the Monticello casino, which they believe would cut into their profits by attracting gamblers from New York City and northern New Jersey. Analysts have said the Monticello casino would generate more than half a billion dollars a year in revenue.
Neither Mr. Goldberg nor the company's general counsel, Clive Cummis, returned telephone calls yesterday requesting comment. Both men were at the Mohawks' Akwesasne Reservation yesterday on the Canadian border in Hogansburg, N.Y.
Gus McDonald, the tribe's executive director, and the six chiefs who signed the agreement also did not return telephone calls.
The tribal clerk, Carol Herne, and a former Mohawk chief, Barbara Lazore, both said they were appalled by the deal with Park Place. The two women said they confronted Mr. Goldberg yesterday at a restaurant on the reservation, where he was meeting with the tribal leaders.
"We can't allow this project to go down the drain," Ms. Lazore said. "I don't believe they're here to help the Monticello project. It'd be the No. 1 competition to Atlantic City."
Casino gambling is unconstitutional in New York, but sovereign Indian lands are an exception. Only 16 days ago, the federal Interior Department approved a four-year-old proposal in which Mr. Berman's group would get around the constitutional problem by giving the federal government 30 acres next to the Monticello Raceway in trust for the Mohawks. The Monticello casino plan is now awaiting approval by Gov. George E. Pataki and, possibly, the Legislature.
But even as Mr. Berman's application was approved in Washington, Mohawk tribal leaders were being wooed in secret by Mr. Goldberg and his adviser, Mr. D'Amato, according to tribal executives, rival casino operators and Catskill Development.
"This seems to add a whole new dimension to an already complex situation," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Governor Pataki. "We'll need to review the document closely. It appears to have some significant implications."
Mr. D'Amato, a longtime adviser to Mr. Goldberg, is also close to the governor. The former senator did not return calls, but Wayne Berman, Mr. D'Amato's partner, said their consulting company ceased representing Park Place on April 14, the day the agreement was signed with the Mohawks. Wayne Berman, who is no relation to Robert Berman, declined to discuss Mr. D'Amato's work on behalf of Park Place. An official in the Pataki administration said that Mr. D'Amato had stepped down as Park Place's consultant to prevent his friendship with the governor from putting Mr. Pataki in an awkward position.
The Park Place deal with the Mohawks is unusual, the investment analysts said, because Indian tribes routinely grant casino development rights for specific locations. They said no tribe had ever given exclusive rights to as large a territory as New York State.
In return for granting Park Place exclusive development rights, tribal leaders received a $3 million loan from the casino company "for use by the tribe in its discretion." The tribe presumably would use the money to bolster its small money-losing casino in Hogansburg, where the Mohawks recently ousted the existing operator as part of a separate deal with Park Place. The Mohawks would also get 70 percent of the profits from every casino, after Park Place is reimbursed for any advances.
The casino development agreement would not cover the Hogansburg casino or a proposal that just surfaced last year for a Mohawk casino in Greene County.
Jason Ader, an analyst with Bear Stearns, said Mr. Goldberg was playing a shrewd game of chess. On the one hand, he said, Mr. Goldberg could be using the prospect of a first-class casino in the Catskills to scare off other companies that are considering building new casinos in Atlantic City.
"The question is, does he ever want to get it built?" Mr. Ader said. "With one-third of his profits coming from Atlantic City, the expansion of gaming in New York could be detrimental to this franchise."
There is little question that the Mohawks want new casinos to provide the tribe with money and jobs. Unemployment on the Mohawks' Akwesasne reservation ranges from 35 to 40 percent. But the year-old casino on the reservation in Hogansburg loses about $300,000 a month.
In an interview earlier this month, one tribal executive expressed concern that Alpha Entertainment, a gambling company that is working with Catskill Development, would not gain the approval of the National Indian Gaming Commission, which oversees casino management contracts signed by Indian tribes. Desperate to avoid another Hogansburg catastrophe, the tribal leaders looked to the largest casino operator in the world for salvation.
Instead of simply buying out Alpha Entertainment and replacing it, however, Mr. Goldberg sought to take over completely. But one tribal adviser said that Mr. Goldberg had promised to build a casino for the tribe in Sullivan County within four months, which the adviser said was absurd. The Interior Department approved a specific proposal at the Monticello Raceway. Any new proposal would have to undergo an approval process that could take years.
Questioning whether Park Place's promises to the tribe could ever be delivered, one Mohawk adviser said, "The chiefs are so obsessed with the on-reservation casino that they've lost sight of the larger picture."
