SECTION: Section 6; Page 68; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 5871 words

HEADLINE: 'You Are Going to El Norte'

BYLINE: By Mirta Ojito; Mirta Ojito is a metro reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
The police came just as i sat down to lunch: a plain yogurt (sweetened with several spoonfuls of sugar), two fried eggs with a little ketchup and fried sweet plantains. I was wearing half of my school uniform. That is, I had on the painstakingly ironed navy blue skirt with the two white stripes, signaling that I was in the 11th grade. On top, I wore a girl's house dress, a bata de casa, to avoid staining my starched white poplin blouse.
I heard their steps on the stairs. Heavy, loud steps. I could tell there were two men and a large woman. The woman was easy. She was our downstairs neighbor and the president of the neighborhood watchdog committee. Years of listening to people climb the 20 polished steps that led to our apartment had trained my ear for the idiosyncrasies of the feet. The men were agile and in charge. They skipped several steps and got to the door before I could call for my mother. 
 A knock. On the red plastic clock above the television set it was 15 minutes after 11 in the morning on May 7, 1980. I looked at my mother, who was just coming out of the bedroom, where she had been sewing a dress for a client. I waited for a signal from her. She had been waiting for this knock a long time; I had been waiting only for the past 14 days.
It had all started early in the morning on April 24, when I woke to the sound of crying. Someone was standing at the foot of my bed.
"Que pasa?" I asked, in a panic.
It was Aunt Magda, my mother's sister. She lived in Guanabacoa, a neighborhood across Havana Bay, much too far from our Santos Suarez apartment for her visit to be casual. It was still dark out. My sister, who was 11, slept soundly next to me. We had shared the old burgundy sleeping couch in the living room since she had left the crib. I was 16 years old.
"You are going to El Norte," my aunt sobbed. My mother joined her at my bedside.
I could hear them, but I could not see them clearly. The day before, an ophthalmologist had given me slow-acting drops to dilate my pupils in preparation for an eye exam, which I was to have that morning. So that's how I awoke the day I learned I was leaving Cuba -- frightened, confused and blinded by my very large pupils.
I had always known my family would leave Cuba, but I figured we would do it in style, wearing nice winter clothes, tearfully bidding farewell to the island from the little square windows of an Iberia Airlines plane. For years my mother even kept a piece of hot pink wool cloth to make me a skirt and short blazer when the time came.
Back then we assumed that every city north of Cuba was cold and snowy. That is how it looked in the pictures my uncle regularly sent from New York and Connecticut in the 1970's. His children playing in the snow. He and his wife bundled up in wool and wrapped in thick, hairy scarves. The whole family against a backdrop of tall, dark buildings, snow piled up around them.
But our careful plans were derailed in the summer of 1980, when we became 4 of the 125,266 Cubans that in a span of five months left Cuba for the United States in what came to be known as the Mariel boat lift.
The boat lift, a chaotic and incomprehensible event then and now to most Americans and to many Cubans, convulsed the island. It remains one of the landmark events in Cuban history, the first indication that Fidel Castro's carefully controlled social experiment had developed deep fissures. It also changed the dynamics of immigration between the United States and Cuba, introducing the possibility of deportation and forever tainting the image of Cuban refugees. And it further undermined President Jimmy Carter's faltering image, contributing to his devastating loss in the elections later that year.
In the political dialogue of the two countries, Mariel remains a point of reference that is much abused. In Washington, lawmakers talk about never allowing another Mariel; in Havana, officials know they can always play their Mariel card -- the threat of unleashing millions of desperate people living only a short boat ride away.
For my family, ignorant of cold war politics and immigration agreements, Mariel was simply a way out, one that my parents had been awaiting a long time. In October 1962, three years after Fidel Castro came to power, they rushed their wedding date to follow my father's family to the United States. But the Cuban missile crisis erupted, dampening the first week of their honeymoon and later, when Washington stopped issuing visas to Cubans, destroying their dreams.
We lived in a one-bedroom apartment that, when I returned for a visit two years ago, seemed even smaller than I remembered. For years we endured food shortages, constant blackouts, the stigma of communicating with relatives living in the United States and, worse, the scorn of people who criticized my parents for taking their children to church and for not thrusting themselves into the revolutionary "project."
Yet, I felt somehow connected to the ideals of the revolution that my parents quietly rejected. As much as a child could, I immersed myself in the project of building a better, more egalitarian Cuba. I was a model Communist Pioneer and probably would have become an enthusiastic member of the Communist Youth if the government itself had not created the conditions to open my eyes -- and those of my generation -- to a new reality.
In 1978, looking to score points with the exile community and the Carter administration (which centered its foreign policy on human rights), Havana suddenly announced the release of hundreds of political prisoners and invited Cuban exiles to visit the island. It was the first time the gusanos, or worms, as we had been taught to call everyone who had "deserted the revolution," were allowed back.
It is hard to overestimate the impact of these policy changes. The government had always claimed that there were no political prisoners in its jails, only terrorists. But here was shocking proof of people being imprisoned simply for disagreeing with the regime. Families -- including mine -- were reunited for the first time in years. Dollars poured in. Overnight, gusanos became mariposas, butterflies. Meeting my family from America, seeing that they were nice people and not traitors, and hearing their stories of hard work and long days -- but also great rewards -- marked a turning point in my life. Disappointed with the lies and hypocrisies of the regime and tired of seeing my parents work and struggle in vain, I told my father I was ready to go with him to the United States when the time came.
Still, nothing could fully prepare me for Mariel. On April 1, 1980, a 31-year-old unemployed driver named Hector Sanyustiz and five of his friends and relatives crashed a borrowed bus through the gates of the Peruvian Embassy in Havana's exclusive Miramar neighborhood. Cuban soldiers guarding the embassy opened fire, wounding Sanyustiz and one of his friends. In the shower of bullets, one Cuban guard was killed.
Angry, Castro ordered the guards removed. As word spread through Cuba that the gates of the embassy were open and unguarded, hundreds, and later thousands, of people flocked to the embassy seeking asylum. Three days later the gates finally closed on a crowd of 10,856 people.
Peru refused to take all the refugees. Embarrassed, Castro needed a plan. Fast. Exactly how the idea of Mariel was concocted is a matter of some debate. American officials said Castro planned it all along. But a Cuban exile named Napoleon Vilaboa says he gave Castro the idea. In Miami, where many people believe Vilaboa was a Cuban intelligence agent -- an accusation he denies -- he is still known as the father of Mariel. Vilaboa, who was in Cuba in 1980 to try to speed the release of a small group of political prisoners, says he told Castro that he should consider another "Camarioca," a reference to the 1965 boat lift that took more than 3,000 refugees to the United States. "But I also told him that he should open it to everybody, because exiles would not return only for the 10,000 in the embassy."
Vilaboa says Castro liked the idea and asked many questions about the logistics. Vilaboa returned to Miami and, in a few days, received a phone call from Cuba giving him the go-ahead. The chosen port was Mariel, a harbor on the northern coast of Cuba, about 20 miles west of Havana.
On April 19, Vilaboa sailed for Cuba, leading a flotilla of 42 boats.
Three days later a brief story in Granma, the government newspaper, touched off a sensation in Havana. It dryly announced that two boats from Miami had gone to Cuba to pick up refugees as well as relatives of the boat owners. When my father read the story, he rushed home and, clutching the paper, stormed into the bedroom, where my mother was bent over her sewing machine. "This is it," he told her. It was about 3 p.m. The next day, while my sister and I slept, they left to call his brother Oswaldo in Miami to ask him to get us out of the country.
To their surprise, by the time they arrived at the telephone company on the evening of April 23, there was a long line of desperate Cubans clutching the same copy of the paper. When my father's turn came, nobody answered the telephone at my uncle's house. My father then called one of his sisters. "The reason you couldn't reach him," she said, "is because he has already left to get you."
Oswaldo, then 42, was an accountant, a husband and the father of two boys. He had just moved to Hialeah, Fla., a suburb of Miami, from New York. He was, and remains, cautious, measured, a man of few passions other than his family and gardening. He had never been in a boat before. He hardly knew how to swim. Yet, when a neighbor told him that he was heading for the Miami River to charter a boat to go to Cuba, my uncle, without hesitation, joined him.
Accompanied by 10 other Cubans and the owner of an old, raggedy lobster boat called the Valley Chief, they left on a Thursday at dusk. Oswaldo had packed a bag with canned sardines, some fruit and two changes of clothes, thinking he would return with us to America the next day. But 16 days would pass before he could see us and 3 more before he could take a shower or brush his teeth again.
When my parents heard that my uncle had already left, they rushed to my aunt's house to tell her the news. She came over before dawn to say goodbye. And that's when I woke up, with the sounds of her sobs at the foot of my bed.
And I thought, Today is the day I leave Cuba. It wasn't. We stayed in our home for 13 more tension-filled days.
Mariel marked the first time socialist Cuba turned against itself. The government staged riots called actos de repudio -- street rallies in which neighbors turned against neighbors, harassing and tormenting those who wanted to leave the country. The victims were often pelted with rocks, tomatoes and eggs. Windows were shattered. Doors were knocked down. Some people were killed, dragged through the streets as trophies to intolerance and hate. Sometimes people trapped inside their homes chose to kill themselves rather than face their tormentors.
We had to tread carefully. We could not tell anyone we were leaving, or change our behavior in any way. We could not say a word against the acts of repudiation for fear of raising suspicions of our own intentions. It was the first time I felt fear in my own country, in my own home. I knew then that it was time to leave.
And I thought I was ready on May 7, the morning I heard the knock on the door and looked to my mother for a sign of what to do.
We approached the door, but did not move to open it. Then our neighbor spoke. "Mirta," she called out to my mother. "Open up. It's the police. You are leaving." My mother opened the door, and in walked a burly, unshaven officer, dressed in olive green pants and a white T-shirt. Without introducing himself, he read our names out loud: Orestes Maximino Ojito Denis, Mirta Hilaria Munoz Quintana, Mirta Arely Ojito Munoz and Mabel Ojito Munoz.
"Are these the names of the people who live here?" he asked. My mother, who had started to shake, whispered, "Yes." He told us what we already knew, that my uncle was at the harbor and that we were leaving. He also said he needed to take an inventory of the house, which meant everything we owned was now the property of the government.
My mother told him that my father had just left for work. If they hurried, she added, they could probably still find him at the bus stop. My sister was in school. The family had to be gathered and readied.
He gave us 10 minutes. One officer went with my mother to find my father. The burly one stayed behind, poking into every drawer, cabinet and shelf in the house. I went to the bathroom to change while our neighbor stood by the door, taking her own silent inventory of our possessions.
As I gathered what I wanted to take with me -- a tear-smeared handkerchief, a dry rose, a picture, a letter, a small calendar with a picture of Varadero Beach, a chocolate-colored lipstick and two pens (which my uncle had brought from the United States the year before) -- I overheard an exchange between the lead officer and our neighbor.
"Why don't you call the other neighbors and arrange something for these people?" he asked her. He was talking about one of the acts of repudiation we had so far been spared.
Our neighbor, a woman who had fought with Castro's guerrillas in the Sierra Maestra, held the rank of lieutenant and was married to an army colonel who had been trained in the Soviet Union. "Nobody touches this family," she hissed at the officer, looking him straight in the eye. "I've seen these kids grow up."
After identifying herself, she ordered: "Get me their pictures from the wall. I want to keep them." She wanted our baby pictures. Later, when the officer wasn't looking, she took the portable Soviet radio my parents had given me for my 16th birthday and hid it underneath her grease-stained housedress.
By then my mother and the other officer had found my father, who went to fetch my sister from school. My mother, returning to the house alone, cried all the way and, faint with emotion, fell on the steps that led to the apartment. Neighbors who rushed to help her found out what was happening. The small apartment soon filled with friends. To the officers' astonishment, the house had a festive atmosphere, sprinkled with a few tears.
I stood on the balcony alone and said a mental goodbye to my house, to my block, my friends, the view. I could see Dulce, the old lady in the corner house, hushing her dogs; Natalia, from across the street, sweeping her wrap-around terrace; two men talking under the street lamp. Everything looked normal. Can't they hear my heart, sense my pain, feel my sadness?
And then, suddenly, my mother called. It was time to go.
I took one last look at my old life. The lunch untouched on the table. My schoolbooks on top of a shelf in the bedroom, where I always left them, away from my little sister's prying fingers. My dolls carefully arranged on top of the dresser, my underwear neatly folded in the second drawer. My parents' 72-piece rainbow-colored wedding china inside a cabinet. Pictures on the walls, our baby clothes boxed on a shelf, dirty clothes in the hamper, dry linen hanging in the patio.
Nobody took the keys.
In the early afternoon we arrived at a place called Fontan. Once a private beach club, it had been taken over by the government, and it showed -- peeling paint, broken pathways, untended gardens. The ocean was in the backyard. Thousands of people crowded on the sand, waiting. For what, we did not know. Where was our boat? Where was my uncle Oswaldo? Sometime during the evening they called our names, and this is how we learned which boat would take us to the United States. From then on the Valley Chief became our new identity.
We formed lines by boat names. In our group there were about 20 people. If a sociologist had wanted an accurate sample of who was leaving Cuba in 1980, our group would have been a good one. We were young, old, professionals, truck and bus drivers, students, homemakers, accountants, gay and straight.
By nightfall the realization that I was leaving Cuba hit me with great force. I suddenly had the urge to call my friends. I wanted someone, besides my parents, to know what was happening to me. I searched in vain for a telephone. Then it occurred to me to go outside the compound to a pay phone. Somehow I convinced my mother that I would be forever miserable if I did not make that call.
Amazingly, she obliged and offered to go with me. Without a pass, or a passport for that matter, we walked out of Fontan, leaving my father and sister behind and risking getting separated. But we were lucky. An enraged mob did not let us go very far.
The street was clogged with demonstrators shouting revolutionary slogans. Halfway down the block, before we could get to a pay phone, someone shouted: "That's two of them. Let's get them!" My mother and I ran back as fast as we could and, without even pausing to check with a guard, pushed open a side door to the building.
With time, I have come to see the episode as a fittingly sad ending to my life in Cuba, one that allowed me to make a quicker transition to the United States. Once you have to run from a mob of your own people, you know you have to go. Without regrets.
As night fell my mother and sister found a thin mattress and went to sleep on the floor. My father and I sat in plastic beach chairs in front of them. All night names of vessels were called over the loudspeakers -- a sign that the boat was ready and the group needed to assemble fast. We did not speak much that night, my father and I, but we observed. And what we saw was pitiful.
A chemistry professor from Santiago de Cuba, on his knees, begging an officer to let him join his wife and children, who were already on the bus to Mariel. His wife's name had been called, while his, inexplicably, had been omitted.
An old woman who cried inconsolably because her only son was forbidden to leave with her because his name had been misspelled in some document. She wanted to stay, but her son pushed her into the arms of an officer, who took her away as she kicked and screamed for her son.
The son left quickly, while the chemistry teacher lingered, still sobbing on his knees.
Dawn found us in the same chairs. About 8 a.m. our boat was called. We went through the process without any problems and soon were sitting in a bus without glass in the windows, leaving us exposed to the fury of the mob outside. We were pelted with tomatoes and eggs. Some people in the bus cried. Others cursed under their breath. An old lady prayed.
After a short ride, we arrived in El Mosquito, a barren, dusty field that served as a holding area for people waiting to board boats at the port of Mariel. We formed a long line outside, in the midst of a woodsy, rocky area, and waited our turn. What we were waiting for, we did not know. But because Cubans were trained to wait in line everywhere, we obeyed.
Sometime in the afternoon our turn came. We were asked to walk into what looked like a small house with a green roof. An officer asked my name and wanted to know what I was carrying. He took my two pens and sent me to a curtained booth for a search. A woman asked me to lift my blouse, unhook my bra and take off my pants and panties. Midway through she took pity on me and let me go.
My father turned in the last of his possessions, 200 pesos, about a month's salary. He protested but was told that where he was going he would not need Cuban pesos. We emerged from the house, without money or identity, into what looked like a sun-scorched military camp.
We were assigned to one of the dozens of olive green tents that dotted a barren field looking out on a pretty stretch of beach that was fenced off and patrolled by security guards. The word was that this was the last stop before Mariel. We were shocked to meet people who had been waiting 10 days. We could not fathom spending a day there, let alone a week.
We had not taken a shower or brushed our teeth since leaving the house the day before. We had no towels, sheets, clean underwear or even an extra set of clothes. We had not slept on a bed or taken off our shoes or had a minute alone. We also had not gone to the bathroom.
Someone pointed us to the showers and toilets, a cluster of tents in the distance. The stench was unbearable. Flies swarmed. My mother felt ill. We decided, instead, to take a bath in the ocean. Salt water, we thought, would be better than no water at all. But when we tried to get to the beach, a guard told us that swimming was not allowed. We went back to the tent.
The camp was divided into three sections. One large area was reserved for people like us who had been claimed by relatives who had come from Miami. Another area, fenced by barbed wire, was for people who had been in the Peruvian Embassy. They had no tents or cots.
Yet another section, closer to the water, was reserved for people who had walked into police stations across the country and applied for permits to leave, declaring themselves escoria. This term covered anyone from a homosexual to an independent thinker to a thief. They were also fenced in and guarded by dogs.
Dusk was fast approaching. We had been told that the loudspeakers would blare through the night. If you missed your name, you had to wait for space on another boat, if and when space became available. I don't think anybody in our group slept that night. An ocean breeze cooled the tent, the loudspeakers droned on and a spotlight canvassed the entire camp.
In the morning, about 10 a.m., our boat was called. "Valley Chief, Valley Chief, Valley Chief." Three times. We rushed to an area where again we were ordered to form a line and board a bus. After a short ride, we arrived at Mariel.
From the bus we could see the masts of the vessels. There were recreational yachts, shrimp boats and little two-person speedboats with people who, seemingly, had buzzed over from Florida just to see what was going on. Good Samaritans were throwing apples and shiny little bags. I later learned that the bags contained potato chips. I remember thinking that it was the first time I had seen apples, but somehow I knew what they were.
There was an atmosphere of energy and optimism around the boats: people coming and going; men in uniform carrying bottles of water; reporters interviewing refugees and boat owners. From the window, I suddenly caught a glimpse of Uncle Oswaldo standing on the dock, tanned and dirty, and with a beard from 17 days out in the sea. He was wearing jeans and a white T-shirt that contrasted sharply with his sunburned skin. Smiling through his tears, he waved at us.
Behind him, white and motionless, lay the Valley Chief, the boat that we thought would take us to the United States.
Not too long after our group boarded the boat, a bus stopped a few feet from the dock and people began pouring out. Some were shoeless; others wore orange uniforms that retained the creases of clothes that had been folded for too long; most had their heads shaved. A few were crying. They boarded the Valley Chief, and the captain was instructed by Cuban immigration officers to take them to the United States.
We did not know it then, but they were people that the Cuban government wanted to get rid of. Some were prisoners, doing time for crimes that ranged from theft to manslaughter. Others were simply nuisances, troubled people who took up space and resources and did not contribute anything to Castro's grand plans for a Socialist utopia. By sending them abroad, the government was not only ridding itself of problems but also turning the Mariel crisis into Washington's problem.
"Sector by sector, the police identified the problem types and told them, plain and simple, 'If you don't leave now, you go to jail for four years,"' says Carlos Cajaraville, a former counterintelligence captain who spent six months working at the harbor. "Most people, given the choice, would opt to leave."
Filiberto Castineira, who was a colonel in the Ministry of the Interior, the internal security apparatus in Cuba, and now sells food from a lunch cart in Miami, worked at the command post that managed the Mariel operation. He says that Castro would call every night on a special line to ask how many boats had arrived, what capacity they had, how many boats had left and with how many people. He then gave orders saying which groups of people should leave the next day.
If too many homosexuals left, then their percentage was lowered and the percentage of families increased. If too many criminals left, which could provoke a response from American authorities in Key West, then that figure was lowered and the percentage of, say, political prisoners was increased. There were seven categories in all.
Washington was not blind to what was happening, but President Carter had his hands tied. In a meeting at the White House, the high command of the Coast Guard informed the administration that there was no way to stop the boat lift without using force, which would lead to a significant loss of life.
"Can you imagine Mr. Human Rights killing innocent refugees seeking freedom from a repressive regime in Cuba?" says Robert Pastor, who was the Carter administration's point man on Latin America and the Caribbean. "We were caught in a dilemma for which we had no answer."
To make matters worse, in early May, President Carter urged Americans to open their arms and hearts to arriving refugees. His statement was interpreted as a sign that all Cuban refugees were welcome, but the administration insisted that the president had been misunderstood.
Five days after the president's remarks the captain of the Valley Chief received the order to leave Mariel. By then the boat's blue waterline was no longer visible. There were 210 people on board, only 17 of whom were related to the Cuban-Americans who had made the trip from Miami. One of the strange men who came on board without shoes asked my father for his nail clipper. When my father asked him what he wanted it for, he said he wanted to cut his veins open. We stayed away from him as much as we could.
The Valley Chief, creaking under the extraordinary weight, refused to move. The captain said that the motor was damaged and that we weren't going anywhere. My uncle went looking for help and returned with a tanned and muscled American sailor who spoke with what I now think was a Texas drawl. I can hear his voice, but not the words, because at the time I did not understand any English.
He had sailed his yacht, Manana, to the port of Mariel as a Red Cross volunteer. As my uncle explained the situation to the man, I sat on the hard cement surface of the docks, trying in vain to understand. From below, I noticed that the man's right arm was fake, but so real-looking that it was almost impossible to detect. The nails were perfectly shaped, and the curves of the forearm imitated the muscles on his left arm.
The man agreed to take the women and children on his yacht and to tow the Valley Chief to international waters. When he tried to throw a rope from the docks to keep the Valley Chief from drifting, his fake arm got tangled up in the ropes and fell into the water. Everybody gasped. My mother fainted and hit the cement with a thud. Then a man dove into the murky waters of the port and, after a few seconds, came out triumphantly holding up the arm. The American, who turned out to be a Vietnam vet, simply took the arm, put it on and continued working. My mother came about. An explosion of applause followed.
The event is etched in my memory because I remember thinking how courageous the man was to lead a full life with only one arm and how great technology must be in the United States to produce such an authentic-looking arm.
It was a sign, I thought then, of good things to come.
My father and uncle stayed behind on the damaged Valley Chief while my mother, my sister and I boarded the Manana. I tried to help in the kitchen making sandwiches, but someone called me up to the deck so I would not miss the last views of Cuba -- the faint edge of a low green hill and the masts of the boats swaying in the breeze. It was a little after 6 p.m., four days after we had left home.
Before Cuba had completely disappeared from view, I began to throw up. There is little I remember after that. I was sick the entire night, curled up on the wet floor next to my sister, who was also sick.
While everyone slept, strewn about the boat, my mother kept a vigil over my sister and me. She was 40 years old and, for the first time in her life, alone with her daughters. She had never been on a boat before, feared the water and didn't know how to swim. Both her daughters were seasick practically to the point of unconsciousness and she was silenced by her lack of English.
At about 3 a.m., I awoke with a violent stomach spasm. I was totally disoriented. I did not know where my head was or in what direction my feet were pointing. I wondered if someone had moved my bed. Then I realized I was not in my bed. "What's wrong?" my mother asked.
I thought for a minute what to say. I was cold and hungry. I had an intense pain in my bladder from not going to the bathroom for so long. I could not feel my legs. My head hurt, as did my throat and stomach, from retching all night long. My clothes were dirty; my hair was matted. I had not changed or washed in five days. I felt like crying, but I was so dizzy that I could not even cry. And of course, pain of all pains, I had left Cuba.
"Nothing," I told my mother. "I'm O.K."
It was already Sunday, May 11, Mother's Day. I remember thinking that my mother was not going to get a card. I had mailed her one the day before we left our house. It was probably already under the door. I reminded my mother that it was her day and went back to my stupor. In a few hours we reached the United States.
So thick was the fog of seasickness that I don't remember seeing land until I actually stepped on the docks at Key West. I don't remember feeling anxious, hopeful or expectant. I only remember the nausea that tortured my empty, pained stomach.
The moment I stepped on land, though, the queasiness disappeared and I started to think of ways to find my father and uncle. In the day and one night we had spent on the Valley Chief, my uncle had taught me his phone number in Florida and I had memorized it. I still remember it, although he moved from that house years ago.
I gave a volunteer the number and asked her to call my aunt Tere. We formed yet another line and from there boarded buses to what looked like a giant warehouse, outfitted for thousands of people. The floor was lined with cots, row after row of them. There was a lot of food, soda and gum. And there were clean bathrooms.
On my way to one of the yellow portables, someone called my name. It was my high school literature professor, a blond woman with blue eyes and delicate features who had always been highly critical of people who did not support the regime. I turned my head the other way. I think I was embarrassed that I had left Cuba and someone had caught me in the act. Never mind that she, too, had left. At that point my departure still seemed like an act of treason. Against what, I didn't know.
We huddled in one cot and waited. At about 8 p.m. we heard our names called through a bullhorn. As we moved toward the voice, we saw Tere and her children, jumping for joy. "There they are! They are here!" Tere kept yelling as she hugged the three of us.
Sometime that night my father and my uncle found us. The Coast Guard had rescued them from the foundering Valley Chief, and my father had arrived in the United States in style, after all. A helicopter had picked them up from the deck of a huge Navy ship and taken them to a landing strip in Key West. The Valley Chief had been towed back to the Keys.
Together, at last, we arrived the next morning at my uncle's house in Hialeah. To me, accustomed to seeing photographs of my relatives in New York, Hialeah was a major disappointment. There were no tall buildings, no interesting architecture, no sense of a city, really. And of course, there was no snow. I remember the summer of 1980 as the longest and the hottest I have ever lived through, despite the constant humming of air-conditioning in every house.
A couple of days after we arrived we had to go to an office to register our presence in the United States. Our lungs were X-rayed and we went through a series of interviews. At the first table, a bald man who spoke Spanish asked our names individually. Before I could tell him, though, he said I could choose any name I wanted. I did not have to give him my real name.
"You are in America now," he said. "You can forget the past and begin anew."
I took his advice and began a new life. But I kept my name and I have never forgotten.
On Sept. 25, 1980, Cuba ended the boat lift. Even Castro became embarrassed by the spectacle of so many people clamoring to leave the island. In all, 125,266 Cubans came to America on 2,011 vessels and one aircraft. I went on to graduate from Florida Atlantic University and started a career in journalism that took me from The Miami Herald to The New York Times.
Today Mariel is just a town lying perpetually under a cloud of dust spewed by a cement factory nearby. At the port itself, there is a geothermal power plant, situated inside a military compound, off limits to civilians. The former Peruvian Embassy is now the parking lot of a nondescript five-story hotel for businesspeople and tourists. No Cubans are allowed.
Twenty years later most Mariel refugees are successful men and women who blend in with other Cuban-Americans in Miami and elsewhere. Among them are writers, television anchormen, entrepreneurs, public relations experts, Disney World executives, restaurant owners, engineers, retirees, homemakers. But 1,750 "Marielitos" remain under the custody of the Immigration and Naturalization Service for crimes committed in the United States; 1,425 have been sent back to Cuba.
When, in 1994, the Cuban government seemed on the verge of playing its Mariel card once again, Bill Clinton, in his first term, did what President Carter had been unable or unwilling to do 14 years before. He ordered the Navy to intercept all refugees and take them to Guantanamo Bay, the American military base in Cuba, and announced that they would never come to America.
Eventually, most of the 30,000 rafters held at the base did make it here. But by denying them immediate entry, President Clinton reversed decades of immigration policy toward Cuba. Since then, Cubans intercepted in the water have been routinely returned to the island.
This remarkable policy shift went practically unnoticed. No protests in the streets of Miami. No outcry from the pro-immigration lobby. No matter how much the boat lift has done for thousands of people like me, it was clear that no one else -- not Washington, not Havana, not even the Cuban exiles -- wanted another Mariel.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 4-23-00: Phenomenon;
While Nasdaq Burns

BYLINE: By Jessica Seigel 

 BODY:
'This is big -- really big," said Bill Sarpalius, a former Texas congressman, taking in the scene at Boot Camp for Start-Ups, a seminar recently held in Manhattan and currently making its way around the country. While the Nasdaq was imitating sine waves on computer screens around the world, Sarpalius, like everyone else in sight, was networking wildly and conferencing on his cell phone. He was on the line with his board working out a merger with a rival while his employees were back at Lobbyforme.com, a Web site that, come May, will allow citizens to pool their resources and hire former congressmen as lobbyists. Getting voted out of office, he decided, was "the best thing that ever happened. Now I'm part of a new frontier. There was the gold rush, the land rush and the oil boom. Now it's the Internet. I'm staking my claim."
Such was the spirit of endless possibility -- tinged with frantic urgency -- among the 1,000 prospectors, most of them white guys under 35. They had paid $995 each to learn how to hone and sell their ideas with the artful savvy of a Hollywood pitch meeting. ("Less is more," advised Bill Joos during the Perfecting Your Pitch seminar. "Bait hooks, don't force feed fish.") 
 Indeed, the convention seemed to take a page from Writers Boot Camp, a how-to sensation founded in a bygone decade, though these young hopefuls were after much more than a two-movie deal. "You have a three-year window to make $100million," Robert Lessin, the chairman and co-C.E.O. of Wit Capital, told a standing-room audience. "After that it's business as usual."
The Boot Camp was organized by Garage.com, a start-up that helps start start-ups and will, of course, be going public later this year. Guy Kawasaki, the company's C.E.O., used to be "chief evangelist" of Apple Computer; at the seminar he seemed to proselytize for the whole New Economy. "The general message," he said, "is, things are still O.K." Translation: V.C. billions are still there for the picking. "Take the money when it's offered."
He didn't have to say it twice to Jeremy McGee, the 17-year-old president of TwoToads.com, a children's e-mail service whose business plan McGee hatched with a partner he met in church and that has subsequently attracted $100,000. Or to the 29-year-old Morgan Stanley broker who is quitting his job to focus on a Web site that "empowers personal trainers."
Another general message to the believers was: B2B (business-to-business marketing) and B2C (business to consumer) are so five minutes ago; from now on it's all about B2B2C. Michael Parekh, managing director of Goldman, Sachs's Internet group, passed the good word to Michael Janay, a 31-year-old who is quitting his job to launch a Web site offering college-admissions services. Janay ran off -- literally -- to revise his business plan. "It just clicked," he said.
By cocktail hour, everyone was fully converted. Even the service staff. Like a Los Angeles parking valet who is working on a screenplay, Antionette Davis, who was working the conference's coat check, confessed she is leaving her job to study graduate computer programming. "Everyone and their mother is doing high tech," she said. Plucky coat-check girl and mother launch Internet start-up -- sort of an "Anywhere but Here" meets Esther Dyson.

LENGTH: 1997 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
London's Tiny, but Mighty, Almeida

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE; Benedict Nightingale is the chief theater critic for The Times of London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
AS a theater reporter for The Times of London wryly wrote the other day, "The Almeida's bid for world domination progresses apace"; and that seems no great exaggeration. Right now, the tiny but hungry playhouse is reaching out from mission control in North London to colonize a bit of East London, a bit of Central London, eventually a bit of New York, and, if NASA ever opens up the planetary system to space thespians, one day no doubt bits of the Moon or Mars or both.
If we discount the much-hyped London debut of Kathleen Turner in a stage version of "The Graduate" -- of which more in a moment -- the Almeida has been gobbling up the London critics' attention in recent weeks. First there was the premiere of Harold Pinter's "Celebration" at the company's grungy headquarters in Islington. Then it presented Nicholas Wright's new "Cressida" in the West End, with a magnificently dilapidated Sir Michael Gambon as a trainer of the boy actors who took female roles in early-17th-century England. And now it has reopened the doors of the East End film studios once used by Alfred Hitchcock and staged "Richard II" with Ralph Fiennes as the king, a production expected at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, along with "Coriolanus," in early September.
 
'Richard II' 
 The Almeida has a habit of dispatching major performers across the Atlantic. Mr. Fiennes as Hamlet, Diana Rigg as Euripides' Medea, Liam Neeson in David Hare's "Judas Kiss," Kevin Spacey in O'Neill's "Iceman Cometh": all have appeared in the company's productions in New York, the first two of them picking up Tony Awards for their pains. But most artistic exporter-importers would not regard "Richard II" as an especially valuable addition to that inventory. Shakespeare's inept English king is not, after all, as massive a creative challenge as his emotionally turbulent Danish prince. The surprise at the Gainsborough Studios, then, is that Mr. Fiennes finds almost more in a lesser role.
Actually, it's a double surprise, since there is something about that elegant profile that makes you half-expect a reprise of the graceful, willowy, vocally exquisite Richard with which John Gielgud established his importance in London 70 years ago. But barely has Mr. Fiennes been ferried onstage in his glistening white robe and glistening white throne than he's suggesting why almost all the English nobles will be delighted to see him lose his crown to the usurping Bolingbroke.
He uses his thin smile either to mock them or to seek reassurance from his flatterers, and his tongue to flaunt his wit or, at one bizarre point, to stick out and wiggle at his angry uncle, John of Gaunt. He is disdainful, petulant, malicious and smug.
But there are political as well as personal reasons for dethroning him. Mr. Fiennes's king is clearly improvising public policy as the whim takes him, whether that means taking charge of Irish wars, banishing dangerously influential men, raising taxes, anything. He seizes the exiled Bolingbroke's lands while picking the petals off a flower, and just as casually. Never have I seen a Richard II who made me so aware of how quick and quixotic his key decisions are, and I have seldom seen a production that so lucidly posed a question still alive when Shakespeare wrote: is there a point when mortals are entitled to depose God's deputy on earth, the divinely anointed king?
Jonathan Kent, who directs, brings energy and pace to a play that can seem a classroom slog, getting good supporting performances from Linus Roache, a Bolingbroke with the resolution and the sureness of political touch that Mr. Fiennes's Richard lacks, and Oliver Ford Davies as a Duke of York less torn than dismembered by his conflicting loyalties. But in "Richard II" it's the title character who matters, and, despite his unsentimental interpretation and coldly chiseled profile, you couldn't call Mr. Fiennes inhuman or finally unsympathetic.
Yes, he displays a self-infatuated glee when he steals Bolingbroke's birthright, and, yes, he thrusts his head forward like a venomous cobra when he rejects a man he pretends to love. But adversity brings out more than just self-pitying bluster and manic mood swings. There is unexpected majesty in Mr. Fiennes's outrage when, high on a balcony, he confronts the rebels. There is a moving realism in his recognition that "I live with bread like you, feel want, taste grief, need friends." And there is a mournful wisdom when, alone in his prison cell, he confesses that "I wasted time and now doth time waste me." Even arrogant, unself-knowing despots can grow -- and Mr. Fiennes's Richard proves it.
 
'Cressida'
 "Cressida" at the Albery is set in the 1630's, 40 years after "Richard II" was first staged and 20 after Mr. Wright's real-life protagonist joined Shakespeare's company, the King's Men, and became what contemporary records describe as one of its "principall actors." And John Shank, as he was called, isn't the only historical character in the play. Almost everyone on the cast list existed: a slick operator called Blagrave, who simultaneously owned one theater and licensed plays in rival houses; John Honyman, who was one of Shank's most successful apprentices; an actor called Richard Robinson, who married the widow of Richard Burbage, the tragedian who first played Hamlet and Lear. There was also a boy called Stephen Hammerton, who was described by one witness as "a most noted and beautiful woman actor who afterwards acted, with equal grace and applause, a young lover's part."
With much of Nicholas Hytner's production occurring in and around Shakespeare's Globe, the play's milieu will fascinate any theater buff. The thespians exchange nostalgic anecdotes and bitchy complaints in the same colloquial style their successors might adopt now, but they also evoke a seedy, perilous London, where boys may be kidnapped, traded, starved or used for sex.
Yet plays need effective plots as well as fascinating settings, and that is where "Cressida" falters. Where is the tension promised by the opening scene, in which Sir Michael's Shank descends from the flies on a cloud, explaining he has had a killer-stroke and denouncing Stephen Hammerton as a traitor? There is also insufficient point, purpose and narrative clarity in the long flashback that follows.
As it turns out, Michael Legge's earnestly effeminate Stephen helps save Shank, who has unwisely invested in a rival company, from financial disaster and debtor's prison. Therefore the explanation for his dying master's incoherent rage is to be found elsewhere, presumably in the triumph that the boy enjoyed when he played the female lead in Shakespeare's "Troilus and Cressida" in a more womanly style than his master thinks proper. But how can we be sure, when we never see Stephen in performance? Still, there are compensations for the play's uncertainties and occasional longueurs, and most of them are called Gambon. Think of a Jacobean minotaur, big and bovine but mentally as well as physically agile, who can roar yet wheedle, sneer yet bring a fierce intensity to his calling -- and you have a wonderfully commanding, varied performance.
 
'Celebration'
"Celebration," the most recent of the few plays Harold Pinter has written in the last two decades, comes in a double bill with his very first, which he wrote in 1957. It is a happy conjunction, for "The Room" sheds a misty, Pinteresque light on almost everything the dramatist has produced in the last 43 years.
Lindsay Duncan's pinched, nervous Rose babbles out banalities to her grimly impassive husband and to the strangers who intrude on her small, shabby flat, obscurely threatening both it and her. As often with Mr. Pinter, there is a sense of unease and embattled dread in "The Room," a sense that nameless horrors may slip like mustard gas through the cracks into private spaces.
There is poison in the air of "Celebration," too, though its smell rises more strongly from the text than from Mr. Pinter's own production, which is often and unexpectedly hilarious. At one of two tables in a chic London restaurant, two mobsterlike brothers are noisily enjoying themselves with their spouses, themselves two slatternly sisters. At the other, a genteel husband is apologizing to his wife for an amour with his secretary, only to be tauntingly informed by her that she, too, has had plenty of affairs, including one with the most obnoxious and foul-mouthed of the diners a few feet away.
Again and again Mr. Pinter contrasts the surface bonhomie -- "What a wonderful restaurant this is!" -- with the ugly drives below. There is insecurity, anger, sexual envy, contempt and even hatred behind the strenuous smiles and the brash bravado. You get a pretty clear idea of the emotional truth when Keith Allen, playing the louder brother, boozily declares that he knows that his friends and family love him, trust him, and wouldn't like "to see me hung, drawn and quartered," or when Steven Pacey as the unfaithful husband declares that he feels a wonderful sense of harmony and for once doesn't want to "kill everyone in sight." It doesn't take a phrase book to Pinterland to decode the menace behind the rhetoric.
Starting with "One for the Road" in 1983, Mr. Pinter has produced several terse, tough plays that deal openly with torture, political wrongdoing and the abuse of human rights. "Celebration" is, perhaps, a surreptitious addition to the same files. The coarse, crude brothers turn out to be "strategy consultants" dedicated to "keeping the peace worldwide." The well-bred adulterer is a banker, keen to do a deal with them. Only one character, an eccentric waiter who bores customers with tall tales of a grandfather who met everyone from T. S. Eliot to Winston Churchill, reminds us that there are or were alternatives to the society Mr. Pinter damns with such sly panache: the consumerist, philistine, sinister and brutal Britain of A.D. 2000.
 
'The Graduate'
 How could anyone who saw them forget Dustin Hoffman's solemn young Benjamin Braddock and Anne Bancroft's infinitely cool performance as the middle-aged mistress he never calls anything more intimate than Mrs. Robinson?
Those with fond or even unfond memories of "The Graduate" will wonder why Terry Johnson has transposed the 1967 film of Charles Webb's novel to the stage, and may not feel that the production at the Gielgud, also directed by Mr. Johnson, provides a sufficient answer.
Still, the story of Ben's seduction and his growing attachment to Mrs. Robinson's daughter Elaine skims along amusingly enough, thanks to banks of louvered wooden walls inside of which a bedroom, a nightclub, even a church can be economically suggested. There are strange miscalculations, though. Anne Bancroft would never have lolled on the floor with Katharine Ross's Elaine, like two sorority girls, and had a boozy rap session about Ben. Indeed, the sudden sight of the elegant Bancroft face, twisted and aged by the discovery that her daughter knows her secret, gave the movie one of its great, wordless moments. Nor would film buffs have been impressed by an ending in which Mrs. Robinson offers Elaine shrugging permission to elope with Ben in the middle of her wedding to a boring admirer.
All the same, the play follows Mr. Webb's novel in stressing that very 1960's subject, the need to resist overwhelming parents and oppressive suburbia. That is why Matthew Rhys's Ben is far more the restless, insecure postadolescent than Mr. Hoffman's prototype, whose rebellion largely consisted of glum silences. Kathleen Turner, too, exudes svelte contempt for her surroundings, giving a performance that lacks Ms. Bancroft's vulnerability but is packed with comic assurance.
The British newspapers, I fear, have devoted much space to salacious descriptions of a moment in which she briefly displays her voluptuous body to a gibbering Ben; the curt sophistication of her acting deserves better than that.

HEADLINE: Where Authentic German Food Sells Out

BYLINE: By THOMAS STAUDTER 

DATELINE: BRIARCLIFF MANOR

 BODY:
TWO regulars, Frances and Peter Myressi, sat at their usual table at the Saturday night dinner held twice a month by the proprietors of the Chilmark German Delicatessen here and waited for their meals to arrive. In the interim they drank from sizable mugs of draft beer.
Ever since October 1998, when Renate and Wolfgang Kerber, the owners, began featuring occasional home cooked German fare like sauerbraten and wiener schnitzel, customers have flocked to their deli, bringing along family members and friends or ordering takeout. 
 The Myressis, sipping their beers, mentioned that they had been to every one of the Kerbers' dinners except two, when they were vacationing in Florida. Longtime residents of New Rochelle who moved to Ossining three years ago, the Myressis, both in their early 50's, recalled first being attracted to the deli by Mr. Kerber's wide selection of imported German beers. Acknowledging their mutual Italian-American roots, the couple conceded that their steady patronage of the Kerbers' dinners has turned them into connoisseurs of German food.
"No matter what you have here, the food is spectacular," said Mrs. Myressi, her eyes widening as a plateful of sliced sauerbraten, dumplings and red cabbage was put in front of her.
At a nearby table, Kenneth Patterson, an Ossining contractor in his 30's, was the host of a group that included his sister, Susan, who had driven up from her suburban Philadelphia home with her friend, Ian Grant of Princeton, N.J. The Pattersons' maternal grandparents, born in Germany, were very much in mind as they tucked into the sauerbraten and gravy-topped rouladen, stuffed meat rolls.
"It rivals my grandmother's,' " Ms. Patterson said of the rouladen as she watched Mr. Grant swab up the gravy and meat left on her plate.
The inspiration for the dinners at the deli, Mr. Kerber said, came in September 1998 after a family vacation to Oktoberfest in Munich. "We were looking to do something different at the store, and because we'd just returned from Germany having our own Oktoberfest seemed like a good idea," he said.
With seating for 16 and using their on-premise liquor license, the Kerbers announced their special dinner to their customers, offering a choice of sauerbraten or wiener schnitzel with side dishes and desserts like apple cake and Black Forest cake. They were amazed at the response.
"We made nearly a hundred separate dinners," Mr. Kerber said. Several patrons who missed out talked the deli owners into an encore the next month, and after yet another sold-out response, the Kerbers decided to feature the dinners once a month, then twice a month in April.
Ossining residents since 1975, Mr. and Mrs. Kerber were born in East Germany and moved to the United States when they were teenagers. They met as classmates at Evander Child High School in the Bronx and were married in 1962.
Initially, Mr. Kerber, 58, was a technician for Zeiss Optics, a manufacturer of precision lenses, but he left the field in 1972 because of too much pressure and opened the College Deli on Fordham Road. Wanting to be closer to home, he eventually sold the deli in the Bronx and in 1982 opened a new deli in the Chilmark Shopping Center.
With few stores and restaurants in Westchester that specialize in German cold cuts and similar products, the Kerbers have built up a loyal clientele. Still, owning and running a mom-and-pop deli is not an easy way to make a living.
"The heydays of the deli are gone," Mr. Kerber said. "Now, supermarkets carry everything, and people are always looking for items that cost cheaper. Our regular customers are the kind of people who still look for quality."
The undeniable crowd pleaser at each of the dinners is Mrs. Kerber's sauerbraten, a marinated variation of pot roast.Other choices include different kinds of schnitzel (veal cutlets), smoked pork chops, roast pork and wurst (sausage) platters.
"My sauerbraten recipe is actually a combination of what Wolfgang's mother and my mother used to make," Mrs. Kerber said, explaining that the key is to marinate a cut of top round beef for a week in water, vinegar, sugar, peppercorns and bay leaves before cooking it.
"There really is no secret, but the sugar makes it not so sour," she said with a wink. "At home I also use wine in the marinade, but not at the store in case any of the customers can't have it in their diet."
Mrs. Kerber, who learned to cook from her mother, attributes the popularity of her dinners to the fact that many customers once had German meals years ago but either didn't have the time to make the dishes themselves or lacked a good recipe.
Or, as Ms. Patterson put it: "With the economy the way it is now, people can afford to go out for dinner or buy takeout meals more often. It's certainly better than stressing out in the kitchen."
All was calm in the deli's tiny kitchen at a little after 5 p.m. on the day of one of the Kerber's dinners. Mrs. Kerber had two large pans of sauerbraten and rouladen warming in the oven and she carefully watched over the pots of baseball-size dumplings, red cabbage and Bavarian-style sauerkraut on the stove. Her cousin, Barbara Schlesiona, 52, who had come from her home in Stamford to help with preparations, was busy readying some takeout orders, which comprise about half of the total dinners they sell.
Meanwhile, the Kerbers' 29-year-old daughter, Christina, wearing a dirndl, was out front with her father to wait on tables. Her older brother, Michael, would show up later to see if any help was needed "and to get a free dinner," Ms. Kerber said with a laugh.
By 6 p.m. the confluence of a full house and a steady stream of takeout orders was keeping all the Kerbers occupied, and the atmosphere was pleasantly hectic.
Patricia Isaza, a graphic designer in Ossining, arrived to pick up dinners to share with a colleague. "Because I'm working on the weekend, I don't have time to make food like this," Ms. Isaza said. "It's great to know you can go into this deli and get a great meal. The sauerbraten is my favorite, and the way they do red cabbage is beyond description."
Emily Grober of Croton-on-Hudson, who arrived to pick up a takeout dinner, said: "I make sauerbraten, too, but I like trying theirs. What I enjoy best is their cabbage soup -- I don't know anyone else who makes it."
Leaning against the counter while waiting for his takeout, Read McFeely, a 50-year-old staff researcher at International Business Machines who lives in Ossining and described himself as a "beer aficionado," drained a half-liter of cold draft and said, "It's rare to find people like the Kerbers who have the expertise and dedication needed to present specialty products." A frequent traveler to Germany, Mr. McFeely added that he enjoyed discussing fine beers with Mr. Kerber, "especially while drinking one."
At one of the tables, Cathy Dunleavy and Arthur Holzman stared at the gravy stained plates before them, which had earlier been heaped with rouladen, spatzel (dumplings) and sauerkraut.
"I can't cook for beans," Ms. Dunleavy, a Carmel resident, said with a sigh. "But if Wolf and Renate want to teach me how, I'd be very happy to learn."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Luring Residential Developers Back Downtown

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A DORMANT textile mill in Paterson and a vacant site once occupied by a building-supply business in Bayonne are to be transformed into rental apartments with the help of a new state program called Downtown Living, aimed at reintroducing middle-income housing into urban neighborhoods.
Earlier this month, the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs awarded $2.5 million in low-interest loans to the two projects, the first of their kind in the two cities. 
 A total of $7.5 million was appropriated to the program by the Legislature as part of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's 1999-2000 budget. Along with the Bayonne and Paterson projects, which will produce a total of 90 apartments, two other projects are in the approval process. They would generate some 600 additional apartments, state officials said.
Governor Whitman, who has said that attracting people of all incomes to cities "is the surest urban revitalization strategy," has also proposed another $7.5 million in next year's budget to finance a second round of apartment-building.
Jane M. Kenny, the commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, said, "The fortunes of our urban centers affect the whole of the state." This program is designed "to provide one more way to help people reinvest in cities," Ms. Kenny added. She cited other state initiatives, like its low-interest mortgage program for home buyers in designated urban areas and the reuse of formerly polluted sites in cities.
There is also the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, which directs growth to areas where water and sewer lines and highways already exist. And developers say the state's purchase of a million acres of open space is making it more difficult to build in the suburbs.
Those programs as well as a growing opposition to creeping suburban sprawl and a strong real estate market have helped rekindle interest in urban areas. Still, the "biggest challenge to cities is retaining and attracting middle-income families," Commissioner Kenny said.
Downtown Living is an expansion of an earlier pilot financing program, which the state began in 1998 and which resulted in two middle-income rental projects: 131 apartments in Morristown and 82 apartments in New Brunswick.
Under the program state loans are available to both for-profit and nonprofit developers at an interest rate that generally is below 5 percent and can be as low 1 percent. The loans are for 15 to 30 years.
To be eligible for a loan, a project must be in one of 70 municipalities that qualify under the state's various urban aid programs. It must also be part of a larger redevelopment plan or one that is expected to stimulate additional investment.
In Paterson, Alpert & Alpert Ltd. of Fort Lee will use a $1.5 million state loan to help finance the first phase of its conversion of the Boris Kroll textile mill to rental apartments. The first 39 units will cost about $3.6 million.The mill's five red-brick buildings, which date from the 1900's and have been designated a state historic landmark, have sat vacant for at least a decade. They take up an entire block, bounded by 20th and 21st Avenues and State and Gray Streets.
Later phases call for the remaining four buildings to be turned into 150 additional rentals and at least 10,000 square feet of retail space, said Joseph Alpert, the vice president of the development company.
The project is the first sizable new middle-income housing development to take shape in Paterson, the state's third-largest city (after Newark and Jersey City), in three decades. The need for all types of housing in Paterson is about 10,000 units, said Bob Grant, a city spokesman.
IN the last decade, he added, Paterson's population has grown to 170,000 from 140,900 in 1990, with the influx of immigrants from Middle Eastern countries as well as Central and South America. But housing construction in the city "has been far less than what potentially could be built," Mr. Grant said. Among the reasons, he said, was the the City Council has been reluctant to provide incentives like tax abatements.
Mr. Alpert said that downtown Patterson was the "perfect area for creating middle-income housing." He cited the mill's location not far from Interstate 80 and the 21st Avenue retail corridor. "Someone has to be first," he said.
Nonetheless, getting the project to this point has taken two years, Mr. Alpert said, adding that "it still would not have been economically feasible without the state financing." What the loan, at a 1 percent interest rate for 15 years, enabled his company to do "was to reduce the cost of the conversion and attract other financing," he said.
Additional financing for the initial phase of the conversion is coming from a $600,000 low-interest Federal loan provided under the Home Program of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and administered by the City of Paterson. The rest will come from Federal historic tax credits, private sources and the developers themselves.
The first 39 apartments, which will have one to three bedrooms and 650 to 1,200 square feet, will be in the mill building closest to 20th Avenue, which will be renamed Paterson Commons I. The renovation is expected to start in August and take a year to complete.
Starting rents for the units are expected to be $650 to $950 a month. There will be no income limits for prospective tenants. Mr. Alpert said he expects the project to draw middle-income people who want to move from rentals in older two- and three-family homes in Paterson to new apartments at the same rent.
In Bayonne, the $1 million state loan will be used to help construct a 4-story, 51-apartment building called Peninsula Court on a vacant site on West 25th Street between Avenue C and Broadway, the city's downtown shopping area. The Alessi Organization, a 38-year-old family-run company in Bayonne, is the developer of the $5 million project, the first multifamily project in the city in 15 years. It "will provide much-needed middle-income housing," said Joseph E. Ryan, Bayonne's public-information officer.
Unlike other Hudson County riverfront cities, Bayonne was largely passed over by the mid-80's real estate boom. One reason was the lack of transportation, but that is changing. Bayonne anchors one end of a new 20.5-mile light rail system, and trains have just begun running on the first 7.5 miles along the Hudson River. Peninsula Court is within walking distance of the 34th Street rail station.
"The housing market in the city has tightened in the last few years in anticipation of the light rail," Mr. Ryan said. Vincent Alessi, the president of the Alessi Organization, added: "The market has finally reached Bayonne."
But, he added, that, "without the state financing to kick-start the process, it would have been much more difficult" to proceed because lenders were reluctant to enter an untested market. Along with the 15-year $1 million state loan at a 1 percent interest rate, Mr. Alessi said his company is financing the remaining $4 million from private sources, including its own money.
Mr. Alessi said he expected the project to draw "older folks from Bayonne who sold their homes but don't want to leave," as well as younger people who now live in other riverfront cities, work in Manhattan and "want to live in an apartment that is 20 to 30 percent larger and 20 to 30 percent less expensive."
Starting rents for the studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments, with 720 to 1,150 square feet, are expected to be $750 to $1,350 a month. As in Paterson, there will be no income limits for the tenants in Bayonne. Amenities planned at Peninsula Court, designed by R. A. German Architects of Manhattan, include a 55-car parking garage. Construction is expected to begin next month and take about a year.

HEADLINE: In Hudson Valley, And Elsewhere, Minor Leagues Are Booming

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:
THERE will be speeches. A politician or two will limber up a rusty arm to lob ceremonial first pitches. An umpire will shout the traditional command, and minor league baseball will come to Long Island, following a trend that has swept the New York region.
The debut of the Long Island Ducks this Friday night, in a gleaming new $19.9 million stadium here, will follow a script that has played out several times in the last six summers in the Hudson Valley, Connecticut and New Jersey. A decade ago, the region had only one minor league team, in New Britain. With the arrival of the Ducks and new teams in Queens and the Catskills this season, there will be 16 teams playing in four leagues within 100 miles of Times Square. Camden is to join them next season, and there is talk of creating three more teams -- in Yonkers, Hartford and Bergen County in New Jersey. 
 Baseball executives cite two overriding reasons for the growth in the region and elsewhere: the popularity of two baseball movies, "Field of Dreams" and "Bull Durham" a few years ago, and handsome new, fan-friendly stadiums with plenty of amenities and amusements, especially for families.
Cities and towns, some struggling economically, have turned to the sport for help in reviving run-down neighborhoods and polishing their images. These communities have pumped millions of state and county dollars into new stadiums; the Ducks alone have reaped nearly $20 million in public funds for their new stadium.
But as the roster of teams grows, some clubs are starting to ask how many are too many. And some industry analysts are wondering just how long the interest will last, and what will happen to public investments if the novelty wanes.
"There certainly is going to be a saturation point," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College and a student of baseball finance. "I think they may be pushing up against it now. But the jury's still out."
For now, experts say a mix of novelty and a fresh love for the age-old essence of baseball has made the minor leagues appealing.
"It represents an older America that we crave," said Michael Aaron Rockland, chairman of the American studies department at Rutgers University. "It represents a softer, sweeter, slower time. Most of us are sick and tired of living by the clock. Here's a game that doesn't go by the clock. Baseball offers us a vision of peace, quietude and timelessness."
Such qualities can also be applied to major league baseball. But promoters of minor league baseball add a few more nouns -- like value and intimacy. The games are affordable for most families, with most tickets priced under $10, rivaling movies, bowling alleys and amusement parks.
"It's absolutely great entertainment," said Bob Tait, who has tickets for half of the Somerset Patriots 70 home games. "There's thousands of people around here who can't get away from taking care of their kids, so they just take them to the ball park. It's safe, it's wholesome, it's close to home and there's great community spirit."
The new ballparks hold between 5,000 and 7,000 fans. They have bright, well-stocked concession stands, close-to-the-field seating and excellent sight lines. Most have picnic pavilions and playgrounds, video arcades, plenty of music and flashy scoreboards with big video screens. Team mascots are fixtures and mingle with fans. Players are routinely made available to children for chatting and signing autographs. Promotional giveaways are common.
Fifty years ago, long before the minor leagues refashioned themselves as family friendly, the teams were little more than training grounds for potential major leaguers. At the height of their popularity in 1949, the leagues drew nearly 40 million fans.
But in the early 50's, attendance started eroding with the rapid spread of television, said Miles Wolff, commissioner of the Northern League, one of the five independent leagues. The slump continued during the Vietnam War and the sour political and cultural mood it created, he added. By 1969 minor league attendance had slipped to about 10 million. It remained stagnant for 15 years.
At the game's low point in the New York region a decade ago, only New Britain fielded a team. It played as a farm team of the Boston Red Sox in the Eastern League, a Class AA league two steps below the major leagues with a 140-game schedule.
New Britain is now called the Rock Cats and is affiliated with the Minnesota Twins. And it is no longer alone.
In 1994 and '95, three new regional teams joined the Eastern League: the Trenton Thunder (a Red Sox farm), the Norwich Navigators (Yankees), the New Haven Ravens (Mariners). At the same time, the New York Penn League, a Class A league, three rungs below the majors, came to the region with the Hudson Valley Renegades (Tampa Bay Devil Rays) in Fishkill in Dutchess County and the New Jersey Cardinals (St. Louis) in rural Sussex County. Last season, the league added the Staten Island Yankees (Yankees), and this summer it will add the Queens Kings (Toronto).
All were hits and have achieved varying degrees of success, with Trenton and Hudson Valley consistently drawing the biggest crowds.
Fan acceptance has spawned the arrival of two independent leagues since 1998, the Atlantic and the Northern. Neither is bound by the restrictive territorial rules that govern minor leagues linked to the majors. Therefore, they can play wherever they are welcome.
The Atlantic has five teams this season in the region, and the Northern three: the New Jersey Jackals at Yogi Berra Stadium in Little Falls, the Waterbury Spirit in Connecticut and the Catskill Cougars in Mountainside, N.Y. The eight independent teams draw their players from youngsters never signed by major league teams and veterans who once played in the affiliated minor leagues or the majors.
Now the Long Island Ducks start play in the Atlantic League with Bud Harrelson, star shortstop for the Mets a generation ago and a team co-owner, serving as its field manager. The mastermind of the Ducks and the Atlantic League is Frank Boulton, now finding a happy ending to a campaign he started in the early 1990's to bring professional baseball to his native Long Island.
"It's very rewarding," Mr. Boulton, 49, said of the Ducks, the league's four other active teams and the one planned for Camden next summer. "Some people like to say I have great vision. I like to say I have a hard head."
Of the four Atlantic League teams now playing, the Somerset Patriots and the Bridgeport Bluefish have been the most popular, drawing home crowds that averaged 5,235 and 4,571, respectively, last year.
Two owners of the Bluefish, Mary-jane Foster and her husband, Jack McGregor, are eager to introduce minor league ball to Westchester.
"I think it's going to be a great baseball site," Ms. Foster said, "with its sheer number of people, and the disposable income and the local interest." She said she and her husband have looked at possible stadium sites in several towns. Currently, they are talking with Yonkers officials about the possibility of building a stadium. She declined to discuss specific locations.
In the next month, Yonkers officials plan to hire consultants to explore the idea. They will examine fan interest, possible stadium sites, construction costs and the question of whether the ballpark should be financed with private or public funds.
Edward A. Sheeran, special assistant to the mayor for economic development, said city officials want to make certain that the county could support minor league ball before making any commitments.
"We're very impressed with the success of the teams that have been popping up," he said.
A Yonkers team would play in the Atlantic League and could compete for fans with the Hudson Valley Renegades, a big hit in Dutchess and neighboring Hudson Valley counties since starting play in 1994.
But neither Ms. Foster nor Skip Weisman, president of the Renegades, seem concerned about one team harming the other.
"We could mutually coexist very happily," Ms. Foster said.
"There's enough people in Westchester for both of us to do O.K.," Mr. Weisman said.
Economic development officials around the region praise the urban renewal value of the teams and the new stadiums, more for burnishing the images of downtown and enticing new investment than creating new jobs. The Newark Bears' new stadium opened last year a few blocks from the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which started a downtown revival.
George Gatta, deputy Suffolk County executive of planning and economic development, said the Long Island Ducks' stadium completes the transformation of "one of the worst neighborhoods" in the county.
And in Bridgeport, the 18-acre waterfront site where the Bluefish play was once filled with abandoned factories and stores, empty gasoline stations and burned-out houses. Now a $45 million, 10,000-seat arena and a 900-car parking garage for railroad commuters and baseball fans are going up at the site.
Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's director of planning and economic development, said the stadium has changed the image of that piece of downtown. Commuters on the Metro-North Railroad once saw abandoned factories covered with graffiti. "Now they see 5,000 fans waving at them," Mr. Freimuth said. "That changes one's mindset about an older city. If image improves, value increases and value draws investment."
But in New Jersey and Connecticut, there is fear of having too much of a good thing.
After the Somerset Patriots began playing about 20 miles north of Trenton last season, the Thunder's average home attendance dropped to 6,197 from 6,628. That still left the Thunder ranked among the top 25 minor league clubs in the country, but it was the team's first attendance drop in its six seasons of play.
But Joseph Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers and a vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers, said the region's economy is at its strongest point in a generation. The minor league expansion, he said, was not stretched too thin.
"This region can accommodate a lot," Dr. Seneca said. "It's a huge market."
But in Connecticut, the three Eastern League teams are jittery about competition. Attendance in New Haven and Norwich had already been slipping when the Bridgeport team made its debut in 1998.
The Bluefish drew an average of about 4,500 fans last year, while New Haven and Norwich had averages of about 2,900 and 3,700, respectively. Both the Ravens and the Navigators had drawn more than 4,000 people in the first two years of operation in 1994 and 1995.
Chris Canetti, New Haven's general manager, said Bridgeport, about 25 miles west of New Haven, has taken some of his team's fans in Fairfield and Westchester Counties.
He said Eastern League players were on the verge of major league careers and called the Ravens' home park, 73-year-old Yale Field, a "true minor league historic old park."
But, referring to Bridgeport's new waterfront stadium, he said, "It's hard to compete with a new $20 million ballpark with every fan amenity imaginable."
For their part, Bluefish officials said they were more interested in looking for new fans in Westchester County and northern New Jersey than squabbling with their baseball neighbors to the east.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk
