HEADLINE: Suddenly This Summer;
The Arrival of a Flock of Minor League Teams Brings Urban Renewal, But Some Nesting Areas Are Crowded

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
THERE will be speeches. A politician or two will limber up rusty arms to lob ceremonial first pitches. An umpire will shout the traditional command, and minor-league baseball will come to Long Island, following a trend that has swept the New York region.
The debut of the Long Island Ducks this Friday night, in a gleaming new $19.9 million stadium here, will follow a script that has played out several times in just the last six summers in New Jersey, Connecticut and the Hudson Valley. Last year, it happened in Newark and Bridgewater, N.J. The year before it was Bridgeport, Conn., and Atlantic City. Next year, under current plans, it will be Camden. 
 A decade ago, the region had only one minor-league team, in New Britain, Conn. This season, with the arrival of the Ducks and new teams in Queens and the Catskills, there will be 16 teams playing in four leagues within 100 miles of Times Square.
Baseball executives cite two overriding reasons for the growth: the popularity of two baseball movies, "Field of Dreams" and "Bull Durham," in the past dozen years, and new fan-friendly stadiums, most of them built with taxpayer money for cities and towns that have turned to the sport for help in reviving run-down or dormant neighborhoods and polishing their images. These communities have pumped millions of state and county dollars into new stadiums; the Ducks alone have reaped nearly $20 million in public funds for their new stadium.
In many places, the investment appears to have paid off. The success of Trenton's team has led to construction of an arena and other new development. Bridgeport, too, is building an arena. The Ducks' new stadium finishes a major redevelopment project in Central Islip that includes a gleaming new federal courthouse, a state courthouse and hundreds of units of new housing.
But as the roster of teams grows, some of the ball clubs are starting to ask how many are too many. In Connecticut, where some of the older teams are leery of an upstart in Bridgeport and a proposed team in Hartford, the old guard is starting to snipe at the newcomers and fret about their muscling in on their territory.
And some wonder just how long the interest will last, and what will happen to public investments if the novelty wanes.
"There certainly is going to be a saturation point," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., and a student of baseball finance. "I think they may be pushing up against it now. But the jury's still out."
But for now, the novelty and a fresh love for the age-old essence of baseball has made the minor leagues appealing.
"It represents an older America that we crave," said Michael Aaron Rockland, chairman of the American studies department at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. "It represents a softer, sweeter, slower time. Most of us are sick and tired of living by the clock. Here's a game that doesn't go by the clock. Baseball offers us a vision of peace, quietude and timelessness."
Such qualities can also be applied to Major League Baseball. But promoters of the minor-league variety add a few more nouns, like value and intimacy. Their games are affordable for most families, with most tickets under $10, rivaling movies, bowling alleys and amusement parks.
The new stadiums are closer to home for many fans; the Ducks' new EAB Stadium, for instance, is a godsend for Long Islanders weary of trips west to Shea Stadium and Yankee Stadium.
Lou Ottens of Clinton, N.J., has forsaken the Yankees for the Somerset Patriots, now two years old, and their new brick and steel stadium in Bridgewater. "Traffic on the George Washington Bridge and the stadium parking lots are too much of a hassle," he said. "Now I just have to go 20 minutes from my home."
Mr. Ottens stopped by the ballpark the other day and bought seven tickets for $59.50. He and his wife planned to share them with any of their 20 nieces and nephews who want to go. Such an outing to Yankee Stadium would have been too expensive, he said.
"Plus, I honestly feel these players will give you a better game than the guys in the majors because they have something to prove," he said. "They're working with a goal: They want to get to the majors. Sometimes I feel the guys already there don't particularly give you a good game sometimes."
Bob Tait and his wife, Marion, have tickets for half the Patriots' 70 home games. "It's absolutely great entertainment," he said. "There's thousands of people around here who can't get away from taking care of their kids, so they just take them to the ballpark. It's safe, it's wholesome, it's close to home and there's great community spirit."
Last season, the 13 minor league clubs that played in the region drew nearly 2.7 million fans. The Yankees drew 3.3 million, a team record, and the Mets attracted 2.8 million, and officials of both teams say they are not worried about losing fans.
"There's enough baseball fans out there," said Jason Zillo, a spokesman for the Yankees. "People want to see good baseball and right now we're providing that to the fans."
The new ballparks hold 5,000 to 7,000 fans. They all have bright, well-stocked concession stands, close-to-the-field seating and excellent sight lines. Most have picnic pavilions and playgrounds, video arcades, plenty of music and flashy outfield scoreboards with big video screens. Team mascots mingle with fans. Children celebrating birthdays are serenaded by the stadium organist, with fans joining in. Players are routinely made available for autographs. Promotional giveaways are common.
Cultural experts say something deeper than gimmickry has spurred the resurgence. Sean Wilentz, director of the American studies program at Princeton University, cites "baby-boomer nostalgia."
"You feel closer to the players, closer to the other fans," he said. "It's a more human feel. And then there's all this cornball stuff, the little contests. It's much more community-oriented. And there's none of the drunkenness and vulgarity you see at some major-league stadiums."
Fifty years ago, long before the minor leagues refashioned themselves as family-friendly, the teams were little more than training grounds for potential major-leaguers in hundreds of small towns and moderate-sized cities around the country. At the height of their popularity in 1949, the leagues drew nearly 40 million visitors.
But in the early 1950's, attendance started eroding with the rapid spread of television and home air-conditioning, said Miles Wolff, commissioner of the Northern League, one of five independent leagues in the country. The slump continued during the Vietnam War and the sour political and cultural mood it created, he said. By 1969, minor-league attendance had slipped to about 10 million. It remained stagnant for about 15 years. Now it is back to where it was before, with attendance of 40.2 million in 1999.
At the game's low point in the New York region a decade ago, only New Britain fielded a team. Then in 1994 and 1995, three teams joined New Britain in the Eastern League, a Class AA league two steps below the majors: the Trenton Thunder (Red Sox), the Norwich Navigators (Yankees) and the New Haven Ravens (Mariners). At the same time, the New York-Penn League, a Class A league, three rungs below the majors, came to the region with the Hudson Valley Renegades (Tampa Bay Devil Rays) in Fishkill, in Dutchess County, and the New Jersey Cardinals (St. Louis) in rural Sussex County. Last season, the league added the Staten Island Yankees (Yankees) and this summer will add the Queens Kings (Toronto).
Fan acceptance of the two affiliated leagues attracted two independent leagues, the Atlantic and the Northern. Neither is bound by the restrictive territorial rules that govern minor leagues linked to the majors.
The Atlantic has five teams playing this season in the region, and the Northern has three: The New Jersey Jackals in Little Falls; the Waterbury (Conn.) Spirit and the Catskill Cougars in Mountain Dale, near Monticello. The eight independent teams draw their players from youngsters never signed by major league teams and veterans who once played in the affiliated minor leagues or the majors and hope to return.
The Atlantic League, now entering its third season, has been the most bullish about expansion, emphasizing baseball as a tool of urban renewal. Its attractive new stadiums, all publicly financed, have gone up in Atlantic City, Bridgeport, Newark and Bridgewater.
Now, the Long Island Ducks start play in the Atlantic League, with Bud Harrelson, star shortstop for the Mets a generation ago and a team co-owner, serving as manager. His pitching coach is a star of the Baltimore Orioles in the late 1960's, Mike Cuellar. The mastermind of the Ducks, and the Atlantic League, is Frank Boulton, the team chairman, who is now enjoying a happy ending to a campaign he started in the early 1990's to bring professional baseball to his native Long Island.
"It's very rewarding, a great sense of accomplishment," Mr. Boulton said of the Ducks, the league's seven other teams, and the one planned for Camden next summer. "Some people like to say I have great vision. I like to say I have a hard head."
Mr. Boulton is the renegade of the region's baseball world. He once was a vice president of the Eastern League, and wanted to transfer a Yankee farm team from Albany to Long Island, but the Mets vetoed the move in 1993 as a violation of their territorial rights.
Instead, Mr. Boulton created the Atlantic League. The newcomers have sharpened competition for fans and shrunk the older teams' geographic markets. Of the four Atlantic League teams now playing, the Somerset Patriots and the Bridgeport Bluefish have been the most popular, drawing home crowds last year that averaged 5,235 and 4,571, respectively. Of all the regional teams, only the Trenton Thunder drew more, an average of 6,197.
Officials of the Somerset club, brimming with confidence after a successful first year, now want to set up a team in Bergen County, New Jersey's most populous. The county executive, William Schuber, is enthusiastic and has ordered a feasibility study. But members of the county Board of Chosen Freeholders have vowed to block any use of public land or money for a stadium.
"Why should taxpayers pay for a private business?" asked the board's most vocal critic, James J. Sheehan. "This is not an essential. I'm opposed to subsidizing the entertainment industry. If it's so successful, they should get financing from a bank."
Mr. Boulton suggested that Camden may be the Atlantic League's last team in New Jersey.
"It's getting pretty dense there," he said. "We have to be real smart about our growth."
For now, he said, the league is looking at Massachusetts and Virginia as possible expansion sites. The league already has teams in Maryland, New Hampshire and Pennsylvania.
Economic development and other government officials praise the renewal value of the teams and the new stadiums, more for burnishing the images of downtowns and enticing new investment than creating thousands of new jobs. The Newark Bears' new stadium opened last year a few blocks from the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which opened in 1997 and started the city's downtown renaissance.
George Gatta, deputy Suffolk County executive of planning and economic development, said the Long Island Ducks' new stadium completes the transformation of "one of the worst neighborhoods" in the county.
And in Bridgeport, the 18-acre waterfront site where the Bluefish play was once filled with abandoned factories and stores and some burned-out houses. Now a $45 million, 10,000-seat arena and a 900-car parking garage for railroad commuters and baseball fans are going up at the site.
Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's director of planning and economic development, said the stadium had changed the image of that piece of downtown Bridgeport.
Commuters passing the site on the Metro-North Railroad once saw abandoned factories covered with graffiti. "Now they see 5,000 fans waving at them," Mr. Freimuth said. "That changes one's mind-set about an older city. If image improves, value increases and value draws investment."
The same thing has happened in Trenton since Mercer County and the state invested $21 million for the ballpark, which opened on the Delaware River in 1994.
An empty factory filled the plot, and private developers had no interest in it. The county government gambled on a minor-league stadium, at the time a rarity in New Jersey. The Thunder prospered beyond expectation. The stadium has spurred major riverfront redevelopment, including a county-financed $52 million arena for minor-league hockey and basketball, conversion of an abandoned steel factory into 500 units of senior-citizen housing and a strip mall and supermarket, new office buildings and a new nightclub.
"It's not the cure-all, but it certainly got the image of Trenton changed for the positive," James Lambert, executive director of the Mercer County Improvement Authority, said.
But last season, when the Somerset Patriots moved in about 20 miles north of Trenton, the Thunder's average home attendance dropped to 6,197, from 6,628. That still left the Thunder ranked among the top 25 minor-league clubs in the country, but it was the team's first attendance drop in its six seasons.
Rick Brenner, the team's general manager, said the Patriots were not a factor in the drop. He blamed highway construction near the stadium, which caused the cancellation of six afternoon games popular with day campers. Both Mr. Brenner and officials in Somerset said they did not believe the two teams were competing for fans.
Similarly, officials of the Newark Bears and the New Jersey Jackals said they did not think they were chasing the same fans, even though their stadiums were only about 10 miles apart.
"There are probably still a million people in northern New Jersey who don't know about the New Jersey Jackals," said Leo Kirk, the team's general manager. "In two to three years, we'll probably have saturated the market enough to know where we stand with the Bears."
Joseph Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers and a vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers, said the region's economy was at its strongest point in a generation. The minor-league expansion, he said, was not stretched too thin.
"This region can accommodate a lot," Dr. Seneca said. "It's a huge market."
But in Connecticut, the three Eastern League teams are jittery about competition. Attendance for the New Haven and Norwich teams had already been slipping when the Bridgeport Bluefish came to their new stadium in 1998. The Bluefish drew an average crowd of about 4,500 last year, while New Haven and Norwich had averages of about 2,900 and 3,700, respectively. Both the Ravens and Navigators had drawn over 4,000 people in their first two years, in 1994 and 1995.
Chris Canetti, New Haven's general manager, said that Bridgeport, about 25 miles west of New Haven, has taken some of his team's fans in Fairfield and Westchester counties.
"It's hard to compete with a new $20 million ball park with every fan amenity imaginable," said Mr. Canetti, whose team plays at 73-year-old Yale Field.
To the north, the owners of the New Britain Rock Cats are nervous about Hartford's hopes to build a $15 million stadium along the Connecticut River for a Northern League team now in Massachusetts. Gov. John G. Rowland opposes giving Hartford any state money because he fears undercutting the state's $12 million investment in 1995 in a new stadium in New Britain, 11 miles from Hartford, said a spokesman, Dean Pagani.
Executives of Connecticut's older teams have also started fighting back against the newcomers by touting their major-league affiliations and criticizing the newer teams' play as bush league.
William F. Dowling, one of New Britain's new owners and a former Yankees executive, called the quality of baseball in the independent leagues "glorified American Legion."
"We've got bona fide potential major leaguers," he said. "All you get in the independents are some retreads and players no one else is interested in."
In Norwich, the uniforms of the Navigators this season will sport the Yankees' logo of top hat and bat as a reminder that the team is part of the Yankee system.
"What's Bridgeport going to do, put a fish on their uniforms?" said Norwich's general manager, Brian Mahoney.
Mr. Boulton, head of the Ducks and the Atlantic League, called criticism of his league's players unfair. He said half of the league's 150 players last season had once played in the major leagues. Mr. Boulton said he believed the league's players were closer to AAA, the top level of player development, than to Class A or the instructional leagues, the lowest farm teams with the rawest prospects, just out of high school or college.
Mr. Kirk, general manager of the Jackals, said the Northern League considered its quality of play to be somewhere between Class A and AA.
"As long as we're good and competitive, it doesn't make any difference if it's A or double-A or triple-A," Mr. Kirk said. "Frankly, the people don't care if they're having a good time."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 4; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1310 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Manhattan Office Space;
Dot-Coms Accounted for 25% of First-Quarter Leases

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IN the first quarter of this year dot-com companies accounted for 25 percent of all the leases executed in Manhattan, eclipsing for the first time the city's traditional mainstay, the banking and finance sector, according to a report by Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services concern.
The company, which has been keeping the figures since 1985, said that the financial sector accounted for more than 15 percent of new leases in the quarter, putting it in second place. 
 The report is an indication of how quickly new-economy companies, which include those involved in e-commerce, new media, network infrastructure, Web technology and software development, have gone from obscurity to become a major factor in the city's real estate market.
This is also illustrated in some figures compiled by Julien J. Studley, a brokerage company specializing in representing tenants. Studley reported that companies in the new-technology sector leased 629,979 square feet of space this January, compared with 252,518 square feet in January 1999, an increase of 249 percent.
Meanwhile, companies in the legal industry signed new leases for 90,611 square feet in January 2000, down from 467,879 in January 1999, and financial companies leased 276,514 square feet in January 2000, a decline from the 350,220 square feet in the year-earlier month.
The new-economy companies have become so important that one of the nation's top brokerage concerns, Insignia/ESG, has established a New Media Group in its organization, to specialize in representing these rapidly growing companies.
"ESG is a big company that knows how to service big companies," said Richard Karson, an executive director of Insignia/ESG and the head of the New Media Group. "We decided to put more concentration on how to service the unique needs of these companies -- particularly the start-ups."
Mr. Karson said these rapidly growing companies put a special emphasis on speed of service but are more adaptable about where they will lease office space than more established organizations.
"Most tenants have an area in mind, but they are flexible about location and have a broader pricing range," he said.
In fact, he said, the whole notion of a Silicon Alley concentrated in Lower Manhattan is outmoded. "Three years ago we were focused on downtown, TriBeCa and Flatiron," he said. "That has all changed."
Today dot-com companies are moving into areas of the city like Chinatown and the meatpacking district that were never previously considered suitable for corporate headquarters. And they are having an impact on the rents in those areas.
A few years ago, space at the Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street was renting for $6 to $9 a square foot, Mr. Karson said. Today, because of the influx of new-media and technology companies willing to accept a location on the far west side of Manhattan, the rental rate is over $40 a square foot, he said.
Since many of the dot-com companies are start-ups run by young people, with formidable technical skills but little business experience, brokers say it can be tough to convince landlords to rent space to them, even when they come to the table laden with cash from venture capitalists.
The answer, some say, is for the leaders of these start-ups to treat landlords, or their representatives, the same as potential investors and convince them of the bright future in store for their companies.
"We need a lot of support from our clients," said David J. Goldstein, a senior managing director of the Studley company. "We have to convince them that a visit to the landlord is like a road show selling their concept to investors. We encourage our clients to get ready early and be prepared to tell their story at a moment's notice."
HE said it was important to convince prospective landlords that the companies would succeed if they could obtain space, hire people and get their products onto the market before their competitors. He said the task was not made any easier by the fact that many of these companies were consuming their early rounds of financing at a fast rate and were facing a jumpy stock market that might not be ready to accept the initial public offering that many of the dot-com concerns were counting on.
Many landlords are keenly aware of the tenuous situation the dot-coms are in, said Bruce Mosler, an executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield. Nevertheless, he said, Cushman & Wakefield has assigned several rising executives to seek out dot-com business on a full-time basis.
"Landlords are aware these are noncredit tenants," he said, and many are reluctant to make investments to build out space in their buildings to accommodate them.
But he said there are payment formulas that landlords will accept from companies that are -- at least temporarily -- cash rich. "One way is to pay the landlord's out-of-pocket expenses plus one year of security deposit," he said.
One much-discussed approach -- landlords' accepting stock or warrants to buy stock at a certain price in the dot-coms as additional compensation for providing space in a tight market -- is not yet the custom in New York, Mr. Mosler said.
"Warrants are part of the game on the West Coast, but they are not a factor in New York," he said. Young people building companies are naturally reluctant to give away part of their future just to get office space, he said, and often, there is a more pressingreason as well. "They need those warrants to recruit key employees," he said.
The creativity of a landlord in structuring the financial terms of a lease depends on the nature of the owner of the property, Mr. Goldstein said. An entrepreneurial owner can be a lot more flexible in making deals than an institutional owner like a pension fund or insurance company.
"That sort of thing is only acceptable to an entrepreneurial landlord," said Mr. Goldstein, who added, "I can't think of an example of a deal including warrants or stock options."
Even if they are not trying to get a piece of the companies they rent space to, landlords have cut back sharply on the incentives they were offering just a few years ago. Interior construction allowances that were $35 to $40 a square foot are now down to $10 to $25 a square foot, Mr. Goldstein said.
PERIODS of free rent have declined as well, but have not disappeared, he added, noting that for landlords "it's easier to offer free rent than write a check."
Dot-com companies can often find themselves in a jam by accepting lease terms that later restrict their ability to grow or arrange financing, said Robert Nash, a real estate lawyer who is a partner in the New York law firm of Schulte Roth & Zabel.
And they are not alone. "The truth is that not many tenants know much about real estate," he said. "It's a simple matter: the landlord is in the real estate business, and the tenant is not."
He said inexperienced tenants may agree to leases that are loaded with provisions intended to protect landlords, but that work to the detriment of rapidly evolving companies.
"They may not be able to sublease without consent," he said. "They may not be able to sell shares without the landlord's consent." If there is a provision requiring that a company's net worth stay above a certain level, it could hamper a company's ability to borrow.
He said that dealing with dot-coms can be difficult for a professional advisers like a lawyer, because their top managers are so busy developing new products that they do not have time to be concerned about complex clauses in leases. But it can also be rewarding because the young executives are more willing to accept advice and allow advisers to participate in decision-making.
"The hard part is getting their attention," Mr. Nash said. "Sometimes the only way to reach them, if you can reach them at all, is by e-mail."

HEADLINE: With Sports and Business, a Drive to Burnish Bridgeport's Image

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
ROY BOE didn't hesitate when asked why he wanted to own a minor-league hockey team franchise in Bridgeport. "One reason is it's 12 minutes from my house," said Mr. Boe of Southport.
The phenomenal success of the Bridgeport Bluefish, the city's professional baseball team, is another reason. "The Bluefish obviously piqued my interest a lot," he said. 
 The Bluefish sell more tickets in Fairfield than in any other community. They sell even more than they do in their hometown, which has two-and-a-half times the population.
In March, Mr. Boe was selected as the franchise owner for the yet unnamed American Hockey League team that will play out of the 10,000-seat arena the city is building next to Harbor Yard, the Bluefish's stadium. The team will be affiliated with a National Hockey League team and will begin its first season in October 2001, he said.
Besides the fan interest in the prospects for a rivalry with the Hartford Wolf Pack, the A.H.L. franchise in the capital city, the new team also fits into a new economic development strategy for Bridgeport that revolves around tapping outside wealth.
Three business clusters were chosen for concentrating business development efforts: tourism, arts and entertainment; office services such as data processing, and metal manufacturing, a traditional Bridgeport industry that survives but has not done as well there as metal manufacturing has nationally.
Bridgeport has long been known as a gritty, hardscrabble city surrounded by prosperous suburbs, and attracting some of the wealth that surrounded it into the city has been an elusive goal. City officials and business leaders said they may have found a new strategy to do just that.
"The city is learning how to access the region's wealth by the choices we make in the kinds of businesses and industry we pursue," said Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's director of planning and economic development.
To a large degree, that has meant overcoming long-held perceptions that it wasn't safe to be in the city after dark and that it was a place with bigger plans than it could pull off. In the early 1990's, a high homicide rate, shuttered business properties, high taxes and an adventure in municipal bankruptcy all reinforced that image.
"The city's image was not good for a number of years," said Paul Timpanelli, executive director of the local business council. "It was seen as crime-laden and dirty. Nobody wants to invest their money in a place that's dirty, unsafe and mismanaged."
Then came the Bridgeport Bluefish. "We were surprised at the awakening of city pride," said Mr. Herbert, who noted that merchandise bearing the team's name and logo, a blue fish holding a bat, sold at a rate three times the norm for minor league baseball. Aided by the team's success on the field, the Bluefish have broken attendance records for independent minor-league baseball teams. Mr. Herbert said he expected that advanced ticket sales will reach 250,000 by opening day this Friday, selling more than half of the 450,000-seat attendance for its entire 76-game season.
At the same time, Bridgeport started to receive some business investment.
Although many people in the city immediately concluded that the team was responsible, Mr. Herbert said it was as much the beneficiary of this economic growth as its cause. "The Bluefish was the first tangible evidence that something was going up," he said.
Mr. Boe said he also has his eye on the down-county sports fans. He always thought that Fairfield County would be a good market for a hockey team. The arena will also serve as a site for circus performances, college basketball games, concerts and trade shows. "The building should bring another 750,000 people, maybe a million, to the city of Bridgeport," he said.
A lot of it is serendipity, and some of it is hard work, Mr. Freimuth said. Good economic times helped, but so did the city's success in getting state and federal funding for projects that make the city more attractive for investment. Harbor Yard was built with $19 million in state and local funding; the arena is being financed with a $35 million state grant; and a parking garage between them, which will also serve commuters, is being built with $16 million in federal money.
Lucky timing was helpful in some projects. For example, the city went looking for funds for a new, combined bus-train-commuter parking transportation terminal just as Congress decided to pass a federal transportation bill. But much of the hard work went unnoticed, such as the years of effort the city government made to reorganize itself and restore its credit, which was recently upgraded to an A rating.
With state and federal brownfield program money the city demolished an old electrical equipment manufacturing building and cleaned up the land so that a 70,000-square-foot commercial bakery could be built there. "The Bluefish brought a spotlight to the city, and through that all the other stuff started to show," Mr. Freimuth said. "The Bluefish didn't create a new bakery on State Street."
The city's new emphasis on clusters of businesses, rather than individual businesses, is the application of an economic development approach created by Professor Michael Porter of the Harvard Business School.
Connecticut's Department of Economic and Community Development had already started to use the cluster approach with the state's aerospace and biotechnology industries when, last year, it hired Mr. Porter's consulting organization, Initiative for a Competitive Inner City, to examine the strengths of Bridgeport, Hartford, New Haven, New Britain and Waterbury and help them create growth strategies.
The state wants to move away from the philosophy of grants and loans to individuals and individual businesses and toward grants and loans to clusters of businesses, explained Kevin Nunn, president of the Bridgeport Economic Resource Center, an organization that acts as an economic development marketing arm for the city government.
Claire Kaplan, a vice president of the Initiative for a Competitive Inner City, said the cluster approach is one in which businesses cooperate to compete. The metal manufacturing cluster businesses in Bridgeport, for example, don't make the same products, but they have the same need to train new machine tool craftsmen to replace an aging work force and to use Internet e-commerce technology to market their products.
Company executives were brought together to work out ways they could cooperate for their mutual benefit. They have created a Web site shared by all of the companies, and they are working with Housatonic Community-Technical College to train new workers, Ms. Kaplan said.
The tourism, arts and entertainment cluster was another opportunity for cooperation. The Bridgeport Bluefish attract visitors to the city, and that might create more demand for new restaurants and business services, such as cleaning companies, caterers and equipment rental.
Mr. Nunn said Bridgeport's downtown is compact, and that is an advantage. Within a half-mile of the Bluefish's stadium and the new arena are museums and live theaters that offer baseball fans the opportunity for an extended visit.
But Mr. Herbert, who is leading that cluster initiative, expressed frustration at the difficulty in getting more high-quality restaurants to open downtown. Only one, Ralph and Rich's, was open all week for dinner, "and that place is always packed." Roberto's, next door to the Polka Dot Playhouse, a live theater, is only open part of the week when the playhouse is open.
The third cluster, office services, may be the city's most audacious.
Bridgeport officials have tried to convince corporations with headquarters "down county," in Stamford and Norwalk, to locate their back-office technical operations, such as data processing and e-commerce systems, in Bridgeport.
"We can do it as part of a collaborative approach with the cities of Stamford and Norwalk," Mr. Nunn said. Bridgeport doesn't want to be seen as "poaching" businesses from other communities. Instead, it wants to take a regional approach. Information-processing operations do not have to be located in expensive corporate headquarters office space, and it would be less expensive to put them in Bridgeport than in Stamford. The advantage for Stamford is it frees up office space, allowing more companies to move there, and relieves highway traffic congestion. Employees would be happy to spend less time commuting, and it would also reduce air pollution, he said.
The major obstacle for the office services cluster is that Bridgeport lacks vacant high-quality office space, and the need to build parking garages raises the price for developing it. Mr. Nunn said Bridgeport is trying to obtain federal funding under a program to reduce traffic congestion and improve air quality to subsidize parking garage construction as a way to add new development.
"The challenge is that now it's only a study and the recommendations have to be implemented," Mr. Herbert said of the city's new development strategy. "I think it will be two or three more years to see if this really made a difference."
Perhaps it will have to do with the economy, Mr. Herbert said. If economic conditions remain good, the city has a better chance to achieve its objectives.
"I think it's going to be really interesting to see where we are five years from now," he said.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes;
In Wilmington, a Historic Theater Expands

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
BY day, downtown Wilmington is bustling. This city, with a population of 73,000, is the home of such major companies as DuPont and MBNA America Bank, and its courts are often the battleground for major corporate clashes.
But when night falls, Wilmington's business district becomes as lifeless as an abandoned Hollywood movie set. For decades, most office workers have fled to the suburbs once the workday ends. Only the lights and activity at the Hotel du Pont and the Grand Opera House have kept tumbleweed off Market Street Mall in the evenings. 
 Now, things are beginning to stir after dark. Upscale restaurants have opened in the last few years, and the Victorian opera house is in the middle of a $13 million expansion. The hope is that the Grand Opera House complex, known here simply as the Grand, will play an important role in revitalizing downtown Wilmington.
"I estimate it will bring an additional 50,000 people a year downtown," said William C. Wyer, the managing director of the Wilmington Renaissance Corporation, a nonprofit development group. "It's a big key."
The opera house expansion is the first major construction on Market Street since the 1980's building boom that followed the state's passage of the Financial Center Development Act and other laws that brought dozens of financial institutions to Delaware, one of which, MBNA, has played a crucial role in Wilmington's economic and cultural life in recent years.
MBNA's growing role has come at the same time as the DuPont Company, Delaware's best-known employer, has scaled back its business operations downtown, although it continues to own the Hotel du Pont and the Playhouse there, a 1,250-seat theater the company opened in 1913. Today, the Playhouse, which bills itself as "the country's oldest continually operating legitimate theater," is frequently used for Broadway road shows.
TWO blocks away from the Playhouse work is roughly halfway complete on a three-story building that will be connected to the Grand Opera House, built as a theater and Masonic temple in 1871. Its elaborate cast-iron facade was made in Philadelphia for the developer, the Masonic Hall Company of Wilmington. The expansion will include a 300-seat theater, rehearsal rooms, an art gallery and offices. The public opening is scheduled for September.
The 70,000-square-foot building is going up on a 0.4-acre site bought by MBNA for about $3.8 million and donated to the Grand. David W. Spartin, a vice chairman of MBNA and the vice chairman for marketing and development at the Grand, a volunteer post, is overseeing construction.
Attendance at the Grand has risen sharply in recent years, growing to 200,000 people last year, up from 71,703 in 1995.
The addition has been named the Edith and Alexander Giacco Building, in honor of a former chairman of the opera house board and his late wife. Mr. Giacco is the former chief executive of Hercules Inc., a Fortune 500 specialty chemical company based in Wilmington. The entire complex, the Grand and the Giacco Building, is being called the Delaware Center for the Performing Arts.
Kenneth A. Wesler, the executive director of the 1,176-seat opera house, a member of the League of Historic American Theaters, said the new 300-seat theater will accommodate avant-garde music, theater and dance troupes, as well as community performances, which draw smaller audiences.
Stephen M. Bailey, associate director of the Grand and founder of the Eastern Performing Arts Center Coalition, said: "A lot of the performances in the new theater will be what are called 'artist development.' Some of the best stuff happening out there, whether music or experimental dance, is absolutely suited to play a 'large stage-small audience' kind of setup. Artists start somewhere -- they don't start at 1,200 seats."
The theater, named the Baby Grand -- which was also the name of a jazz and rhythm-and-blues club on Wilmington's East Side in the 1950's -- is being wired to allow the theater to respond to the rapid changes the Internet and other technological advances are making to the entertainment business, Mr. Bailey said.
The plans originally called for the architecture of the new construction to mimic the Grand's French Second Empire style. Modeled after the Paris Opera, the Grand's cast-iron facade is painted white to imitate marble.
NOTABLES from a century or more ago all played the Grand, among them Lillie Langtry, Henry Ward Beecher and John Philip Sousa. With the third-largest stage in the country, the theater originally had 1,404 seats, not including the boxes. (Seats were removed in later renovations.)
When the expansion was announced last year, preservationists who saw the architectural renderings contended the new construction would detract from the Grand because it looked too much like it. It would also have played havoc with the Grand's Masonic symbolism. Toni Young, the author of "The Grand Experience: A History of the Grand Opera House," wrote that the architecture was based in part on the numbers 3, 5 and 7, which are significant in Masonic principles. For example, there are five sections to the facade, each with three arches and three keystones on the second and third floors.
The building was altered in the 20th century to serve as a movie house, but it gradually deteriorated. In 1971, 100 years after it was built, a group was organized to restore the opera house, which reopened in 1976.
Because of public concern that the addition might detract from the historic opera house, the Grand management decided to take some architectural cues from one of the two buildings already on the site, the former Loews Aldine Theater, a movie palace built in 1921. Only the facade, the box office and first 25 feet of the theater remained. The rest had been demolished in 1988. The other building on the site was a small store, used most recently as a card shop and not architecturally significant.
Once construction got under way last summer, the Grand's management decided to tear down what remained of the Aldine after discovering that preserving it would cost about $1 million. Preservationists protested, saying the facade was an important part of Wilmington's history. The city's Design Review Commission, which oversees alterations to historic buildings, stopped the demolition, but not before most of what remained of the Aldine was in rubble.
Work resumed on the new building after Grand management agreed to redesign the facade, using cast stone to imitate the Aldine's light-gray terra cotta, which had been made to look like granite. This meant making molds of salvaged architectural elements. Unlike the old Aldine, the new building, designed by Homsey Architects of Wilmington, will have a third floor with curved windows and a mansard roof, a nod to a similar architectural elements at the Grand.
The Giacco Building will be joined to the Grand by a neutral link. What had been the old card shop will contain the stairs and elevators, and although the Grand and the new building will appear separate from the street, there will be an unimpeded flow between the two on the upper floors.
Along with the new construction, the opera house interior has received a $400,000 refurbishing. Last year, 16 artists from Evergreene Painting Studios Inc. in New York, which worked on the restoration of Radio City Music Hall and Grand Central Terminal, painted an intricate gold-leaf band of trompe l'oeil paneling and flowered swags beneath the frescoed ceiling, using historical photographs as a guide.
"All this has contributed to making an historic performing arts center," said Mr. Wyer of the Wilmington Renaissance Corporation. "It's taking us back to our heritage."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Getting Rentals Off Regulation

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
AS rents and apartment prices in New York City continue to rise, landlords, among them investor owners of co-ops and condominiums, have been increasing their efforts to deregulate rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments, many real-estate lawyers say. And while that may be bad news for some tenants, it could be good news for co-ops that have many renters living in sponsor- or investor-owned apartments.
"With the ever-increasing prices in the rental market, and the out-of-sight prices of co-ops, I've noticed a dramatic increase in the number of 'nonprimary-residence' cases and 'luxury-decontrol' cases being brought against tenants," said Errol A. Brett, a Manhattan real estate lawyer who represents both tenants and co-op boards. 
 A tenant in a rent-regulated apartment must use it as a primary residence. If a landlord believes a tenant has a primary residence elsewhere, and can prove it in court, the apartment can be deregulated. In luxury decontrol, a rent-stabilized apartment can be removed from regulation if the rent is $2,000 a month or more and the gross annual income of the apartment's occupants is $175,000 or more for two years. Using either strategy successfully, Mr. Brett said, can provide a landlord with a deregulated apartment that can be rented or sold at market-rate prices.
"To tenants, apartments are homes," Mr. Brett said. "But to landlords, apartments are investments."
David Ng, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that he, too, had noticed an increase in cases being brought by landlords -- particularly by those who are sponsors or investors who own co-op or condominium apartments -- under the luxury-decontrol provision of the rent-stabilization law.
For a landlord to deregulate an occupied apartment renting for more than $2,000 a month, Mr. Ng said, he must first send a document to the tenant asking whether the household income exceeds the $175,000 threshold. If the tenant does not respond within 60 days, Mr. Ng said, the landlord can then petition the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for an automatic deregulation order. In most cases, he said, the division will grant the order if the tenant has not complied with the landlord's request for information.
Even if the tenant responds to the landlord's query and says the income threshold has not been exceeded, Mr. Ng said, most landlords will exercise their right to ask the division to verify the tenant's income against state tax records. Such persistence, Mr. Ng said, can provide a significant benefit for the landlord.
Once an apartment is deregulated, Mr. Ng said, the landlord must offer it to the tenant at a market rate rent. If the tenant declines, the landlord can rent it at market rate to anyone. If the apartment is a co-op or a condo, the sponsor or investor can either rent out the unit, sell it, or even combine it with an adjacent unit he may own in the building.
Colleen F. McGuire, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants, said that landlords can also decline to renew the lease of a tenant who does not use a regulated apartment as a primary residence.
"It's the landlord's burden to prove that a rent-stabilized apartment is not being used as a primary residence," Ms. McGuire said. On the other hand, a tenant's saying that an apartment is his primary residence is not necessarily enough. "The courts will look at a wealth of information to determine primary residency," she said.
A landlord first must provide the tenant with written notice that the landlord has reason to believe the tenant is not occupying the apartment as a primary residence. If the tenant refuses to vacate the apartment when the lease expires, Ms. McGuire said, the landlord can start eviction proceedings. And at that point, Ms. McGuire said, the landlord is entitled to obtain all information in the possession of the tenant that may be pertinent to the landlord's claim.
"That means the landlord can get copies of your phone bills, your credit card statements, your bank accounts, your driver's license, tax returns, voting records and even your magazine subscriptions," she said, adding that tenants may black out personal financial information on any of the forms. "Then the landlord can use all those documents to create a set of footprints to show where you're really spending your time."
While no single document would be considered absolute proof of primary residency, Ms. McGuire said, some documents carry greater weight than others. Tax returns, driver's licenses and voting records, for example, would generally be considered a fairly reliable indication of where one's primary residence is. At the same time, however, simply using the address of the rent-stabilized apartment on such forms is not, in and of itself, enough to protect a tenant who is using another home as a primary residence.
"There are lots of things that can wave a red flag to a landlord," Ms. McGuire said, explaining, for example, that if a tenant has credit card bills sent to a New York City address, but the charges on the bills throughout the year are from merchants and restaurants in, say, Florida, then the tenant would have a hard time convincing a judge that he or she spent most of the year in New York. And while a tenant who spends 183 days or more in an apartment will generally be considered to be using the apartment as a primary residence, it is not always just the tenant who is counting the days.
"Some landlords will even hire a private investigator to track a tenant's movements," Ms. McGuire said.
But why would a landlord go to such expense just to be able to decline to renew a rent-stabilized tenant's lease if the apartment itself remains under stabilization?
"Because in most cases, the apartments don't remain under stabilization," said Mr. Ng, the landlord-tenant lawyer. A regulated apartment in a co-op or condo becomes deregulated as soon as the tenant departs. In a rental building, once a landlord has been successful in evicting a tenant from a rent-stabilized apartment, the landlord can make whatever capital improvements are necessary to bring the rent for the vacant apartment above $2,000, thereby exempting it from rent stabilization.
Mr. Ng explained that by law, the landlord can increase the monthly rent for the apartment by 1/40th of whatever amount has been spent on capital improvements. That amount, when combined with the permitted vacancy allowance of as much as 20 percent, can easily raise the monthly rent of many apartments above the $2,000 threshold.
Alan D. Kucker, a Manhattan lawyer who frequently represents landlords, said that the landlords are basically doing what prudence dictates and the law allows.
"It's no great secret that landlords make decisions based on sound investment analysis," he said. "So when the time is right to rent apartments, they rent them. And when conditions are right to make a profit by selling, they do what they can within the law to sell them."
Arthur I. Weinstein, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said that he, too, has noticed an increase in the number of co-op sponsors and investors using aggressive strategies to remove apartments from regulation. But that, he said, is good news for co-ops.
"Co-ops are very desirous of sponsors selling their units," Mr. Weinstein said, explaining that buildings with high numbers of rental tenants often have difficulty getting financing for share loans and underlying mortgages. "A co-op is absolutely delighted to have as many sponsor sales as possible. It makes for a much healthier co-op."

PUB-DATE: April 23, 2000

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3009 words

HEADLINE: The Bases Are Loaded;
Minor League Baseball Is on a Streak, but How Many Teams Are Too Many?

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
THERE will be speeches. A politician or two will limber up a rusty arm to lob ceremonial first pitches. An umpire will shout the traditional command, and minor-league baseball will come to Long Island, following a trend that has swept the New York region.
The debut of the Long Island Ducks this Friday night, in a gleaming new $19.9 million stadium in Central Islip, will follow a script that has played out several times in just the last six summers in New Jersey, Connecticut and the Hudson Valley. Last year, it happened in Newark and Bridgewater. The year before it was Bridgeport, Conn., and Atlantic City. Next year, under current plans, it will be Camden. 
 A decade ago, the region had only one minor-league team, in New Britain, Conn. This season, with the arrival of the Ducks and new teams in Queens and the Catskills, there will be 16 teams playing in four leagues within 100 miles of Times Square.
Baseball executives cite two overriding reasons for the growth in the region and elsewhere: the popularity of two baseball movies in the past dozen years, "Field of Dreams" and "Bull Durham," and new, fan-friendly stadiums, most of them built with taxpayer money from cities and towns that have turned to the sport for help in reviving run-down or dormant neighborhoods and polishing their images. These communities have pumped millions of state and county dollars into new stadiums; the Ducks alone have reaped nearly $20 million in public funds for their new stadium.
In many places, the investment appears to have paid off. The success of Trenton's team has led to construction of an arena and other new development. Bridgeport, too, is building an arena. The Ducks' new stadium finishes a major redevelopment project in Central Islip that includes a gleaming new federal courthouse, a state courthouse and hundreds of units of new housing.
But as the roster of teams grows, some of the ball clubs are starting to ask how many are too many. In Connecticut, where some of the older teams are leery of an upstart in Bridgeport and a proposed team in Hartford, the old guard is starting to snipe at the newcomers and fret about them muscling in on their territory.
And some industry analysts are wondering just how long the interest will last, and what will happen to public investments if the novelty wanes.
"There certainly is going to be a saturation point," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., and a student of baseball finance. "I think they may be pushing up against it now. But the jury's still out."
For now, experts say a mix of novelty and a fresh love for the age-old essence of baseball has made the minor leagues appealing.
"It represents an older America that we crave," said Michael Aaron Rockland, chairman of the American studies department at Rutgers University. "It represents a softer, sweeter, slower time. Most of us are sick and tired of living by the clock. Here's a game that doesn't go by the clock. Baseball offers us a vision of peace, quietude and timelessness."
Such qualities can also be applied to major-league baseball. But promoters of the minor-league variety add a few more nouns, like value and intimacy. Their games are affordable for most families, with most tickets priced under $10, rivaling movies, bowling alleys and amusement parks.
The new stadiums are closer to home for many fans; the Ducks' new EAB Stadium, for instance, is a godsend for Long Islanders weary of trips west to Shea and Yankee Stadiums.
Lou Ottens of Clinton has forsaken the Yankees for the Somerset Patriots, now two years old, in their new brick and steel stadium in Bridgewater. "Traffic on the George Washington Bridge and the stadium parking lots are too much of a hassle," Mr. Ottens said. "Now I just have to go 20 minutes from my home."
Mr. Ottens stopped by the ballpark the other day and bought seven tickets for the Patriots second home game for $59.50. He and his wife plan to share them with any of their 20 nieces and nephews who want to go to the game. Such an outing to Yankee Stadium would have been too expensive, he said.
"Plus, I honestly feel these players will give you a better game than the guys in the majors because they have something to prove," he said. "They're working with a goal -- they want to get to the majors. Sometimes I feel the guys already there don't particularly give you a good game sometimes."
Bob Tait and his wife, Marion, have tickets for half the Patriots' 70 home games. "It's absolutely great entertainment," Mr. Tait said. "There's thousands of people around here who can't get away from taking care of their kids, so they just take them to the ballpark. It's safe, it's wholesome, it's close to home, and there's great community spirit."
Joe Tozzi, 42, of Piscataway, came to buy two Patriots polo shirts in the park's gift shop, well stocked with team umbrellas, waste cans, caps, clothing and seat cushions. He saw several games last summer with his brother Phil and his nephew, 9, and niece, 5. "It's not as restraining for the kids as Yankee Stadium, where they have to stay in their seats," he said. "Here, they can walk around. It's like a big picnic. Everybody seems to know everybody else."
Last season, the 13 minor-league clubs that played in the region drew nearly 2.7 million fans. The Yankees drew 3.3 million fans, a team record, and the Mets attracted 2.8 million, and officials of both teams say they are not worried about losing fans.
"There's enough baseball fans out there," said Jason Zillo, a spokesman for the Yankees. "People want to see good baseball and right now we're providing that to the fans."
But David Howard, the Mets senior vice president for business affairs, criticized the level of play on teams without organizational links to the majors.
"While it may be entertainment, it's not going to be high quality baseball," Mr. Howard said. "When the fans come out to Shea, they will appreciate even more so that we have the best athletes in the world playing the game on an entirely different level."
The new ballparks hold from 5,000 to 7,000 fans. They all have bright, well-stocked concession stands, seating close to the field and excellent sight lines. Most have picnic pavilions and playgrounds, video arcades, plenty of music and flashy outfield scoreboards with big video screens. Team mascots mingle with fans. Children celebrating birthdays are serenaded by the stadium organist, with the fans joining in. Players are routinely made available for autographs. Promotional giveaways are common. Before the Atlantic City Surf's games, the team president, Ken Shepard, sells freshly baked chocolate chip cookies, 2 for $1, behind home plate.
Cultural experts say something deeper than gimmickry has spurred the resurgence. Sean Wilentz, a history professor at Princeton University and director of its American Studies Program, cites "baby boomer nostalgia."
"You feel closer to the players, closer to the other fans," Professor Wilentz said. "It's a more human feel. And then there's all this cornball stuff, the little contests. It's much more community-oriented. And there's none of the drunkenness and vulgarity you see at some major-league stadiums."
Fifty years ago, long before the minor leagues refashioned themselves as family-friendly, the teams were little more than training grounds for potential major-leaguers in hundreds of small towns and moderate-sized cities. At the height of their popularity in 1949 the leagues drew nearly 40 million fans.
But in the early 1950's, attendance started eroding with the rapid spread of television and home air-conditioning, said Miles Wolff, commissioner of the Northern League, one of the five independent leagues. The slump continued during the Vietnam War and the sour political and cultural mood it created, he said. By 1969, minor-league attendance had slipped to about 10 million. It remained stagnant for about 15 years. Now it's back to where it was before, with attendance of 40.2 million in 1999.
At the game's low point in the New York region a decade ago, only New Britain fielded a team.
Then in 1994 and 1995, three new regional teams joined New Britain in the Eastern League, a Class AA league two steps below the majors: The Trenton Thunder (Red Sox), the Norwich Navigators (Yankees) and the New Haven Ravens (Mariners). At the same time, the New York-Penn League, a Class A league, three rungs below the majors, came to the region with the Hudson Valley Renegades (Tampa Bay Devil Rays) in Fishkill in Dutchess County, and the New Jersey Cardinals (St. Louis) in rural Sussex County. Last season, the league added the Staten Island Yankees (Yankees) and this summer will add the Queens Kings (Toronto).
Fan acceptance of the two affiliated leagues has attracted two independent leagues, the Atlantic and the Northern. Neither is bound by the restrictive territorial rules that govern minor leagues linked to the majors. Therefore, they can play wherever they are welcome.
The Atlantic has five teams playing this season in the region, and the Northern has three, The New Jersey Jackals, at Yogi Berra Stadium in Little Falls; the Waterbury (Conn.) Spirit and the Catskill Cougars in Mountain Dale, N.Y., near Monticello. The eight independent teams draw their players from youngsters never signed by major league teams and veterans who once played in the affiliated minor leagues or the majors and hope to return to them.
The Atlantic League, now entering its third season, has been the most bullish about expansion, emphasizing baseball as a tool of urban renewal. Its attractive new stadiums, all publicly financed, have gone up in Atlantic City, Bridgeport, Newark and Bridgewater.
Now, the Long Island Ducks start play in the Atlantic League, with Bud Harrelson, star shortstop for the Mets a generation ago and a team co-owner, serving as its manager. The mastermind of the Ducks, and the Atlantic League, is Frank Boulton, the team chairman now enjoying a happy ending to a campaign he started in the early 1990's to bring professional baseball to his native Long Island.
"It's very rewarding, a great sense of accomplishment," Mr. Boulton said of the Ducks, the league's seven other teams, and the one planned for Camden next summer. "Some people like to say I have great vision. I like to say I have a hard head."
Mr. Boulton, 49-year-old former high school catcher in Brightwaters, his hometown, is the renegade of the region's baseball world. He once was an executive in the Yankee system and a vice president of the Eastern League. He wanted to transfer a Yankee farm team from Albany to Long Island. But the Mets vetoed the move in 1993 as a violation of their territorial rights.
Instead, Mr. Boulton created the Atlantic League, free of the rules giving major-league clubs and their farm teams power to keep new teams from their territories. The newcomers have sharpened competition for fans and shrunk the older teams' geographic markets. Of the four Atlantic League teams now playing, the Somerset Patriots and Bridgeport Bluefish have been the most popular, drawing home crowds last year that averaged 5,235 and 4,571, respectively. Of all the regional teams, only the Trenton Thunder drew more, an average of 6,197.
Officials of the Somerset club, brimming with confidence after a successful first year, now want to set up a team in Bergen County, New Jersey's most populous county. The county executive, William Schuber, is enthusiastic and has ordered a feasibility study. But members of Bergen's Board of Chosen Freeholders have vowed to block any use of public parkland or public money for a stadium.
"Why should taxpayers pay for a private business?" asked the board's most vocal critic, James J. Sheehan. "This is not an essential. I'm opposed to subsidizing the entertainment industry. If it's so successful, they should get financing from a bank."
Mr. Boulton suggested that Camden may be the Atlantic League's last team in New Jersey.
"It's getting pretty dense there," he said. "We have to be real smart about our growth."
For now, he said, the league is looking at Massachusetts and Virginia as possible expansion sites. The league already has teams in Maryland, New Hampshire and Pennsylvania.
Economic development and other government officials praise the urban renewal value of the teams and the new stadiums, more for burnishing the images of downtowns and enticing new investment than creating thousands of new inner-city jobs. The Newark Bears' new stadium opened last year a few blocks from the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which opened in 1997 and started the city's downtown renaissance.
George Gatta, deputy Suffolk County executive of planning and economic development, said the Long Island Ducks' new stadium completes the transformation of "one of the worst neighborhoods" in the county.
And in Bridgeport, Conn., the 18-acre waterfront site where the Bluefish play was once filled with abandoned factories and stores, empty gasoline stations and some burned-out houses. Now a $45 million, 10,000-seat arena and a 900-car parking garage for railroad commuters and baseball fans are going up at the site.
Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's director of planning and economic development, said the stadium had changed the image of that piece of downtown Bridgeport. Commuters passing the site on the Metro-North Railroad once saw abandoned factories covered with graffiti. "Now they see 5,000 fans waving at them," Mr. Freimuth said. "That changes one's mind-set about an older city. If image improves, value increases and value draws investment."
The same thing has happened in Trenton since Mercer County and the state invested $21 million for the ballpark that opened on the Delaware River in 1994.
An empty factory filled the plot, and private developers had no interest in it. The county government gambled on a minor-league stadium, at the time a rarity in New Jersey. The Thunder prospered beyond expectation. The stadium has spurred major riverfront redevelopment, including a county-financed $52 million arena for minor-league hockey and basketball, conversion of an abandoned steel factory into 500 units of senior-citizen housing and a strip mall and supermarket, new office buildings and a new nightclub.
"It's not the cure-all, but it certainly got the image of Trenton changed for the positive," James Lambert, executive director of the Mercer County Improvement Authority, said of baseball.
But last season, when the Somerset Patriots moved in about 20 miles north of Trenton, the Thunder's average home attendance dropped to 6,197 from 6,628. That still left the Thunder ranked among the top 25 minor-league clubs in the country, but it was the team's first attendance drop in its six seasons of play.
Rick Brenner, the team's general manager, said the Patriots were not a factor in the drop. He blamed highway construction near the stadium, which caused the cancellation of six afternoon games popular with day campers. Both Mr. Brenner and officials in Somerset said they did not believe the two teams were competing for fans.
Similarly, officials of the Newark Bears and the New Jersey Jackals said they did not think they were chasing the same fans, even though their stadiums were only about 10 miles apart.
"There are probably still a million people in northern New Jersey who don't know about the New Jersey Jackals," said Leo Kirk, the team's general manager. "In two to three years, we'll probably have saturated the market enough to know where we stand with the Bears."
Joseph Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers and a vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers, said the region's economy was at its strongest point in a generation. The minor-league expansion, Dr. Seneca said, was not stretched too thin.
"This region can accommodate a lot," he said. "It's a huge market."
But in Connecticut, the three Eastern League teams are jittery about competition. Attendance for the New Haven and Norwich teams had already been slipping when the Bridgeport Bluefish came to their new stadium in 1998. The Bluefish drew an average crowd of about 4,500 last year, while New Haven and Norwich had averages of about 2,900 and 3,700, respectively. Both the Ravens and Navigators had drawn more than 4,000 people in their first two years of operation in 1994 and 1995.
Executives of Connecticut's older teams have started fighting back against the newcomers by touting their major-league affiliations and criticizing the newer teams' play as bush league.
William F. Dowling, an owner of the New Britain Rock Cats and a former Yankee executive, called the quality of baseball in the independent leagues "glorified American Legion."
"We've got bona fide potential major leaguers," he said. "All you get in the independents are some retreads and players no one else is interested in." In Norwich, the uniforms of the Navigators this season will sport the Yankees' logo of top hat and bat as a reminder that the team is part of the Yankee system.
"What's Bridgeport going to do, put a fish on their uniforms?" said Norwich's general manager, Brian Mahoney.
But Mr. Boulton, head of the Ducks and the Atlantic League, called criticism of his league's players unfair. He said half of the league's 150 players last season had once played in the major leagues and many were hoping to return. Mr. Boulton said he believed the league's players were closer to AAA, the top level of player development, than to Class A or the instructional leagues, the lowest farm teams with the rawest prospects just out of high school or college.
Mr. Kirk, general manager of the Jackals of the Northern League, said that league considered its quality of play to be somewhere between Class A and AA. "As long as we're good and competitive, it doesn't make any difference if it's A or double-A or triple-A," Mr. Kirk said. "Frankly, the people don't care if they're having a good time."

HEADLINE: Take Me Out to the Crowd;
Hope of Urban Renewal Leads to an Explosion of Minor-League Teams

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:

"It's very rewarding, a great sense of accomplishment," Mr. Boulton said of the Ducks, the league's four other active teams, and the one planned for Camden next summer. "Some people like to say I have great vision. I like to say I have a hard head."
Mr. Boulton, a 49-year-old former high school catcher, is the renegade of the region's baseball world. He once was an executive in the Yankee system and a vice president of the Eastern League. He wanted to transfer a Yankee farm team from Albany to Long Island. But the Mets vetoed the move in 1993 as a violation of their territorial rights.
Instead, Mr. Boulton created the Atlantic League, free of the rules giving major-league clubs and their farm teams power to keep new teams from their territories. The newcomers have sharpened competition for fans and shrunk the older teams' geographic markets. Of the four Atlantic League teams now playing, the Somerset Patriots and Bridgeport Bluefish have been the most popular, drawing home crowds that averaged 5,235 and 4,571, respectively, last year. Of all the regional teams, only the Trenton Thunder drew more, an average of 6,197.
Officials of the Somerset club, brimming with confidence after a successful first year, now want to set up a team in Bergen County, New Jersey's most populous county. The county executive, William Schuber, is enthusiastic and has ordered a feasibility study. But members of Bergen's Board of Chosen Freeholders have vowed to block any use of public parkland or public money for a stadium.
"Why should taxpayers pay for a private business?" asked the board's most vocal critic, James J. Sheehan. "This is not an essential. I'm opposed to subsidizing the entertainment industry. If it's so successful, they should get financing from a bank."
Mr. Boulton suggested that Camden may be the Atlantic League's last team in New Jersey.
"It's getting pretty dense there," he said. "We have to be real smart about our growth."
For now, he said, the league is looking at Massachusetts and Virginia as possible expansion sites. The league already has teams in Maryland, New Hampshire and Pennsylvania.
Economic development and other government officials praise the urban renewal value of the teams and the new stadiums, more for burnishing the images of downtowns and enticing new investment than creating thousands of new inner-city jobs. The Newark Bears' new stadium opened last year a few blocks from the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which opened in 1997 and started the city's downtown renaissance.
George Gatta, deputy Suffolk County executive of planning and economic development, said the Long Island Ducks' new stadium completes the transformation of "one of the worst neighborhoods" in the county.
In Connecticut, the three Eastern League teams are jittery about all the competition. Attendance for the New Haven and Norwich teams had already been slipping when the Bridgeport Bluefish came to their new stadium in 1998. The Bluefish drew an average crowd of about 4,500 last year, while New Haven and Norwich had averages of about 2,900 and 3,700, respectively. Both the Ravens and Navigators had drawn more than 4,000 people in their first two years of operation in 1994 and 1995.
Chris Canetti, New Haven's general manager, said that Bridgeport has taken some of his team's fans in Fairfield and Westchester counties.
"It's hard to compete with a new $20 million ballpark with every fan amenity imaginable," said Mr. Canetti, whose team plays at 73-year-old Yale Field.
To the north, the owners of the New Britain Rock Cats are nervous about Hartford's hopes to build a $15 million stadium along the Connecticut River for a Northern League team now in Massachusetts. Gov. John G. Rowland opposes giving Hartford any state money because he fears undercutting the state's $12 million investment in 1995 in a new stadium in New Britain, 11 miles from Hartford, said a spokesman, Dean Pagani.
William F. Dowling, one of New Britain's new owners and a former executive vice president of the New York Yankees, praised the state's decision as a wise regional approach to minor-league baseball in Connecticut. New Britain's attendance has lagged behind that of the other regional teams for years. Its new owners have mounted an aggressive new marketing campaign to attract new fans. And they were buoyed by a record crowd of 6,452 at the Rock Cats's opening game on April 7.
Hartford's mayor, Michael P. Peters, is looking to the private sector to help finance a stadium for Hartford's first minor-league team in 50 years.
Waterbury wants to build a new $10 million stadium to replace the 70-year-old home field of its team, the Spirit, of the Northern League. Governor Rowland has not ruled out state money for Waterbury because its marketing area does not overlap New Britain's, Mr. Pagani said.
Joseph Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers and a vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers, said that the region's economy is at its strongest point in a generation. The minor-league expansion, he said, was not stretched too thin.
"This region can accommodate a lot," Dr. Seneca said. "It's a huge market."
Still, executives of Connecticut's older teams have started fighting back against the newcomers by touting their major-league affiliations and criticizing the newer teams' play as bush league.
Mr. Dowling called the quality of baseball in the independent leagues "glorified American Legion."
"We've got bonafide potential major leaguers," he said. "All you get in the independents are some retreads and players no one else is interested in." In Norwich, the uniforms of the Navigators this season will sport the Yankees' logo of top hat and bats as a constant reminder that the team is part of the Yankee system.
"What's Bridgeport going to do, put a fish on their uniforms?" said Norwich's general manager, Brian Mahoney.
Mr. Boulton, head of the Ducks and the Atlantic League, called criticism of his league's players unfair. He said half of the league's 150 players last season had once played in the major leagues and many were hoping to return. Mr. Boulton said he believed the league's players were closer to Class AAA, the top level of player development, than to Class A or the instructional leagues, the lowest farm teams with the rawest prospects just out of high school or college.
Mr. Kirk, general manager of the Jackals of the Northern League, said that league considers its quality of play to be somewhere between Class A and AA. "As long as we're good and competitive, it doesn't make any difference if it's A or Double A or Triple A," Mr. Kirk said. "Frankly, the people don't care if they're having a good time."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk
