HEADLINE: The View From/New Haven;
25 Years Later, Antiwar Activists Are Still Involved in Cause

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
THIS coming weekend marks the 25th anniversary of the end of the war in Vietnam -- the time in 1975 that helicopters lifted off from the roof of the American Embassy in Saigon, ending the United States military presence.
Antiwar advocates in New Haven, who have remained active over the past quarter-century, are planning a commemoration called "The War Then, the War Now: 25 Years After Vietnam, What Did the U.S. Learn?" 
 The event, which consists of speeches and music, will take place Saturday from 2 to 4 p.m. at Center Church on the Green. Another commemoration is planned the following day in New York City at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue.
Featured speakers in Connecticut will be Ngo Vinh Long and Kathleen Cleaver. Mr. Long, while a Vietnamese student studying in the United States, helped lead opposition to the war. He currently teaches history at the University of Maine.
Al Marder, another organizer of the event, said Mr. Long was invited because "he is profoundly knowledgeable, one of our outstanding scholars in the field of Asian history." Mr. Long had supported the government of North Vietnam and the National Liberation Front, the formal name for the Viet Cong, in the South, which made him controversial among many Vietnamese immigrants to the United States.
Ms. Cleaver, 54, was a leader of the Black Panther Party, which took a strong antiwar position from its early days.
There haven't been any previous commemorations of the antiwar movement like this, Mr. Marder said, and he added that he hoped there wouldn't be any negative response. He said the event would be one of "reconciliation and understanding," especially regarding Vietnam veterans.
"We looked at G.I.'s as victims, not fomenters," he said. A veteran will also be speaking at the event.
Mr. Marder considers the last few months of protests against the World Trade Organization, International Monetary Fund and World Bank, especially the involvement of young people, as "seminal events, bringing students, labor, peace movement people together." He said it made the connection from the antiwar movement to the current upsurge in activism, which was at the heart of why this event had been organized.


 Stephen Kobasa, one of the planning committee members, graduated from Seymour High School in 1965 and saw his first antiwar demonstration that same year in New Haven. "I discovered the world," he said, "and became a conscientious objector." He attended Fairfield University and wrote to his draft board, asking for a meeting to discuss his views. The draft board refused to see him, so he sent back his draft card, which was punishable by up to five years in prison.
"I'm still waiting to hear from them," he said. "The system does not always confront you. Sometimes it treats you with indifference." That taught him an important lesson, he said. "The system can't legitimate your resistance -- you have to do that on your own."
Mr. Kobasa, 52, was involved with the part of the movement known as the Catholic Left and provided support for covert and overt antiwar actions. He attended Yale Divinity School from 1969-72, where he organized support for the Black Panthers. He said he was not nostalgic about that period because he saw a lot of faults within the movement, where sexism, racism and self-righteousness blunted the dreams of freedom and equality. Mr. Kobasa lives in New Haven with his wife and two daughters, and teaches at a Bridgeport Catholic high school. This seemingly average existence has been punctuated by a dozen arrests and short stints in jail.
"I'm still struggling to be a conscientious objector," he said. "It's not a one-time thing. We live in a society that's defined by violence."
Mr. Marder, 78, said the war "radicalized people, mostly young people, who saw our country invade another country with no justification."
As a result, he added, "they are radicalized for life, and no longer accept their government's blandishments unquestioningly."
Virginia Simon, 75, is another New Havener who did not fit the stereotype of the young hippie protester; she said she always resented that cliche. She was a middle-aged mother of four young adults and got drawn into the antiwar movement when she saw how the war affected them.
Ms. Simon headed a group in New Haven called the Peace and Justice Coalition. She went to Washington, D.C., almost every month for meetings or rallies. She worked especially with other women, many from church organizations -- "ladies in our 40's, 50's and 60's," as she put it. "There was this tremendous impetus to try to stop this craziness," she said.
By the time the war ended, an estimated three million Vietnamese, military and civilian, both in the north and south, had been killed, along with 58,000 American military personnel. But there was a big emotional reward, said Ms. Simon of the rallies. "There is so little opportunity to share what you believe and what you feel with a significant number of people," she said.
For the past 25 years Ms. Simon has been an active member of the Greater New Haven Peace Council. She said people had found many ways to stay active. "They may not be doing the same kind of thing, but they are doing something to help their community."
Ms. Cleaver, a Guilford resident, has Vietnam War-era memories that span the globe. In 1970, while the trial of some members of the Black Panther Party was taking place in New Haven, Ms. Cleaver and her husband at the time, Eldridge Cleaver, founded the international section of the party in Algiers in the former headquarters of the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam.
Also that year, an American People's Anti-Imperialist Delegation, co-led by Mr. Cleaver, went to Vietnam. "The party was deeply involved in antiwar activity and in solidarity with the people of Vietnam," Ms. Cleaver said. "You had Martin Luther King Jr. wondering how long he could ask young men to be nonviolent in the face of a country that was so violent," she said, adding that two factors led to an "explosive growth" in the Black Panther Party: one was Dr. King's assassination, and the other was the growing number of returning black Vietnam veterans.
She said it was impossible to put the war behind her, "because it destroyed the social fabric in the African-American community -- especially through the introduction of massive amounts of heroin and other drugs -- and widened the gap between rich and poor."
Ms. Cleaver returned to the United States in 1975, and several years later graduated from Yale College and Yale Law School. She now works at the New York Public Library Center for Scholars and Writers and is writing a book about the revolutionary movement.
"I'm trying to be a chronicler of attempts to bring about change," she said. "I'm older now. I have different responsibilities. But I see the same things now that disturbed me then: racism, exploitation. What really disturbs me is the militarization of the police, which is also a direct result of the war in Vietnam."
With the Gulf War, former President George Bush said that the United States was cured of its so-called Vietnam syndrome, which limited military intervention abroad because of the potential threat of massive resistance at home.
"I think we should never be cured of the Vietnam syndrome," Mr. Kobasa said. "I don't think it's an illness, it's a state of health."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
You Can Take the Boy Out of Camden . . .

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY; Irvin Molotsky, a Washington correspondent for The New York Times, was a member of the Camden High School class of 1956.

 BODY:
MARTIN SHERMAN, Camden High School class of 1956, left his hometown and went on to become a successful playwright, something that doesn't surprise the former Angela Ciccotelli very much.
While still in his neo-Shakespearean phase (that is, in the fifth grade), young Martin wrote a play, "Homlio and Roulette," casting his friend Angela in the lead female role, not the least because the Ciccotelli backyard in the Parkside neighborhood was larger than most. 
 He remembered her performance. He autographed her copy of the 1956 Camden High School yearbook to "the first little actress since Marilyn Monroe who laughs when she should cry (last scene)."
Mr. Sherman, as so many others did, left Camden at the first opportunity, and when his little star, now Angela Ciccotelli Mulloy, saw him recently it was for the first time in 44 years.
She and five other members of the class of 1956 joined Mr. Sherman for a small reunion, lunch in a theater district restaurant in Manhattan, and opening night for his new play, "Rose," at the Lyceum Theater on Broadway.
It is a one-woman play about a Holocaust survivor, a subject Mr. Sherman has written about before, starring Olympia Dukakis.
"Everyone always says I look like Olympia Dukakis," said Helene Goldman Singer, who postponed a trip to Paris to attend opening night. At the cast party at Sardi's after the performance, Ms. Dukakis agreed that there was a resemblance and gave Ms. Singer permission to sign autographs for overly insistent fans.
Members of the Camden High School class of 1956 do not get to go to many Broadway opening nights or cast parties at Sardi's. The events brought back memories of their childhoods in the once-prospering city that is no longer recognizable to them.
Nancy Lemerman Hermann's parents owned a candy store that was across the street from the Parkside Theater, a movie house that no longer exists. In fact, there are no movie houses at all in Camden now. And the Walt Whitman Hotel, where the class of 1956 held its prom, is gone as well.
RCA Victor, which made most of America's first television sets in Camden, is gone. Campbell's Soup, which fed several generations of children their lunchtime tomato soup, is mostly gone. The New York Shipbuilding Corporation, which built the warships that helped the American victories in the two world wars, is gone.
In 1950, not long before Mr. Sherman's class graduated from high school, Camden's population hit its peak: 124,555. That class of 1956 was in the advance guard of leaving town and Camden's population last year was estimated at 83,546 -- so many of them unemployed, on welfare and addicted that the city seems to totter. Even the mayor is under indictment, the third mayor in 20 years to face criminal charges.
Before things started falling apart, there was a lot going on in Camden.
Dr. Michael Grossman, another former grad, remembers the radio program broadcast each week on WCAM, a station then owned by the city, which had studios on the top floor of the City Hall. The program was produced by the Y.M.C.A., which no longer exists, and was across the street from Camden Catholic High School, which also no longer exists.
While a student at Hatch Junior High School, Mr. Sherman wrote, directed and starred in a 15-minute segment of the program, a sitcom he called "The Adventures of Don and Henry."
Dr. Grossman, a cast member who put aside acting in later life to become an obstetrician-gynecologist (he was, after all, voted most likely to succeed), said, "I don't remember how many programs we did, but I am sure we were great."
The recollections of Mr. Sherman (class actor in 1956) are not quite the same. "We just giggled a lot on the air," he said.
Dr. Grossman made the trip for opening night from Cherry Hill, as did another 1956 graduate, Myrna Caplan Fineman, who teaches emotionally disturbed youth at the Brookfield Academy. Ms. Fineman probably has seen more of Mr. Sherman's plays than any of his longtime friends, including "Bent," his story of gay men killed during the Holocaust, and "When She Danced," the story of Isadora Duncan.
Ms. Hermann (Miss Personality in 1956, Ms. not yet having been invented) came from Scotch Plains, where she markets commercial carpet backings made by the Dow Chemical Company.
Ms. Singer came from Reading, Pa., where she runs a travel agency, and Ms. Mulloy came from Orange, Va., where she and her husband, Richard Brown, run Willow Grove Inn, a 1790's plantation house converted to a bed and breakfast with a restaurant that is among the most outstanding in the stretch from Washington to Charlottesville. One old grad came from Washington.
Mr. Sherman came the farthest, from London, where he now lives and where he has been able to get his plays produced more quickly than New York. He is a gay man and Jewish, and homosexuality and the Holocaust figure in many of his plays.
Ms. Fineman remembered the odd parties that Mr. Sherman organized as a boy. There was one, she recalled, when he served some candy and then announced to his friends that they had just eaten chocolate-covered grasshoppers. That was very funny stuff in the 1950's.
At the reunion lunch, after he got over the mortification of being photographed by his old friends at such a hip theater district restaurant as Joe Allen's, Mr. Sherman remembered his favorite party stunt.
"I told everyone that there was going to be a surprise guest," he said. "Then I left through the back door, ran around to the front and came in, the surprise guest at my own party." Not quite the level of Tom Sawyer watching his own funeral but very funny in Camden.
Dr. Grossman and Mr. Sherman were in the boys' finals of Camden High's annual public speaking contest that year. Dr. Grossman said: "Martin did 'The Treasurer's Report' by Robert Benchley. He was absolutely hilarious. I did 'John Brown's Body' -- very dramatic. Martin should have won, but comedy never wins, so I won."
Dr. Grossman remembered Mr. Sherman's family, his father, Joseph, and his mother, Julia. "Joe Sherman was the first ever public defender in Camden County," he said. "He then returned to practice criminal law. He took clients who could barely afford to pay. He was a legend among local attorneys."
Sad things happened in Camden in those days. "Mother had Huntington's disease," Mr. Sherman said. "She was increasingly bedridden, certainly during the last 15 years of her life. It is a horrible, horrible disease."
Mean things happened. "There was a girl in the class who everyone hated," Mr. Sherman said. "I don't know why. So I befriended her. She wanted to become a jazz singer. I don't think it's a story that ended well."
Tragic things happened. Some thuggish boys beat up on Mr. Sherman, who looked frail as a youth, and there was a disturbed boy named Joseph Ernst. "He would occasionally come in to homeroom and show his collection of pictures of baseball players," Mr. Sherman said, "and the teacher and everyone else ignored him, so I feigned interest in baseball, and he protected me."
Not many years later, Joseph Ernst murdered his girlfriend when she tried to break off their relationship. He was executed in the state prison electric chair in Trenton a few years later.
"Rose" won awards and critics gave it rave reviews in London. Not so in New York.
The critic of The New York Times, Bruce Weber, said that "for all its picaresque detail, her story resonates on the tired frequency of a lecture about the wages of forgetting the past.' The New York Post's critic, Donald Lyons, wrote: "The play, an insufferable lecture, is Martin Sherman's imagining the past, not surprising from one who imagined himself a gay victim of the Nazis in the 1997 film 'Bent.' "
On the other hand, the critic in The Daily News, Fintan O'Toole, felt that "Rose" marked "a real maturing" for Mr. Sherman by adding the element of restraint that had been missing in his earlier work.
There was no restraint among the six longtime friends from the Camden High School class of 1956. "It is blissful to see Martin so successful," Ms. Singer said.

(Photographs by Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 790 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/AT&T Headquarters at 195 Broadway;
A Bellwether Building Where History Was Made

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
WE didn't find anything that was in keeping with its history," said John Heath, a spokesman for AT&T, explaining its decision, which became known last week, not to move its signature Golden Boy statue back to Manhattan.
The possibility of a park had been suggested -- and vigorously endorsed -- by Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern. Other possibilities were Golden Boy's original location atop the old AT&T Building at 195 Broadway or at the city-owned building at 346 Broadway, the former New York Life Insurance Building. But AT&T decided to leave Golden Boy where he now is, in front of its operational headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J. 
 Mr. Heath said that AT&T never seriously considered the pyramid on which the sculpture originally stood at 195 Broadway. For Peter S. Kalikow, the developer who bought building from AT&T in 1983, it will always be the missing element in a $3 million restoration. "I still want to put Golden Boy back," he said.
 The statue was created under the aegis of Theodore N. Vail, AT&T's president who was something of a golden boy himself. He learned telegraphy is his early 20's, first at Western Union and then at the Union Pacific Railroad, where he rose quickly by making striking improvements in fast mail service. When Vail became the general manager of the nascent Bell Telephone Company, he moved it to New York and extended its reach into long distance and telephone manufacturing, organizing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to oversee its growing empire.
 Vail became the president of AT&T in 1907 and of Western Union in 1909, when AT&T acquired it, promising important economies of scale. To house this new enterprise, Vail planned a new 29-story headquarters at 195 Broadway in 1912, to be built in two parts along the full blockfront from Dey to Fulton Streets.
 The first part, at the Dey Street corner with an L-shaped wing connecting to Fulton Street, was not completed until 1916. So in 1915, when Alexander Graham Bell completed the first cross-country telephone call, he had to do it from another telephone company building on the south side of Dey Street. In that call, Bell repeated his famous words of 1876 -- "Mr. Watson, come here, I want you" -- to Thomas A. Watson in San Francisco.
 WHILE the building was going up, AT&T spun off Western Union in 1913, amid antitrust allegations. About this time, AT&T had commissioned Evelyn Beatrice Longman, a sculptor, to design an appropriate statue for its new building. The statue was a 24-foot winged male figure in gilded bronze, standing atop a globe, encircled by cables and holding electric bolts in one hand. She called the finished work "Genius of Telegraphy."
By the time it was installed on the stepped pyramidal top of the Fulton Street wing of the AT&T Building in 1916, however, Western Union was gone, and the statue was renamed "Genius of Electricity." The official name was changed once more, in the 1930's, to "Spirit of Communication," reflecting the company's evolution. But it was the Golden Boy nickname that stuck.
 World War I delayed the Fulton Street half of the AT&T Building, which was finally completed in 1922. It presented a massive neo-Classical rebuke to the Beaux-Arts froufrou of earlier downtown skyscrapers. Layer upon layer of Doric and Ionic columns in cool gray granite rose up like an ancient monument. Welles Bosworth, its architect, designed the lobby as a forest of 43 giant marble columns, notable in their Doric simplicity, one of the great commercial interiors of the city.
 American Architect magazine noted that this emphasis on simplicity extended to the smallest details: "There are no manufacturers' names to be seen anywhere in the building, not even in the elevators. It is a relief to the tired brain, not to be forced to read lettering on all the fixtures, as has been so universally customary in this country. One sees no name placarded on the exterior of this building. It needs none."
 Mr. Bosworth worked extensively for the Rockefeller family -- he designed Kykuit, their Westchester estate -- and in 1924 moved to France to supervise the Rockefeller-financed restoration of Versailles.
Although the first cross-country call was placed from another building, the first trans-Atlantic call, to London in 1927, was made from 195 Broadway, said Dr. Sheldon Hochheiser, AT&T's corporate historian.
In 1980, the Landmarks Preservation Commission proposed the lobby of 195 Broadway for landmark designation, although it never acted. In 1983, AT&T moved to new headquarters at Madison Avenue and 55th Street and installed Golden Boy at the entrance. In 1992, when AT&T leased the building to Sony, Golden Boy was moved to Basking Ridge.

All that remains of the original statue, formally the "Spirit of Communication," is the pyramid on which it once stood. HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
All Eyes Are on Fort Lee

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: FORT LEE

 BODY:
Ralph Larsen could have been almost anywhere on Tuesday morning.
Cloud Nine would have been one good place. Or maybe teeing off at Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, where he is a member. 
 Mr. Larsen is the chief executive of Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick, and his company, the subject of a glowing cover story in the latest issue of Barron's, reported outstanding quarterly earnings that morning. Its stock was headed up four points in the first hour of trading.
But where Mr. Larsen chose to be was in a rather undistinguished office building on Fletcher Avenue here, since that is where what happens in business is really happening these days. On the sixth floor -- just north of the KFC and across the street from the Red Oak Diner -- is CNBC, the most popular financial news network in the world.
After getting made up, Mr. Larsen would have a few minutes on the air with Ted David, the CNBC anchor of "Market Watch," telling his compadres and competitors alike how wonderful things are at Johnson & Johnson.
"I'm getting more comfortable at this," Mr. Larsen said about his time on CNBC. "You have to. This is important for us."
More and more, New Jersey-based CNBC is becoming the epicenter of the world of financial news. On Friday, April 14, when the Dow Jones industrial average nosedived 618 points, the Nielsen company counted more than a million viewers tuned to the network from 4:15 to 4:30 p.m., just after trading closed on the stock market.
"Nielsen doesn't count bars and trading floors and offices, so you've got to figure that could be up by a factor of three," said Joe Kernen, a CNBC stock market reporter, known for his "Winners and Losers" segments. "We are essential news for anyone who wants to know what happens on Wall Street."
And CNBC is not NBC's only hand in New Jersey. Its sister cable news network, MSNBC, is situated farther south, in Secaucus. The network's presence, if only out of convenience, opens for the nation a window on New Jersey.
On Tuesday, for example, Ben & Jerry's was celebrating its anniversary by giving out ice cream cones. The company was also announcing its quarterly earnings -- not as robust as expected -- so CNBC's afternoon producer, Andy Hoffman, sent a crew to Ben & Jerry's on Palisades Avenue in downtown Englewood to illustrate the story.
"We could have done it anywhere, but why not here in New Jersey," said Mr. Hoffman. "When Kohl's was expanding, we went to a Kohl's on Route 4. It was a legitimate business story, and we could illustrate it close by. And we're always mentioning Fort Lee on the network."
Since merging with the Financial News Network in 1991, CNBC -- a sister cable network of NBC, which is owned by General Electric -- its viewership has increased tenfold -- to an average 323,000 households ecah business day, in some measure due to Wall Street's continuing bull market.
"The long good times for stocks means more people own them, which means more people care about watching us," said Mr. Kernen. "I've been on the tarmac at the airport and some baggage guys said, 'Hey, say something good about Continental so the stock goes up.' "
Little wonder that some of those formerly faceless financial reporters who regularly roam the highways and mini-malls of North Jersey have had cases of mini-stardom. Take Mr. Kernen, who has been profiled by several national magazines. And Ron Insana, the anchor on the program "Street Signs," appears regularly on many NBC news programs as well as the nationally syndicated "Imus in the Morning" radio show -- which is also broadcast on MSNBC.
Another of CNBC's market reporters, Maria Bartiromo, has even been Regis Philbin's guest co-host on ABC's "Live with Regis and Kathie Lee."
But the soul of CBNC may be the three wise guys who appear on "Squawk Box" from 7 to 10 a.m. -- which Mr. Kernen affectionately calls "our pre-game show." Mr. Kernen and his stock-reporting sidekick, David Faber, banter while reporting the mornings business news with the program's anchor, Mark Haines.
"I couldn't be here and be boring about business news," said Mr. Haines, who was a local news anchor in New York and Philadelphia before attending law school at the University of Pennsylvania and then coming to CNBC. "We have to inject a little fun into it. About five years ago, things weren't going all that well in the morning, so management said, 'O.K., try it your way.' It gives us a healthy perspective."
The group has popularized the Alan Greenspan Briefcase Index, which has been uncanny in predicting the moves by the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee to raise and lower interest rates. Alerted by a viewer, Mr. Haines -- a Plainfield native who now lives in Monmouth County -- researched tapes and noted that when Mr. Greenspan, the head of the Federal Reserve, carried a fat briefcase to the meetings, interest rates rose; a thin briefcase indicated lower rates.
For a time, when Mr. Faber, called "The Brain" by his co-anchors, reported on Priceline.com, the hotel and airline Internet company whose advertisements feature William Shatner, the "Star Trek" theme would play.
More often than not, however, Mr. Kernen and the rest are deadly serious about getting their information right.
And "Squawk Box" viewers, particularly day traders, can hang on Mr. Kernen's every word.
"I may do a tease going into a commercial like, say, 'There's a biotech stock with some interesting results,' " he said. 'By the time we come back, they've figured out what I was previewing and the stock could be up or down three points. It's daunting."
Mr. Kernen, an eight-handicap golfer at Baltusrol and a former stockbroker,said: "I'm an unabashed capitalist. I like bull markets and I'm not fond of bear markets. A strong economy is good for everyone. A day like last Friday, well, I don't like those days, but I guess they keep people watching.'
A resident of Englewood, Mr. Kernen added, "One day we may even be able to get Faber over here from that Sodom, New York."
And like a real Jersey guy, he then drove across Fletcher Avenue for lunch at the Linwood Plaza strip mall.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Putting Technology Jobs On Women's Career Radar

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MY wife, Christine Negroni, has just published a book. After she's done with the signings and interviews, she moves to the mundane world of the once-published. What, she has to decide, will she do next?
Writing another book would be satisfying, but not necessarily profitable. Broadcast journalism, her previous career, is profitable, but not necessarily satisfying. She is looking for a challenge. She wants to do good. And she wouldn't mind making some money. 
 If this were a different economy, I'd just laugh. Instead, I said, "Try the Internet."
"You're kidding," she replied. After all, she has little interest in computers.
Many information technology companies are scrambling to fill all the jobs they have created, and even with stock market uncertainty some have tapped a ready supply of workers -- women who have been out of the work force. Women Work, an organization based in Washington, says there are 35 million stay-at-home moms in the United States, many of them eager to have jobs. And companies are eager to train them, computer skills or no.
Jill Miller, director of Women Work, said it has set up programs with companies like Intel and Time Warner to ease women into high-technology jobs. "Stay-at-home moms represent the largest pool of nontraditional candidates," Ms. Miller said. "The problem is trying to convince women to consider I.T. jobs."
Mills College in Oakland, Calif., has programs to train second-career professionals in computer science. Ellen Spertus, an assistant professor, said graduates have landed at start-ups and big companies like Apple Computer, Hewlett-Packard and Sun Microsystems.
Previously, the Internet was not on the career radar of women like Bernadette Crawford, 51; Margot Hand, 49; Jennifer Knebel, 40; and Holly Hough, 42. But after working earlier in their careers in jobs as diverse as child care, marketing, finance and advertising, they all ended up at Aabalone Red, a Web site developer in Darien, Conn. Ms. Crawford had been nanny for the children of Aabalone's owners; after the children were older, she was offered a job at the company.
Their jobs range from research to keeping books and working with clients. They all had to become intimate with computers and the Internet. Ms. Knebel, who had worked at Bank of America and Prudential and has a master's degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, was more than willing to learn. "When I stopped working in '93, we were working on I.B.M. 386's," she said. "When Aabalone hired me, they handed me a Mac. I knew I could figure out the Internet. I like challenges."
Alec Wiggin, who runs Aabalone with his wife, Gail, says that these women may lack computer skills initially but that they bring valuable work experience to their jobs.
"They know what it means to act professionally, to meet deadlines and be part of a team," Mr. Wiggin said. "All those things, when you are working with younger people, can take time to learn. I like the professional maturity of this pool of people. They come with a set of skills that are harder to teach."
Gail Wiggin says that if women are eager to learn, the company is willing to train them. "There are all these intelligent women not working," she said. "We take these women, bring them in and say, 'Look, do you want to learn about this industry?' "
Anita Borg, president of the Institute for Women and Technology in Palo Alto, Calif., said women should want to expand their skills. "Women need to know that they have to go for jobs that they don't have all the skills for," she said. "They have to know that there is great demand in this particular labor market. And saying 'I'm smart, I can do this, train me' is a great strategy. It takes some moxie."
After Simona Carini, 37, of Orinda, Calif., receives a master's degree in computer science at Mills, she plans to find just the right job.
"I don't want to work for a company whose only aim is to make money," she said. "I've done that, and I don't want to do it again. Women have different priorities."
Which gets us back to my wife. Her quest took her to Manhattan for an interview at a dot-com. She came back impressed, saying she was now convinced that such companies would define the future. Whether she joins this company or another, I don't think she's going to be home much longer.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 9; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Soccer Neighborhood, Empty Net

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Day or night, go to any bar in the Ironbound with a satellite dish when professional soccer is being played and chances are there will be a crowd tossing back a few and watching the game.
"They go crazy," said Nanda Cerquira, owner of Tio Pepe, where patrons were leaping from their seats, pumping their fists in the air and shouting last Wednesday afternoon as Real Madrid and Manchester United battled in European Cup competition on the bar's motion-picture-sized screen. 
 At Pegasus Sporting Goods on Ferry Street, which stocks 20 models of outdoor soccer shoes and another 20 for indoor play, a sales clerk, Anna Santos, said gravely: "It's not like, 'My favorite sport.' It's something much more than this."
So it is a disappointment to residents of the Ironbound -- the city's most economically vibrant and socially stable neighborhood -- that even after construction of major amenities like the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and a minor-league baseball team, a soccer stadium has eluded city officials, community activists and the owners of the Major League Soccer's MetroStars.
Hopes for a stadium here rose again recently, when YankeeNets, the organization that owns the New Jersey Nets basketball team and has agreed to buy the Devils hockey team, began negotiating to buy half of the MetroStars.
YankeeNets intends to build a $295 million arena near the Pennsylvania Station under a redevelopment plan that the city is in the process of adopting. Had the organization become an owner of the MetroStars, it would have probably sought to build a soccer stadium too. But last month, negotiations between YankeeNets and MetroMedia, which owns the MetroStars, collapsed.
Afterward, Mayor Sharpe James pledged his continued support for a soccer stadium, although he did not provide any details. At the same time, the president of the East Side Community Center, Jack DaSilva, a local banker and realtor, announced that his group had gathered nearly 3,000 signatures on a petition in support of a soccer stadium.
"I am very confident that, if the MetroStars had a stadium in Newark, they would be sold out for every game they play," Mr. DaSilva said.
Jose Fernandes, owner of the Play Ball Restaurant on Ferry Street, said: "Most of the businesses here are Portuguese, and we pay taxes. The people in this area, they don't know anything about baseball or American football or those kinds of sports."
Three years ago, Mayor James a Democrat, and County Executive James W. Treffinger, a Republican, reached across party lines to shake hands on a deal that would have developed a sports complex in an Ironbound park with stadiums for minor league baseball and soccer.
But the plan was killed by a combination of factors, including opposition led by a group known as the Ironbound Community Corporation, which feared the loss of recreational space, including a soccer field. Basically, the group preferred playing to watching.
The baseball stadium, which is known as Riverfront Park and is home to the Newark Bears, was eventually built on a different site, just off McCarter Highway outside the Ironbound section.
"It's a complex issue," said Joe Della Fave, the group's president. "There are overcrowded schools and not enough places to play, and that's got to be a priority."
Councilman Augusto Amador, who represents the Ironbound section as part of the East Ward -- where the baseball stadium and the performing arts center are situated -- said he fully supported a stadium.
Last Tuesday, Mr. Amador met with the general manager of the MetroStars, Nick Sakiewicz, to discuss the city's old Ironbound Stadium site, a deteriorating piece of city-owned property where a hulking concrete grandstand and an overgrown oval track linger as reminders of when the stadium was host to local matches and exhibitions featuring foreign professional teams. It is sandwiched between a hockey arena where indoor soccer is also played, and a large open space that is now being cleaned up and leveled for use as a multipurpose athletic field.
Even so, Mr. Amador said, the Ironbound has higher priorities, including construction of a replacement for the aging and overcrowded East Side High School, a project that does not necessarily conflict with a soccer stadium, but must come first.
In addition, the Ironbound is becoming increasingly congested, a condition that stadium plans would have to be careful not to aggravate.
"Soccer is synonymous with the Ironbound," Mr. Amador said. But, he added, "We have to minimize the negative impact that a stadium might have."
Rick Cerone, the Bears' owner, said a soccer stadium could only help his team by boosting Newark's profile as a sports venue. "The more the merrier," he said.
What is contemplated, Mr. Amador and Mr. Sakiewicz said, is a 25,000-seat stadium that could cost from $40 million to $60 million. Most of the project would be financed privately, although the city would be asked to pay for road and other infrastructure improvements, Mr. Sakiewicz said.
For now, the MetroStars play at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, which is difficult to reach by public transportation, and where the team's lease is up after the 2001 season. Exactly one stadium has been built specifically for a Major League Soccer team since the league debuted in 1996, a $28.5 million project finance privately in Columbus, Ohio, said Dan Courtemanche, a league spokesman.
Mr. Courtemanche said the stadium had solidified the Columbus Crew's identity among its fans, and helped the team lead the league in average attendance last year, at 17,406 a game. In contrast, the MetroStars, which have struggled as a franchise, averaged just over 14,000 last year.
To be sure, not everyone in the Ironbound is passionate about soccer.
Manuel Ferreira, 13, was among several young hockey players working out at the rink on inline skates last week. Why does he prefer hockey?
"More speed," he said.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 911 words

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Self-Service Gas Stations, Meet Self-Serving Politicians

BYLINE: By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
After all the snarling and braying about the recent surge in oil prices, isn't it about time that someone offered the moguls at OPEC at least a little thanks?
True, the cartel may have gouged Americans out of billions of dollars by cutting production and artificially driving up prices. The spike in oil prices may have stoked fears of inflation and further destabilized an already skittish market. But the oil barons' bare-knuckled capitalism brought at least one positive side effect to New Jersey: it compelled state officials to re-examine their nonsensical ban on self-service gas stations. 
 To lifelong New Jersey residents it may come as a surprise to learn that there are 48 other states out there that allow drivers to attempt the death-defying task of placing a nozzle into their cars' gas tank and squeezing a handle. (The only other holdout is Oregon, a place so contrary that it legalized assisted suicide and medical marijuana.)
Self-service proponents say the practice has become widespread because it offers drivers a choice, either pay a little more for full service or do it themselves and save money. A recent study by a professor at the University of Montana and a Justice Department analyst concluded that gas prices for New Jersey self-service customers would drop three to five cents if the state lifts the ban.
In a state where more than 4.6 billion gallons are sold each year, the annual savings could total hundreds of millions of dollars.
To the Flat-Earth full-service-crowd however, such talk is a recipe for social upheaval and financial ruin. Spouting conspiracy theories worthy of an "X-Files" episode, they warn that oil companies would somehow use the self-service islands to raise prices for all drivers. They point to New Jersey's gas prices, already the lowest in the region, and say there's no reason to lift a ban that has been in effect since 1949. But the biggest reason for the state's cheap gas is the fact that New Jersey levies one of the lowest gas taxes in the country. Allowing self-service would give customers the chance to pay even lower prices.
Some of the more hysterical full-service types even warn that smokers who gas up their own cars might accidentally self-immolate.
(Question for Oregon law professors: Would it be legal for Dr. Jack Kevorkian to fill up his own car if he contracted glaucoma and held a lit joint at the pump?)
The most compelling argument against self-service comes from those who say it would be unfair to the disabled, infirm or elderly. But Stephen G. Carrellas, coordinator of National Motorists Association's New Jersey chapter, said that New Jersey could require self-service stations to have one attendant working at all times to assist those motorists unable to pump gas themselves -- at no extra charge.
"No one is being a forced into a straitjacket," said State Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Republican from Demarest, who is drafting a bill to lift the ban. "It's like, should you go to a vegetable stand or to a supermarket?"
If arguments like these sound logical, that's just the problem. When it comes to the tangled, irrational relationship between New Jerseyans and their cars, there's no place for logic.
Prof. Michael Aaron Rockland, chairman of the American Studies Department at Rutgers, said that the state was so suburbanized that New Jerseyans depended on autos to conduct the most basic daily functions.
"You ask someone in New Jersey where they're from and they don't name a town, they name an area," Mr. Rockland said. "The implication is that you need a car to do anything. People in New Jersey are passionate about cars, obsessed with cars."
That obsession helped induce State Senator Garry J. Furnari to become a leading defender of the ban. Mr. Furnari, a member of the Commerce Committee, was holding a hearing on home heating oil prices late last winter and within minutes, he said, it "morphed into a shouting match" about the impending plague of self-service.
His office was soon besieged by phone calls, letters and e-mails from senior citizens, advocates for the disabled and traditionalists who just didn't want to pump their own. Mr. Furnari, who knows a winning political issue when he sees one, still isn't sure why people feel so inflamed by the issue. But he feels their pain.
"These people see it as yet another attempt to take something away from them," he said.
Given the intensity of that reaction, Mr. Cardinale's bill faces an uphill battle. The last attempt to repeal the ban, in 1988, won the votes of 4 of the state's 40 senators. Governor Whitman, already mired in auto-related problems surrounding the state's troubled E-ZPass system and auto emissions testing program, said she wasn't convinced the savings warrant the risk of losing 20,000 gas attendants' jobs.
But no one would suggest that every auto be fitted with horseshoes just to keep blacksmiths employed. And James E. Benton, executive director of the New Jersey Petroleum Council, said there were as many jobs available in a self-service station as a full-service station.
"If you get rid of the ban, you can dedicate a person to be a mechanic and to a convenience store," he said. "Those things might ultimately be more profitable and lead to more productive, better-paying jobs."
Better yet, maybe the state's displaced gas attendants can be trained in psychology and specialize in treating New Jersey's auto-centric absurdities.

PUB-DATE: April 23, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1014 words

HEADLINE: Personal Business;
WhatSeminar, Dad? It's Play Time.

BYLINE: By JANE WOLFE 

 BODY:
MARKETERS at the Four Seasons resort on Maui, looking for the newest way to attract business meetings, think small: hula lessons, volcano visits and lei-making, all for children ages 5 to 12.
At the Ritz-Carlton in Boston, conference planners boast about their most popular suite -- the $725-a-night junior presidential, designed for guests 2 to 4 feet tall -- with an adjoining room for parents or a nanny. Like other hotels in the chain, it has a program called "Ritz Kids." 
 And at the Loews Coronado Bay Resort in San Diego, where 70 percent of the guests are business travelers, the hotel is constantly expanding its list of baby sitters, pediatricians and activities -- like classes on explorers, pirates and nautical rope-tying -- for its youngest clientele.
Hotels, especially resorts with plenty of meeting space, are adding all manner of attractions to compete for a growing number of business travelers who do not want to leave home without their children. "When meeting planners call us, they mention right off that they want to have something fun for the kids to do," said Sara Harper, public relations director at the Loews Coronado. "If we didn't have well-conceived programs for kids, we'd lose business."
In a booming economy, many overworked parents have been struggling to find more time for their children -- so they are taking them along on business trips. The number of youngsters on such trips more than tripled over the 10 years through 1998, according to the Travel Industry Association of America.
Hotels that hardly tolerated children in the past are finding more ways to delight this newest group of discriminating travelers while their parents attend meetings. From $40 to $75 a day, most of the best hotels offer day camps with carefully planned activities that are educational as well as fun. For an additional $30 to $40, parents can see that their children are kept busy at night, whether at beach parties or at elaborate buffet tables designed to accommodate short arms and legs. Even at city hotels, where most activities are indoors, children keep busy with arts and crafts, cooking classes and even staff-sanctioned, late-night raids on the hotel refrigerator.
At the Ritz-Carlton in Boston, parents can spend $240 to enroll children in an all-day etiquette program that teaches table-setting and manners, food preparation and presentation, thank-you-note writing and ballroom dancing. The program has been so successful that it was expanded in January to include "executive etiquette," for adults.
Hotels are piling on so many enticing programs for children that parents, hearing of them, often demand to be treated as well.
The Loews Coronado had only children in mind when it started offering its "dive-in movies" on Friday nights. The plan was for children to float in inner tubes in the swimming pool while watching a movie on a giant poolside screen. But the program turned into a family activity when parents, after a long week of business meetings at the hotel, began joining their children in the pool.
"We're seeing evidence of just how time-deprived parents are, and just how important it is for them to incorporate business and pleasure," Ms. Harper said.
AT the Ritz-Carlton in Naples, Fla., parents are often seen sneaking out of their meetings to jealously observe the children's program in action. Last August, the Risk Insurance Management Society arranged its conference events to coincide with the children's activities schedule -- thus giving families more time together. The group went to this effort even though there were only 40 children with the 500 adults.
"It's not enough just to drop your child off with a baby sitter at the beach," said Ann Hughes, the public relations director at the hotel. "Our goal is to have the kids go home with an experience that they can talk to Mommy and Daddy about."
Now hotels are working on the details, like the huge, colorful bath sponges shaped in the letters of the child's name in their rooms at the Four Seasons on Maui, or the milk and cookies and toddler-size terry-cloth robes in that suite at the Ritz in Boston.
Hotels are also treating special requests from children -- their favorite videos, say -- as seriously as those from their parents. And the children are grateful for the new respect.
Eight-year-old Shelby Rachleff of Portola Valley, Calif., is not a big tipper, but she notices that employees of the Four Seasons on Maui call her by name and remember such personal preferences as how she likes her hamburgers. "They treat the kids really equal to the parents," she said.
In a less bullish economy, parents might think twice about the expense of taking a child to the Maui resort, where the most popular two-bedroom suites cost $1,495 a night. But for now, many parents are willing to pay a price for convenience. "We offer complimentary cribs, high chairs and baby carriages, and we baby-proof the room before they even check in," said Yvonne Biegel, the hotel's public relations director, "so our guests can get on a plane and come here without having to haul all that stuff."
Even at the hotels, however, there are choices to be made between work and family.
"You'll see some parents hanging out with their kids at night, instead of networking with other business people," said Cathy Keefe, spokeswoman for the Travel Industry Association. "You don't want to ignore the kids, but you also don't want to ignore the business. It is possible to reach a balance, as is proven by the sheer number of people who are doing it."
Not everyone, however, is in favor of taking children on business trips to fancy resorts. Letitia Baldrige, who has written many a book on manners, warns that children might become hopelessly spoiled. "Children who are traveling in such style, staying in a suite that costs $725 a night, begin to think that it's natural to live that way," she said. "When the economy takes a downturn, and they have to stay home, then how will the children feel, and, for that matter, how will the parents feel?"
